title: Radical Pacifist Jesuit Priest Daniel Berrigan Dies at 94 - Breitbart
content: The Rev. Daniel Berrigan, a Jesuit priest famous for his   and   protests, died Saturday in New York at the age of 94. [Together with his younger brother, Philip, who was also a Catholic priest at the time, Berrigan was a leader of the radical   movement in the 1960s, and continued protesting against war for several decades.  Father Berrigan emerged as a radical Catholic voice against the Vietnam war in the 1960s and sprang into the spotlight in 1968 when he and several other activists seized 600 draft cards of troops about to be deployed in Vietnam and burned the files in rubbish bins with homemade napalm. The group of protesters, known as the â€œCatonsville Nine,â€ issued a declaration denouncing the Catholic Church and other religious bodies for their â€œcowardiceâ€ before Americaâ€™s â€œcrimes. â€ We confront the Roman Catholic Church, other Christian bodies, and the synagogues of America with their silence and cowardice in the face of our countryâ€™s crimes. We are convinced that the religious bureaucracy in this country is racist, is an accomplice in this war, and is hostile to the poor. The Berrigan brothers were subsequently convicted of destroying government property, and sent to prison. Daniel ended up serving eighteen months in a federal penitentiary, during which time he and Philip appeared on the cover of Time magazine.  Other protests followed, leading to more arrests and prosecutions. From 1970 to 1995, Berrigan spent a total of nearly seven years in prison. In 1980, the Berrigans and six others broke into a General Electric nuclear missile site in Pennsylvania, sabotaging warhead nose cones and pouring blood onto documents and files. Berrigan also protested against the 1991 Gulf War, the Kosovo War, the U. S invasion of Afghanistan, the 2003 invasion of Iraq, and the prison in GuantÃ¡namo Bay. While focused against war and nuclear arms, Berriganâ€™s protests went beyond pacifism to embrace other causes as well. He believed that â€œracism and poverty, militarism and capitalist greed were interconnected pieces of the same big problem,â€ and he took part in protests against capitalism such as the Occupy Wall Street movement in New Yorkâ€™s Zuccotti Park. â€œThe evils of capitalism,â€ Berrigan said, â€œare as real as the evils of militarism and the evils of racism. â€ Parting ways with many of his friends on the left, however, Berrigan also protested abortion and was a vocal advocate of the   cause. â€œI have always made it clear,â€ he said, â€œthat I am against everything from war to abortion to euthanasia. I have avoided being a   person. â€ In a glowing   in the Jesuit magazine America, Berrigan is remembered as a â€œpeacemakerâ€ and a â€œprophet. â€ Follow Thomas D. Williams on Twitter   Follow @   <! [CDATA[! function( d,s, id){var js, fjs=d. getElementsByTagName( s)[0],p= ^

title: Bernie Sandersâ€™s Campaign Past Reveals Willingness to Play Hardball - The New York Times
content: During the 1986 race for governor of Vermont, Bernie Sanders bristled at the popularity of the Democratic incumbent, Madeleine Kunin. Mr. Sanders, who was running against her as an independent, saw himself as a leader, and viewed Ms. Kunin as a lightweight. â€œShe does very well on television,â€ he told one interviewer. â€œShe has an excellent press secretary. â€ But really, he said another time, the governorâ€™s appeal came down to one trait. â€œMany people are excited because sheâ€™s the first woman governor,â€ he said. â€œBut after that, there ainâ€™t much. â€ Mr. Sanders has long presented himself as an     politician from rural New England, now seeking the presidency with promise of a political revolution. But his combative side has now emerged as the Democratic race has tightened and Hillary Clinton has sharpened her own rhetoric. The result is a far harsher tone in the Democratic campaign and a transformed Senator Sanders, who is now making the kinds of   attacks that some of his advisers regretted he did not deploy sooner. But his aggressiveness also worries some supporters who were powerfully drawn to his positive persona that forswore politics as usual. The senatorâ€™s assertiveness was on vivid display in Thursdayâ€™s debate with Mrs. Clinton ahead of the   New York primary on Tuesday, which Mr. Sanders must win big to dent Mrs. Clintonâ€™s strong lead in the delegates needed for the nomination. But he is also seeking to match the vigorous jabs from her aides and allies, who ignored Mr. Sanders for much of last year and are now assailing his policy ideas and leadership abilities on a   basis. His advisers say he is reacting to the New York political environment as well. â€œPolitical combat is more restrained in places like Iowa and New Hampshire, but itâ€™s completely different in New York, and Bernie has no problem defending his ideas in a tough way against Secretary Clintonâ€™s,â€ said Tad Devine, a senior adviser for the Sanders campaign. Mrs. Clinton is now trying to hold off Mr. Sanders while not alienating his supporters, whom she would need in the general election. But she is also refusing to back down, and their spiky clashes are suddenly making for a more explosive and unpredictable race. More than anything, the recent Sanders broadsides reflect a political strategy he has carried out in previous campaigns: the use of blunt criticisms, sarcastic asides and a thundering style against his opponents. In the 1986 race, Mr. Sanders argued that he would be a strong feminist and do more for women than Ms. Kunin had. While granting that Ms. Kunin was â€œnot corrupt,â€ he questioned if she had the same â€œcourageâ€ that he had. He repeatedly challenged her credentials as a fellow progressive, using some of the same language he aims at Mrs. Clinton. In the end, he damaged Ms. Kunin politically, as some Clinton supporters and political analysts think he may do in the current race. â€œIn a tough fight, Bernie is hardly the     guy that he claims to be,â€ said Garrison Nelson, a longtime political science professor at the University of Vermont. Ms. Kunin was not the only foe that Mr. Sanders attacked with insinuations, as opposed to the more overtly negative television ads that Mr. Sanders has forsworn. In his 1990 race for Congress, he frequently laid political bait for his Republican opponent and relished watching him stumble. And in his 2006 Senate campaign, Mr. Sanders relentlessly linked his moderate Republican opponent with George W. Bush and Dick Cheney, and accused him of running â€œthe most negative, dishonest campaign in the history of the state of Vermont. â€ While such tactics are not unusual in many campaigns, Mr. Sanders has long tried to claim the high road. Yet if his past opponents remember anything about him, itâ€™s Bernie the brawler. â€œThe way he kept tagging me as a typical rich guy who only cared about rich Republicans  â€”   it was very tough, and very effective,â€ said Richard Tarrant, a software executive who was the Republican Senate nominee in 2006 and ran many aggressive television ads. â€œBernie knew that I earned my money myself, that my wealth was  . But that didnâ€™t matter. â€ In the current race, after days of needling by the Clinton camp about his policies and ability to answer tough questions, Mr. Sanders hit back this month by saying Mrs. Clinton was â€œnot qualifiedâ€ for the presidency because she had taken money from wealthy donors and supported the war in Iraq and some   agreements. Some Sanders supporters expressed dismay that their candidate was resorting to such sharp exchanges  â€”   a Guardian columnist wrote on Tuesday that she felt â€œbetrayedâ€  â€”   while the leading Republican candidate, Donald J. Trump, picked up the line of attack. â€œBernie Sanders says that Hillary Clinton is unqualified to be president,â€ Mr. Trump wrote on Twitter. â€œBased on her decision making ability, I can go along with that!â€ Mr. Sanders has started running commercials in New York criticizing Mrs. Clinton for accepting   speaking fees from Wall Street banks but not supporting a federal $15 minimum wage. And in Thursdayâ€™s debate, he suggested that Mrs. Clintonâ€™s speaking fees had influenced her to be soft on Wall Street regulation. She quickly dismissed that, saying that she had called out bankers over business practices  â€”   drawing a sarcastic response from Mr. Sanders. â€œSecretary Clinton called them out  â€”   oh my goodness, they must have been really crushed by this,â€ he said. â€œAnd was that before or after you received huge sums of money by giving speaking engagements? So they must have been very, very upset by what you did. â€ While Mr. Sanders has not run   and highly personal ads against Mrs. Clinton  â€”   the sort that traditionally characterize a negative campaign  â€”   Mrs. Clintonâ€™s advisers accused Mr. Sanders of breaking his word. â€œAt times he does it deftly, but make no mistake, every day Senator Sanders is launching another attack, and thatâ€™s not how he said he would run his campaign,â€ said Joel Benenson, Mr. Clintonâ€™s campaign strategist. Mr. Devine, a longtime strategist for Mr. Sanders, said his candidateâ€™s quips and tone were a far cry from the   vitriol in the Republican race. He insisted that Mr. Sanders was seeking to reveal substantive differences with Mrs. Clinton, and denied that his candidate fears the Democratic nomination is slipping away. â€œI think the race is just increasingly engaged,â€ Mr. Devine said. In Vermont, however, Mr. Sanders was known for belittling opponents at times, rather than merely challenging their ideas. During one debate in the 1986 governorâ€™s race, Mr. Sanders was asked if he viewed Governor Kunin as â€œthe lesser of two evils,â€ given his descriptions of the Democratic and Republican parties as â€œTweedledumâ€ and â€œTweedledee,â€ and if he thought he might contribute to her political â€œdemise. â€ Mr. Sanders chuckled and then looked at Ms. Kunin, seated a few feet away. â€œGovernor, how does it feel to be the lesser of two evils?â€ he asked. â€œI think that really is what this campaign is about. â€ Ms. Kunin was  . Toward the end of that campaign, Ms. Kunin said, Mr. Sanders argued at a rally in Burlington, Vt. that he would do far more for women than Ms. Kunin. â€œBernie thought I was an empty suit, and insisted that he was the better feminist because he would solve income inequality and that would help women,â€ Ms. Kunin said in the interview. â€œHe could be sarcastic, but also very subtle. â€ A supporter of Mrs. Clintonâ€™s presidential bid, Ms. Kunin said she saw similarities between his treatment of the two women. â€œHeâ€™s not going to say, â€˜Sheâ€™s a woman, sheâ€™s not qualified,â€™â€ said Ms. Kunin, who was   with 47 percent of the vote after Mr. Sanders siphoned off some support. â€œBut he can paint a very subtle illusion talking about qualifications and judgment. â€ Mr. Devine, the adviser to Mr. Sanders, said the senator would never make   attacks, in the 1980s or today. â€œHis focus is on issues,â€ he said. Peter Smith, the Republican candidate for governor in 1986 and the congressman Mr. Sanders ousted in 1990, said that Mr. Sanders used passion to create â€œa contrast between him and his opponent that may not, in fact, exist. â€ Mr. Sandersâ€™s aides in the 1990 campaign said they would regularly taunt Mr. Smith about his positions on issues like the minimum wage, which the congressman would dispute, and then Mr. Sanders would come forward and accuse Mr. Smith of dishonesty. As a result, a running theme of that campaign was that Mr. Sanders had integrity and Mr. Smith lacked it. â€œThe tool he uses is his intensity and his belief that, on the major issues he cares about, there is only one right answer,â€ Mr. Smith said. â€œAnd it is his. â€

title: NBCâ€™s Kristen Welker: â€™No Doubtâ€™ Brexit Vote Making Democrats â€™Jitteryâ€™ - Breitbart
content: According to NBC News White House Correspondent Kristen Welker, the United Kingdomâ€™s vote to separate from the E. U. has made Democrats â€œjittery. â€  She said Saturday on MSNBC of Brexit, â€œThereâ€™s no doubt that this is making Democrats jittery to some extent. For example, if the economy here starts to stall, that could make voters more likely to choose Donald Trump, a Republican candidate, and, of course, thereâ€™s concerns that what happened in Europe underscores that there is a stronger than expected populous sentiment here in the U. S. Secretary Clinton trying to reach out to the populous in her own party. Of course, Senator [Bernie] Sanders still technically in the race. â€ Follow Trent Baker on Twitter @MagnifiTrent

title: Mark Zuckerberg should put his money where his mouth is and throw Peter Thiel off Facebookâ€™s board
content: â€™â€™ â€™Mark Zuckerberg says that he believes in freedom of expression.â€™ â€To prove it, he should ask Peter Thiel, who funded a legal campaign designed to drive Gawker Media out of business, to step down from Facebookâ€™s board of directors.â€ â€™Earlier this month, an anonymous former Facebook employee accused Facebook of showing liberal bias in the story selection for its Trending news box.â€™ â€™The employee, a former journalist, told  that stories about Mitt Romney, Rand Paul, and other conservative interests were kept out of that box, even though they were organically trending with readers.â€™ â€Conservatives began to rumble about discrimination. It seemed a little disproportionate, as that Trending news box is in a tiny corner of the site  â€”   this wasnâ€™t about the News Feed that most Facebook users spend most of their time with.â€ â€™But Facebook reacted quickly and aggressively.â€™ â€™It showed the world  that its human news curators were supposed to follow as they chose the stories to appear in that tiny box. It held a  during which they were encouraged to air their grievances. Glenn Beck, who attended, later  some at the meeting for acting as if they wanted â€affirmative action for conservatives. â€â€™ â€Zuckerberg, Facebookâ€™s CEO, defended the company in a Facebook post:â€ â€Itâ€™s not the first time Zuckerberg has defended freedom of expression. After terrorists attacked the offices of Franceâ€™s Charlie Hebdo magazine for publishing parody cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad, Zuckerberg :â€ â€Thiel, the billionaire PayPal cofounder,  he had spent about $10 million funding various legal campaigns against the media organization Gawker, including one brought by former pro wrestler Hulk Hogan. Hogan was upset because Gawker published footage from a video tape of his having sex with a friendâ€™s  .â€ â€Thiel acknowledged this only after Forbes  even though Gawker founder Nick Denton  â€”   and others  â€”   had been speculating about Thielâ€™s involvement for some time.â€ â€™Thiel was partly upset about a 2007 article in Valleywag, a Gawker publication, about his being gay  â€”   the first article about his sexuality. He told  that similar articles about his friends and others that â€ruined lives for no reasonâ€ inspired the suit.â€™ â€Gawker, in its  on Thursday, also suggested that Thiel was upset about Valleywagâ€™s general attitude toward Silicon Valley and innovation, which skewed toward criticism  â€”   or at least skepticism  â€”   rather than cheerleading.â€ â€Whatever the reason, Thiel did what he did, and now Gawker is facing a  for violating Hoganâ€™s privacy.â€ â€Thiel wasnâ€™t doing anything illegal. The law in the US is very favorable toward free speech, no matter whoâ€™s funding that speech or how much money theyâ€™re spending.â€ â€™Gawker has written a lot of nasty, personal stories about people over the years. Denton  in an open letter to Thiel that the publication had sometimes â€overstepped the lineâ€ and swung into â€snark.â€ The courts are hearing numerous cases against Gawker, and it might lose one or more of them on appeal.â€™ â€™But spending years looking for people who have potential grievances against a publication, then secretly funding their lawsuits, is not consistent with the principles of free expression.â€™ â€Either youâ€™re for free expression, or youâ€™re kind of for it. And if youâ€™re kind of for it, then youâ€™re not really for it at all.â€ â€Zuckerberg says heâ€™s for it. Nowâ€™s the time to prove it.â€ â€™Mark Zuckerberg says that he believes in. ..â€™

title: â€™Never Trumpâ€™ Taps Their Candidate: Bald Unknown Mormon Hill Staffer from Goldman Sachs Who â€˜Resettledâ€™ Refugees for UN
content: With less than 100 days until the election, the Never Trump movement has fielded yet another independent presidential candidate to keep Republican nominee Donald Trump out of the White House. [This time their candidate is Evan McMullin. Here is what we know about him.  Candidacy Announced by Joe Scarborough, MSNBCâ€™s Joe Scarborough broke the news of McMullinâ€™s candidacy, dedicating two hours of his show on Monday to McMullinâ€™s long shot bid. Scarborough also tweeted the news: BREAKING FIRST ON @Morning_Joe: Multiple sources say an independent conservative candidate will announce his candidacy for president today.  â€”   Joe Scarborough (@JoeNBC) August 8, 2016,  Multiple sources tell me the candidate is Evan McMullin. Wharton grad, CIA alum, Goldman Sachs, Republican Policy Director, US House,  â€”   Joe Scarborough (@JoeNBC) August 8, 2016,  McMullinâ€™s official website went online this morning bearing what appears to be his campaign motto: â€œItâ€™s never too late to do the right thing. And if we work together, thereâ€™s nothing we canâ€™t achieve. â€  From CIA to Goldman Sachs to Republican Establishment, McMullin has never held elected office. According to his LinkedIn profile, from   he worked as an operations officer in the national clandestine service for the Central Intelligence Agency managing â€œclandestine operations related to counterterrorism, counterinsurgency, energy, political stability, and counterintelligence. â€ He then went on to work as an investment banking associate for Goldman Sachs in San Francisco for three years. In 2013, he moved to Washington, D. C. to become the senior advisor to the House Committee on Foreign Affairs and then, two years later, the Chief Policy Director for the House Republican Conference, where he was responsible for advancing the policy agenda of the Republican leadership in the House. When John Boehner stepped down as Speaker, McMullin wrote on Facebook: â€œToday we learned that Congress will soon lose a tremendous leader in Speaker Boehner. â€ Boehnerâ€™s ouster as Speaker was widely celebrated by grassroots conservatives as a victory for the Tea Party movement over the feckless and equivocating GOP leadership Boehnerâ€™s Speakership represented. However, McMullin had nothing but praise for Boehner as â€œone of the most humble, gracious, and savvy leaders Iâ€™ve ever encountered. â€ McMullin said he was â€œgratefulâ€ for the opportunity â€œto learnâ€ from Boehner. Former â€œVolunteer Refugee Resettlement Officerâ€ and Fierce Critic of Trumpâ€™s Position on Muslim Migration  According to McMullinâ€™s LinkedIn profile, he worked in 2001 as a â€œVolunteer Refugee Resettlement Officerâ€ for the United Nations, where he â€œvetted and processed   refugees from the Middle East and Africa for resettlement to third countries. â€ McMullin, who is a member of the Council on Foreign Relations, is also a fierce critic of Trumpâ€™s call for a temporary ban on Muslim migration to the United States. He wrote on his Facebook page: â€œAs Donald Trump continues attacking Muslims and as a former CIA officer, Iâ€™d like all Americans to know the truth: American and other Muslims have played a central role in virtually every counterterrorism win weâ€™ve had since  . They are an indispensable asset in this fight. Attacking them as a group makes America weaker, not stronger. â€ He has also posted on his Facebook page about the plight of Syrian refugees, linking to an Amnesty International article on refugees and noting: â€œSobering facts: Over 50 million people around the world  â€”   including 50% of Syrians  â€”   have been forced from their homes due to conflicts in the worst global refugee crisis since WWII. â€ Brainchild of Rick Wilson and Funded by Romney Donor, Joe Scarborough noted this morning that McMullin has â€œthe backing of key $$ contributors in the Republican Party. â€ The candidate revealed by sources  has an impressive resume and the backing of key $$ contributors in the Republican Party.  â€”   Joe Scarborough (@JoeNBC) August 8, 2016,  Thatâ€™s no lie. One of the key Never Trump figures behind McMullin is none other than â€œ  â€ Rick Wilson, who last October declared that the GOP donor class must â€œput a bullet in Donald Trumpâ€ to stop him. Buzzfeed reports: â€œSources said Wilson was in Washington on Sunday meeting with members of McMullinâ€™s prospective campaign  â€”   which includes some who were involved in a group called Better for America, which has been pushing an independent presidential bid. â€ As a 501( c)(4) organization, Better for America (BFA) canâ€™t officially endorse a candidate even though itâ€™s supporting McMullinâ€™s bid. ABC News reports that the group â€œhas been funded in part by John Kingston, a   conservative donor who bundled for Mitt Romney. â€ Kingston also has ties to George W. Bush and John McCain, according to The Hill. The Hill reports that â€œseveral members of BFA have left the group so they can begin working on McMullinâ€™s campaign or a supporting   seemingly putting him in position to benefit from their ballot access work. â€ According to The Hill, among those working for McMullin: Republican pollster Joel Searby and conservative lawyer Mohammed Jazil have resigned from BFA to join McMullinâ€™s campaign, a source said, while ballot access expert Kahlil Byrd and Democratic strategist Ileana Wachtel have left the group to launch a    . Narrow Path to Victory, McMullinâ€™s path to victory is extremely narrow to  . Joe Scarborough noted that McMullinâ€™s long shot campaign â€œhas more to do with stopping Donald Trump than actually electing a president. â€ The deadline for independent candidates to get on the November ballot has already passed in a number of states  â€”   including Texas with its large electoral count. However, Better for America is perhaps seeking to sue states like Texas to get on the ballot. The Hill notes that â€œto get into the presidential debates, a candidate must poll at 15 percent in five national surveys leading up to the three scheduled debates and show that they are appearing on enough state ballots to have a path to 270 electoral votes. â€ At this late date, with more organized candidates like the Libertarian Partyâ€™s Gary Johnson and the Green Partyâ€™s Jill Stein struggling to reach the 15 percent margin, itâ€™s hard to see how McMullin will make it onto the debate stage, and without that national platform, his candidacy will remain unknown to the majority of voters. A Mormon Candidate to Appeal to Mormon Voters in Utah, Arizona, and Idaho, McMullin is a Mormon and a graduate of Brigham Young University. Like Never Trump leader Mitt Romney, who served as a Mormon missionary in France, McMullin also did Mormon missionary work in a Catholic country. ABC News reports that McMullin was a missionary in Brazil, and his LinkedIn profile notes that he speaks Portuguese. Itâ€™s no secret that Donald Trump has a Mormon problem, as his polling in traditionally red states with large Mormon populations shows. The Huffington Post notes that McMullinâ€™s candidacy could have the most impact in three such states: Utah, Arizona, and Idaho. In fact, the date of McMullinâ€™s announcement comes just in time to make the August 15 deadline to get on the Utah ballot as an independent candidate. Utahâ€™s election laws only require 1, 000 voter signatures for a candidate to be included on a ballot  â€”   a relatively easy number to achieve. Glenn Beckâ€™s Never Trump Scheme at Play? During a July 27 radio interview with fellow Never Trump member Erick Erickson, Glenn Beck and his   articulated an ambitious scheme to run a third party candidate in red states that are not battleground states for Trump. The idea, which was explained by Beckâ€™s   Stu Burguiere, is to have this independent candidate siphon off enough votes from Trump to keep Trump and Hillary Clinton under the threshold of 270 electoral votes needed to win the race outright, thereby throwing the election to the House of Representatives to decide the outcome, where they hope a Republican House will elect their independent candidate or another person who is not Trump. They suggested the candidate should be someone like Mitt Romney, but that was only because they couldnâ€™t choose Paul Ryan due to his position as the Speaker of the House. (They assumed that Ryan was the ideal candidate for this scheme because presumably House Republicans would vote for him). Burguiere    said that â€œthe will of the people is a serious problem with thisâ€ scheme because the people actually voted for Trump, but Beck, Erickson and their Never Trump compatriots apparently believe in thwarting democracy to save it from Trump. Though McMullin is not as ideal a candidate as Romney, he is a fellow Mormon who is hoping to challenge Trump in deep red states with large Mormon populations. Could McMullinâ€™s long shot candidacy be a part of a more elaborate scheme to keep Trump and Hillary below 270 electoral votes and throw the election to the House? After all, keeping Trump under 270 is a lot easier than winning 270.

title: Harry Reid: Obama Nominating Scalia Replacement in â€™A Little Over Three Weeksâ€™ - Breitbart
content: On February 18, Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid ( ) said President Obama will nominate a replacement for Antonin Scalia to the Supreme Court in â€œa little over three weeks. â€[According to Fox News, Reid met with Obama on Thursday then told MSNBC, â€œWeâ€™re going to have someone in the next few weeks. â€ He then clarified, saying, â€œI think it will be a little over three weeks. â€  Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell ( ) has already said he believes Scaliaâ€™s vacancy should be filled by the next president, and Republican presidential hopeful Ted Cruz said he is â€œabsolutelyâ€ determined to filibuster any Supreme Court nominee put forward by Obama this year. Sen. Chuck Grassley ( ) released a statement on February 13  â€”   the day of Scaliaâ€™s death  â€”   in which he contended that the job of nominating a new Supreme Court justice belonged to the next president, rather than Obama. By February 16, he had modified his stance, telling Radio Iowa, â€œI would wait until the nominee is made before I would make any decisions. In other words, take it a step at a time. â€ The Supreme Court is crucial to the survival of individual gun rights in America. With the death of Scalia, the court is now divided   on crucial decisions like District of Columbia v. Heller (2008) and McDonald v. Chicago (2010). The Heller ruling struck down D. C.â€™s gun ban as a violation of the individual right to keep and bear arms, and McDonald struck down Chicagoâ€™s gun ban on the grounds that Second Amendment rights are incorporated under the Fourteenth Amendment. Such incorporation means the Constitution not only protects gun rights from federal infringement but from state infringement as well. AWR Hawkins is the Second Amendment columnist for Breitbart News and political analyst for Armed American Radio. Follow him on Twitter: @AWRHawkins. Reach him directly at awrhawkins@breitbart. com.

title: This startup wants to turn crazy-popular unboxing videos into a new â€™QVC for millennialsâ€™
content: â€™  â€™ â€™   The former CTO of Hulu wants to build a company that can change   how Generation Z shops on mobile, creating what he likes to call   a â€QVC for Millennials.â€  â€™ â€   Eric Fengâ€™s plan is built around one thing thatâ€™s super   popular with  : Unboxing videos.  â€ â€™   â€Itâ€™s not just people opening up the packs, but user reviews and   comparisons, tutorials  â€”   the product review category is huge,â€    said. â€™ â€™   On Thursday, Feng unveiled his new company, Packagd. The   startup plans to stream live video of the stars of unboxing   videos talking about new products. Consumers will be able to   watch the videos through Packagdâ€™â€™s apps and will be able to buy   the products that are mentioned by just tapping on a â€add to   cartâ€ button as the video plays.   â€™ â€™   Over the last year, Feng and his team have been working in   stealth to sign agreements with more than 20 YouTube stars   and strike partnerships with brands like Best Buy and Microsoft   to sponsor the videos. â€™ â€   Packagdâ€™s business plan consciously drew inspiration from QVC,   the cable channel where hosts showcased new products that viewers   could order by calling a number displayed on their screens. Many   placed their orders and many more watched just for the   entertainment. â€ â€™   The live product demos are a bid to bring back the joy of   shopping, something that Feng feels like has been stripped in the   internet era.  â€™ â€™   â€Ecommerce has gotten so efficient that itâ€™s not fun anymore,â€   said Feng, who is Packagdâ€™â€™s CEO. â€People donâ€™t window shop.   People donâ€™t shop with their friends. Amazon is relentless about   minimizing the number of pages that you see before purchase.â€ â€™ â€™   He continued: â€For us, we want to bring discovery. We want you to   have fun while youâ€™re shopping.â€ â€™ â€   Feng, who is also a partner at venture capital firm Kleiner   Perkins, got the idea for Packagd   after learning  on YouTube. The top   5 unboxing channels on YouTube have over 33 million   subscribers combined, according to Fengâ€™s Kleiner partner   Mary Meeker. â€ â€™   YouTube has to cater to all kinds of different video creators and   types of content. As popular as the unboxing videos have   become, they could do even better if a company focused solely on   them, Feng bet. â€™ â€   So Feng and his team built Packagd to work just for     unboxers, . Feng thinks   Packagd can help them become as popular among young adults   on their mobile devices as QVC hosts have been among the   retirees glued to their TVs. And heâ€™s banking that they can help   sell products much like the hosts have done on QVC and Home   Shopping Network. â€ â€™  â€™ â€™   â€We want you to discover not just videos for products you know   about, but videos for products you donâ€™t know about. And have   those videos driving purchasing decisions,â€ Feng said. â€™ â€™   For its modern and mobile spin on QVC,  is starting with a six hour   block of live shows that it will stream through its app every   day.  â€™ â€™   These arenâ€™â€™t intended to be the â€Buy! Buy! Buy! The clock is   ticking down!â€ style of infomercials you may see on TV. Instead,   Packagd is encouraging its new hosts to take a more informal   approach. Theyâ€™â€™ll chat with viewers live while streaming the   unboxing videos theyâ€™â€™ve already uploaded to YouTube. Feng   hopes the effect will be more like interacting with a friendly   expert than hearing a   sales pitch. â€™ â€™   â€Unboxers we feel have cracked the code on this content type.   They created a content format thatâ€™s super interesting, super   engaging,â€ Feng said. â€Weâ€™re not asking them to create new   videos. Weâ€™re not asking them to adopt it for our platform. Weâ€™re   saying we want to showcase them in a different way.â€ â€™ â€™   The company is starting with a new app called Unboxed that   focuses on reviews of tech products, ranging from drones,   laptops to smart home devices. Packagd plans to follow   Unboxed with an app focused on beauty product reviews that it   hopes to launch in two months. After that will come a toy review   app.  â€™ â€   During each live show, the host will field questions   from Unboxed users who will be able to submit them using a   chat feature in the app. Users will be able to buy whichever   products the hosts are touting via a purchase button at the   bottom of their screens. If they do, theyâ€™ll earn loyalty   points they can apply towards discounts on future purchases made   through Unboxed. â€ â€   Such purchases will benefit the hosts as well; theyâ€™ll get   affiliate commissions. And they wonâ€™t have to share those with   Packagd. Instead, 100% of the affiliate revenue will go the   hosts, Feng said.  â€ â€   Packagd plans to make money by convincing brands to pay   to sponsor certain time slots of its live streams. Those partners   could either work with a product reviewer to build a show or   create their own. Either way, Unboxed service will work the same   for users. Theyâ€™ll  be able to ask hosts questions and buy   what they see.  â€ â€™   â€We want you to feel like youâ€™re in the live QVC audience and   talking to the host,â€ Feng said. â€What drives a lot of   transactions on QVC is affinity with the host.â€ â€™ â€™   The company will offer users more to watch than just the six   hours of live, hosted videos. To accommodate users who may   not be interested in the product being touted at a particular   moment in the live stream, Unboxed will also   offer a library of   videos for a range of   products.  â€™ â€™  â€™ â€   But Packagdâ€™s apps will be missing something you normally find on   YouTube and on other video sites or apps: a search bar. Thatâ€™s   intentional; Feng want to encourage users to browse products and   discover things serendipitously through the app rather than   accommodate shoppers who already know what they want to buy. â€ â€™   â€You donâ€™t turn on QVC when you know you want the DJI Spark,â€   Feng said.  â€™ â€   Despite Fengâ€™s conviction that mobile shopping can be   transformed, he acknowledges the challenge Packagd faces. â€ â€™  â€™ â€   While the companyâ€™s been able to convince product reviewers to   host its video stream, it will have to lure in consumers too, and   they may be harder to attract. If theyâ€™re already watching   product videos on YouTube or finding products on Instagram,   they may not see the need to download a new app to get similar   information.  â€ â€™   (Packagd plans to use product giveaways and a physical booth   at the electronics show, E3, to convince them to give the app a   try.) â€™ â€™   Still, Feng is hopeful that if Packagd builds something   better for both unboxers and consumers, success will follow.   The company has already raised $7. 5 million from top Silicon   Valley venture capitalists, who are betting it will do for   unboxing videos what Twitch did for gaming. â€™ â€   Even though YouTube is the dominant player today, itâ€™s investing   too widely and not focusing enough on translating its popularity   into purchases, Feng said. Thatâ€™s where thereâ€™s an opening for   Packagd, he added.  â€ â€™   â€Iâ€™m hoping the fact that these videos are so popular means there   is demand to consume them. I think the bigger existential   question is does that demand to consume those just stay on   YouTube?â€ Feng said. â€It may. We may not be able to pull it off.   That may be a real competitive risk that we just canâ€™t solve. But   we wonâ€™t know until we launch and try.â€  â€™ â€™The former CTO of Hulu wants to build a company. ..â€™ â€™â€™ â€™â€™ â€™â€™

title: More Than 200 MS-13 Members Reside in Long Island, FBI Says
content: There are more than 200 members of the violent, El Salvadorian   gang in the Long Island, New York area, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation. [The FBIâ€™s Long Island Gang Task Force Director Geraldine Hart told NBC New York in an interview that members of   â€œbolster their ranking among other gangs by using violence. â€  Hart told the media that the   gang problem, specifically as its members are usually illegal immigrants, is a national issue across the U. S. â€œThis is not a local problem,â€ Hart told NBC New York. â€œThis is a national and international problem. We know that there are direct links from El Salvador up here into the New York area. â€ The area of Brentwood, Long Island, more precisely, has undergone a transformation due to the   gang and its roots in illegal immigration. As the Center for Immigration Studies (CIS) notes,   flourished in Brentwood as placement of unaccompanied minor illegal immigrant children grew more than 100 percent from 2015 to 2016. Brentwood has seen a booming El Salvadorian population in an area that was once primarily working class, Puerto  . â€œBy 2010, nearly 40 percent of the community was born in or had citizenship from a Central American country,â€ CIS Fellow Joseph Kolb writes. â€œThis figure was nearly six times the national average. The majority 68 percent Hispanic population shifted now to 51 percent Central American and 18 percent Puerto Rican. â€ Recent Long   deaths by   include the brutal murders of Nisa Mickens and Kayla Cuevas, two teenage girls beaten and killed by illegal immigrant gang members, Breitbart Texas reported. Other recent murder victims of   include teenagers Michael Lopez Banegas, Jefferson Villalobos, Jorge Tigre and Justin Llivicura, all of whom were beaten to death in Long Islandâ€™s Recreation Village Town Park, Breitbart Texas reported. John Binder is a reporter for Breitbart Texas. Follow him on Twitter at @JxhnBinder.

title: Congress barely meets DHS deadline
content: Washington (CNN) The House approved a   extension of funding for the Department of Homeland Security,  avoiding a partial shutdown just hours before a Friday night deadline.  President Barack Obama signed the bill, which funds the Department of Homeland Security until March 6.  The bill does nothing to resolve the central issue that has turned the agencyâ€™s funding into a political football: immigration. Republicans will again push to tie money for DHS to legislation rolling back Obamaâ€™s immigration orders. Senate Democrats will block that effort, ensuring another tumultuous week on Capitol Hill and more uncertainty for the hundreds of thousands of people who work at DHS. There was already plenty of drama in Congress on Friday. Earlier in the day, the House rejected a bill that would have kept DHS open for three weeks, a shocking twist that renewed questions about Speaker John Boehnerâ€™s grip on the House. Rep. Steve Womack,   who is close to House leadership, described House Speaker John Boehnerâ€™s situation as like a â€vice.â€ â€™Hell of a positionâ€™ â€Itâ€™s a hell of a position to be in,â€ Womack said Friday evening. â€I just canâ€™t imagine the frustration the speaker must have now.â€ READ: What happens if DHS shuts down? Two senior House Republican sources tell CNN there was serious concern among those close to the Speaker that if he allowed a vote on a clean DHS funding bill without immigration language, conservatives would make a motion to vacate the chair, which amounts to a direct challenge to his job. Pennsylvania GOP Rep. Charlie Dent acknowledged to reporters he heard conservatives were using the DHS fight to try to remove Boehner. â€Right now, we have to get serious,â€ he said. â€I think a lot of people better get serious about governing and itâ€™s time for all of these, you know, DC games to end. I mean all these palace coups or whatever the hell is going on around here has to end, and we have to get down to the business of governing.â€ The battle over DHS funding comes more than 16 months after political chaos tipped the entire government into a shutdown. Republicans bore the brunt of the publicâ€™s blame for that episode and polls indicate the party would be blasted again. A CNN poll last week found 53% of Americans would blame Republicans in Congress if the department shuts down, while 30% would blame Obama. Another 13% said both would deserve the blame. Boehner has been here before    wedged between his   flank and the Senate. House conservatives want to continue fighting to block Obamaâ€™s actions on immigration and want to go to conference with the Senate to work out their differences . Implications for Boehner, How he handles the showdown could dictate the rest of his speakership, as House conservatives warn compromising now means heâ€™s effectively allowing Democrats to block GOP agenda for the next two years.  The Senate approved a   funding bill Friday even though it wasnâ€™t expected to go anywhere in the House. On a   bipartisan vote, the Senate cleared a   â€cleanâ€ DHS bill, after stripping of provisions opposed by Democrats that would have blocked Obamaâ€™s immigration orders. Even as he and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell deployed completely different strategies to address the impending funding lapse, Boehner insisted the GOP is on the same page. â€It is not a fight amongst Republicans. All Republicans agree we want to fund the Department of Homeland Security and we want to stop the Presidentâ€™s executive action with regard to immigration,â€ he said. Court ruling, Some Senate Republicans are urging the House to point to the recent ruling by a Texas judge to suspend the administrationâ€™s program to process visas for those wanting to remain in the country. â€The courts have acted. Accept the victor that the courts have given us, which is the President does not have the authority to do what he has done and vote to continue to fund the Department of Homeland Security. I think that is the right decision,â€ Sen. John Barasso,   said on CNN on Thursday. Some conservatives have said they donâ€™t feel any pressure to fund the agency before the deadline because most employees would still be required to come to work. Rep. Tim Huelskamp,   told CNN that employees at the agency just got paid last week so there is enough time to debate the issue before they need to approve continued funding, even on a short term basis. Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson dismissed that notion and told reporters â€that minimizes the impact of forcing people to work without a paycheckâ€ and said he continues to press for â€full funding.â€

title: British Decision on Nuclear Plant Angers China and France - The New York Times
content: LONDON  â€”   The decision of the new British government to postpone a deal on a nuclear power station, to be built by France with major Chinese investment, has shocked both of those countries and is a potentially major step away from the policies of former Prime Minister David Cameron. The sudden choice of Prime Minister Theresa May not to sign the deal but to take until the autumn for further study, reportedly on security and economic grounds, has angered both Paris, which will be crucial to Britainâ€™s future relations with the European Union after the countryâ€™s vote to leave the bloc, and Beijing, which Mr. Cameron had cultivated aggressively for investment and trade ties despite criticism that he was subordinating human rights and geopolitical concerns to commerce. The menu had already been published for a grand lunch after a signing ceremony last Friday on the Somerset coast, the site of the proposed Hinkley Point C nuclear power station, which is designed to produce 3, 200 megawatts with two new French reactors at a cost of at least 18 billion pounds, about $23. 7 billion. The day before, the board of the largely   EDF, the French power utility, voted 10 to 7 to approve Hinkley Point, despite serious concerns about the ability of the company to handle the project and its costs. But late Thursday night, Downing Street said it would not sign the deal the next day as planned. Travel by French and Chinese officials to Somerset for the party was canceled, and the â€œhoi sin local lamb skewersâ€ and mackerel ceviche had to be abandoned. While Downing Street said that Mrs. May had told President FranÃ§ois Hollande of France the week before that she would postpone the deal, the board of EDF was taken by surprise.   LÃ©vy, the companyâ€™s chief executive, said he had been unaware of the British hesitation before the boardâ€™s vote and found out about it during a newspaper interview. Mrs. May told Mr. Hollande that her new government wanted to look at the deal again, as any new government would. But since then it has become clear that her main concerns are with the Chinese involvement, and she seemed to be signaling an end to the British willingness to be Chinaâ€™s best Western ally in return for Chinese investment. Having served as home secretary for six years before becoming prime minister, Mrs. May is security minded and had expressed concerns in cabinet meetings during the Cameron administration about bringing Beijing into such a sensitive project. The project is meant to provide about 7 percent of Britainâ€™s electricity needs. She was also reported to have been unhappy on security grounds when British Telecom agreed to a deal with the Chinese telecommunications company Huawei. While China is funding just over a third of the Hinkley Point project, the real advantage for Beijing is that the deal offers China a chance to build and operate a nuclear power plant of its own design at another site in Britain, at    in Essex. That reportedly troubles Mrs. May because it could give China control over an important part of Britainâ€™s energy supply. On Monday, China reacted angrily to suggestions that its investment in the project threatened British security. The official Xinhua news agency published a commentary arguing that the delay â€œadds uncertainties to the â€˜Golden Eraâ€™ of  . K. tiesâ€ and suggesting that further Chinese investment in Britain could be rethought. â€œChina can wait for a rational British government to make responsible decisions, but cannot tolerate any unwanted accusation against its sincere and benign willingness for   cooperation,â€ the commentary said. Mr. Cameron and his chancellor of the Exchequer, George Osborne, had made a big pitch for closer economic and   ties with China, including a   state visit last October by President Xi Jinping. The British decision in March 2015 to become the first Western country to join Chinaâ€™s rival to the World Bank, the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, shocked the Obama administration. The Hinkley Point C project is still expected to go ahead at this point, especially given the added British jobs. But Mrs. May could try to alter Chinaâ€™s role. The delay was interpreted as a message to Beijing and Washington that her position toward China is more skeptical than that of Mr. Cameron and Mr. Osborne, who had aspirations of becoming prime minister but whom she fired from government. On Monday, Helen Bower, a spokeswoman for Mrs. May, said that Britain did not want a break with Beijing. â€œWith the role China has to play on world affairs, on the global economy, on a whole range of international issues, we are going to continue to seek a strong relationship with China,â€ she said. As for France, Mr. Hollande has near record disapproval ratings in the polls and faces elections in May. He has pushed for EDF to win the project as a needed lift for the countryâ€™s nuclear industry, which has suffered since the disaster at Fukushima in Japan. This   pressurized water reactor is complex, and the company has experienced construction problems and severe cost overruns as it tries to finish the first ones in Finland and Flamanville, France. EDF unions, some board members, engineers and senior executives have expressed deep reservations over the financial risks the construction of the reactor entailed for the indebted power company.

title: Police Helicopter Deployed, Karaoke Machine Confiscated After Song Mocking Bin Laden Played at Party
content: A British police officer was moved to activate her panic button after taking offence at a parody song making fun of former   leader Osama bin Laden being played at a garden party, bringing in serious   to a small English village. [The officer pressed the panic button on her   camera after being dispatched to a garden party in a picturesque Cambridgeshire village at around 10pm on Thursday and overhearing a song being played that mocked Osama Bin Laden. Responding to the call for help, the local force dispatched another ten officers and a police helicopter, Cambridge News reports.  It is alleged that in addition to the parody song making fun of the dead terrorist,   were also shouting â€œ  abuseâ€ a suggestion the partygoers deny. Mark Donovan, who attended the party in the Cambridge village  â€”   which dates back to the time of the Domesday Book  â€”   spoke to the paper after the incident, and said: â€œWe was having a summerâ€™s evening in my neighbourâ€™s garden as we donâ€™t have one. We had our karaoke machine on playing music through our phones from YouTube which are all approved songs. â€œIt was about 10pm and the music may have been a little loud but it was before 11pm. Someone must have made a complaint, and a police officer attended our address, at which time a song from YouTube called the Bin Laden Song came on. â€œThis police officer said she took offence at the song and pressed her panic button on her body cam and thatâ€™s when about ten police turned up and the police helicopter. â€œThey are now investigating it as a racist crime. It is ridiculous. â€ Police have seized the karaoke machine.

title: Mark Tapson: Trumpâ€™s Big Agenda: David Horowitzâ€™s New Book Lays Out the Plan
content: After eight years of treasonous subversion by Barack Obamaâ€™s radical administration to fundamentally transform the United States, Donald Trumpâ€™s election victory is galvanizing a revival of American exceptionalism. But Trump and his team face formidable opponents as they begin the Herculean task of reversing the course of Obamaâ€™s failed presidency: not only a vengefully determined left but an entrenched Republican establishment in Washington D. C. and a stubborn contingent of Never Trumper politicians and pundits. [David Horowitzâ€™s new book, Big Agenda: Presidentâ€™s Trumpâ€™s Plan to Save America  â€”   the first major book to be released on Trumpâ€™s presidency  â€”   lays out a strategy for combating those opponents of the  â€™s conservative restoration.   The founder of the David Horowitz Freedom Center, the leftâ€™s most hated apostate, and the rightâ€™s most aggressive strategist, Horowitz reveals major components of Trumpâ€™s plan for his first 100 days and his   agenda in the slim but essential Big Agenda (available Tuesday, January 17 from Humanix Books). The book has earned unqualified support from the likes of Dinesh Dâ€™Souza, gay conservative firebrand Milo Yiannopoulos, Clinton Cash author Peter Schweizer, Rush Limbaugh (who calls the book â€œa road map for a winning agenda that conservatives will embraceâ€) and Ann Coulter, who recommends it as a â€œbrilliant battle plan. â€ Horowitz begins by profiling the adversaries. â€œ[T]he first concern of Americans disturbed by the radicalism of the Obama years,â€ he declares, is the division within the Republican party itself. For eight years the Republican Party mustered only tepid opposition to President Obama. This was a party made feckless by its incomprehension of the nature of the left, by a failure of nerve, and by a lack of the will to win. Then Trump barreled onto the scene with a readiness to â€œdisregard the politically correct restraints on public discourseâ€ and to â€œrelentlessly attackâ€ Democrats who could dish it out but were unaccustomed to having it thrown back at them. As a result, the â€œpassions Trump aroused in the electorate sparked a revolt in the Republican Partyâ€ and thrust the political outsider ahead of his 16 rivals in the primaries and then on to election victory against Hillary Clinton.   Beyond the sharp division that still remains in his own party, Trump and his supporters face the   zealots of an ideology fueled by ugly, dehumanizing hatred for anyone who stands in the way of their utopian vision  â€”   a hatred exemplified in Hillaryâ€™s demonization of conservatives as â€œirredeemable deplorablesâ€: racists, sexists, Islamophobes, homophobes, xenophobes  â€”   â€œyou name it,â€ she said on the campaign trail. Trump fearlessly identified that hatred during the second presidential debate when he told the audience that â€œHillary has tremendous hatred in her heart. â€ Republicans have been playing defense for so long that Trumpâ€™s willingness to publicly characterize progressives for what they are, Horowitz notes with admiration, â€œwas probably unprecedented in the annals of modern presidential politics. â€ Horowitz realized correctly that Trump was the only Republican who had a chance against Hillary. In Part Two of the book Horowitz identifies the leftist agenda, the overarching goal behind the issues, that Trump and the right must understand and counter. He points to Saul   progressives like Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton as evidence that the Democratic Party â€œhas moved so far to the left in recent decades that it now operates on the sixtiesâ€™ principle that the issues it advances are mere stepping stones on the way to more radical changes. â€ Those changes mean the dismantling of individual freedom and the consolidation of power in the hands of the state. That explains the leftâ€™s drive to establish a totalitarian infrastructure through their obsessive push for the passage of Obamacare, their religious devotion to save the planet from   â€œclimate changeâ€ (which they deem a greater threat to national security than terrorism) their social justice solutions to what they insist against all evidence is Americaâ€™s â€œsystemic racism,â€ and their globalist pursuits, which include lawless Sanctuary Cities, open borders policies, and a willful blindness toward our Islamic fundamentalist enemy. Horowitz breaks down all of these issues to demonstrate how they are central to the leftâ€™s   agenda.  Part Three, approximately half the book, presents Horowitzâ€™s strategy for the way forward. â€œThe goal,â€ he begins, â€œis to put Democrats on the offensive  â€¦     to expose their hypocrisy and turn their firepower against them  â€¦     The strategy is to go for the jugular. â€ Conservatives generally are uncomfortable with the idea of political brawling, even when on the ropes as they have been throughout the Obama years. But Horowitz stresses that if your first response to, say, the leftâ€™s kneejerk use of the race card is to go on the defensive, then you are losing. â€œTo turn around the political battles conservatives have been losing for so long, they must begin every confrontation by punching progressives in the mouth,â€ he declares, referring to boxer Mike Tysonâ€™s famous observation that â€œeverybody has a game plan until you punch them in the mouth. â€ Donald Trump is better suited to pursuing such a strategy than any Republican leader in recent memory. Horowitz goes on to note that the right must attack the left with equal moral force, particularly at the Democratsâ€™ Achilles heel: their atrocious record on race as exemplified in their monopoly control of Americaâ€™s inner cities and the suffering and misery they have wrought there. Conservatives must also attack progressives for what Horowitz calls their wars on men and women, their leftist indoctrination in our schools, their politicized   institutions such as the progressive Ford Foundation, their powerful, thuggish government unions, and their corruption and foreign influence peddling. And the right must destroy the false narrative that the Democratic Party is the party of the people. In short, the right must, as one chapter title puts it, â€œgo on the attack and stay on it. â€ We must be as willing to morally stigmatize the left as they are us. We must fight fire with fire. And then we must take things a step further â€œand create a unifying theme that has a moral resonanceâ€ with which we can level the political playing field. â€œThat theme is individual freedomâ€: The New Republicanism must be a movement opposed to the progressivesâ€™ sellout of American sovereignty, of Americaâ€™s historical uniqueness. It must be unapologetic in its patriotism and in its commitment to rebuilding America economically and militarily. Third, the New Republicanism must show its contempt for a political correctness that denies the virtues of Americaâ€™s culture, which is founded on individual rights and equality before the law. It must oppose progressive â€œmulticulturalism,â€ which seeks to replace this culture with   hierarchies of gender, class, and race. â€œThis is the moral language Republicans need to use if they are going to defeat the progressive agenda,â€ Horowitz insists. He concludes the book with a battle plan for the first 100 days that includes such recommendations as restoring Guantanamo, moving our embassy in Israel to Jerusalem, defunding sanctuary cities, promoting energy independence, nixing illegal immigration amnesty, attacking IRS malfeasance, dismantling Obamacare, and following through on Trumpâ€™s promise of a New Deal for black America. â€œNo president since FDR and his famed â€˜100 Daysâ€™ has the chance Donald Trump has,â€ David Horowitz has said, to reshape the American political landscape at home and abroad  â€”   if conservatives understand the nature of the enemy we face and how to engage them successfully.  Big Agenda succinctly educates the right about that enemy and maps a clear way forward to victory and restoration. Mark Tapson is the editor of TruthRevolt. org and a Shillman Journalism Fellow at the David Horowitz Freedom Center.

title: In Pennsylvania, Unbound Delegates Remain Wary of Donald Trump - The New York Times
content: PHILADELPHIA  â€”   Mary Ann Meloy, one of the 54 Republican delegates elected in Pennsylvania on Tuesday as free agents to the Republican National Convention, said she would find it very hard to vote for Donald J. Trump. Ms. Meloy had a sister with cerebral palsy. And Mr. Trumpâ€™s disparaging treatment of people with disabilities, she said, â€œmade me want to jump through the television screen. â€ Because of the unusual latitude the Pennsylvania Republican Party gives to the delegates like Ms. Meloy who are not required to support any candidate, Mr. Trumpâ€™s crushing victory in the state on Tuesday is more complicated than it may appear. â€œThe bottom line is that being an uncommitted delegate gives you the ability to take all the facts into consideration,â€ said Ms. Meloy, who lives in Harmar Township outside Pittsburgh and got her start in politics volunteering for Richard M. Nixon in 1968. â€œCertainly the will of the people in your district  â€”   thereâ€™s a lot to be said for that. â€ But, she continued: â€œWe have a representative form of government. Not a democracy. A representative democracy. â€ Mr. Trump won Pennsylvania with nearly 57 percent of the vote. He carried every county, including Ms. Meloyâ€™s, and even won large urban ones with diverse and highly educated populations like Philadelphia, the kind of territory that he has often found inhospitable to his rancorous brand of politics. Yet in the trench warfare fight for the Republican presidential nomination  â€”   the smaller, less understood delegate races that could prove far more pivotal to Mr. Trumpâ€™s campaign  â€”   the situation remains fluid. He appeared to have won about 40 of Pennsylvaniaâ€™s 54 unbound delegates, along with another 17 awarded to him outright as the statewide winner. The remaining 14 delegates have either expressed no preference or said they would not vote for Mr. Trump. Should Mr. Trump fall short of receiving a majority of the delegates he needs to secure the nomination before the convention  â€”   an outcome that seems less likely after Tuesday but still looms as a possible spoiler  â€”   a small number of unbound delegates could make all the difference. From a former congressman turned lobbyist in Erie to a gastroenterologist in Philadelphia, the uncommitted, unbound delegates chosen in Pennsylvaniaâ€™s 18 congressional districts to represent the state at the national convention in July were examples of just how unpredictable and counterintuitive the nominating process can be. Completely untethered from the public opinion, the delegates who are unbound under state party rules could find themselves grappling with a number of concerns in a contested convention, both political and personal, many of which have nothing to do with the preferences of the voters who elected them. Together, Pennsylvaniaâ€™s 54 unbound delegates will form the largest group of free agents when Republicans meet in Cleveland in July. And if the vote is close, the nominee could rise or fall on the Pennsylvania Republican Partyâ€™s experiment with political free will. Many newly elected Trump delegates find this maddening. â€œHow do you justify not voting for him at the convention? What rationale could people possibly have?â€ asked Lynne Ryan, who lives in New Castle, in the stateâ€™s northwest corner along the Ohio border. â€œBut people will find a reason. Trust me. â€ Ms. Ryan, a topsoil farmer and flight attendant, campaigned as a committed Trump supporter. But at least one of the other delegates elected from her area, Phil English, a former congressman, has been wary of Mr. Trump. In few states are the quirks of the American party system as evident as in Pennsylvania, which delivered only 17 of its 71 delegates outright to the winner of its primary, Mr. Trump. The remaining 54 delegates were elected blindly by voters in each of the stateâ€™s 18 congressional districts. The only way voters knew if they were voting for a delegate who supported their favored presidential candidate was if they went to the trouble of educating themselves. That information was not printed on the ballot. And in some cases it was not knowable at all, because many delegate candidates ran saying they would not commit to any candidate now. â€œThe campaign is fluid,â€ said Bob Bozzuto, executive director of the Pennsylvania Republican Party, recounting his conversations with delegate candidates recently who have said they wanted to leave themselves some flexibility. â€œWe talk to some who have been recruited by a campaign and say â€˜Iâ€™m going to vote for the candidate Iâ€™m signed up to vote for,â€™â€ he said. â€œYou have some others,â€ he added, â€œwho say, â€˜the time between April 26 and July 18 might cause me to have some conversations, and Iâ€™ll see what happens. â€™â€ Determining how many Pennsylvania delegates are solidly for Mr. Trump, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas or Gov. John Kasich of Ohio is complicated, given that personal preferences can shift so quickly. The New York Times interviewed delegates, analyzed lists of the campaignsâ€™ preferred delegate candidates and relied on media reports to arrive at its totals. But Mr. Trump hopes to prevail on the unbound delegates by sheer force. He has been making an impassioned case that he deserves the nomination because he has a wide leads in the popular vote, and should not be denied the nomination if he falls just short of a majority at the convention. His underperformance in some states to Mr. Cruz has left him short of that majority, and on Tuesday, the Texas senator appeared to pick up only a few delegates in Pennsylvania. The Timesâ€™s analysis counted only three. By framing his possible loss as a denial of popular will and a power grab by the establishment, Mr. Trump has frustrated efforts by Republicans who have tried to hold him back and push the convention into multiple rounds of balloting, an outcome that could very well result in the nomination of someone more palatable to party loyalists. But the overwhelming margin of Mr. Trumpâ€™s win in Pennsylvania shows that delegates buck the results at their own peril. Some were slowly coming to this realization. â€œI want to do the right thing,â€ said Mr. English, a former congressman who was elected as a delegate on Tuesday representing the northwestern corner of the state. He said he has reservations about Mr. Trumpâ€™s ability to unite the party and wants to spend more time thinking about his decision. But he said he ultimately could not foreclose voting for Mr. Trump given how well he did in his district. â€œThe expectation had been that Trump would be staying below 50 percent. That clearly is not the dynamic thatâ€™s out there,â€ he said, adding, â€œThatâ€™s loomed very large in my thought process. â€ In Pennsylvania, long relegated to the role of political footnote in the nominating process because it holds its primary so late in the cycle, a victory has not been important to Republicans since 1980, when George Bushâ€™s victory in the state revived his campaign against Ronald Reagan. But this year Pennsylvania Republicans could find themselves the center of a contested convention, much as they were in 1976 when Mr. Reagan made an   bid to overcome President Gerald R. Ford by naming Richard Schweiker, a Pennsylvania senator, as his running mate. The move did not, however, impress Pennsylvania delegates, or many other delegates for that matter. Mr. Reagan lost on the first ballot. â€œThese delegates are all trying to dance,â€ said Representative Charlie Dent, a Republican who represents the Lehigh Valley. â€œOn the one hand they say they want to support the district. But they all have their own preferences. And they will come under tremendous pressure from all the candidates. And not just the candidates but party leaders and elected officials. â€ Seth Kaufer, a Philadelphia gastroenterologist elected as a delegate on Tuesday, said he has already met personally with Mr. Cruz and Carly Fiorina, who worked on the Texas senatorâ€™s delegate outreach team before becoming his running mate on Wednesday. He also met Mr. Kasich. The one candidate he has not met is Mr. Trump. For now, Dr. Kaufer said, he is waiting to decide which one to support at the convention in Cleveland. Hearing from Mr. Trumpâ€™s team  â€”   or their highly motivated supporters  â€”   now seems all but certain, whether Dr. Kaufer welcomes it or not. Mr. Trump carried Philadelphia County with almost 60 percent of the vote.

title: France Blames Russia For Poor Performance of Left-Wing Presidential Candidate
content: PARIS (AP)  â€”   Franceâ€™s foreign minister is denouncing possible Russian meddling in the French presidential campaign as â€œunacceptable. â€[  Ayrault, in an interview published Sunday in newspaper Journal du Dimanche, said Russia appears to be targeting centrist candidate Emmanuel Macron, while favoring more   candidates such as conservative Francois Fillon and nationalist Marine Le Pen.  Macronâ€™s campaign has described hacking attempts that it suspects are linked to Russia, though itâ€™s unclear whether the detected activity was more than routine cybersecurity breaches. The Kremlin has denied involvement. Ayrault is quoted as saying â€œthis kind of interference in French democratic life is unacceptable  â€¦    . The French will not accept anyone dictating their (electoral) choices. â€ The French government is holding an election security meeting Friday to discuss concerns raised by alleged Russian interference in the U. S. presidential campaign.
