Most prominently, the Washington Redskins football team, who have twice had their trademark protections revoked for having a name that â€œdisparagesâ€ American Indians. Writing for the Court, Justice Samuel Alito reasoned that the entire purpose behind the provision rendered it facially unconstitutional. â€œIt offends a bedrock First Amendment principle: Speech may not be banned on the ground that it expresses ideas that offend,â€ he wrote. In contravention of this principle, the Patent and Trademark Office devised a test to determine whether a trademark was too offensive for the federal government to protect. If a â€œsubstantial composite, although not necessarily a majority, of the referenced group would find the proposed mark . . . to be disparaging in the context of contemporary attitudes,â€ the trademark could not be registered. This test, by disfavoring a certain subset of speech specifically on the view it expressed, constituted â€œviewpoint discrimination,â€ a fundamental limit on governmentâ€™s power to regulate private speech. The provision was not saved by the governmentâ€™s arguments that trademark protection was a matter of â€œgovernment speechâ€ or was a â€œsubsidyâ€ over which the first Amendment did not apply in its broadest sense. â€œIf private speech could be passed off as government speech by simply affixing a government seal of approval, government could silence or muffle the expression of disfavored viewpoints,â€ the opinion reads: Holding that the registration of a   converts the mark into government speech would constitute a huge and dangerous extension of the   doctrine, for other systems of government registration (such as copyright) could easily be characterized in the same way. A concurring opinion by Justice Anthony Kennedy and joined by the Courtâ€™s more liberal justices, called the policy â€œthe essence of viewpoint discrimination,â€ and determined there was no need to even consider the government speech and subsidy arguments. The same law was held unconstitutional on the same grounds by an en banc panel of the Federal Circuit in 2015. The government, then represented by   Solicitor General Donald Verrilli, petitioned to the Supreme Court in a last attempt to save the law. Mondayâ€™s ruling by the nations highest court cements the end of the seldom enforced provision.

title: Kellyanne Conway to Jill Stein: â€™Give it Upâ€™ - Breitbart
content: On this weekendâ€™s broadcast of â€œFox News Sunday,â€ while commenting on 2016 Green Party presidential nominee Dr. Jill Steinâ€™s attempts to initiate recounts of the presidential vote in several swing states,   Donald Trumpâ€™s campaign manager and transition adviser Kellyanne Conway said, â€˜Iâ€™d say to her give it up. â€  Conway continued, â€œEven your friends in the Clinton campaign have admitted these recounts wonâ€™t change any results. â€ Follow Pam Key on Twitter @pamkeyNEN

title: Crackdown: Turkey Blocks all Access to Wikipedia
content: ISTANBUL (AP)  â€”   In a move that social media users called censorship, a Turkish court on Saturday blocked access to Wikipedia, the free online encyclopedia, enforcing an earlier restriction by Turkeyâ€™s telecommunications watchdog. [The Information and Communication Technologies Authority (BTK) said an Ankara court ordered Saturday that a â€œprotection measureâ€ related to suspected internet crimes be applied to Wikipedia. Such measures are used to block access to pages or entire websites to protect â€œnational security and public order. â€  In response, Wikipedia founder Jimmy Wales tweeted his support for those who labeled the decision censorship: â€œAccess to information is a fundamental human right. Turkish people I will always stand with you to fight for this right. â€ Turkey Blocks, an internet censorship monitor, said users in Turkey have been unable to access all language editions of Wikipedia since 8 a. m. Saturday. â€œThe loss of availability is consistent with internet filters used to censor content in the country,â€ the monitor said. The site had initially been blocked by BTK under a provisional administration measure. The exact reason for the ban remains unclear. But Turkeyâ€™s official news agency, quoting the Ministry of Transport, Maritime Affairs and Communications, said Saturday the site was blocked for â€œbecoming an information source acting with groups conducting a smear campaign against Turkey in the international arena. â€ The   Anadolu Agency said officials had warned Wikipedia to remove content likening Turkey to terror groups but the site â€œpersistentlyâ€ did not. Turkey had demanded that Wikipedia open an office in the country, act in line with international law and abide by court decisions and not be part of â€œblackout operation against Turkey,â€ according to the agency. Anadolu said if these demands are met and the content removed, the site would be reopened. Opposition lawmakers also criticized the court order. Republican Peopleâ€™s Party parliamentarians Eren Erdem tweeted the ban puts â€œTurkey in line with North Koreaâ€ while Baris Yarkadas called it â€œcensorship and a violation of the right to access information. â€ Turkeyâ€™s status is listed as â€œnot freeâ€ on the 2016 Freedom on the Net index by independent rights watchdog Freedom House. It says over 111, 000 websites were blocked as of May last year. Wikipedia, a collaborative online reference work, says it is ranked among the 10 most popular websites.

title: Six New England Patriots Say They Will Skip a White House Visit - The New York Times
content: At least six members of the Super   New England Patriots have said they will not visit the White House for the traditional meeting that championship teams have with the president. Running back LeGarrette Blount, defensive end Chris Long and defensive tackle Alan Branch on Thursday became the latest to announce that they would skip the visit. Long posted on Twitter that he â€œplanned on skippingâ€ in response to a column in The Daily News that urged him to skip. Blount revealed his decision on Fox Sports in a radio interview on â€œThe Rich Eisen Showâ€ later in the afternoon. â€œI just donâ€™t feel welcome in that house,â€ Blount said. â€œIâ€™m going to just leave it at that. â€ Branch told Sirius XM Radio that he planned to spend time with family. A day earlier, the Pro Bowl linebacker Dontâ€™a Hightower bowed out when he told ESPN, â€œBeen there, done that,â€ having visited with a championship Alabama team. Tight end Martellus Bennett told reporters after the Super Bowl that he would not go: â€œIt is what it is,â€ he said. â€œPeople know how I feel about it. Just follow me on Twitter. â€ The outspoken Bennett had joked that he might move to outer space after Donald J. Trump was elected. The Pro Bowl safety Devin McCourty, a team captain,  told Time magazine: â€œBasic reason for me is I donâ€™t feel accepted in the White House. With the president having so many strong opinions and prejudices, I believe certain people might feel accepted there while others wonâ€™t. â€ Bennett and McCourty were in the news for their activism last fall, when they raised their fists in protest during the national anthem for one game. At the time, athletes in various sports were protesting racial oppression in the country. The number of Patriots absences may well increase. Running back James White said he had not made up his mind whether to go. â€œIâ€™ll wait till the time comes and decide then,â€ he said. No date has been scheduled for this yearâ€™s ceremony honoring the Patriots. The ceremony for last yearâ€™s champions, the Broncos, took place in June. Perhaps no other team has as close an association with Trump as the Patriots. Just before the election, Trump claimed that he had the support of Patriots quarterback Tom Brady and Coach Bill Belichick. Brady, who displayed a â€œMake America Great Againâ€ cap in his locker during the campaign, never explicitly endorsed Trump, but he spoke favorably of him and they have socialized. Trump also cited a supportive letter he had received from Belichick, and several news media accounts confirmed the letter was authentic. The teamâ€™s owner, Robert K. Kraft, has said he has considered Trump a longtime friend. Brady did not attend his teamâ€™s visit with former President Barack Obama at the White House, in 2015, citing family issues. But some athletes who have skipped the trip over the years have explicitly given politics as a reason. Bruins goalie Tim Thomas declined to visit the Obama White House with his teammates in January 2012, saying in a statement: â€œI believe the federal government has grown out of control, threatening the rights, liberties and property of the people. â€œBecause I believe this, today I exercised my right as a free citizen, and did not visit the White House. â€ Baltimore Ravens center Matt Birk cited his opposition to abortion as the reason for skipping a 2013 visit. A number of other athletes have skipped the ceremony while citing scheduling conflicts or family commitments. Presidents for years have invited sports figures to the White House, but the tradition of honoring championships teams there solidified under Ronald Reagan. Major professional champions and many college champions stop by for a presentation and a photo opportunity. Six Patriots, so far, wonâ€™t make the trip this year.

title: NYT Publisher Sends Personal Message to Subscribers Who Canceled Over Bret Stephens Column - Breitbart
content: The publisher of the New York Times is personally reaching out to former subscribers who canceled their subscriptions over the paperâ€™s decision to hire conservative columnist Bret Stephens. [Publisher Arthur O. Sulzberger Jr. sent an email Friday afternoon to former subscribers who specifically mentioned Stephens as the reason they canceled their subscriptions but still opted in to receive messages from the Times, Politico reported.  â€œOur customer care team shared with me that your reason for unsubscribing from the New York Times included our decision to hire Bret Stephens as an Opinion columnist. I wanted to provide a bit more context,â€ Sulzberger began the letter. Less than six percent of readers who cancelled their subscriptions to the Times listed Stephens as a reason for dropping their subscriptions, according to a Times spokesman. Stephens, a former Wall Street Journal columnist and critic of President Trump, got slammed by Times readers after he penned his first column questioning the validity of the science behind climate change. The column led to complaints from various progressives on Twitter, a Change. org petition demanding the paper rescind Stephensâ€™ job offer, canceled subscriptions, and a public editor column devoted to responding to readersâ€™ complaints about Stephens. Sulzberger said in the letter that it is important that readers recognize the difference between news and opinion while noting that NYT Executive Editor Dean Baquet â€œhas sharply expanded the team of reporters and editors who cover climate change. â€ The publisher mentioned several recent Times articles on climate change, such as one article that suggested climate change caused rising waters in China, and then encouraged readers to â€œsign up for a free newsletterâ€ from the â€œclimate deskâ€ for news about the subject. â€œThe Timesâ€™s Opinion pages remain an independent and unblinking forum for debate from a wide range of viewpoints among   informed writers and readers. I donâ€™t think, in these polarizing and partisan times, thereâ€™s anything quite like it in American journalism,â€ Sulzberger wrote. He added that with so many people â€œtalking past each other about how best to address climate change,â€ he hoped that exposing people to different viewpoints on the subject will encourage people to work together to come up with bipartisan solutions. Sulzberger, however, still maintains that the paper will only publish certain points of view over others. â€œThis does not mean that the Times will publish any commentary. Some points of view are not welcome, including those promoting prejudice or denying basic truths about our world. But it does mean that, in the coming years, we aim to further enrich the quality of our debate with other honest and intelligent voices, including some currently underrepresented in our pages,â€ he wrote.

title: Ted Cruz: Establishment Has Abandoned Marco Rubio for Donald Trump - Breitbart
content: Ted Cruz has a theory as to why everyone is warming up to Donald Trump: Trump will make deals in Washington D. C. instead of fighting for conservatism. [Speaking to reporters after a campaign rally, Cruz said that the establishment was no longer looking to Marco Rubio as their champion.  â€œWeâ€™re seeing something remarkable happening in this Republican primary,â€ Cruz said, according to National Reviewâ€™s Eliana Johnson. â€œRight now, the Washington establishment is abandoning Marco Rubio, theyâ€™ve made the assessment that Marco canâ€™t win this race, and the Washington establishment is rushing over to support Donald Trump. Weâ€™re seeing that happen every day, and Mr. Trump is welcoming that support. â€ Last night, Cruz made a similar argument in a recent interview, calling Trump part of the â€œWashington cartel. â€ â€œThe cartel exists to make deals and to pick winners and losers through cronyism and corporate welfare,â€ Cruz said in an interview with BuzzFeedâ€™s Rosie Gray. â€œAnd so itâ€™s no surprise that more and more of the establishment is beginning to support Donald Trump. Because Donald has promised to make deals and to continue the cronyism and corporate welfare of Washington. Thatâ€™s what the cartel does. They make deals with Democrats. â€ Cruz said that Trump was more likely to make deals with Democrats to help get things done. â€œDonald Trump said just yesterday that the problem with me is that I wouldnâ€™t go to Washington to make a deal and go along to get along with the Democrats,â€ Cruz said in the interview. â€œIf youâ€™re looking for someone whoâ€™s a dealmaker, whoâ€™ll capitulate even more to the Democrats, whoâ€™ll give in to Chuck Schumer, Harry Reid, and Nancy Pelosi, then perhaps Donald Trump is your man. â€

title: Kamala Harris to Replace Scalia on Supreme Court? - Breitbart
content: California Attorney General Kamala Harris may be on Barack Obamaâ€™s list of nominees to fill the Supreme Court vacancy left by Antonin Scaliaâ€™s death. [Various media outlets have mentioned Harris as as a prospective nominee, including the New York Times, Associated Press, USA Today, the National Law Journal and the SCOTUSblog, according to the Los Angeles Times.  Former Obama White House advisor David Axelrod has also mentioned Harris. Harrisâ€™ campaign spokesman Nathan Click dismissed the speculation, saying, â€œWhile the attorney general is honored to be mentioned in these conversations, sheâ€™s committed to her current job and continuing her fight for California families in the U. S. Senate. â€ Obama has a special fondness for Harris, featuring her as a speaker at the Democratic National Convention in 2012 and once calling her â€œthe  â€ attorney general in the country. Harris champions leftist positions on virtually everything, including abortion, ending the federal ban on medical marijuana, easing a path to citizenship for illegal immigrants, and shorter sentences for some drug crimes. She notably refused to defend Proposition 8, which outlawed   marriage in California, saying it violated the Constitution. She defended the law forcing members of public employee unions to help pay for collective bargaining, and appealed the ruling against unions in Vergara vs. California. As San Francisco district attorney, Harris refused to press for the death penalty against a gang member who killed a police officer. Judge Paul Watford, another Californian, has also been mentioned by the New York Times and the Washington Post as a possible successor to Scalia. He clerked for Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, was nominated by Obama to be an appellate judge in 2011, and was confirmed by the Senate in 2012. He, like Harris, is African American.

title: Christina Hoff Sommers: â€™Women are the Privileged Sex in Educationâ€™ - Breitbart
content: In an interview with The Dartmouth Review, Resident Scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, Christina Hoff Sommers, spoke about feminism, political correctness, and the state of free expression on college campuses. [In the interview, Sommers argued that girls and women are the privileged sex when it comes to educational status.  Girls and women are the privileged sex in education. From preschool to graduate school, and across ethnic and class lines, women get better grades, they win most of the honors and prizes, and theyâ€™re far more likely to go to college. Today women earn a majority of bachelorâ€™s degrees and advanced degrees. Latino girls are now slightly more likely to attend college than white boys. When an education policy analyst looked at current trends in higher education he quipped, only half in jest, â€œThe last male will graduate from college in 2068. â€ Our schools have offered untold number of admirable and effective programs to strengthen girls in areas where they languished â€”  in sports, math, and science. Where are the programs to help boys in areas where they falter: reading, writing, grades, school engagement and college matriculation? So far Congress, schools of education, school boards and the Department of Education have looked the other way. She also argued that universities must move away from identity politics if they are to return to a place where all ideas are welcome to be explored.

title: EXCLUSIVE: RNC Condemns Bill Kristolâ€™s Anti-Trump Third Party as â€™Helping to Elect Hillary Clintonâ€™ - Breitbart
content: WASHINGTON â€”  The Republican National Committee (RNC) is throwing cold water on pundit Bill Kristolâ€™s efforts to form a third party to challenge Donald Trump in the general election. [Bill Kristol, son of Irving, is trying to get retired senator Tom Coburn or retired Texas governor Rick Perry to run independently if the GOP Establishment canâ€™t figure out how to broker the convention in Cleveland to deny Trump the nomination.  RNC spokesman Sean Spicer told Breitbart News that â€œany effort to facilitate a third party ultimately is helping to elect Hillary Clinton. â€ â€œThe Republican Party must be united to take back the White House,â€ Spicer said. Kristol has been touting his potential third party on Twitter. The name of the third party: The   Republicans. https:  .   â€”   Bill Kristol (@BillKristol) March 20, 2016,  â€œIf theyâ€™re going to do that, theyâ€™re going to do that but then you might as well just hand the election to Hillary Clinton or whoever runs,â€ Trump told George Stephanopoulos Sunday. â€œFrankly, the Republicans wouldnâ€™t have even one percent chance of winning if thatâ€™s the case. So if theyâ€™re going to be stupid and theyâ€™re going to do that instead of embracing these millions of people who are coming in to vote, then theyâ€™re going to have to do that. And Iâ€™ll tell you what, thatâ€™s going to mean more than any other thing. Itâ€™s going to mean four or five justices, super liberal, placed on the Supreme Court. Our country will never, ever be the same. â€ Kristol and his cohorts might not actually care if they help to elect Hillary Clinton. It will give the partyâ€™s power brokers a chance to stave off the populist takeover of their party as embodied by Trumpâ€™s rise, and they can presumably go back to picking the nominees again in 2020. This plot also eliminates Trumpâ€™s own   leverage. Trump canâ€™t threaten to split the Republican vote in November if the party itself wants the vote split so Clinton can win. But before any   shenanigans occur, the Establishment is going to do everything it can to broker the convention in Cleveland. Trump needs to get 1, 237 delegates during primary season, which he thinks he can do â€œfairly easily,â€ in order to win the Republican nomination on the first ballot. If he doesnâ€™t win on the first ballot, then many state delegates on later ballots can be freed from voting with their state and can form alliances to elect an Establishment candidate. John Boehner already said that he would support House Speaker Paul Ryan on a later ballot, and Ryan did not conclusively rule out the idea of accepting a brokered nomination. Trump supporter Chris Christie, who leads the Republican Governors Association, said recently that â€œI do not want to go back to the days of the 1800s and 1700s  â€¦     where a bunch of, you know, legislators, no offense, pick the United States Senator or pick, you know, who is going to be the Presidential electors. â€ â€œThe fact is I like the way this system works and even though sometimes it has worked to my advantage and sometimes it has worked to my disadvantage,â€ Christie said in remarks at a press conference that were provided to Breitbart News by his office. â€œSo, I do not, I think it is wrong, I do not think we should be disenfranchising people. People vote for who they want to vote for. The one who gets the most votes should be the one who gets to be the nominee, in my view. â€ â€œItâ€™s childish nonsense,â€ Newt Gingrich told Breitbart News, referring to a   brokered convention. â€œThere are two potential presidential nominees. One is named Donald. One is named Ted. The idea that some clever Washington intellectual or power broker  â€”   put quote marks around â€˜power brokerâ€™  â€”   can step into an election in which millions have voted and magically change the trajectory of history? Itâ€™s goofy. Thereâ€™s two players standing. â€ Conservative commentator Erick Erickson is also leading a group that wants a brokered convention and is working with former Bush administration official Bill Wichterman to try to get it done. But an effort is already underway by grassroots conservatives to stop the Establishment in its tracks. Breitbart News reported that Trump and Ted Cruz delegates in Tennessee are already forming an alliance to make sure that their convention votes go to either Trump or Cruz and will not end up going to an Establishment candidate.

title: California School Bans Tag, Says Game â€˜Too Roughâ€™ - Breitbart
content: Gold Ridge Elementary School in Folsom, California has banned the game of tag. [Principle David Frankel sent a note home to parents saying, â€œStudents were instructed that physical contact including tag games, touch football, etc. were not allowed on the yard. â€  Why would this   tradition of playground fun get the axe? According to school district spokesman Daniel Thigpen, things had gotten just a bit too physical. Thigpen explained, â€œIn this case, kids were getting too rough  â€¦    so the school told them to stop playing those games  â€¦     Itâ€™s not uncommon for a school to enact specific recess rules to address specific behavior problems. â€ Students will face disciplinary action should they not comply. The punishments will begin with a referral, and then a   conference, according to school officials. According to The Daily Mail, the school has claimed that the note was only sent home to some parents, and thereâ€™s some confusion over whether the ban applies to all students.   Mallory Giddens is not a fan of the new rule. Giddens told KOVR television, â€œI donâ€™t really like it. I mean I donâ€™t really play tag but I donâ€™t think itâ€™s fair to everyone else that plays tag!â€ Giddens continued, â€œMy principal, he doesnâ€™t want us to have tag at school because people, they touch too hard. Sometimes they push people over and my principal doesnâ€™t want anyone getting hurt. â€ Follow Dylan Gwinn on Twitter: @themightygwinn

title: Five-Year-Old Girl Suspended After Making â€™Shooting Motionâ€™ with Stick Shaped Like Gun - Breitbart
content: A    girl in Hoke County, North Carolina, was suspended for one day after she made a â€œshooting motionâ€ with a stick shaped like a gun. [The girl â€”  Caitlin Miller â€”  was playing â€œKings and Queensâ€ at recess on Friday and her role in the game was â€œto protect the royals. â€ She picked up a stick shaped like a gun to do this and, according to ABC 11, â€œHoke County Schools said Caitlin posed a threat to other students when she made a shooting motion, thus violating policy 4331. â€  Caitlinâ€™s mother, Brandy Miller, says her daughter â€œwas alienated by her friends and teachers as a result of the suspensionâ€ and is hopeful that the school will apologize to Caitlin. As of the now, the school system is standing by the suspension. They issued a statement, saying: Hoke County Schools will not tolerate assaults, threats or harassment from any student. Any student engaging in such behavior will be removed from the classroom or school environment for as long as is necessary to provide a safe and orderly environment for learning. Hoke County School Superintendent Freddie Williamson knows about the suspension. On March 23 Breitbart News reported that    Hunter Jackson was suspended for seven days from his   A Place to Grow, for bringing an empty . 22 casing to school. Hunterâ€™s mother said â€œa stone faced teacherâ€ handed her a letter announcing the suspension and told her that Hunter had brought a â€œshotgun bulletâ€ to school. title: Germany evacuates 50,000 people on Christmas to defuse massive bomb
content: (CNN) More than 50, 000 people had to be evacuated from a city in south Germany on Christmas Day after a 1.  World War II bomb was found there.  The bomb was discovered last week in Augsburg, during construction work on an underground car park. An evacuation area more than a mile (1. 5 kilometers) in radius was announced for December 25, including 32, 000 households and around 54, 000 inhabitants. Residents were told to be out of their homes by 10 a. m. at the latest, and evacuation centers were set up in local schools and gymnasiums. Just after 7 p. m. the cityâ€™s official Facebook account announced the bomb had been successfully defused and the evacuation was over. Photos showed Augsburgâ€™s mayor, Kurt Gribl, going into the pit where the bomb was sitting to thank the work crews who had given up their Christmas to work on the explosive. â€Aircraft bomb disarmed    these brave men are the real heroes of this historical day. Thank you deep down from the heart,â€ Gribl said on his Twitter account. The city also confirmed in a statement that the bomb was a British one that had been dropped on the city in World War II. Authorities had previously decided to wait to defuse the device until Christmas, as there was no immediate danger from the bomb.  In Germany, families hold their main celebration on Christmas Eve, rather than Christmas Day as in many other Christian countries. More than 70 years after the end of the second World War, unexploded bombs are still causing problems across Europe. In August 2015, a 250 kilogram (550 pound) bomb was discovered on a construction site in East London, forcing a   evacuation while it was defused. One year earlier, in January 2014, a bulldozer struck an unexploded bomb in Euskirchen, Germany, killing one person and injuring others.

content: Washington (CNN) Seriously, Twitter, Let. It. Go. The usually   Idina Menzel had a slight stumble as she was belting out her siren song, â€Let It Go,â€ for the thousands gathered in Times Square for Dick Clarkâ€™s New Yearâ€™s Rockinâ€™ Eve. title: NRA will comment on Philando Castileâ€™s death following investigation
content: (CNN) Critics are calling out the National Rifle Association for not quickly coming to the defense of Philando Castile, who was fatally shot by a police officer in Minnesota this week after reportedly acknowledging that he had a weapon and a concealed carry permit. â€Where is the gun rights lobby?â€ wrote Amanda Marcotte on Salon. com of Castileâ€™s case and that of Alton Sterling, who was shot and killed by police in Louisiana after a 911 caller said he brandished a gun. â€Here are two American citizens that were killed while doing what the NRA claims is a constitutional right. Surely this must be a gross injustice in the eyes of the NRA! Surely they will be demanding action, petitioning congressmen, demanding the Department of Justice to step forward and make sure that every American has a right to arm themselves without fear of being gunned down by the police! Right?â€ Castileâ€™s fiancÃ©e   the immediate aftermath of the shooting, showing Castile slumped against the driverâ€™s seat, with blood soaking through his shirt. She says he told the officer he had a gun and a permit, but police have not commented on the events that led up to the shooting. But Friday afternoon    almost two days after Castile was killed    the NRA posted a statement on Twitter. It did not mention him by name. â€As the nationâ€™s largest and oldest civil rights organization, the NRA proudly supports the right of   Americans to carry firearms for defense of themselves and others regardless of race, religion or sexual orientation.  â€The reports from Minnesota are troubling and must be thoroughly investigated. In the meantime, it is important for the NRA not to comment while the investigation is ongoing.  â€Rest assured, the NRA will have more to say once all the facts are known,â€ the statement said. CNN cannot independently confirm that Castile had a   permit, as his family has said. Officials with the Minnesota Department of Public Safety and the Hennepin County Sheriffâ€™s Office told CNN such data is private under state law. â€Under Minnesota law, information about an individualâ€™s â€™permit to carryâ€™ status is not public,â€ Bruce Gordon, communications director for the Minnesota Department of Public Safety, said in an email. Before the NRA statement was posted Friday afternoon, the group took a lot of heat for its silence. Cam Edwards, who hosts an NRA podcast, seemed to raise questions about the situation. â€Our right to keep and bear arms is not based on the color of our skin,â€ Edwards said. â€Itâ€™s not based on how much money we make, itâ€™s not based on where we live. .. thatâ€™s what our rights are based on, those protections that are enshrined in the Constitution    not granted by the Constitution, but protected by the Bill of Rights.â€ Others were angered when the NRA maintained its early silence on Castileâ€™s death, in particular, but posted a statement from CEO and Executive Vice President Wayne LaPierre regarding the killings of five police officers in Dallas on Thursday night    killings that came during a largely peaceful protest of the deaths of Castile, Sterling and other   during encounters with police. â€On behalf of the more than five million members of the National Rifle Association, and especially on behalf of our members from the law enforcement community, I want to express the deep anguish all of us feel for the heroic Dallas law enforcement officers who were killed and wounded, as well as to those who so bravely ran toward danger to defend the city and the people of Dallas,â€  the statement read. â€With heavy hearts, NRA members honor their heroism and offer our deepest condolences to all of their families.â€ Some commenters were angry there was still no mention of Castile at the time of its statement on the police deaths. â€I really am not trying to rock the boat but no words about Philando Castile? This whole week has been a mess for every side at least say something,â€ wrote Kris Taylor on Facebook. â€Stop hiding behind political correctness and pride and who supports who to open your eyes that there is a serious conversation that needs to happen and it starts with establishments of influence like National Rifle Association.â€ Others supported the organization. â€The NRA represents ALL law abiding gun owners,â€ wrote Jodie L Dine.

title: Buchanan on â€˜Russiagateâ€™: Only Known Crimes Committed Are Leaks to Media
content: Columnist Pat Buchanan asks why greater emphasis isnâ€™t being placed on the leaking of classified intelligence to the media concerning the investigation of alleged connections between the Trump campaign and the Russians. If FBI director Comey is unwilling to investigate these illegal leaks, Buchanan suggests a special counsel should. [From Buchananâ€™s latest column:  Is the FBI investigating the intelligence sources who committed felonies by illegally disclosing information about the Trump campaign? Comey would not commit to investigate these leaks, though this could involve criminal misconduct within his own FBI. Again, the only known crimes committed by Americans during and after the campaign are the leaks of security secrets by agents of the intel community, colluding with the Fourth Estate, which uses the First Amendment to provide cover for criminal sources, whom they hail as â€œwhistleblowers. â€ Indeed, if there was no surveillance of Trump of any kind, where did all these stories come from, which their reporters attributed to â€œintelligence sourcesâ€? Attorney General Jeff Sessions has recused himself from any role in the Russian hacking scandal. But the Justice Department should demand that the FBI put the highest priority on investigating the deep state and its journalistic collaborators in the sabotage of the Trump presidency. If Comey refuses to do it, appoint a special counsel. Read the rest here.

title: When It Comes to a Veil, Brides Can Take It or Leave It - The New York Times
content: Molly Guy, the owner of Stone Fox Bride, a SoHo bridal shop, often finds herself catering to an unconventional client, one inclined to tweak or entirely dispense with tradition  â€”   and with it the wearing of a wedding veil. That bride, she said, â€œcan barely stomach the idea of wearing a white dress, let alone a veil. â€ Another type, Ms. Guy said, is more likely to conform. â€œHer mother and grandmother got married in a veil, and she will adhere to tradition. â€ Yet a third, she said, reads Vogue and doesnâ€™t care about the traditional: â€œShe loves the accessory element of a veil. â€ Whichever type of bride  â€”   in favor, opposed or simply on the fence  â€”   her decision to wear a veil, or reject it, is apt be fraught, heavily weighted by considerations of faith, family pressures, feminist principles and the no less compelling dictates of style. But what sets this bride apart from her motherâ€™s generation is a ringing conviction that wearing a veil is less often a matter of custom than it is one of personal choice. Allison Shoening, 33, of Centennial, Colo. a project manager for a law firm, is to marry in September. She chose to wear a veil with the blusher, the portion that covers her face. â€œI struggled with the decision myself for a while,â€ Ms. Shoening said. â€œOver all, I like the look of a veil. It adds an   element to my wedding. â€ And a wisp of decorum. â€œIf I go strapless, I want to keep my look balanced,â€ she said. â€œI just donâ€™t want everything bare. â€ Others drop the veil, or at least the blusher, dismissing these elements as relics of male oppression, about as unwelcome on oneâ€™s wedding day as a pair of manacles. When she married four years, ago, Jessica Huseman, 26, left her head bare. â€œMy   and I both find the idea of a veil to be a little silly,â€ she said. Pointedly, Ms. Huseman said: â€œWe had this mutual agreement to share our lives. It was troubling, if you saw marriage as a partnership of equals, to wear a veil. â€ â€œThe idea of my husband lifting a veil over my face as his possession in front of our family and friends would have made me feel objectified,â€ she said. Those saying no to the veil included a number of women with deeply held religious convictions and strong family ties. Emily Dause, 30, who grew up in a family of evangelical Christians, saw no betrayal of her faith in replacing the veil with a headband for her coming May wedding. â€œIt seemed to me that a veil is connected to being seen as a package, something to be given away on her wedding day,â€ said Ms. Dause, a teacher from Mechanicsburg, Pa. â€œIt was disturbing that the veil has been viewed historically as connected to superstitions about warding off demons. â€ She and others also see the veil as a symbolic reference to the virginity of the bride. Some brides sidestep the issue entirely, said Alexis Swerdloff, the    editor of New York Weddings. She said they replace the frothy length of cloth with a smaller, more discreet head covering, something like the birdcage (a small veil that cups the face) or the more   fascinator, an ornamental headpiece customarily embellished with a wisp of tulle extending slightly over one eye. Such choices tend to be governed less by custom than by taste. Wearing a fascinator, or alternately, a garland of flowers or   comb, â€œis a way of saying, â€˜Oh, so, Iâ€™m a modern, cool bride, and I just like the way this looks,â€™â€ Ms. Swerdloff said. Meghan Boledovich, a restaurant forager at Print in New York, plans to wear a small veil when she marries in July. â€œI would wear it mostly because of how it looks,â€ she said. According to the Wedding Report, which tracks industry trends, based on government data and surveys of couples, the average amount spent on dress accessories (mostly veils, but other items, too) was $226 in 2015, a drop of 1. 3 percent from 2014. In a   culture, itâ€™s not surprising that brides favoring the veil tend to be swayed by images of   muses like Princess Grace of Monaco, Bianca Jagger, Stevie Nicks or more contemporary figures, like Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge, or Jerry Hall, who married Rupert Murdoch in March with her head covered by a cloud of lavishly embroidered tulle. As with many stylistic choices, â€œThese things really come down to what people seeing in magazines, on blogs and on the runway,â€ said Ms. Guy of Stone Fox Bride. For inspiration, she refers her clients to a roster of hip role models, Gwen Stefani and Solange Knowles, among others, never mind that on her wedding day, Ms. Knowles had subbed the veil for a     white cape. Lindsay Short, a senior accessories buyer for Davidâ€™s Bridal in Conshohocken, Pa. said she is seeing an uptick in brides who wear veils. â€œIn particular to a return to the cathedral veil,â€ she said. â€œOur customer tends to be the bride that wants the ball gown and the fairy tale. â€ A recent resurgence of   formfitting gowns calls for the trailing veil and train, Ms. Short said. â€œIt gives her that showstopping moment many brides still dream of. â€ Kristen Maxwell Cooper, the executive editor of The Knot, said surveys last year of brides who use that   website showed that 57 percent bought a veil. In contrast, in 2013, only 31 percent of the brides surveyed said they bought one. â€œSometimes choosing to wear a veil has nothing to do with tradition,â€ Ms. Cooper said. â€œThe feeling is that itâ€™s just something beautiful. If youâ€™re going to wear it, itâ€™s now or never. â€ Mara Urshel, an owner of Kleinfeld Bridal in Brooklyn, said that the company is selling as many veils as it did four or five years ago, despite price increases: Some cost $6, 000 or $7, 000, or even as much as $10, 000, for the type of elaborately embellished variations some luxury houses now offer to match their gowns. (Veils more typically start at $300 and may go up to $2, 500.) Ms. Swerdloff, who skipped the veil at her own wedding this month, was somewhat startled to discover that, contrary to her expectations, most of brides who were photographed for New York Weddingsâ€™ spring 2016 issue did indeed wear a veil. So eager were some New Yorkers to make a style splash on their day of days, they insisted on wearing an ultralong veil, once relegated to the formal setting of a church or palatial estate, in the most informal surroundings. â€œIâ€™ve seen a lot of long veils on   brides wearing short dresses, and getting married in a community garden,â€ Ms. Swerdloff said. For some    an elaborate veil remains the single most effusive expression of a long cherished fantasy. â€œI always imagined I would wear a cathedral veil,â€ said Allison Appell Cohen, 27, an account manager for Blue Cross Blue Shield of Texas in Dallas. â€œEvery girl wants to be princess for a few hours,â€ Ms. Cohen said. â€œThe veil is a statement maker, itâ€™s so regal. Just to have it and the train of my dress trailing behind me: I knew thatâ€™s what I wanted. â€ Others, loath to sacrifice tradition, cling to the veilâ€™s symbolism. Karen Salva, 28, a location scout and makeup artist in the film industry, was married this month in Mystic, Conn. in a   Jewish ceremony, her face and hair concealed. â€œAs I got to the huppah,â€ she recalled, â€œmy mother lifted the veil up and presented my husband to me. â€ Benjamin Stern, her fiancÃ©, had covered her face with the blusher veil, a variation on a Jewish wedding custom known as the badeken. Ms. Salva was moved: â€œIt was symbolically a way of for him to say: â€˜Let me do this one last thing for you. Let me protect you and shelter you. â€™â€ Posting on the wedding blog â€œLove My Dress,â€ Jennifer Cranham commented that she initially hesitated to wear a veil. â€œBut now, itâ€™s one of the things Iâ€™m most excited about,â€ said Ms. Cranham, who will marry this year. Her mother was as well. Ms. Cranham wrote that when she tried on her veil in the fitting room, her mother gazed at her raptly. â€œThe dress didnâ€™t get tears,â€ Ms. Cranham said. â€œBut the veil did. â€

title: Yates: â€™There was nothing casual about thisâ€™
content: (CNN) Former acting Attorney General Sally Yates on Tuesday shot down the White Houseâ€™s efforts to downplay the severity of her warnings about former national security adviser Michael Flynn. â€There was nothing casual about this,â€ Yates said in an interview with CNNâ€™s Anderson Cooper, reacting to White House press secretary Sean Spicerâ€™s assertion that her warning about Flynnâ€™s interactions with Russian representatives was a â€heads up.â€  â€I absolutely did not use the term heads up,â€ Yates told Cooper. â€I called (White House counsel) Don McGahn and told him I had a very sensitive matter I need to discuss with him that day in person.â€  The exclusive interview, which aired in its entirety Tuesday evening, was Yatesâ€™ first on television since being fired by President Donald Trump. It was taped on Monday morning, prior to an explosive report by The New York Times that Trump had asked ousted FBI Director James Comey to end the investigation into Flynn.  Earlier this month, Yates testified in front of the Senate Judiciary Committeeâ€™s Subcommittee on Crime and Terrorism regarding the Trump campaignâ€™s alleged ties to Russia, particularly Flynnâ€™s contact with Russian Ambassador to the US Sergey Kislyak.  Prior to Trump taking office, Flynn had discussed sanctions with the official.  During her testimony she said that, at the end of January, after reading the details of a Flynn interview with the FBI, she had called McGahn and warned him that Trumpâ€™s national security adviser could easily become a blackmail target for Russians based on the answers Flynn gave to the FBI. Responding to a question from Cooper on whether she agreed with the White House line that Flynn was dismissed over a â€trust issueâ€ rather than a legal one, she said, â€I donâ€™t know how the White House reached the conclusion that there was no legal issue. It certainly wasnâ€™t from my discussion with them.â€  She demurs on whether she thought that his contact with Russian officials was a fireable offense.   â€Whether he is fired or not is a decision by the President of the United States to make, but it doesnâ€™t seem like thatâ€™s a person who should be sitting in the national security adviser position,â€ she said.  Five things we learned from the Sally Yates hearing, Urgency, Yates told Cooper that she expected the White House to act urgently on information that she had given the administration that Flynn had been compromised by his contact with Russian officials prior to Trumpâ€™s inauguration.  â€We expected the White House to act,â€ she said. When asked by Cooper if she expected the administration to act quickly, Yates replied, â€Yes.â€  â€There was an urgency to the information?â€ Cooper clarified. â€Yes,â€ Yates said. Flynn remained in his position for 18 days after Yates had informed the administration about her concerns over his conduct.  Preet Bharara, Sally Yates and James Comey: Fired while investigating Donald Trump, Let go, Yates, who was appointed by President Barack Obama, was fired as acting attorney general at the end of January when she refused to defend the Presidentâ€™s first attempt at a ban on travelers and refugees entering the US from a number of   countries.  She was dismissed for â€refusing to enforce a legal order designed to protect the citizens of the United States,â€ the White House said at the time. â€(Yates) has betrayed the Department of Justice,â€ the White House statement said. Yates also denies that she was behind the leaking of a story to The Washington Post about Flynnâ€™s calls with Kislyak, which led to his dismissal. â€Absolutely not. I did not and I would not leak classified information,â€ she told Cooper. She said that she was â€concernedâ€ that her information appeared not to be acted upon, but concedes that â€something elseâ€ might have been done â€that maybe I just wasnâ€™t aware of.â€ Asked what she thought of a tweet from Trump ahead of her appearance before the Senate committee, seemingly accusing her of leaking the story to the Post, she said that it was just one of â€a number of tweets that have given me pause.â€ Before she refused to defend the travel ban, Yates said she considered resigning. â€The bottom line is I felt like resigning would have protected my personal integrity, but not the integrity of the Department of Justice,â€ she said. Ultimately, she told Cooper, she has no regrets about her decisions during her tenure as acting attorney general. But Yates said she does not plan on getting into politics, despite rumors that she may run for Georgia governor.

title: Cruz Rips â€™Rankâ€™ Hypocrisy of â€™Idiotsâ€™ Protesting the Election of Trump - Breitbart
content: .@tedcruz: These idiots rioting in the streets are the same people who demanded   Trump accept the results of the election pic. twitter.  Thursday on Fox News Channelâ€™s â€œFox  Friends,â€ Sen. Ted Cruz ( ) slammed those protesting against the results of last weekâ€™s election of Donald Trump.  Cruz pointed out the hypocrisy of the protesters, noting they had an expectation of Trump accepting the results of the election, whereas they have seemingly failed to do so. â€œWe have seen hypocrisy on rank display from the left,â€ Cruz said. â€œAll of the folks who jumped on their high horse and were lecturing   Trump, â€˜Youâ€™ve got to accept the results of the election,â€™ look  â€”   these are now the idiots who are protesting in the street, laying their bodies down in front of cars and disrupting traffic. â€ â€œWe had an election,â€ he continued. â€œThe people spoke. Democracy is a powerful, powerful way of choosing. And you know, I think across this country  â€”   I think this is across the line of Republican, of Democrats, of independents, of Libertarians  â€”   I think Americans are excited about the opportunity to have an administration that protects our rights, that brings back jobs. â€ Follow Jeff Poor on Twitter @jeff_poor

title: House Republicans Urge Appropriators to Block Sanctuary City, Amnesty Funding in Spending Bills - Breitbart
content: House Republicans are pressing appropriators to defund sanctuary jurisdictions that protect illegal immigrants by refusing to cooperate with federal immigration authorities. [In a letter to the committee heads that oversee Department of Homeland Security and Justice Department funding, the 42 lawmakers, led by Rep. Paul Gosar ( ) urge that their upcoming spending bills include language blocking funding from sanctuary cities.  â€œThe concept of sanctuary city policies is in direct opposition to the Rule of Law,â€ the letter reads. â€œA nation of laws must enforce established law, not seek ways to skirt enforcement. Sanctuary cities defy federal immigration laws by harboring untold numbers of illegal immigrants and providing safe havens for criminals, many of whom are violent offenders. â€ In addition to pressing for appropriators to defund sanctuary cities, Gosar marshaled lawmakers to press appropriators to include additional immigration items in their spending bills.   members signed onto Gosarâ€™s letter seeking for appropriators to leverage certain DHS funding in order to pressure the administration into finishing the rest of the   border fence.   House member joined Gosar in a letter calling for the upcoming DHS spending bill to block funding for President Obamaâ€™s executive amnesty. â€œThe House of Representatives  â€”   indeed, the legislative branch  â€”   must take a stand against these overreaching actions. Our constituents sent us to Washington to put a stop to this nonsense. The Founding Fathers meant for this hallowed body to be tied most closely to the will of the American citizenry. We must assert out constitutional power of the purse against the president. In doing so, the will of the people will be done,â€ the 36 lawmakerâ€™s letter reads. Additionally, Gosar led 20 House members to block funding for the Central American Minors (CAM) program to fly Central American minors to the U. S. and 47 members joined Gosar to fully fund the State Criminal Alien Assistance Program (SCAAP).

title: Carbon monoxide suspected in hotel pool death
content: (CNN) A teenage boy died and 14 other people were hospitalized after guests at a southern Michigan hotel were found unconscious around an indoor pool. Fire officials said they believe the cause was carbon monoxide poisoning.   The 14 were taken to local hospitals Saturday, according to police in Niles, a town of about 11, 000 just north of the Indiana state line.   Jessica Hines, a spokeswoman for Lakeland Hospital there, told CNN one person was â€confirmed dead on arrival.â€ The Niles Police Department identified the deceased as    Bryan Douglas Watts of Niles. Eight other children were taken to Memorial Hospital in South Bend, Indiana, police said. Three were released by Saturday evening and the other five were reported in good condition Sunday at noon. They include five children found unconscious alongside Watts at the Quality Inn  Suites hotel pool. Their ages range from 12 to 14 years old, Niles police said. Another child, who police said had just left the pool area, was found unresponsive in a   room. Five first responders were also treated and released. Carbon monoxide levels were high, police say, Police responded to the hotel around 10 a. m. ET, according to CNN affiliate  . Police said that, when they arrived, carbon monoxide levels at the hotel were 800 parts per million, according to CNN affiliate  . US standards for carbon monoxide are 35 parts per million for a   exposure.   Niles Fire Department Captain Don Wise attributed the incident to a faulty pool heater. â€The ventilation system on the heater had issues. The exhaust was not functioning properly,â€ said Wise. â€Our mechanical inspector verified that. The hotel is shut down now until repairs are made.â€ He said the hotelâ€™s pool room had no carbon monoxide detectors â€to the best of our knowledge.â€ Carbon monoxide is an odorless, colorless and tasteless gas that is produced when a fuel is burned. When too much carbon monoxide is in the air, it can replace the oxygen in red blood cells and can lead to tissue damage or death. Choice Hotels, which owns the Quality brand, released a statement about the incident, saying it is â€working closely with local officials to manage the situation. . .. Our highest priority is always the safety and   of our guests.â€

title: Donald Trump Returns to Bashing â€™Fake Mediaâ€™
content: President Donald Trump returned to his attacks on the biased media, after a weekend away from Washington D. C.[â€œThe Fake Media (not Real Media) has gotten even worse since the election,â€ he wrote on Twitter. â€œEvery story is badly slanted. We have to hold them to the truth!â€  Last week, some in the media were surprised after Trump referred to them as â€œvery honorable peopleâ€ during an event at the White House. Trump appeared to be watching Fox and Friends on Monday morning, praising the show for some of their analysis. â€œâ€™The first 90 days of my presidency has exposed the total failure of the last eight years of foreign policy! â€™â€ he wrote. â€œSo true. â€

title: Trump Army secretary pick gave a lecture arguing against the theory of evolution
content: (CNN) President Donald Trumpâ€™s pick to be secretary of the Army, former army doctor Mark Green, is a   â€creationistâ€ who delivered a lecture arguing against the theory of evolution.  Greenâ€™s views and past statements are facing scrutiny ahead of his confirmation hearing, which has yet to be scheduled. If confirmed, Green wouldnâ€™t be the only prominent doctor and member of the Trump administration to reject evolution. HUD Secretary Ben Carson has also made similar arguments and once said the theory of evolution was encouraged by Satan. Green, a Tennessee state senator, has faced opposition from Democrats and LGBT groups over his past   comments. In one comment, from September, Green said, â€If you poll the psychiatrists, theyâ€™re going to tell you that transgender is a disease.â€ The National Academy of Sciences says that the theory of evolution â€is supported by so many observations and confirming experiments that scientists are confident that the basic components of the theory will not be overturned by new evidence.â€ The group adds, â€Because the evidence supporting it is so strong, scientists no longer question whether biological evolution has occurred and is continuing to occur. Instead, they investigate the mechanisms of evolution, how rapidly evolution can take place, and related questions.â€ Green rejects the conclusions of scientists in his lecture. In his 2015 speech to a church to Cincinnati titled â€™Isnâ€™t Evolution A Solution? Green dedicated nearly an hour to explaining why his work as a medical doctor taught him to reject the theory. Green claims that the theory of evolution violates physical law, using the example of a lawn mower left out in a backyard. â€The evolutionists have their bad argument, too,â€ Green said. They say, â€™Well, I canâ€™t explain how it went from this to incredibly complex, so it must have been billions of years.â€™ Thatâ€™s kind of where they put their faith. The truth of the matter is is the second law of thermo fluid dynamics says that the world progresses from order to disorder not disorder to order. â€If you put a lawn mower out in your yard and a hundred years come back, itâ€™s rusted and falling apart. You canâ€™t put parts out there and a hundred years later itâ€™s gonna come back together. That is a violation of a law of thermodynamics. A physical law that exists in the universe.â€ Green also argues that processes allowing human life, such as   are â€™irreducibly complexâ€™ and says that is evidence of a creator. â€Irreducible complexity is important in the argument for the creationist because of this: Evolution assumes a series of minuscule changes over time, and each change has to give a survival advantage to the organism. If it doesnâ€™t, and it causes a disadvantage the organism dies and evolution ends,â€ Green said.  Later in the speech, Green adds, â€The question is, did all of this happen by chance operating inside the laws of chemistry and physics? Or is this unbelievable engineering, and is the scientific mind going to look at it and make the conclusion, observation, and conclusion that it was created and not that it evolved. Again, remember time is not the hero of the plot. Time is the villain, because over time things break down, they donâ€™t assemble themselves together.â€ Green did not respond to a request for comment. A White House spokesperson told CNNâ€™s KFile that a spokesperson handling Greenâ€™s nomination would contact them, but Greenâ€™s spokesperson did not. In a statement announcing his nomination in early April, Secretary of Defense Jim Mattis put his full support behind Green. â€He had my full support during the selection process, and he will have my full support during the Senate confirmation process. I am confident of Markâ€™s ability to effectively lead the Army,â€ Mattis said.

title: OBAMA: Leaked Trump tape shows that heâ€™s â€™insecureâ€™
content: â€™  â€™ â€™   President Barack Obama on Sunday called the shocking leaked 2005   recording of Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump    â€by the    â€ a sign of the Manhattan   billionaireâ€™â€™s insecurity. â€™ â€™   The recording of Trump, which was picked up by a hot mic and    on Friday, came from an   interaction between Trump and television personality Billy Bush.   In addition to his comments about grabbing women â€by the   â€   Trump made a litany of other sexually suggestive remarks. The   Post reported it came after Trump married his third wife,   Melania. â€™ â€™   â€One of the most disturbing things about this election is just   the unbelievable rhetoric coming at the top of the Republican   ticket,â€ Obama said at a fundraiser in Chicago. â€I donâ€™â€™t need to   repeat it.
