title: Mexican Stateâ€™s New Court System Appears Broke and Not Ready for Implementation
content: PIEDRAS NEGRAS, Coahuila  â€”   Less than three months before this border state needs to fully implement a new judicial system, court officials claim that the courthouses are not only inadequate, but the funds for basic office needs have run dry. [Breitbart Texas traveled to the Mexican States of Tamaulipas and Coahuila to recruit citizen journalists willing to risk their lives and expose the cartels silencing their communities.  The writers would face certain death at the hands of the various cartels that operate in those areas including the Gulf Cartel and Los Zetas if a pseudonym were not used. Breitbart Texasâ€™ Cartel Chronicles are published in both English and in their original Spanish. This article was written by Coahuilaâ€™s â€œJM Martinezâ€ and Breitbart Texasâ€™ Ildefonso Ortiz.   It remains unclear what happened to the judicial funding. The U. S. government provided $68 million in aid to Mexico in 2014 in an effort to get the new judicial system up an running.  This border state is one of the states that, according to court officials who spoke out to Breitbart Texas, continues to lag behind with employes having to purchase office supplies out of their own pocket. Breitbart Texas visited the border city of Piedras Negras where the state does have one courthouse with two small courtrooms for the trials. However, high ranking officials with the Coahuila Attorney Generalâ€™s Office who spoke with this reporter stated that they have not been provided with the bare essentials to keep the courthouse running.  One clerk that spoke out under the condition of anonymity stated that his office doesnâ€™t even have paper and he had to provide his own materials.  When it comes to the logistics, Coahuila was originally scheduled to have one courthouse in each of itâ€™s six judicial regions. Breitbart Texas was able to only locate three courthouses, one in Saltillo, one in Piedras Negras, one in Monclova. A command level state police officer that spoke with this outlet confirmed that the lack of courthouses has resulted in police officers having to transport prisoners from throughout the state to the three courthouses in the state.  According to various police sources in Coahuila, prisoners from Ciudad Acuna and Sabinas are transported in police convoys to the courthouses in Piedras Negras and Monclova respectively due to the lack of courtrooms in their particular jurisdiction.  In 2014, the U. S Agency for International Development known as USAID provided Mexico with $68 million in aid for the implementation of a series of reforms that would turn that countryâ€™s judicial system from one that had written trials to one with public oral trials. The move is part of the ongoing Merida Initiative or Plan Merida which provides aid to Mexico in an effort to stem the growth of organized crime in that country. The funds that were received by Mexico were then to be disbursed to the 31 states in that country in an effort to help the transition.  The judicial reform in Mexico has been widely promoted by that countryâ€™s federal government since it is set to add some transparency to a judicial process that is largely perceived to be full of corruption.  According to the information published by Mexicoâ€™s Secretariat of the Interior,  the new judicial system is set to be fully operational on June 18, 2016. However, the process has been plagued with delays. Mexicoâ€™s El Universal reported in early 2015, that at the time, only six states in the country had achieved a 60 percent implementation rate. Last October, Coahuilaâ€™s El Zocalo Newspaper interviewed a local congressman who warned that Coahuila continues to lag behind in the implementation of the judicial system.  â€œOur judicial system has been in crisis for years, we donâ€™t need more improvements, the learning curve is intolerable,â€ Congressman Leonel Contreras was quoted by Zocalo. â€œThe delivery of justice is not a game, we can not take the luxury of taking the liberty of innocents and letting criminals go free. â€

title: Ayotte says Trump â€™absolutelyâ€™ a role model for kids in NH debate, later says she misspoke
content: Washington (CNN) New Hampshire GOP Sen. Kelly Ayotte said during a debate on Monday that she would â€absolutelyâ€ point to Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump as a role model for a child. She issued a statement after the debate saying she â€misspoke.â€ The   senator was asked by a moderator during the NECN debate: â€Would you tell them to be like Donald Trump? Would you point to him as a role model?â€  â€I think that certainly there are many role models that we have, and I believe he can serve as president and so, absolutely. I would do that,â€ she said at the New England College hosted debate in Henniker, New Hampshire. In a statement afterward, Ayotte said: â€I misspoke tonight. While I would hope all of our children would aspire to be president, neither Donald Trump nor Hillary Clinton have set a good example and I wouldnâ€™t hold either of them as role models for my kids.â€ Ayotte is currently locked in a hotly contested Senate reelection race against Democratic rival, Gov. Maggie Hassan. Ayotte has said she is voting for Trump, but not endorsed him for president. Ayotte has said that she will she will â€stand upâ€ to Trump if he becomes president    but she will vote for him in November.  â€I will take on my own party,â€ Ayotte told CNN in Nashua in August. â€I really believe that this is a big issue in this race    that I am the one candidate that will stand up to whomever is in the White House to do good things when we can work together    also when itâ€™s wrong to stand up to them.â€ During Mondayâ€™s debate, someone   asked Ayotte: â€If you think he can serve as president, why wonâ€™t you endorse him?â€  â€Because Iâ€™ve had some disagreements with him,â€ she said. â€And Iâ€™ve been quite clear about those disagreements. And this is an area where Gov. Hassan has been lockstep with Secretary Clinton. I havenâ€™t heard major disagreements that sheâ€™s had with Secretary Clinton so whoâ€™s going to step up for the people of New Hampshire?â€  Since Trump launched his campaign last summer, he called some Mexicans â€rapistsâ€ during his announcement speech, said Sen. John McCain isnâ€™t a â€war heroâ€ because he was captured, proposed a temporary Muslim ban, mocked a disabled reporter during a campaign rally, repeatedly made harsh comments about women, and attacked the Khans, a Gold Star family, for their comments at the Democratic National Convention. And at a rally in Pennsylvania this weekend, Trump hit Clinton on her â€stamina,â€ said that Clinton is not â€loyalâ€ to her husband, former President Bill Clinton, and called her an â€incompetentâ€ and â€sarcastic woman.â€  In the past, Ayotte has been heavily critical on Trumpâ€™s controversies, including his attacks against the Khan family.  When Trump was asked about Ayotte in an August Washington Post interview, he criticized her lack of support and implied she was weak. â€You have a Kelly Ayotte, who doesnâ€™t want to talk about Trump, but Iâ€™m beating her in the polls by a lot. You tell me. Are these people that should be representing us?â€ he said. â€We need loyal people in this country. We need fighters in this country. We donâ€™t need weak people. We have enough of them.â€

title: Junior Seau daughter to speak at Hall of Fame
content: (CNN) After a week of controversy, the daughter of the late NFL star Junior Seau will speak on stage during her fatherâ€™s induction at the Pro Football Hall of Fame, the hallâ€™s president said in a written statement. Sydney Seau had been told she would only be a part of a video tribute to her father and would unveil his bronze bust, but wouldnâ€™t speak to the audience live. The decision was based on   old policy, officials from the Hall of Fame said. But Saturday, Fox Sports first reported Sydney Seau would be interviewed about her father during the ceremony next Saturday.  â€Our goal is to maintain our policy regarding enshrinement speeches, but also show compassion and understanding,â€ Pro Football Hall of Fame President David Baker said in a statement. When Sydney Seau unveils her fatherâ€™s bust she will be joined by her two brothers and her half brother. The Hall of Fame said Sydney Seauâ€™s presentation speech will be included in the video, which will be two times longer than the tributes for the other inductees. Seau was 43 when he killed himself in May 2012 and was posthumously diagnosed with chronic traumatic encephalopathy, a brain disease that can result from repeated head trauma. His case was among those that increased scrutiny of NFL policies regarding concussions and player safety. The circumstances surrounding Seauâ€™s death are not expected to be mentioned in the presentation. Seauâ€™s family filed a wrongful death lawsuit against the league in 2013. Junior Seau wanted Sydney, 21, to present him if he were ever chosen for the Hall of Fame, and a news release from the organization earlier this month implied that Sydney would indeed be the presenter.   Sydney Seau expressed frustration to The New York Times at not being able to speak at the event:  â€I just want to give the speech he would have given.  It wasnâ€™t going to be about this mess.  My speech was solely about him.â€ After the Times article, football writers and fans criticized the policy that would keep her from giving a live speech.    A Hall of Fame spokesman told CNN last week that the original decision to not have the family speak was made â€strictly on the policyâ€ and â€has nothing to do with any other circumstances.â€ The Hall of Fame had said it was following a policy initiated in 2010.  According to a statement released last week, the ceremony features â€expanded presenting video (longer than the videos of living inductees) followed by the traditional unveiling of the bronzed bust and no additional comments made from the podium.â€ Honorees who are alive give a speech after their tribute videos.   In April, a federal judge approved a settlement to a lawsuit by more than 5, 000 former NFL players who accused the league of hiding the dangers of concussions.  For players who retired by July 7, 2014, the settlement provides up to $5 million for serious health effects associated with head trauma. Seauâ€™s family had opted out of this lawsuit, choosing to pursue a settlement independently. A player who was once nicknamed the â€Tasmanian Devilâ€ for the intensity of his playing style, Seau was known for his willingness to keep playing despite pain and injuries.  His friend and former NFL player Donald McPherson said players such as Seau operated under the mentality, â€Ignore pain, leave it on the field and never back down.â€   His Hall of Fame induction honors a career spanning 20 seasons for the Chargers, Dolphins and Patriots. He was an   first team  . Junior Seau is the second player to be inducted posthumously. Former Los Angeles Rams     Les Richter was honored in 2011. His son, Jon, appeared in the tribute video but didnâ€™t speak at the ceremony.

title: Michelle Obama Denounces Donald Trump in CUNY Commencement Speech - The New York Times
content: In tones both aspirational and political, Michelle Obama on Friday used her last commencement address as first lady to salute graduates of the City College of New York as â€œliving, breathing proof that the American dream endures,â€ while also criticizing â€œ â€ leaders who engage in â€œanger and intolerance. â€ Mrs. Obama did not specifically mention Donald J. Trump, the presumptive Republican nominee for president. But her intent could not have been clearer as she warned that â€œleaders who rule by intimidation  â€”   leaders who demonize and dehumanize entire groups of people  â€”   often do so because they have nothing else to offer. â€ â€œHere in America, we donâ€™t give in to our fears,â€ she told the class of 2016, with its 3, 848 graduates, in an outdoor ceremony on the collegeâ€™s Manhattan campus. â€œWe donâ€™t build up walls to keep people out because we know that our greatness has always depended on contributions from people who were born elsewhere but sought out this country and made it their home. â€ For Mrs. Obama, the address, the last of her three commencement speeches this year, was intended to highlight several issues that have been dear to her, including public education and immigration. Noting the collegeâ€™s proximity to the Statue of Liberty, she said there was â€œno better way to celebrate this great country than being here with you. â€ Mrs. Obamaâ€™s commencement address at City College, the flagship school in the City University of New York system, was the latest high point in its long, distinguished history. In 1847, it was founded as the Free Academy of New York, with a mission to provide an education to anyone, at low cost. But her visit also came at a precarious time for the CUNY system, which has been troubled by overcrowded classes, shrinking course options and budget cuts, as described in a recent investigation by The New York Times. Faculty members and employees represented by the universityâ€™s biggest union, who have worked without a raise for six years, recently voted to authorize a strike in the fall if no contract deal was reached. Indeed, dozens of faculty and students on Friday morning handed out fliers to people filing past security to enter the campus, in Upper Manhattan, urging public officials to invest more money in the system. None of the speakers at the commencement directly addressed CUNYâ€™s woes. But in her   address, which elicited frequent and enthusiastic applause, Mrs. Obama said that â€œpublic education is our greatest pathway to opportunity in America. So we need to invest in and strengthen our public universities today, and for generations to come. â€ At several points, she mentioned notable immigrants, or the children of immigrants, who had attended City College, including Jonas Salk, Ira Gershwin, Colin L. Powell and Andrew S. Grove, the former Intel chief executive, who died in March. But she also applauded the valedictorian and salutatorian of the graduating class, who delivered rousing addresses on the importance of diversity and the   battle to break cultural barriers. Mrs. Obama added some personal perspective, as well: â€œItâ€™s the story that I witness every single day when I wake up in a house that was built by slaves, and I watch my daughters  â€”   two beautiful, black young women  â€”   head off to school, waving goodbye to their father, the president of the United States, the son of a man from Kenya who came here to America for the same reasons as many of you: to get an education and improve his prospects in life. â€

title: Judge Jeanine to Obama: Stop Focusing on Gun Control, Shoot Terrorists Instead - Breitbart
content: During the Saturday broadcast of â€œJusticeâ€ on Fox News Channel, host Judge Jeanine Pirro urged President Barack Obama to take his focus away from removing guns and instead, using guns to take down terrorists.  Pirro said Obama is â€œ  in the leftist political ideologyâ€ when it comes to gun control, while he should be focused on protecting Americans and letting them defend themselves. â€œMr. President, the issue is terrorism, not mass shootings. And yet, because of a political agenda, you refuse to the biggest danger that we face. Instead of blaming guns, why donâ€™t you start shooting terrorists? Now, maybe you donâ€™t have time to focus on this because youâ€™re too busy emptying Guantanamo and trading deserters for Taliban generals. And as a result of your   in the leftist political ideology, you should be focused on protecting us and letting us defend ourselves. The police cannot do it all. â€ Follow Trent Baker on Twitter @MagnifiTrent

title: Donald Trump: Time For Law Enforcement To Start Profiling Radical Muslims - Breitbart
content: Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump wants American law enforcement to start profiling radical Muslims and stop being politically correct about the terrorist threat Americans face. [â€œYouâ€™ll never solve the problem if youâ€™re afraid to use the real name. This is radical Islamic terrorism,â€ he said, after a bomb went off in New York City and injured 29 people. Over the weekend, law enforcement officials discovered and diffused several bombs placed around the city.  Trump praised law enforcement for doing an excellent job combating terrorism in Americaâ€™s cities, but suggested that political correctness was getting in the way. He cited the security measures by Israel as an example. â€œIn Israel they profile, theyâ€™ve done an unbelievable job, as good as you can do,â€ Trump said. â€œThey profile. They see somebody that is suspicious, they will profile, they will take that person in, theyâ€™ll check out. Do we have choice? Look whatâ€™s going on? Do we really have a choice?   â€¦     This is only going to get worse. â€ Law enforcement are currently seeking the whereabouts of    Ahmad Khan Rahami, an American citizen of Afghan decent for questioning about the attacks.  Trump ridiculed President Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton on Monday, criticizing them for being weak on terror and failing to address the source of terrorism because of political correctness. â€œOur leaders are  â€”   I donâ€™t even say â€˜weak,â€™  â€”   I say â€˜stupid,â€™â€ he said in an interview on Fox and Friends. Trump warned that these kinds of attacks would continue, as long as Obama and the Democrats continued to welcome additional refugees from Syria into the United States and fail to destroy ISIS overseas. â€œWeâ€™ve been weak, our country has been weak,â€ Trump said, calling Syrian refugees â€œcancer from within. â€ Trump said that ISIS was started by Hillary Clinton and Obama after they exited Iraq, leaving terrorist elements the freedom to rebuild. â€œThese are sick evil people that want to destroy this country, the way we coddle them, and the way weâ€™re afraid to say anything, and weâ€™re afraid to say what the problem is and who they are and they donâ€™t want to say radical Islam they donâ€™t want to talk about radical Islamic terrorism,â€ Trump said.

title: Kris Kobach Enters Kansas Governor Race to End â€˜Insaneâ€™ Policies like Charging American Students Three Times as Much as Illegals
content: Kansas Secretary of State Kris Kobach discussed his gubernatorial campaign with SiriusXM host Matt Boyle on Fridayâ€™s Breitbart News Daily. [Kobach said taxation would be a core issue in his campaign.  LISTEN: â€œSome people may know Kansas. We did cut our income taxes quite a bit and reduced to zero the taxes on LLCs and S corporations a few years ago,â€ he said. â€œBut a coalition of Democrats and liberal Republicans in the legislature just raised those taxes back up, doing so on the theory that they had to, to balance the budget. â€ â€œI think that Kansas doesnâ€™t have a revenue problem. It has a spending problem. We should have been cutting the budget,â€ he contended. On immigration, Kobach said Kansas is â€œa fairly conservative state, but our legislature hasnâ€™t been conservative, and weâ€™ve kind of become the sanctuary state of the Midwest. â€ â€œWeâ€™re not formally a sanctuary state, but we do nothing to discourage illegal immigration,â€ he elaborated. â€œWe give aliens   tuition. I want to stop that. â€ Kobach noted Kansas is â€œone of the very few states west of the Mississippi that does not have term limits,â€ which he saw as vital to fighting corruption. â€œAs a result, our legislators, some of them form entire careers in the state legislature. Iâ€™d like to see us have term limits for the legislature, as well as for the entire list of statewide offices,â€ he said. Kobach wryly conceded, â€œThe left is not excited that Iâ€™m runningâ€ when Boyle noted the panoply of   groups denouncing his candidacy for governor. Boyle noted the left was fearful that Kobach really would put a stop to â€œunbelievableâ€ policies like giving discounted   tuition rates to illegal immigrants. â€œItâ€™s insane,â€ Kobach agreed. â€œI mean, think about it: Youâ€™ve got someone who lives in a neighboring state, say Missouri. A kid grows up there, wants to go to Kansas University or Kansas State, pays three times as much in tuition as an illegal alien. It makes no sense whatsoever. Itâ€™s against federal law. Congress was trying to stop this way back in the nineties they passed a law saying no state could do it, but several states did anyway. â€ â€œWeâ€™re going to try to stop that. I think you just need a governor who will come in and say, â€˜Look, Iâ€™m not budging. Weâ€™re going to do it, and weâ€™re going to do it now, or weâ€™re going to do it later, but weâ€™re going to do it while Iâ€™m governor,â€™â€ he said, promising to â€œdraw some lines in the sand and not let anyone cross them. â€ Kobach laid out three major points in his   agenda. â€œOne I already mentioned was term limits. Try to push term limits through. Now, thatâ€™s going to be a heavy lift since we donâ€™t have the popular initiative. Weâ€™re going to have to push it through the legislature, and you know most politicians donâ€™t like limiting their own terms in legislatures,â€ he said. â€œSecond is pass a statute stopping the revolving door,â€ he continued. â€œRight now in Kansas, you can retire from the legislature, and then the next day, you can start lobbying your former colleagues. Weâ€™ll put time limits on how soon you can become a lobbyist in Kansas. You can become a lobbyist somewhere else if you want, but not in Kansas. â€ Kobach said his third goal would be to achieve political transparency by replacing â€œRepublicans in Name Onlyâ€ who tend to side with Democrats. â€œWe really have this problem very badly in Kansas,â€ he explained. â€œIf you look at the numbers, our legislature in the Senate is 32 to 8  â€”   32 Republicans to 8 Democrats. Similar lopsided numbers in the House, over a   majority Republican. But many of those Republicans are truly RINOs  â€”   Republicans in Name Only. They vote with the Democrats all the time. When they go home, they talk like Republicans. They might even use the word â€˜conservativeâ€™ to describe themselves. But then, they come in and become a completely different person when they are in the state legislature. â€ â€œOne of the things the governor has to do is actually call people out by name and say, â€˜Look, I need this personâ€™s voteâ€™ and try to get the public aware of who these people are who are breaching the public trust,â€ said Kobach.  â€œIf their district wants to elect someone who is liberal and votes with the Democrats, so be it. But there is a real deception going on. You see it in states like Kansas, where there are districts across the western part of our state which will not elect a Democrat, period. So what the Democrats do is, they just run as Republicans,â€ he said. Kobach agreed with Boyle that voters are tired of politicians who say one thing and do another. â€œI think theyâ€™re also tired of the politician who talks like everything he says is carefully polished and has gone through three focus groups,â€ Kobach added. â€œThe thing that people loved about Trump is that heâ€™s speaking from the gut. They could tell that this is what the guy really thinks. His speech wasnâ€™t prepared and screened and reviewed by others, a bunch of     baloney, but is actually a guy telling us what he thinks. I think thatâ€™s important. â€ â€œNobody can do it like President Trump does it, but thatâ€™s kind of the way I have spoken to my constituents as secretary of state: â€˜Here, this is what Iâ€™m going to do. Iâ€™m not going to beat around the bush. If you donâ€™t like it, donâ€™t vote for me,â€™â€ he said. Breitbart News Daily airs on SiriusXM Patriot 125 weekdays from 6:00 a. m. to 9:00 a. m. Eastern. Listen to the full audio of the interview above.

title: Obama Ignores Three Attempts for Comment on Trumpâ€™s Appointment of Steve Bannon - Breitbart
content: President Barack Obama has dismissed three separate attempts by the media to get the president to criticize   Donald Trumpâ€™s decision to appoint Stephen K. Bannon to a top White House post. [One reporter questioned Obama about Bannonâ€™s appointment during the presidentâ€™s press conference on Monday in the White House briefing room, before his trip to Greece.  The reporter asked: What do you say to those Americans who may not doubt that there will be a peaceful transition but that are concerned about some of the policies and sentiments that were expressed by   Trump himself or his supporters that may seem hostile to minorities and others? Specifically, Iâ€™m talking about the announcement that Steve Bannon, who is a proponent of the     movement, what many call the white nationalist movement, is going to have a prominent role in the White House under President Trump as his chief strategist and senior advisor. What message does that send to the country, to the world? But Obama refused to engage with the ongoing criticism of Bannon, citing his responsibility to promote a smooth transition of power. â€œI think itâ€™s fair to say that it would not be appropriate for me to comment on every appointment that the   starts making if I want to be consistent with the notion that weâ€™re going to try to facilitate a smooth transition,â€ Obama replied. In Greece, Obama was asked during a press conference with Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, specifically about â€œthe fact that Stephen Bannon was made as chief strategistâ€ questioning whether the   could be a reliable partner with Europe as a result. Obama replied he was â€œcautiously optimisticâ€ that Trump could shift from campaign mode to governing mode. â€œ[T]hereâ€™s something about the solemn responsibilities of that office, the extraordinary demands that are placed on the United States, not just by its own people but by people around the world, that forces you to focus, that demands seriousness,â€ he said. Obama was again offered the chance to criticize Trumpâ€™s staff picks again during a press conference in Germany. â€œIâ€™m wondering, as well, if youâ€™ve advised your successor to be extra mindful of what you see as some very worrisome trends, particularly when it comes to making his own potentially powerful staff picks,â€ one reporter asked Obama during his press conference on Thursday with German Chancellor Angela Merkel. Obama replied that Trump ran an â€œextraordinarily unconventional campaign,â€ that resulted in â€œthe biggest political upset in perhaps modern political history. â€ He admitted that Trump needed to unify the country with his decisions as president, but did not refer specifically to his staff choices. Obama is unique among Democrats in not outrightly condemning Bannonâ€™s appointment, falsely accusing Trump of putting a white supremacist and a white nationalist into the White House. House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi and Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid both blasted Bannon, demanding that Trump rescind his decision for Bannon to serve as his adviser. â€œIf Trump is serious about seeking unity, the first thing he should do is rescind his appointment of Steve Bannon,â€ Reid said in a speech on the Senate floor. â€œRescind it. Donâ€™t do it. Think about this. Donâ€™t do it. â€ Pelosi denounced the decision in a statement to reporters on Monday. â€œBringing Steve Bannon into the White House is an alarming signal that   Trump remains committed to the hateful and divisive vision that defined his campaign,â€ she said. Pelosi also asked Vice   Mike Pence for Donald Trump to reconsider his decision to appoint Bannon to his staff, during a private meeting at the Capitol.

title: Bloomberg News Poll: Trump 43 Clinton 41 - Breitbart
content: The latest Bloomberg News national poll shows that Donald Trump two points ahead of Hillary Clinton. [Trump earns 43 percent support to Clintonâ€™s 41 percent. Libertarian candidate Gary Johnson earns 8 percent while Green Party candidate Jill Stein got 4 percent.  The poll shows that both Clinton and Trump have the same favorability ratings 42 percent rate them favorably while 56 percent rate them unfavorability ratings. Trump leads Clinton on voterâ€™s impressions of his health. Sixty one percent say that Trump has excellent or good while only 36 percent said the same about Clinton. Only 8 percent suggested that Trumpâ€™s health was poor, while 31 percent said that about Clinton. But voters expect Clinton to do much better in Mondayâ€™s presidential debate than Trump.   percent of voters expect Clinton to win, while 39 percent expect Trump to win. The poll surveyed 1, 002 likely voters  during September   with margin of error of plus or minus 3. 1 points.

title: BuzzFeed â€™Updatesâ€™ Poll Showing 97% Support for Trump, Claims Respondents Arenâ€™t â€™Real Peopleâ€™ - Breitbart
content: After commissioning a poll which showed 97% support for Republican candidate Donald Trump in the upcoming presidential election, BuzzFeed added an â€œupdateâ€ to its findings to remind readers that the poll â€œdoes not reflect real people. â€[The poll asked readers who they would be voting for in the election. Out of the 13 million people who responded, the results showed 97% for Trump, 1% for Hillary Clinton, 1% for other candidates, and 1% for people who hadnâ€™t decided.  After seeing the results of the poll, BuzzFeed added an â€œupdateâ€ to the poll, admonishing readers, â€œThis poll no longer accurately reflects the opinions of real people. Please remember to vote in the upcoming election. â€ BuzzFeed is a vocal critic of Donald Trump and in June ended its advertising contract with the Republican party after Trumpâ€™s nomination, citing Trumpâ€™s proposed ban on Muslim immigration. CEO Jonah Peretti said the ban would â€œmake it impossible for our employees to do their jobs. â€ You can follow Ben Kew on Facebook, on Twitter at @ben_kew, or email him at ben@yiannopoulos. net

In a Monday debate, Fox Sports 1 â€œUndisputedâ€   Skip Bayless praised free agent quarterback Colin Kaepernick for his 2016 national anthem protest, calling it â€œpowerfulâ€ with a â€œpositiveâ€ national and international impact.  â€œHas there ever been a more powerful spokesman than Colin Kaepernick became early this football season?â€ Bayless asked. â€œHe had positive national, if not international, impact for the literal stance that he took. â€ Follow Trent Baker on Twitter @MagnifiTrent

title: Ann Coulter: Under En-Dowd
content: To celebrate Donald Trumpâ€™s inauguration this week, Iâ€™m returning to my new favorite parlor game: quoting Republican consultants on the 2016 campaign. [It never gets old! Also, this exercise reminds us of the many things we are thankful for this week: Donald Trump, the cluelessness of his opponents, and Nexis transcripts.  Our featured GOP consultant this week is Matthew Dowd, chief strategist for the   campaign and   Mr. Magoo. Nominally a conservative in a liberal business, Dowd couldnâ€™t pull off a full Arianna, so if he wanted to sit in a warm studio on Sunday mornings issuing pronouncements as if from Mount Olympus, he had to come up with an act. Even a guy like Dowd  â€”   wrong on everything else, from the time of day to whether itâ€™s raining  â€”   accurately sussed out what the media wanted: a   playing â€œthe conservative. â€ How else to explain the fact that the entire American media refused to have on anyone who supported the man who just won a landslide presidential election? The territory Dowd carved out for himself was: patriotic sage, above partisanship, announcing on every subject that both sides were wrong, he alone was right. This made him a regular panelist on ABCâ€™s â€œThis Weekâ€ with George Stephanopoulos. Dowdâ€™s â€œboth sides are wrongâ€ offering to the   church was condescending and tiresome, but it would help if he were, from time to time, correct. Instead, from the moment Trump announced, Dowd treated us to hilariously boneheaded prognostications that were instantly proved wrong and never acknowledged as he issued each successive boneheaded prediction. On Feb. 7, 2016, Dowd pronounced that the nominations would be wrapped up in â€œApril for the Democrats and May for the Republicans. â€ Trump won the nomination by May 4 and Hillary won it in June  â€”   two months after Dowdâ€™s confident prediction. On April 3, Dowd said Trump â€œcanâ€™t win a general election for all intents and purposes. â€ (â€œFor all intents and purposesâ€ is what consultants add to   statements to make them sound weighty.) Trump won the election  â€”   and he won it with far more electoral votes than Dowdâ€™s candidate ever got. On May 1, Dowd said, â€œItâ€™s going to be a    election, unfortunately. â€ Trump won both white men and white women, decisively. White women without a college degree carried the Midwest for Trump. (See here.) Dowd spent several Sundays in May assuring viewers that a   candidate would be on stage at the debates: â€œI think there is likely to be somebody else standing in the debates and that changes the dynamics. â€ That never happened. After Trump wrapped up the nomination, Dowd claimed he had predicted it! â€œWell, I was very bullish on Donald Trump in the primaries,â€ he said on May 8. His use of the term â€œbullishâ€ was, well,  . As for Trump winning the general election, Dowd declared it â€œunlikely. â€ (Based on his fantastical recollections of his own predictions, I assume he is currently claiming to have predicted Trumpâ€™s win in the general election.) In the week leading up to the election, Dowd was a whirling dervish of soothsaying on Twitter: NOVEMBER 1, â€œ@matthewjdowd Any expenditure of time or money by Trump in PA, VA, MI and NH is a total waste. Campaign mismanagement if they keep it up. â€ Of the four states Dowd considered â€œa total wasteâ€ for Trump to campaign in, he won the two biggest, worth more than twice as many electoral votes as the other two combined  â€”   and one of those he lost by only 0. 3 percent. NOVEMBER 2, â€œ@matthewjdowd clinton has a better chance of carrying Arizona than trump does of carrying Mi or Wiâ€ Trump carried both Michigan and Wisconsin. Hillary did not win Arizona. NOVEMBER 4, â€œ@matthewjdowd Look for sure signs Trump will lose: 1. â€˜The only poll that matters is election dayâ€™ 2. â€˜Our vote doesnâ€™t show up in polls.â€™ 3. â€˜Trumanâ€™â€ Although Trump never made any excuses  â€”   he won!  â€”   all three of those statements turned out to be true. (See Time magazineâ€™s â€œMadam Presidentâ€ issue.) NOVEMBER 5 was Dowdâ€™s Latino Appreciation Day: â€œ@matthewjdowd even if Trump gets the exact % of votes of whites, blacks  Asians as Bush in 2004, Trump would lose by 3 million votes due to Latinos. â€ â€œ@matthewjdowd Trump will lose latino voters by a larger margin than romney. Who set a new modern low. â€ â€œ@matthewjdowd It looks like Trump campaign was right, the silent hidden vote is showing up: Latinos are voting at record levels. Motivated by Trump. â€ Trump won more of the Hispanic vote than either McCain or Romney  â€”   and probably more than Bush, for whom we only have nonsense numbers (as both Republican and Democratic analysts agree  â€”   see here and here). NOVEMBER 6, â€œ@matthewjdowd If trump loses Ohio and Florida one reason is that Clinton campaign head faked them into thinking he had chance in Michigan.  media helpedâ€ Trump won Michigan. Also Ohio and Florida. On Nov. 6  â€”   48 hours before the election  â€”   Dowd announced on ABCâ€™s â€œThis Weekâ€ that Trump would lose, â€œand lose badly. â€ Bored with his own omniscience, Dowd explained, â€œGeorge, to me, this election has been   â€¦     incredibly predictable actually from the primary. â€ Mr. Magoo had more wisdom to impart: â€œOn election night, Hillary Clintonâ€™s margins among nonwhite voters and among   voters are going to be the highest margins weâ€™ve ever seen. â€ Dowdâ€™s sweeping declarations turned out to be less accurate than a blindfolded monkey throwing darts in a bar. On Twitter, Dowd assured his readers: NOVEMBER 7, â€œ@matthewjdowd Clinton wins by five points. Over 300 electoral votes. Trump loses by more popular votes than Romney. â€ Final electoral vote: Trump, 304 Clinton, 227. TV bookers couldnâ€™t get enough of Dowd. What smugness! What monumental cluelessness! ABCâ€™s â€œThis Weekâ€ is a show famous for confronting guests with their own prior statements. Would ABC play this game with its own Powerhouse Roundtable prognosticators? Surely a man of Dowdâ€™s integrity would come on the air and admit, â€œI couldnâ€™t have been more wrong!â€ HELLO! That didnâ€™t happen at all! Dowd was allowed to sit out the Sunday after the election. The following Sunday, he was in his usual seat on the Powerhouse Roundtable, right back to giving his sweeping, grinning predictions, with no acknowledgment that he had been spectacularly  â€”   and characteristically  â€”   wrong in every prediction heâ€™d made, all year long. Thatâ€™s why Dowd is our   Mr. Magoo. As Trump is being sworn in and visions of the wall are dancing in your head, remember that if he ever runs out of bricks, he can always use Republican consultants.

title: Profitable Pickups May Be in Cross Hairs of Trump Border Tax - The New York Times
content: DETROIT  â€”   There are many reasons for the steady success of the three major American automakers in recent years, but none are bigger than the surging sales of   pickup trucks. General Motors, Ford Motor and Fiat Chrysler dominate the segment in the United States market, and they rely on pickups for a sizable portion of their earnings in North America as a whole. But President Trumpâ€™s proposed border tax on imported vehicles could throw a wrench in the profit machine, particularly for G. M. and Fiat Chrysler, which build a large percentage of their pickups in Mexico. At the same time, Ford  â€”   which makes all of its pickups in American factories  â€”   would most likely benefit at the expense of its rivals. The Trump administration has pledged to levy tariffs of up to 35 percent on vehicles imported from Mexico and possibly elsewhere, primarily to prod automakers to increase production and jobs in the United States. In response, all three of the Detroit companies have announced plans for new investments in their American operations. Ford went a step further by canceling plans to build a $1. 6 billion plant in Mexico that had been criticized repeatedly by Mr. Trump. Yet the possibility of tariffs on trucks overshadows the    so far between a new president determined to expand the American economy and automakers that count on pickups as a huge source of income. â€œThere is an awful lot at stake with a border tax on trucks,â€ said Michelle Krebs, an analyst with Autotrader. com, a   site. â€œThese are the cash cows for Detroit. â€ Pickup sales have been an important component of the consistent growth of the American auto market, which last year set a record with nearly 17. 5 million vehicles sold. The combination of low gas prices and a need by businesses to replace older trucks has stimulated demand, especially for   pickups, more than 90 percent of which are made by the three Detroit companies. In January, the three   vehicles in the nation were pickups: the Ford   G. M.â€™s Chevrolet Silverado, and Fiat Chryslerâ€™s Ram model. The companies earn an estimated $8, 000 to $10, 000 in profit on each truck sold  â€”   compared with $3, 000 on a passenger car  â€”   so Detroitâ€™s financial fortunes inevitably rise and fall on the success of their truck products. Yet for G. M. and Fiat Chrysler, much of that success is dependent on truck production in Mexico, where labor costs are significantly lower than in unionized factories in the United States. Industry analysts estimate that   of G. M.â€™s annual pickup production comes from its sprawling assembly plant in Silao, Mexico. And while Fiat Chrysler is expanding its American output of trucks, it still relies on its factory in Saltillo, Mexico, for 30 to 40 percent of its pickups, the analysts say. Ford, by contrast, makes its pickups at three plants in the United States. Automakers do not reveal profit margins on particular vehicles. But companies pay workers less than $10 an hour in Mexico, versus the top union wage of $29 in American plants. That differential makes Mexican trucks more profitable for G. M. and Fiat Chrysler than those produced in the United States. There are other costs associated with Mexican production, including shipping vehicles by rail or   to American dealerships. But lower labor rates still make Mexico an attractive production option for automakers. A border tax would wipe out that cost advantage, and could prompt manufacturers to raise prices on   vehicles. â€œAutomakers could possibly eat the cost of a 5 to 10 percent tariff, but not a tax of 20 or 30 percent,â€ said Ron Harbour, an automotive analyst with the consulting firm Oliver Wyman. â€œThey would probably have to pass some of that on to consumers. â€ Higher prices could cool demand for pickups made by G. M. and Fiat Chrysler. The companies could also try to make up the cost of a border tax by spreading price increases across the breadth of their product lineups. While it is not uncommon to reallocate production among factories  â€”   for example, to make more   trucks in American plants and shift less profitable small cars to Mexico  â€”   it is expensive and   to do so. G. M. is also vulnerable to potential tariffs on imported parts for pickups made in its factories in Flint, Mich. and Fort Wayne, Ind. About 38 percent of the parts for all G. M. pickups are made in the United States and Canada, and 55 percent are produced in Mexico, according to statistics compiled by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. About 56 percent of the parts in Fiat Chryslerâ€™s pickups are made in the United States and Canada, and 29 percent are produced in Mexico. At Ford, about 70 percent of its pickup components are made in the United States and Canada, and 15 percent come from Mexico. For all three automakers, that mix of parts applies whether the truck is made in the United States or Mexico. It is not clear whether Mr. Trumpâ€™s vision of a border tax would apply to parts or only finished products. One industry analyst, Colin Langan of UBS Securities, singled out G. M. in a recent research report for its vulnerability to a tariff on pickups. â€œThe border tax is a clear risk to G. M.â€™s   pickup trucks,â€ Mr. Langan wrote. â€œThe timing is also challenging as G. M. plans to retool its pickup facilities ahead of the 2018 pickup launch. â€ G. M. executives declined to talk about the impact of a tariff on the companyâ€™s pickups during a conference call with analysts last week on its 2016 earnings. The companyâ€™s chief financial officer, Chuck Stevens, said it was premature to discuss the implications of a border tax. â€œThere are a lot of moving parts,â€ he said. â€œWe want to work with the administration to make sure what is best for the U. S. economy. â€ G. M.â€™s chief executive, Mary Barra, stressed that about 80 percent of the products that the company sells in the United States are  . As a member of Mr. Trumpâ€™s business advisory council, Ms. Barra said, she has outlined how difficult it is for an automaker to adjust production strategy on the fly. â€œI think that understanding has been well received,â€ she said of meeting with the president and his advisers. Other vehicles made in Mexico, such as Fordâ€™s Fusion sedan and G. M.â€™s Cadillac SRX sport utility vehicle, could also be affected by a border tax. But because of their popularity and profits, pickups are the most vulnerable products. â€œA tariff on pickups would be a real challenge, especially for G. M.,â€ said Ms. Krebs of Autotrader. â€œTrucks are so important to their bottom line, and this is uncharted territory. â€
