S. mosques, even as several hundred young Muslims from the U. S. have gone to wage jihad for the Islamic State and are now waging jihad here. U. S. law enforcement officials must take it upon themselves to learn about what Islam and jihad are really all about, then strategize accordingly about how to stop it. The mosques must be monitored. Muslim immigration must stop. All over the world, the brutal sharia is being imposed on   and free thinkers. Bangladesh is awash in the blood of free thinkers, poets, secularists, and  . The slaughter there is daily now. Devout Muslims tried to kill us in Garland one year ago today for the same reason: perceived insults to Muhammad  â€”   in other words, violation of Islamic law. Under Islamic law, just a whisper that you offended or criticized Muhammad, and you are marked for death. Itâ€™s just that simple. The world is looking away, just as it did during the rise of the Third Reich. Deaf, dumb, blind is the world to the extermination of millions in jihad wars. There is no excuse now. Echoing Dr. Ernst Janning from Judgment at Nuremberg, no one can pretend not to know. There are websites  â€”   mine, Jihad Watch, The Religion of Peace, et al. â€œWe didnâ€™t knowâ€ wonâ€™t fly. The world was guilty then, and the world is guilty now. Then, the world said, â€œtake Sudetenland. Take the Rhineland, Take Austria. Take Czechoslovakia. â€ And now, the world says, take Syria. Take Gaza, Take Judea, Samaria, Lebanon, the Ivory Coast, Libya  â€¦     The world says, â€œIslam is peace. â€ The world says, â€œItâ€™s not millions of victims, itâ€™s hundreds. â€ Thatâ€™s a blatant lie, but what difference does that make? We stand for justice, truth, and the value of a single human. What will you tell your children and grandchildren when they ask you, â€œWhere were you?â€ Listen to Geller on Breitbart News Daily on SiriusXM this morning: Pamela Geller is the President of the American Freedom Defense Initiative (AFDI) publisher of PamelaGeller. com and author of The   Presidency: The Obama Administrationâ€™s War on America and Stop the Islamization of America: A Practical Guide to the Resistance. Follow her on Twitter here. Like her on Facebook here.

title: Yes, thatâ€™s J. Peterman from â€™Seinfeldâ€™ pitching an IPO on TV â€”Â no, thatâ€™s not the most surprising thing about it
content: â€™  â€™ â€™   â€Ever heard of Uber or Lyft?â€ â€™ â€   The man on TV has   gray hair and looks directly into   the camera. Behind him, thereâ€™s a false backdrop of trading   screens and skyscrapers. Itâ€™s an ad running on CNBC and Fox News   for something called YayYo. â€ â€™   â€Yes, YayYo,â€ the man says. The  isnâ€™â€™t for its   app. Itâ€™â€™s for an . â€™ â€™   The man looks familiar, but his pitch is unusual. â€™ â€™   You could make millions, like the early investors in Uber, he   suggests. â€Do it now. Before all the shares are gone.â€ â€™ â€™   Watching these ads, two questions come to mind: â€™ â€™   The answer to both is yes. The actorâ€™â€™s name is John Oâ€™â€™Hurley. How   itâ€™â€™s possible that heâ€™â€™s pitching shares in a risky startup on TV   is more complicated. Even though the IPO is â€qualifiedâ€ by the   Securities and Exchange Commission, the aggressive way YayYo   shares are being marketed could be problematic, experts say,   especially since the pitch is to    investors. â€™ â€™  â€™ â€™   The company is a tiny startup with no working product, few   staffers, but a big marketing budget. YayYo says it wants to be   the Kayak of the   industry, allowing you to compare   prices and book rides on Uber, Lyft, and other such companies in   a single app. â€™ â€™   At the center of it all is Ramy   whose life before   starting YayYo involved working with an arms dealer, promoting   â€Men Are from Mars, Women Are From Venus,â€ and led ultimately to   accusations of a   scheme and one of the   biggest securities bailouts in history. â€™ â€™     never admitted wrongdoing but was barred from running   a public company for five years, a steep comedown for a man who   once proudly rubbed shoulders with the likes of Hugh Hefner,   Ivanka Trump, and royalty as he sought to amass a fortune. â€™ â€™     is pitching investors on the YayYo IPO thanks to the   2012 Jumpstart our Business Startups, or JOBS . Meant to   spur investment in smaller companies, it also allowed companies   to pitch their IPOs on TV for the first time and created a new   kind of   whereby entrepreneurs can raise up to $50   million from just about anyone. â€™ â€™  â€™ â€™   â€If you would  â€”   write this in a positive way,â€   said in   the third of a series of interviews with Business Insider,   concerned about being portrayed negatively. He spoke with   reporters over the phone and in person at his Beverly Hills   office. â€™ â€™   In those conversations, Batrawi said YayYo has big plans. In   addition to its aggregator app, YayYo says it is gearing up to   launch its own    with a fleet of luxury cars   and salaried drivers behind the wheel. â€™ â€™   â€We are moving along in pretty good shape,â€ he said. â€™ â€   But while YayYo aggressively solicits investors on TV, the   companyâ€™s products are far from ready, and some of his claims   donâ€™t seem to stand up. â€ â€   Launching the aggregator service is dependent on securing   agreements with companies such as Uber and Lyft so that it can   integrate those servicesâ€™ prices and available cars into the   YayYo app. â€ â€™     said in one conversation that those deals were on the   way. YayYo is in â€contactâ€ with Uber and it has an â€agreementâ€   with Lyft, he said. â€™ â€™   Uber and Lyft deny this. â€™ â€™   â€We sent YayYo a    letter several weeks ago and   have suspended their access to Lyft,â€ Adrian Durbin, a Lyft   spokesman, told Business Insider. â€I think itâ€™â€™s fair to say that   their CEOâ€™â€™s characterization of our relationship is wildly   inaccurate.â€ â€™ â€™   Uber has no deal of any kind with YayYo, according to Kaitlin   Durkosh, a spokeswoman for Uber. â€™ â€™   Later,   said the company never got Lyftâ€™â€™s      order, and Bob Vanech, a YayYo board member,   said it has some â€clever strategiesâ€ to deal with the fact that   Uber and Lyft are denying companies like YayYo access to their   information. YayYo plans to partner with   companies   â€three through 100,â€ he said. â€™ â€™   YayYo said it is planning a beta in the next couple of weeks. â€™ â€™   â€We work 18 hours a day,â€   said. â€We know how close we   are. It may feel like vaporware for some people. But the moment   we start launching and generating revenue, which is not far   along, our valuation is so much lower than what you would   consider what Uber and Lyft is and everybody else.â€ â€™ â€™   The IPO, with a share price of $8, already values the company at   $200 million. â€™ â€™   Which brings us to those TV ads with John Oâ€™â€™Hurley of â€Seinfeldâ€   fame. â€™ â€™  â€™ â€™   â€You might never have thought youâ€™â€™d be able to have a chance to   invest in the new millennium movement of ridesharing,â€ Oâ€™â€™Hurley   says   to prospective investors in YayYoâ€™â€™s ad   announcing its IPO. â€™ â€™   The YayYo spot boils down to this pitch: You probably missed out   on investing in Uber and Lyft before they made investors   millionaires. But because of the new SEC rule, YayYo is your   chance for some   riches. â€™ â€™   â€Because of YayYoâ€™â€™s business model, YayYo can scale faster than   any one of these   companies can alone,â€ the ad says.   Experts say the implication that YayYo could become bigger than   Uber is audacious enough to attract legal and regulatory   scrutiny. â€™ â€™   About 700 people have already invested,   says, with   individual investments ranging from a single $8 share purchase to   $100, 000. â€™ â€™     says repeatedly that the ads target only professional,   savvy investors who watch   channels like Fox   Business and CNBC during the day. â€™ â€   But those networks also attract many hobby investors and   retirees, and the adâ€™s own script specifically speaks to     investors. â€ â€™   â€With these new SEC rules, it makes it possible for the little   guy like you or me to buy into an IPO previously unavailable,â€   Oâ€™â€™Hurley tells TV viewers. â€™ â€™   Those new SEC rules are something called â€Regulation A+,â€ which   was approved in March 2015 as part of the JOBS Act. â€™ â€™  â€™ â€™   Regulation A+ made it easier for   startups like YayYo   to essentially crowdsource investment in a â€ .â€ Itâ€™â€™s like   Kickstarter, except investors become real shareholders. â€™ â€   The idea was to open startup investing to Main Street, as long as   they donâ€™t put in more than 10% of their income or assets. â€ â€™   And as part of the rules, there are fewer requirements and   regulations for companies like YayYo than if it were to do a     IPO. â€™ â€™   There are actually two kinds of Regulation A+ offerings. In Tier   1, a company can raise up to $20 million from investors in a   year. Importantly, Tier 1 is regulated more by individual states   than the SEC. Tier 2 offerings, like YayYo, are larger  â€”   raising   up to $50 million in a year  â€”   and though both require an SEC   review, the latter offerings are not subject to review by the   states. â€™ â€   To the public, that these offerings are submitted to the SEC   might imply that itâ€™s a pretty good bet. â€ â€™   â€That gives some comfort level to your average person,â€ said Sam   Guzik, a   lawyer at Guzik & Associates.   â€That this is something that has been qualified by the SEC. Most   people donâ€™â€™t take the time to read the disclosure, and if they   do, they are not going to understand or appreciate it.â€ â€™ â€   For those who do wade through YayYoâ€™s SEC filings, which are   comprehensive, just how risky this investment is becomes clear   quickly. â€ â€   The companyâ€™s products are still in development, and much of its   app is being developed by outside vendors under a licensing deal. â€ â€™   Without agreements in place with companies like Uber and Lyft,   the filing says â€the technical barrier to entry is steep.â€ â€™ â€   YayYo has no history for investors to judge its prospects, and   its executives have no history working together, or running   similar companies. Its auditor says thereâ€™s substantial doubt   YayYo can continue as a going concern. At the end of October,   YayYo had only about $160, 000 cash on hand. â€ â€™   â€This is a company on the edge,â€ Peter Henning, a former SEC   official and professor of law at Wayne State University, told   Business Insider. â€Itâ€™â€™s very risky, which they say it is. Should   mom and pop be investing in this? You hope anyone investing in   this is putting money in theyâ€™â€™re willing to throw away.â€ â€™ â€™  â€™ â€™   Some of those risk factors are typical of any     â€ â€ company. Others that have done Regulation A+ IPOs   include    which is working on an inexpensive   car, and      which designs robotic security systems. Either  fail, but both already have customers paying for their   products or placing deposits. â€™ â€   At this point, YayYo is mostly marketing.   paid rapper   Master P to write a    for the service, an ad that   showed Business Insider   during a visit to the companyâ€™s Beverly Hills offices. â€ â€   But most of its marketing is targeting investors and those ads   donâ€™t mention or allude to the risks. Itâ€™s up to prospective   investors to read through the dozens of pages of SEC filings to   see what theyâ€™re getting themselves into. â€ â€™   â€Most people have fallen asleep by page two,â€ Henning said. The   SEC filing is â€very intimidating.â€ â€™ â€   And thatâ€™s what worries experts and some regulators. Do investors   really know what theyâ€™re buying, and do they know who theyâ€™re   doing business with? â€ â€™  â€™ â€™   The life story of Ramy   according to Ramy     goes like this: â€™ â€™   Born in Switzerland, he wound up in Montreal where, at age 12,   after reading the   â€Think and Grow Rich,â€ he took   to heart its message of not procrastinating wealth and left home.   He hitchhiked his way to Tampa, Florida, because all the great   rich guys were in America,   says. â€™ â€™   He dropped out of high school, considering it another impediment   to riches, and was homeless for the first five Florida years,   partly living out of an old Cadillac, finding quarters on the   street, recapping tires, and doing odd jobs, but he â€tried not to   work for anyone else.â€ â€™ â€™   Somehow, by 23, he says, he made his first million with a     business. â€™ â€™   One day in the  â€™â€™80s he was watching â€Lifestyles of the Rich   and Famous.â€ The subject  was   Adnan Khashoggi, the   arms dealer infamous for his   profligate spending and role in the   scandal. At the   time, Khashoggi was said to be the richest man in the world. â€™ â€™   â€My goal is to be that,â€   thought back then. â€So when I   saw him, I just decided thatâ€™â€™s the guy I need to work with.â€ â€™ â€™  â€™ â€   As   tells it, he sold everything and spent a year   searching for Khashoggi, tracking down his inner circle  â€”     including his psychic and chauffeur.   says he started   paying some of Khashoggiâ€™s staff to tell him where he might find   the man himself. â€ â€™   Finally,   said, after ingratiating himself, he landed   his first assignment from the billionaire: buying a       company called Jetborne. â€™ â€™   Thus began what   nostalgically calls â€the Khashoggi   years,â€ where he was the billionaireâ€™â€™s No. 2 for nearly a decade,   â€negotiating transactions everywhere,â€ meeting heads of states,   sometimes holding multiple meetings in a single hotel lobby  â€”     â€one in every cornerâ€  â€”   he says. â€™ â€   The work he did with Khashoggi is also touted in his official bio   in YayYoâ€™s . â€ â€™   What was he selling then? â€Different things. Russia needed   airplanes,â€ he says. There was a pipeline deal. â€Whatever you can   think of, we pretty much did.â€ â€™ â€     was living the good life. Even today, his     accounts are full of pictures from past decades: playing poker   with Carl Icahn, standing next to former Los Angeles Clippers   owner Donald Sterling. In the â€™90s, he met Oâ€™Hurley, who was   dating a flight attendant on one of the private planes that     owned back then. â€ â€™  â€™ â€     said he was the one who introduced Donald Trump to   Khashoggi at Olympic Towers when they were all in New York in the   early â€™90s. â€ â€™   â€It is interesting he became president,â€   said. â€I   would have never guessed that one.â€ â€™ â€   Through all this, itâ€™s not completely clear how   made   money. In court testimony from a case against Khashoggi,     says Khashoggi didnâ€™t pay him a salary but rather   covered his travel expenses (at hotels, for instance) when they   were doing deals. â€ â€™   Still,   had other ways to profit from his connection.   When someone once paid $100, 000 to introduce them to Khashoggi,   who would, in turn, introduce that person to some princes,     took a $25, 000 cut for making the connection, he   testified in a separate court case in 2012. â€™ â€™  â€™ â€   In the  â€™90s   set off on his own. â€ â€™   â€I didnâ€™â€™t want to always be Adnanâ€™â€™s guy,â€ he said. â€I wanted to   be my own guy.â€ â€™ â€™   Around this time,   had some marital problems and read   the book â€Men Are From Mars, Women Are From Venus.â€ It helped   him, and he started going to seminars held by its author, John   Gray. â€™ â€™   He went up to Gray after one of the sessions and persuaded Gray   to let him market the series, creating infomercials selling   videos and other products tied to the hit   book. â€™ â€™   â€He was my first product,â€   said of Gray. â€™ â€™   Gray calls   a master of infomercials. â€™ â€™   Sales soared, and the two became friends. Gray even became a   financial backer. â€™ â€™   â€Anything he does I would invest in,â€ Gray said in an interview   with Business Insider. â€Heâ€™â€™s only brought me great success.â€ â€™ â€™   Gray invested in the company that sprang from the infomercials,   GenesisIntermedia. â€™ â€™  â€™ â€™   The company branched out into other products like  and   says the company evolved into an   â€incubatorâ€ that acquired and built companies to market and spin   off for a profit. â€™ â€™   One was a network of â€internet kiosksâ€ for shopping malls called   Centerlinq, and to market it, he turned, as he would time and   again, to his friend    most famous for his role as Elaineâ€™â€™s eccentric boss on   â€Seinfeld.â€ â€™ â€   It was the   boom of the late â€™90s, and   was   taking full part. In 1999, he took GenesisIntermedia public.     says Genesis was flying high. â€ â€™   â€Iâ€™â€™m hoping you write this one,â€   says as he rattles   off stats about the companyâ€™â€™s   era. Revenues grew   â€exponentially.â€ The stock was up â€about 1, 000 percent in two   years.â€ â€™ â€   That was true until it wasnâ€™t. Before long, the stock would be   worthless, but Gray didnâ€™t lose faith in  . â€ â€™   â€Heâ€™â€™s responsible. Heâ€™â€™s friendly, tremendous integrity,â€ Gray   says of  . Gray said heâ€™â€™s also invested in YayYo. â€™ â€™   The SEC had a different view. â€™ â€™  â€™ â€™   In 2006, about four years after the company collapsed, the      along with Khashoggi and others, with   manipulating GenesisIntermedia stock. â€™ â€™   The SEC alleged that GenesisIntermedia lent its stock to brokers   in exchange for cash and then engaged in a number of actions to   prop up the stockâ€™â€™s price. That included making thousands of   trades â€to create the false appearance of widespread investor   interest,â€ and hiring Courtney Smith, a bullish financial   commentator who would appear on Bloomberg TV and CNBC. â€™ â€™   Profits were funneled to Khashoggi through a Bermuda company   called Ultimate Holdings, which then lent the shares to others,   who were left holding the bag when the stock price tumbled from   $25 a share to pennies. â€™ â€   In the governmentâ€™s charges, the actions resulted in $130 million   in illegal profits and the largest bailout in the history of the   Securities Investor Protection Corp. wiping out several   middlemen brokerages, like  in Minnesota. â€ â€™     said in a 2009 deposition that he was â€trying to make   [Khashoggi] money to prove that I was kind of  â€”   he was like my   mentor  â€”   and I really looked up to him.â€ â€™ â€™   The case was    in 2010. The SEC barred   and Khashoggi from running   public companies for five years. Neither admitted nor denied   wrongdoing. â€™ â€   Courtney Smith, the TV commentator, was acquitted of charges   against him. Heâ€™s now a consultant for YayYo. â€ â€™     dismisses the charges he faced, and he has long blamed   an FBI agent and stock manipulator for dooming his company. â€™ â€™   â€  hit,â€   said. â€Arabs were a good target for people   at the time, the SEC and all of that. They filed the lawsuit   after five years before the statute of limitations ran out   because they couldnâ€™â€™t find anything wrong. And after battling for   seven years we just ended up with a consent decree . .. It wasnâ€™â€™t   fraud then, it isnâ€™â€™t fraud now   â€¦     At the end, they found the   people were who shorting the stocks were hired FBI agents.â€ â€™ â€™   More recently, in an unrelated 2014 case, investors sued     alleging that he misled them about an investment in a     company that   controlled called   Xerveo, which sold diet products. The case was later settled,   California court documents show. â€™ â€™  â€™ â€™   You wonâ€™â€™t find YayYoâ€™â€™s name in the visitorâ€™â€™s directory at 9665   Wilshire Blvd. in Beverly Hills, but if you head down a drab   hallway on the eighth floor, youâ€™â€™ll see a sign that says â€YAY   YO.â€ â€™ â€   Walk right in (no one answers the door) and youâ€™ll find four   people sitting around a long table. â€ â€™   At center is   surrounded by a programmer, a      guy, and a   coordinator. â€™ â€™   In a room across the hall, women wearing headsets answer calls   from prospective investors. â€™ â€™   YayYo looks like a lot of startups do. Staffers wear   and   jeans. Plans are scribbled across whiteboards. â€™ â€   An ad for the YayYo IPO has just aired on TV, and     pulls up the websiteâ€™s analytics. The number starts soaring: 177,   290, and then over 500 people on the site all at once. â€ â€™   â€As soon as [Oâ€™â€™Hurley] finishes talking, then it really   accelerates,â€   says. â€Itâ€™â€™ll keep going higher.â€ â€™ â€™   If youâ€™â€™re wondering,   said he didnâ€™â€™t know that â€yayoâ€   is sometimes . He wanted a catchy name, â€like Google,â€ but also   one thatâ€™â€™s easily pronounced in Chinese, where he wants to   expand. â€™ â€™   â€We have 100 times more positive comments on it than negative   comments. Itâ€™â€™s very memorable.â€ â€™ â€   But itâ€™s what Oâ€™Hurley says in the ad that could get YayYo into   trouble. â€ â€™   â€There are really only two rules,â€ Sara Hanks, a former SEC   official, CEO and founder of CrowdCheck, told Business Insider.   â€Donâ€™â€™t lie, and donâ€™â€™t say anything that is misleading in any   way.â€ â€™ â€™  â€™ â€™   But whatâ€™â€™s â€misleadingâ€ is somewhat subjective. â€™ â€™   â€You know it when you see it,â€ Hanks said. â€™ â€   Legal experts had varying views of where the line is, but   identified specifics in YayYoâ€™s ad they would generally advise   clients avoid: â€ â€   Vanech, the board member, said the ad was approved by lawyers,   and then filed with the SEC, which contacted YayYoâ€™s attorneys   and requested changes to the visual background behind Oâ€™Hurley,   which had imagery that looked too much like the New York Stock   Exchange and the SEC logo. He said regulators did not object to   the script. The SEC declined to comment. â€ â€   Most companies go public when theyâ€™ve already proved something,   like sales or a promising drug in development. â€ â€™   â€YayYoâ€™â€™s advantage is that they have a substantial marketing   budget,â€ Darren Marble  â€”   CEO of CrowdfundX, which does marketing   for companies doing Regulation A+ IPOs  â€”   told Business Insider.   Based on the number of times the ad has played, YayYoâ€™â€™s ad   spending is likely hundreds of thousands of dollars. â€™ â€™  â€™ â€™   The ad has run at least 33 times nationally since it debuted on   April 19, which cost the company at least $111, 000, according to   analytics company  which tracks only national airings. The ad has likely   run far more times on DirecTV, which reaches a sizable portion of   the population. â€™ â€     like YayYoâ€™s are still novel. To some, they already   have a stigma: Why canâ€™t the company raise traditional venture   capital, they wonder. But proponents say a successful Regulation   A+ can raise millions of dollars without founders having to give   up control to outside investors. â€ â€™   But if these early years of Regulation A+ are marked by failures,   it could cast a permanent pall over these kinds of offerings. â€™ â€™   â€Regular investors are the ones that can fall for a scam,â€   Henning of Wayne State University said. â€™ â€   When lawmakers were debating the JOBS Act, some state regulators   objected, saying it could put small investors at risk. Two states   sued because the JOBS act reduces statesâ€™ ability to police   deals. â€ â€™   If YayYo had decided to do an offering   Act, it would   have come under state regulatorsâ€™â€™ control. A few states assess   the â€meritâ€ of   and some may have objected to YayYoâ€™â€™s   ads. â€™ â€™   â€Generally speaking, as a state regulator, when we have the   authority to review, we will object to ads when a startup or   smaller company compares itself to a larger,     company,â€ said Faith Anderson, chief of registration and   regulatory affairs for the securities division of the Washington   State Department of Financial Institutions. â€™ â€™  â€™ â€   Some states, such as Massachusetts, may have denied the entire   YayYo offering because the company has no track record, no   independent directors, or because of  â€™s history with   the SEC. â€ â€   But in larger filings, like YayYoâ€™s, itâ€™s only the SEC, not the   states, in control. â€ â€    â€™s past SEC action must be disclosed  â€”   itâ€™s in the   filing  â€”   but it wonâ€™t stop him from offering the IPO, because it   occurred before the JOBS Act was passed. â€ â€   All this is slowing Regulation A+â€™s rise into the mainstream. â€ â€™   â€I donâ€™â€™t believe that the regulation is inherently flawed; I   think that it will take some time before we see quality companies   using it,â€ said Cass Sanford, a lawyer at Sichenzia Ross Ference   Kesner LLP. â€™ â€   Past performance is no indication of future results.  â€™s   colorful past doesnâ€™t mean YayYo isnâ€™t real. Itâ€™s no doubt a   highly risky investment, but its executives say they are true   believers. â€ â€™   â€That is our intention here: to build a great company,â€ Vanech   said. â€™ â€   Yet there are other questions.   says heâ€™s also a 10%   investor in a mysterious biotech startup called NeurMedix that   plans its own Regulation A+  complete with   Oâ€™Hurley on the offering page. â€ â€     also owns an   company called  which is planning a     soon. The details of that company are vague, but   Oâ€™Hurley makes an appearance there too. â€ â€™   And while   may have cleaned up his act,     records show he owns a number of websites promoting the three   IPOs and featuring articles about himself as an â€  .â€     wouldnâ€™â€™t comment. Records show he also    fuckyouall. net. â€™ â€™   â€We are doing everything we can to comply with all laws, to   follow the SEC guidelines, to use best practices, to give   individual investors the chance to get in at the ground floor,â€   Vanech said in the final interview. He said this level of   â€journalistic scrutiny at this stage of the businessâ€ is   unwarranted. â€™ â€   And to Ramy   his past and YayYoâ€™s prospects are all   fully disclosed to investors. â€ â€™   â€There are a lot of risks in this. But there is a lot of upside   if we do execute. This is what people are betting on,â€ he said.   â€It really is up to the public to decide if this is for them or   not.â€ â€™ â€™ Additional reporting by Frank Chaparro, Rebecca Harrington,   and Lydia Ramsey. â€™ â€™YayYo is a startup that plans to be an. ..â€™ â€™â€™ â€™â€™ â€™â€™

title: Austria to Ban Burqas from October
content: VIENNA (AFP)  â€”   New Austrian legislation came into force Friday that will ban the   Islamic veil in public places from October 1. [The outlawing of the burqa or other clothing concealing the face follows similar moves in other countries in the European Union, starting with France in 2011.  In Austria, people who break the new law could be fined up to 150 euros ($168) according to the legislation approved by parliament in May and signed into law by the president this week. Other measures include a clampdown on distributing extremist material, and immigrants being obliged to sign an â€œintegration contractâ€. A   â€œintegration programmeâ€ will include courses in â€œvaluesâ€ and the German language. Failure to attend can result in cuts to social security payments. The legislation was hammered out by the centrist government amid strong support for the   and the arrival of 90, 000   since 2015. The â€œgrand coalitionâ€ under Chancellor Christian Kern collapsed last month and early elections were called for October 15. The   Freedom Party (FPOe) whose candidate came close to winning the largely ceremonial presidency last year, is riding high in opinion polls ahead of the vote.

title: Arab Social Media Fumes over French Burkini Ban
content: JAFFA, Israel  â€”   Social media users across the Arab world are still expressing outrage over the conduct of French police officers who recently attempted to enforce a new law forbidding burkinis by forcing a Muslim woman to remove her garments on a beach in Nice on the French Riviera. [Police officers patrolling the beach reportedly saw the woman and ordered her to remove the burkini, which is an   swimsuit that covers the whole body except the face, the hands, and the feet. According to one eyewitness, fellow   applauded the police officers and others yelled at the Muslim woman, â€œGo home. â€  Just a few days earlier, a French court in Nice rejected an appeal filed by a human rights organization against the decision of several municipalities in the Riviera in southern France to ban the burkini on their beaches. The issue has continued to stir the anger of social media users in the Arab world. Abdelrahmah Dam wrote on Twitter, â€œThe burkini is shaking the foundations of secularism in France. A modest piece of cloth confuses the politicians and eliminates the hope for freedom. title: NBC News Asks Donald Trump About Challenging Election Results â€” Twice - Breitbart
content: One of the most jarring moments from the first presidential debate Monday night was a closing question about â€œaccepting the outcome of the electionâ€  â€”   which NBC News asked Republican candidate Donald Trump a second time in the spin room. [During the debate, Trump said he â€œabsolutelyâ€ would accept a Hillary Clinton electoral victory. So why ask it again  â€”   when the first time was already a weird red herring?  Per the transcript of the debate, Trump used moderator and NBC Nightly News anchor Lester Holtâ€™s final question to pivot to a broader issue on immigration, before answering it directly: HOLT: Mr. Trump, very quickly, same question. Will you accept the outcome as the will of the voters? TRUMP: I want to make America great again. We are a nation that is seriously troubled. Weâ€™re losing our jobs. People are pouring into our country. The other day, we were deporting 800 people. And perhaps they passed the wrong button, they pressed the wrong button, or perhaps worse than that, it was corruption, but these people that we were going to deport for good reason ended up becoming citizens. Ended up becoming citizens. And it was 800. And now it turns out it might be 1, 800, and they donâ€™t even know. HOLT: Will you accept the outcome of the election? TRUMP: Look, hereâ€™s the story. I want to make America great again. Iâ€™m going to be able to do it. I donâ€™t believe Hillary will. The answer is, if she wins, I will absolutely support her. Later in the spin room, an NBC correspondent  â€”   not clearly identified but sounding like Hallie Jackson  â€”   repeated the question. As video from NBC shows, this reporter asked only one question as Trump made his way through a line of reporters, and she chose as her only contribution to the   discussion: â€œWill you accept the outcome of the election?â€ Trump responded, â€œOh yes, absolutely. I will. â€ The odd emergence of this topic calls to mind the 2012 election, when ABC News anchor and former Clinton White House employee George Stephanopoulos bizarrely raised the topic of birth control during a Republican primary debate, baffling   Mitt Romney. That issue became a line of attack for President Obamaâ€™s reelection campaign, fueling speculation of collusion between the White House and the establishment media. It also brings back memories of the first Republican debate in 2015, where moderator Bret Baier opened by asking the candidates to pledge their support to whoever won the primary race. Trump was the only person on stage who raised his hand to avoid that commitment. Perhaps NBCâ€™s producers were hoping for a similar contrarian moment on a   unity question. They wanted Trump to urge his supporters to reject the election results and cause widespread chaos  â€”   to sound like a NicolÃ¡s Maduro or some other caudillo, a big theme in the Never Trump movement. They wanted to plant a meme that Trump may encourage a violent coup, even a civil war  â€”   so they can blame him for any more violence against his supporters. However, Trump quickly shut it down, with an â€œabsoluteâ€ yes  â€”   even when they tried to fish for a gaffe a second time. That second time obviously wonâ€™t be the last we hear of this silly question. Much like the 2012 birth control narrative and repeated questions about David Duke, the establishment media will keep bringing up this topic until they get an answer that helps their preferred candidate. As I watched the debate aftermath last night, one moment was especially saddening. A member of CNNâ€™s debate focus group said she was disappointed that the candidates did not discuss substantive issues the one she wanted to hear about most was health care. If the   spin room questions were any indication, â€œprofessionalâ€ journalists will continue to disappoint her for quite a long time.

title: LGBT â€™Shame Listâ€™ Includes Christian Colleges with No Documented Discrimination Incidents - Breitbart
content: A recent â€œshameâ€ list which purported to rank the institutions of higher education that are the least   included several Christian colleges with no documented history of discrimination. [The organization behind the list, Campus Pride, sought to create a list of institutions that were engaging in practices counter to the interests of the LGBT community.  When the   group was asked for documented proof of the incidents that occurred, they vaguely suggested that criteria for the â€œshameâ€ list is based on the general â€œharms of   bigotryâ€ rather than a documented record of specific incidents. Asked for an   summary of documented incidents of LGBT discrimination at schools whose listings donâ€™t mention any, a Campus Pride spokeswoman reiterated the criteria for inclusion on the list. These 102 â€œabsolute worstâ€ institutions â€œhave chosen to openly discriminate against LGBTQ youth and have requested Title IX exemptions to perpetuate the harms of   bigotry,â€ according to the groupâ€™s press release last month. Despite the lack of actual incidents, Campus Pride Executive Director Shane Windmeyer wrote an editorial for NBC News asking corporations to cease their business relationships with the religious institutions named in the shame list. â€œCorporations also have a choice to exercise their values. Donâ€™t donate to these campuses. Donâ€™t recruit or hire at these colleges,â€ Windmeyer said. â€œSimply choose not to do business with those who choose discrimination over inclusion and diversity. â€ Tom Ciccotta is a libertarian who writes about Free Speech and Intellectual Diversity for Breitbart. You can follow him on Twitter @tciccotta or email him at tciccotta@breitbart. com

title: â€™Impartialâ€™ BBC Calls Trump Election â€™An American Tragedyâ€™
content: Britainâ€™s public broadcaster  â€”   the BBC  â€”   has called the election of Donald Trump an â€œAmerican Tragedyâ€ in a headline for an article featuring an interview with the editor of the New Yorker magazine. [David Remnick, editor of the stridently   New Yorker was granted an interview with BBC News, part of the British media company which is funded to the tune of billions of pounds a year by a television tax forced on the UK public.  Opening with his widely publicised comments from November when Mr. Remnick said of the Trump victory that it was â€œan American tragedyâ€ and â€œa sickening event in the history of liberal democracyâ€ the BBC lauded the   figure as a â€œhero to many in liberal America and beyondâ€. His magazine has recently taken to publishing instructional articles on ways â€œto Oppose a Donald Trump Presidencyâ€ which includes information on signing   petitions, protesting at the Presidential Inauguration, and even calling for an end to Americaâ€™s Electoral College, the very system devised by the Founding Fathers to stop major, now liberal, population centres consistently dominating the country. Claiming that the success of   Trump was not down to a significant change in American politics but rather the willingness of the Mr. Trump to harness the concerns of many Americans affected by â€œglobalisation,  â€ Remnick said: â€œHeâ€™s a brilliant, I think pernicious, but brilliant demagogue, who was able to act as a demagogue  â€”   a successful demagogue  â€”   on the national level the likes of which youâ€™ve never seen in the United Statesâ€. â€œI get it  â€¦     I understandâ€ Having failed  â€”   as with many in the mainstream media  â€”   to predict the Trump victory Mr. Remnick was at pains to emphasise how he understands the grievances which led to that vote. Stating â€œIâ€™ve travelled everywhere in this country. I live in this country. I live in a city of immigrants. I have all kinds of relatives, quite frankly, who voted for Trumpâ€ the   based journalist used the phrases â€œI get itâ€ and â€œI understandâ€ over a dozen times in the course of the interview. Despite the apparent empathy, the BBC reported Remnickâ€™s scorn on   Trump, including on his transition team picks and campaign, remarking: â€œI donâ€™t think you would call Donald Trumpâ€™s behaviour during the presidential campaign one of unification, decency, kindness, dignity. It was one of accusation. Playing the racial dog whistle  â€”   it really wasnâ€™t even a dog whistleâ€. He also had criticism lined up for media organisations, accusing some of failing to   to his standards. Mr. Remnick said: â€œI have my part to play as a journalist, and to publish fact, to investigate deeply, to speak the truth as we see it, to check facts, to live in a   world  â€”   which not all journalism does. â€œIt never did, and now itâ€™s even more chaotic and bizarre, and a lot of whatâ€™s entering into the world of political discourse  â€”   not least the Trump world  â€”   is this notion of   based news  â€¦     Trump himself has trafficked in these conspiracy theories whether itâ€™s about the Chinese and global warming or about any number of other thingsâ€. Ironically, the journalist also had a critical word for his BBC interviewer. When asked whether the USA had a unique problem in not having a media organisation that the majority could trust in, he hit back at the BBC, remarking: â€œIf you think that French state television or the BBC in England is somehow a common narrative of the country, I think youâ€™re fooling yourself. I bet you there are a lot of people, the people in the north of England, who think the BBC is a bunch of leftiesâ€. â€œA little moustache and an armbandâ€ Completing his interview by comparing Mr. Trump with Adolf Hitler, and led on by the BBC interviewer remarking: â€œBut the conditions are there, you said  â€”   this may be how this startsâ€ Remnick said he didnâ€™t want to see a repeat of history. He said: â€œI think a lot of countries have had the circumstance of believing it could never happen here, and it happened slowly, slowly and then all at once. And part of my alarmism, if you want to call it that, was to, in my own small way, be part of a sounding of an alarm, and a   that weâ€™re not going to repeat history. â€œI donâ€™t think anybody thinks that a funny man is going to come out with a little moustache and an armband, with people marching in an odd way. No, we have a reality television billionaire whoâ€™s adopted certain ideological and characterological things that are not for the better of this country, in my view. And taken to its logical conclusion, yeah I think itâ€™s a form of American authoritarianism at stake. And I think thatâ€™s an alarm worth soundingâ€.

title: In Georgia, close isnâ€™t nearly good enough for Democrats
content: (CNN) Winning isnâ€™t everything in politics. Itâ€™s the only thing. And on Tuesday night, Democrats came up short in the   winnable special election of 2017: The suburban Atlanta 6th District of Georgia.  CNN called the race for Republican Karen Handel shortly after 10 p. m. ET, with her holding a lead of more than 10, 000 votes over Democrat Jon Ossoff. The race, which was to replace Health and Human Services Secretary Tom Price in a seat Donald Trump carried by just a single point in 2016, was the most expensive in history    as both candidates, national parties and their associated super PACs dumped tens of millions into a seat widely seen as a barometer of the national mood. The final price tag on the race soared to north of $55 million. Both candidatesâ€™ messages were entirely nationalized as well. Ossoff sought to cast Handel, who had served as secretary of state in Georgia and run unsuccessfully for governor and Senate in recent years, as a tool of Trump.  Handel similarly sought to link Ossoff to Democratic House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi of California. Although Ossoff was heavily funded by liberal donors outside the state, he never cast himself as a progressive warrior    instead putting himself in the mold of a centrist problem solver.  That was enough to get him 48% in the stateâ€™s â€jungle primaryâ€ in May in which all of the candidates from both parties ran on a single ballot. But it was not enough to push him over the top in a    race with a largely inoffensive Republican in Handel. While the race will be heavily analyzed for national repercussions and lessons    and it should be, given how much money and   both national parties did    this was also, in part, a local race. Handel was a known    if not beloved or maybe just      figure in the district thanks to her time in statewide office and her repeated unsuccessful runs for other offices.  Ossoff was a newcomer who didnâ€™t live in the district he was hoping to represent    a fact Handel and national Republicans made much of. (Nota bene: You donâ€™t have to live in the congressional district you represent you only have to live in the same state.) Neither was a very good candidate Ossoff was stiff and robotic on the trail while Handel struggled to win over voters that, ideologically, should have been hers from the start. The national implications, however, will dominate the story coming out of this race. Special elections    given their usually odd timing    are almost always a battle of base intensity between the two parties. The people who turn out to vote in a June 20 special election runoff    two months(!) after the initial vote    are hardcore partisans. The game in special elections, then, is not persuading voters who arenâ€™t sure about their views. Itâ€™s ensuring that the base is fired up and turns out. Everyone knew the Democratic base was ginned up beyond belief at the chance to send Trump a message about his performance in the first 150 days of his administration. The big question mark was whether the GOP base    perhaps worn down by Trumpâ€™s seemingly   series of   wounds    would be equally as intense. It turns out that they were motivated    as has been the case since at least 2010    by the idea of Ossoff as nothing more than a Pelosi henchman. Republican strategists successfully convinced GOP voters that a vote for Ossoff was a vote for values anathema to their own. National Democrats will tell you that the race should have never been this close    and that Ossoff even threatening Handel suggests big trouble for Republicans on the ballot next November.  But deep down they know they needed    and still need    a win in a   race in which the fight was between   and  . Along with Archie Parnellâ€™s loss Tuesday night in a South Carolina special House election, Democrats have now lost four straight specials this year where at least some within the party saw the chance for an upset. (Kansasâ€™ 4th District and Montanaâ€™s   seat are the other two.) There are no moral victories in politics. No matter what the losing side says    and they always say this    the only thing that really matters when it comes to special elections is the â€Wâ€ and the â€L.â€ Had Ossoff won, he would have become an immediate national sensation for Democrats    proof positive that the Trump agenda was being rejected even in   seats in the south. Donations to the Democratic House and Senate campaign committees would have soared. Democratic candidates on the fence about whether or not to run in 2018 would have taken the Ossoff victory as a sign that the national environment was beginning to tilt heavily in their sideâ€™s favor. Now none of that will happen. Sure, it is still possible for Democrats to retake the House in 2018. As the May 2010 special election in Pennsylvaniaâ€™s 12th District proved, a single race is not necessarily all that predictive. Democrats won that   special only to go on and lose 63 seats    and the majority    less than six months later. But as important as what Democrats wonâ€™t get is what Republicans avoid: The   panic that would have been triggered by a Handel loss. Had she come up short, any Republican incumbent in an even marginally competitive House seat would have immediately been on the phone to House Speaker Paul Ryan of Wisconsin and National Republican Congressional Committee Chair Steve Stivers of Ohio fretting over how Trump was going to cost them their jobs. Those worries will disappear    at least for the moment    with Handelâ€™s victory. So yes, this is one race. And history suggests thereâ€™s just as good a chance that it means nothing as there is that it tells us everything we need to know about Trump and the 2018 election.  But Democrats are depressed and Republicans are rejoicing. And that tells you exactly why Georgia matters.

title: Jim Brown on Why Heâ€™s â€™Pulling forâ€™ Trump: â€™He Is Going to Be for All the Peopleâ€™ - Breitbart
content: Monday, former NFL star Jim Brown appeared on ESPNâ€™s â€œSportsCenter,â€ and the Cleveland legend was asked to explain his previous comments where he said that things will eventually work out for the better now that Donald Trump has been elected as President Barack Obamaâ€™s successor.  Brown, who supported Hillary Clinton in the 2016 election, said Trump will either â€œshake things up the right wayâ€ or â€œshake things up the wrong way,â€ which would lead to a resistance. He added that he is â€œpulling forâ€ Trump, and he knows the   will â€œbe for all the people. â€ Transcript as follows:  I think that things are being shaken up. I think that people are being provoked to come out with their real feelings. I think that it looks negative a great degree, but I think that any time you put a person in a position of responsibility that their good side can come out. So, Donald is going to either be a great leader and shake things up the right way, or heâ€™s going to shake things up the wrong way and thatâ€™s going to make the great people come out and resist it. So, itâ€™s just not going to be neutral. Itâ€™s not going to lay dead. Itâ€™s going to be very provocative and Iâ€™m hoping it will be provocative in a very positive way. So, Iâ€™m pulling for the president. He is the president, and I know that he is going to be for all the people and I hope that that bravado that he presents becomes a positive energy so that we could all get behind doing the right thing. Follow Trent Baker on Twitter @MagnifiTrent

title: Exclusive-Sen. Rand Paul: Hillary Clinton â€™Has Significant Health Problemsâ€™ - Breitbart
content: Kentucky Republican Sen. Rand Paul tells Breitbart News Hillary Clinton is not in good health and she has not been forthright about her health challenges. [Paul, who has continued as a practicing eye surgeon since his 2010 election to the Senate, says itâ€™s impossible to reach a conclusion about someoneâ€™s health without an actual examination.  â€œI think she has some significant health problems â€”  I donâ€™t know what they are,â€ he said. â€œHer losing consciousness, there, which by all appearances she did lose consciousness, is not something commonly associated with pneumonia,â€ the surgeon said. The former first lady had a heat stress incident while attending the Sept. 11 Ground Zero ceremony in New York City. After the incident, the Clinton left the ceremony abruptly, which her campaign ascribed to part of her struggle with a bout of pneumonia. Videos of the Democratic nominee for president appear to show her collapsing and being hauled into a black van. Paul said he was confused by how Clintonâ€˜s doctor explained her pneumonia. â€œThe diagnosis as a something being a   infection is kind of a strange way to describe a pneumonia as well,â€ he said. â€œHer heath is an issue,â€ he said. â€œParticularly the fact that she has not been very forthcoming with it. â€ After a poor showing in the Iowa caucuses, the senator closed down his presidential campaign and focused his efforts on securing a second term in the Senate. According to the University of Virginiaâ€™s Center for Politics, Paulâ€™s seat is scored as a safe Republican seat. The senator says heâ€™s happily surprised how well GOP nominee for president Donald Trump is doing with two months left in the presidential campaign. â€œIn Kentucky, Trump is doing very well and he has narrowed the gap a lot in the battleground states,â€ he said. Paul, who is a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee,  said if the New York City developer has a good first debate, he can win the election. â€œMy advice â€”  although it has not been requested â€”  is to make the point that she is not fit to be    because she pulled the security out of Benghazi,â€ he said, Trump should also make the point that Clinton has been wrong on Iraq, Libya and Syria, which proves she lacks the wisdom and judgement to be president, he said.

title: The real story behind Uber CEO
content: (CNN) Itâ€™s a sad statement about Silicon Valley today that virtually no one there is surprised about the latest developments at Uber, including allegations of sexual harassment, or a video of the   and CEO berating an Uber driver.  These are only the most recent in a long line of incidents from a company that has celebrated disruption above community, and prized money, power and control above morality.  The natural question is: How can a company like Uber get away with such egregious behavior over and over again?  Uber is a poster child of this Silicon Valley era: As long as the business is growing, companies can be amoral at best, immoral at worst. Until companies like Uber move in the direction of a stronger corporate governance, that is unlikely to change.  First, some context. I have some personal experience with the company. Like many, I once loved Uberâ€™s service.  Then, one night in 2011, I was in an Uber in New York when I started getting text messages from a woman I had only met once telling me my exact location, street by street. Dismayed, I looked around to see if she was in an adjacent car.  It turned out she was at the launch event for Uberâ€™s Chicago operation, and my identity was displayed on a screen, along with other â€tech notables,â€ as the woman described it. Furious for the violation of my privacy, I immediately stopped using Uber.  Later, after seeing Uber do a range of unethical things such as create and cancel 5, 550 Lyft rides, I wrote about my experience, asking whether Uber could be trusted. When that blog post went viral, an editor suggested I get in touch with Uber   and CEO Travis Kalanick, and give him a chance to respond.  I did just that, but he never replied to my emails. Itâ€™s no secret that Kalanick, who actively shapes Uberâ€™s culture, is known for treating people as a means to an end.  I have heard the companyâ€™s culture described to me routinely by Kalanickâ€™s colleagues as â€toxic.â€ One can only imagine what it would be like to be a woman inside Uber. Lawsuits will pile up soon enough, and that may be the only thing that will change Uber.   The real story about Uberâ€™s egregious behavior starts with weak corporate governance, especially in an era in which some Silicon Valley founders take nearly total control of their companies.  Google founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin popularized a â€  share structureâ€ whereby their shares hold 10 times as much voting power as common shares, while giving no voting rights to employee shares. Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg followed suit, allowing him to maintain control as well, as did Snap in preparing for its IPO. These structures take power away from everyone but the founders.  Uberâ€™s share structure isnâ€™t made public, but make no mistake: Kalanick completely controls Uber, including the board. Three of the board members, including Kalanick, are insiders, including another member of the infamous â€ â€ (his      and exclusively male    colleagues). Another newer board member, Arianna Huffington, wants to help address the accusations of harassment, but Iâ€™m told she doesnâ€™t have real power on the board beyond a close relationship with Kalanick. I am not even sure if Uberâ€™s board, including venture capitalist Bill Gurley of Benchmark, can fire Kalanick.   But thatâ€™s exactly what needs to happen: A fish rots from the head, and Uberâ€™s problems begin with Kalanick. Silicon Valley doesnâ€™t do   very well, but every toxic company and founder is enabled by a whole array of stakeholders. The influential angel investor Chris Sacca, who reportedly had a personal falling out with Kalanick some time ago, owns 4% of Uber. Last week, Sacca tweeted to Susan Fowler, whose blog about harassment while working at Uber started this latest PR storm, â€This is awful. Iâ€™m very sorry it happened to you. I canâ€™t imagine how that must have felt and still feels now.â€ When Sacca was then asked in a reply tweet what Uber investors (such as himself) can do moving forward, Sacca tweeted: â€Well, as you might have read, I have zero say in how that company is run. Frustrating.â€  What a weak  . Sacca didnâ€™t hesitate to use a personal blog to voice about Twitter, where he is also an investor.  Instead, he set of a media firestorm by writing an 8, 500 word manifesto about what Twitter should do. It was seen as a direct critique of Twitterâ€™s   Dick Costolo, who resigned a week later. If Sacca is so frustrated about the situation at Uber now, whereâ€™s the manifesto this time?  I want to hear it. The obvious difference between Uber today and Twitter then is that Twitter was struggling, while Uberâ€™s business continues to perform. Uberâ€™s enablers are obviously focused on cashing in someday. Their actions show that aside from a few rare exceptions, Uberâ€™s investors are going to stay silent publicly, no matter how egregious the incident. Or they will defend him, as Inside. com founder and Uber investor Jason Calacanis has done, telling CNBC that Kalanick â€is going to turn into one of those legendary CEOs that we have seen like Bill Gates . .. people are not perfect, they need to improve and I think heâ€™s on that journey.â€   In this era, money routinely trumps everything else in Silicon Valley and so much of America.  If you only have principles when itâ€™s beneficial to your wallet, you donâ€™t have principles. If only Silicon Valley had better mirrors. I was there when Uber began. One night in 2009, at a little jazz bar on Fillmore Street in San Francisco, I was shown the first prototype of the Uber app by   Garrett Camp, a very creative guy, back when it was just two red dots blinking to represent two San Francisco black cars. Neither of us could have dreamed that night just how big an opportunity was ahead. So as not to squander that opportunity, now is the time for a new generation of adult leaders to step up, so the needed changes can be made. I do believe Uber can change. But Travis Kalanick needs to go first. There are some very talented and impressive people and leaders inside the company.  If changes canâ€™t be made because one person controls everything, then we should all be very concerned. An earlier version of this piece listed Peter Sims as the author of â€True North.â€ He is the   along with Bill George.

title: MILO: â€™Feminists are Disappearingâ€™ So Fast That â€™Soon They Will Be Endangeredâ€™ - Breitbart
content: During his show at the University of Colorado, Boulder, tonight, Breitbart Senior Editor MILO claimed that feminists are disappearing so rapidly, theyâ€™ll soon be classed as an endangered species.[  â€œCU Boulder is an important university for me to speak at. Your mascot is the Buffalo. A large ugly beast that is quickly disappearing from the American landscape. Just like feminists!â€ proclaimed MILO. â€œYou may think Iâ€™m kidding, but feminists are disappearing. Honestly, itâ€™s really sad you guys!â€ â€œJust 18% of American women identify as feminist, and that number is rapidly dropping,â€ he concluded. â€œSoon they will be so endangered we really will treat them like buffaloes and keep them in zoos. â€ Written from prepared remarks. Milo wears tan shirt by UNCL, $55. White womenâ€™s suit jacket by Calvin Klein, $60. White jeans by Robin, $550. Limited edition Timberlands, $180. Louis Vuitton belt, $350. Silver Versace shades, $340. Chains and pearls, too much to count. Charlie Nash is a reporter for Breitbart Tech. You can follow him on Twitter @MrNashington or like his page at Facebook.

title: Gawker Is Said to Be Sold to Univision in a $135 Million Bid - The New York Times
content: Gawker Media, whose fierce independence afforded it an unsparing approach to web journalism that influenced news organizations across the internet and the wider media world, was sold to Univision at auction on Tuesday, giving the freewheeling company an outside owner for the first time since its founding 14 years ago. Univision bid $135 million to beat out the digital media publisher Ziff Davis, according to three people with direct knowledge of the deal who spoke on condition of anonymity because the price had not been made public. A bankruptcy judge is to officially approve the sale at a hearing later this week. The sale came two months after Gawker filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy, a concession to the financial pressure the company faces from a $140 million legal judgment in an    lawsuit by the former professional wrestler Hulk Hogan, whose real name is Terry G. Bollea. Making matters worse for Gawker was Peter Thiel, the billionaire Silicon Valley entrepreneur, who acknowledged after the Hogan trial that he had funded the lawsuit and was providing financial support for other legal cases against the company. Univision will not assume the $140 million judgment. Univision, best known for its   television network, has recently moved aggressively to expand its online portfolio, and adding Gawkerâ€™s sites fits with its plans to extend its reach beyond   viewers. Univision bought a large stake in The Onion this year and acquired full control of Fusion, the news site and cable channel that it started with the Walt Disney Company in 2013. Univision also owns other digital media companies, including The Root, a site focused on   issues. In a statement, Nick Denton, Gawkerâ€™s founder and chief executive, said: â€œI am pleased that our employees are protected and will continue their work under new ownership  â€”   disentangled from the legal campaign against the company. We could not have picked an acquirer more devoted to vibrant journalism. â€ Univision declined to comment. For Gawker, the sale is the end of an era. Founded in 2002 by Mr. Denton, a former journalist for The Financial Times, the site attracted young journalists who took on articles that traditional media organizations were sometimes reluctant to pursue. The company had its critics, who said its sites skirted the boundaries of good taste. It initially had only two sites  â€”   Gawker, a news and gossip site that largely covered New York media and society, and Gizmodo, a gadgets and technology blog. What journalists initially lacked in monetary compensation, they made up for in a kind of industry cachet. Employees went on to found influential sites like The Awl and work at publications like The New Yorker and Time. â€œOne thing that has always been true about Gawker is that it was an amazing incubator of talent,â€ said Adam Moss, the editor in chief of New York magazine, which has hired many former Gawker journalists. He added, â€œTo a large extent, the voice that they worked out at the beginning became a kind of template for the way people talk on the web. â€ Mr. Denton was known for saying that journalists too often share the most interesting stories they know only with each other at the bar after work, and the company held the value of entertaining readers seemingly above all else. Over the years, Gawker Media espoused a gossipy, wry tone that often made much of the traditional media seem  . The company blogs now include Jezebel, which is aimed at women, and Deadspin, the sports site. But Gawkerâ€™s    approach has also been to its detriment. Mr. Bollea sued Gawker Media in 2012 over its publication of a video that showed him having sex with the wife of a friend. He has been unable to collect from Gawker on the $140 million judgment because of its bankruptcy filing. Mr. Denton, who is personally liable for $10 million and jointly liable for $115 million, filed for bankruptcy this month, listing $10 million to $50 million in assets and $100 million to $500 million in liabilities. Gawker had revenue of $17. 8 million for the year through July 21, according to filings in connection with the bankruptcy. It reported $48. 7 million in revenue in 2015 and $43. 8 million in 2014. Mr. Thielâ€™s battle with the company began in 2007, when Valleywag, one of Gawkerâ€™s   blogs, wrote a post saying he was gay. â€œI had begun coming out to people I knew, and I planned to continue on my own terms,â€ Mr. Thiel wrote in an   in The New York Times that was published online on Monday. â€œInstead, Gawker violated my privacy and cashed in on it. â€ He wrote that he was â€œproud to have contributed financial supportâ€ to Mr. Bolleaâ€™s case and would continue to support him â€œuntil his final victory. â€ Last summer, after Gawker published and then removed an article about a married male media executive who sought to hire a gay escort, the company was thrown into turmoil over disagreement about whether the post should have been taken down. Two top editors resigned, and Mr. Denton vowed to make the site nicer. Since the verdict in the Hogan case was handed down by a Florida jury in March, Gawkerâ€™s typical defiance has been tinged with resignation. During a party in July at The Box, a burlesque club in Lower Manhattan, the drinks flowed freely, and so did cheeky jokes about Mr. Thiel and the companyâ€™s bankruptcy. Last week, at its offices near Union Square, Gawker held its final party as an independent company. It was billed as a   affair  â€”   the wine and beer were gone by 8 p. m.  â€”   and the mood was somewhere between reunion and Irish wake. â€œWe have shown with our backs against the wall the kind of character and determination and verve and style that I think we can absolutely be proud of,â€ Mr. Denton told a crowd that had assembled on the large    area that has become the companyâ€™s default gathering place. â€œIn a week, weâ€™re going to know the identity of the companyâ€™s new owner, and Iâ€™m hopeful and confident that the parent company that the sites will be under will allow them to thrive. â€ In a note to employees, Vivek Shah, the chief executive of Ziff Davis, said his company had withdrawn from the auction â€œonce we felt the price and terms exceeded our threshold. â€ When Gawker filed for bankruptcy, Ziff Davis submitted a $90 million offer for the company. A   stalking horse bidder, Ziff Davis would have assumed ownership of Gawker if no other bidder had emerged. As part of its agreement for being the first bidder, Ziff Davis will collect a $2. 475 million breakup fee. It was not clear what the sale would mean for Mr. Denton. Whether he stays on at Univision may not be up to him, and there have been indications that he may be ready to step away. In the last year, Heather Dietrick, Gawker Mediaâ€™s president and general counsel, has taken on more of a leadership role. It was also not clear whether Univision would hold on to Gawker. com, the flagship site that was at the center of the Hogan suit. Under Univision, Gawker will become a relatively small part of a large company. That could work in Gawkerâ€™s favor if it is allowed to operate on its own, without too much oversight from its new parent. But Univision, which has indicated in the past that it planned to go public, could also reshape Gawker in its own image. Gawkerâ€™s   business was also a draw for Univision. Univision and Gawker had been in discussions about a potential investment before the Hogan trial, but those talks collapsed.

title: GOP: â€™Permanent Ground Gameâ€™ Working with Trump Campaign Gains Seen In Key States - Breitbart
content: After Mitt Romney lost in 2012, Reince Priebus,  the chairman of the Republican National Committee promised he would build a permanent GOP ground game that would be ready in 2016 to compete against the Democrat partyâ€™s overwhelming     machine. [Now, a party representative says the   effort is coming together and delivering concrete results for both the party and the partyâ€™s nominee for president Donald Trump, as the states ramp up their early voting and absentee ballot requests.  â€œOur ground game is working    with the Trump campaign,â€ the spokesman said. â€œThe RNC continues to work hard for the nominee and the entire Republican Party ticket in order to get voters to the polls. â€ The GOP field operation was completely rebuilt, starting in 2013, with party operatives sent to key battleground states and kept there for the   engaging, registering and turning out voters for the Republican Party, he said. The operatives also contributed to the partyâ€™s national database of voters. â€œThe fact that the GOP has been â€˜permanentlyâ€™ in the field for years, means that we have had a tremendous head start on the Clinton campaign and are still in the lead,â€ he said. In Florida, the party suspended operations Wednesday, so that its people could focus on their own safety and the safety of their loved ones as Hurricane Matthew battered the state, the spokesman said. But, before the stand down for Matthew, Republican operatives in the Sunshine State had submitted more than 335, 000 more requests for absentee ballots than in the 2012 election cycle, which gives the GOP an advantage of 84, 435 absentee ballot requests more than the requests handled by the Democrats, the spokesman said. In 2012, President Barack Obama won Florida by less than 75, 000 votes. From 2012, Republicans have added 262, 000 more voters than Democrats in Florida, he said. The representative said in Pennsylvania, GOP operatives have been catching up with Democrats. In 11 of of the 14 days before the call, Republicans have requested more absentee ballots than Democrats, he said. â€œThis turns the Democratic advantage to less than 1, 000 in a state that has gone Blue for the last two decades. â€ The spokesman said in the Keystone State, Republicans have   Democrats in September, adding 30, 000 new voters to the rolls that month. In the last four years, Republicans have added 223, 552 voters in the state. In September, Republicans out registered Democrats and New Mexico and Iowa, too, he said. In Iowa, Democrats have been underperforming their 2012 results, he said. Wednesday alone, the GOP submitted absentee ballot 5, 000 more requests than the Democrats in Iowa. There are 39, 000 more registered Republicans in Iowa than in 2012, he said. Democratic absentee ballot requests in Iowa are off 51 percent from 2012, he said. In Michigan, Republicans have a 59, 000 request advantage for absentee ballots, he said. The pace of requests in Michigan for the last 14 days was    the spokesman said. â€œThis is a flip from the previous two weeks, when Democrats were leading. â€ In the three days before the conference call, absentee ballot requests in North Carolina from Republicans have been 1, 902 more than from Democrats, where the GOP is already in the lead, he said. In the last week of September, GOP volunteers and operatives have knocked on more than one million doors. he said. Before Hillary Clinton accepted the Democratic nomination for president, RNC operatives and staff had logged more than 1. 2 million hours of organizing, the spokesman said.

title: United Airlines CEO has finally apologized
content: â€™  â€™ â€   United Airlines CEO Oscar Munoz on Tuesday released another   statement  of a     passenger from one of his airlineâ€™s flights over the   weekend. â€ â€™   After  on Monday, Munoz   has finally apologized to the customer, who has been . â€™ â€™   â€Like you, I continue to be disturbed by what happened on this   flight and I deeply apologize to the customer forcibly removed   and to all the customers aboard,â€ Munoz said. â€I want you to know   that we take full responsibility and we will work to make it   right.â€ â€™ â€™   The tone of Munozâ€™â€™s latest statement is a departure from  which apologized only for having   to â€ â€ certain passengers. In a later letter, he   reaffirmed his support for his employees. â€™ â€   Tuesdayâ€™s statement eschews corporate and legal jargon in favor   of more conciliatory language. â€ â€™â€™ â€™   Public fury about the behavior of United and the aviation   officials has reached a fever pitch over the past two days, with   many vowing to boycott the airline. â€™ â€™   The statement reads: â€™ â€™United Airlines CEO Oscar Munoz on Tuesday. ..â€™ â€™â€™ â€™â€™ â€™â€™

title: Hurricane Matthew looks ominous from space
content: â€™  â€™ â€™   Hurricane Matthew is barreling into southeastern United States as   a  category 3 storm. â€™ â€™   Meteorologist Eric Holthaus, in  on Thursday  â€”   when the   cyclone was stronger, yet expected to weaken  â€”   said â€Matthew   is a storm unlike any yet seenâ€ in some parts of Florida. â€™ â€™   â€Since weather records began in 1851,  (Category 4, with   sustained winds of at least 135 mph that the National Hurricane   Center  as   â€™â€™catastrophicâ€™â€™) has ever made landfall in Florida north of West   Palm Beach,â€ Holthaus said. â€™ â€™   The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)   hurricane hunters who are  and an international fleet of   satellites are keeping close tabs on the situation. â€™ â€™   The above image is a composite of several images taken by    around 8 a. m. EDT on Friday,   October 7, 2016. Because it was taken in the dark, itâ€™â€™s 100% not     : Itâ€™â€™s infrared weather data layered on top of NASAâ€™â€™s   â€â€ satellite images. â€™ â€™   The following image is a composite made in daylight by NOAA   satellites on Wednesday, October 5. The large size of Matthew   compared to nearby landmasses is clear: â€™ â€™  â€™ â€™   NOAA and NASA also provided this   image: â€™ â€™  â€™ â€   And this is an animated sequence showing Matthewâ€™s path from   October  : â€ â€™ â€™ â€™   Astronauts and cosmonauts are also getting  of   the storm from the International Space Station, as they fly about   200 miles above it every 90 minutes: â€™ â€™  â€™ â€™   Hurricane hunters who flew through Matthew on Friday morning    and even stronger gusts. â€™ â€™   The NOAA said on Friday morning that Matthew is â€huggingâ€ onto   Floridaâ€™â€™s eastern coast and headed for a destructive spree up the   shoreline at a speed of about 13 mph. â€™ â€™   The most recent computer simulations of the storm suggest it   could blow out to sea, loop back, and  with whatever remnants are left. â€™ â€   The National Hurricane Center (NHC) has also issued a hurricane   warning for Georgiaâ€™s and much of South Carolinaâ€™s coasts: â€ â€™  â€™ â€™   In a  NOAA said the storm could have   â€potentially disastrous impacts for Florida.â€ Areas that bear the   brunt of the storm can expect torrential rain, incredibly   damaging winds, powerful storm surges, and flooding. â€™

title: One in 6 American Adults Say They Have Taken Psychiatric Drugs, Report Says - The New York Times
content: About one in six American adults reported taking at least one psychiatric drug, usually an antidepressant or an   medication, and most had been doing so for a year or more, according to a new analysis. The report is based on 2013 government survey data on some 37, 421 adults and provides the   snapshot of prescription drug use for psychological and sleep problems to date. â€œI follow this area, so I knew the numbers would be high,â€ said Thomas J. Moore, a researcher at the Institute for Safe Medication Practices, a nonprofit in Alexandria, Va. and the lead author of the analysis, which was published Monday in JAMA Internal Medicine. â€œBut in some populations, the rates are extraordinary. â€ Mr. Moore and his   Donald R. Mattison of Risk Sciences International in Ottawa, combed household survey and insurance data compiled by the federal Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality. They found that one in five women had reported filling at least one prescription that year  â€”   about two times the number of men who had  â€”   and that whites were about twice as likely to have done so than blacks or Hispanics. Nearly 85 percent of those who had gotten at least one drug had filled multiple prescriptions for that drug over the course of the year studied, which the authors considered   use. â€œTo discover that eight in 10 adults who have taken psychiatric drugs are using them long term raises safety concerns, given that thereâ€™s reason to believe some of this continued use is due to dependence and withdrawal symptoms,â€ Mr. Moore said. Dr. Mark Olfson, a professor of psychiatry at Columbia University, who was not involved in the study, said the new analysis provided a clear, detailed picture of current usage: â€œIt reflects a growing acceptance of and reliance on prescription medicationsâ€ to manage common emotional problems, he said. The most commonly used type of drug was an antidepressant like Zoloft and Celexa, followed by an   or sleeping pill like Xanax and Ambien. All of these drugs can have withdrawal effects, including panic attacks and sleep problems, for many people on them long term. The prescribing of most   pills is strongly regulated in this and other countries because the drugs can be habit forming. Usage rates were also higher with increased age, with one in four people of retirement age reporting at least one prescription. This is a growing concern among some doctors, as the incidence of diagnosable mental problems, with the exception of insomnia, tends to be much lower in elderly people than in young adults. The increased rates in this group are most likely due in part to the fact that most elderly people get psychiatric drugs from their primary care doctor, who often prescribe for episodic conditions like mild depression and insomnia. â€œParticularly for this group, we need to be mindful of the   in prescribing,â€ Dr. Olfson said. â€œThese are not benign drugs. â€

title: From Bill Murray Chanting â€™America!â€™ to Mike Eruzione Wearing Penny Loafers, Ryder Cup Runneth Over in Strange - Breitbart
content: CHASKA, Minn.  â€”   From Bill Murray playfully chanting â€œAmerica! America!â€ to drunken rowdies tauntingly serenading Rory McIlroy with â€œSweet Carolineâ€ to a female military band singer belting out Elle Kingâ€™s â€œExâ€™s and Ohâ€™sâ€ at an ostensibly   event, the Ryder Cup offered plenty of strange sounds and sights this weekend. [Tiger Woods kept a low profile, save for his garish sunglasses, all week as he is working his way back into polite society. He barely spoke at the press conference and kept his celebrations low key. Weâ€™ll see if a humbled Tiger plays better golf but I think his years of competing for major championships are over.   America needs to come up with better chants. The hokey â€œI believe that we will winâ€ chant was monotonous and caused eye rolls from many in the crowd. And as a patriot, I love hearing â€œThe Star Spangled Bannerâ€ sung proudly  â€¦    . .but not every 20 minutes.  Rory McIlroy had the misfortune of dealing with hecklers on almost every single hole from his introduction Friday on the first tee where a few spectators yelled out â€œRory is shortâ€ to a psychotic fan running up to him Saturday between the seventh and eighth green and yelling, â€œSuck a d*** Rory!â€ Whatever happened to Minnesota nice? Idiotic golf fans have been getting away with shouting â€œbababooeyâ€ and â€œmashed potatoâ€ after every tee shot. Itâ€™s regressed from this silliness to the vile, vulgar insults a class act endured this weekend. Sad.  Mike Eruzione of 1980 USA Hockey fame is certainly wringing every bit of celebrity out of that game played 36 years ago. Good for him, I guess. He was a featured guest and walked 18 holes with Phil Mickelson. He chose to wear black leather penny loafers with no socks â€”  a strange choice when youâ€™re going to walk 18 holes.  Warning to those who plan to attend a Ryder Cup in the future. Donâ€™t expect to see much golf. With the immense crowds and the fact that on Friday and Saturday there are only four groups out at a time, you just donâ€™t get to see many golf shots. Itâ€™s not like a regular tournament where there is play on every hole. That said, the spirit and camaraderie of the event makes waiting around enjoyable. Dan Redmond can be found on twitter @danfromdc

title: Valeantâ€™s collapse is a happy story â€” it shows companies with no real economic purpose will fail
content: â€™In a healthy capitalist system, if the thing you are doing is not adding value in the real economy, you should not be able to make money at it for very long.â€™ â€Unfortunately, thatâ€™s not always how it works. But the   â€”   a company whose primary business is not developing drugs but finding ways to charge more for existing ones, and whose stock price is down 89% from its   high  â€”   is a good sign that    strategies will fail in the long run.â€ â€There are two separate crises facing Valeant. One is an accounting scandal: did the company use improper techniques to inflate its revenues? This is an interesting question, but as Bloombergâ€™s Matt Levine notes, .â€ â€Valeantâ€™s other crisis goes to the core substance of its business. Like a larger version of Martin Shkreli, it has a strategy of acquiring existing drugs and jacking up their prices. In many cases, these drugs are not under patent, meaning a competitor could legally offer the same product and charge less, but for a variety of regulatory and market reasons that did not happen quickly.â€ â€™â€™ â€™This strategy is all about exploiting mistakes by other players in the market: The Valeant bet was that competitors will fail to enter markets in which it is charging egregious prices, and that consumers and medical insurers (including the government) will not pay close attention to the prices they are paying. â€™ â€™The problem with a business strategy predicated on mistakes by others is that the mistakes may eventually stop.â€™ â€™As anger over price gouging by the drug industry rose, insurers cracked down on pharmacies and pharmacy benefit managers that pushed overpriced Valeant drugs. One key purpose of  may have been to confuse insurers about who was filling prescriptions, but that jig is up. Meanwhile, politicians  have said they will find ways to stop Valeant from charging so much.â€™ â€™Lots of businesses can become political punching bags for their pricing. But when oil companies or software companies or bona fide pharmaceutical companies come under political attack, they point to the useful things they do that generate real economic value, and warn that political interference will make those things stop.
