Still, Bilitzke said heâ€™s not yet healthy enough to be put up for adoption. â€At this point itâ€™s too early to say what the course of action will be,â€ she said. â€But because he is stable, we are encouraged.â€ In an interview with CNN affiliate WDIV, Ramos said the dog appeared to be well socialized and behaved. â€He gets along with everybody that heâ€™s encountered so far,â€ Ramos said. â€And despite his injuries, he still has a fantastic attitude.â€ Though he doesnâ€™t yet have a permanent home, the animal does now have a name: Baron. â€He needs a name,â€ Bilitzke said. â€We want to give him a voice, so he needs a name.â€

title: Election night isnâ€™t a party for presidential transition staff
content: Washington (CNN) Away from the balloon drops of victory and somber concessions of defeat on election night, a small club of political animals will be watching under very different circumstances. For the few hundred people who have been working for Hillary Clinton and Donald Trumpâ€™s transition efforts, the results of the election either mean the beginning of some of the most intense months of their life    or the end of a heap of prep work that heads to the shredder. They have spent the past several weeks feverishly drafting options for what a Trump or Clinton administration would look like, assembling names for potential appointments, figuring out how to execute policy promises and drawing up an agenda for the first 100 days in office.   The winners have to keep in mind theyâ€™re working bright and early the next morning. â€I remember on election night I could not go to Chicago and watch the victory party because were we to win, I would have to open the transition office next morning,â€ recalled Christopher Lu, President Barack Obamaâ€™s transition executive director.  What is a presidential transition? He said he watched the returns from DC.  â€I recall being at a bar up on Capitol Hill and people asked me what I did, and I said I worked for Sen. Obama and I think they all said, â€™Why arenâ€™t you in Chicago? â€™â€ said Lu, now the deputy secretary of Labor. â€I remember shortly after the race was called at 11 p. m. on election night, I got a phone call from the head of the General Services Administration,. .. â€™We have certified that Barack Obama is the   of the United States and we essentially give you keys to a federal building and access to federal funding,â€™â€ Lu said. â€While everybody was celebrating, I knew that the next morning I had to get up and open an office at 9 a. m. and so your election night certainly has a different tone than the other people who youâ€™re working with.â€ That sentiment was echoed by Clay Johnson III, who oversaw the transition of President George W. Bush. Like Lu    who has known Obama since law school    Johnson is an old friend of Bushâ€™s, going back to their high school days at at Andover.  Johnson said Bush charged him with planning for a future administration in June 1999    16 months before it would happen. So election night was basically a confirmation of a mindset he had held for months.  â€The campaign people, their work is over, so they are besides themselves with jubilation and just so happy,â€ Johnson said. â€Election night, when the personâ€™s successful, only confirms the mindset that the transition people have had for the last three, four, five months, that this candidate is the person thatâ€™s going to be the next president of the United States. Thatâ€™s nice. Thatâ€™s happy. Iâ€™m glad for them, but meanwhile, letâ€™s get back to work.â€ â€Maybe theyâ€™ll have an extra cocktail or two or congratulate their campaign buddies,â€ Johnson continued, â€but their time to celebrate is Inauguration Day. . .. Thereâ€™s a little deferred gratification for the transition people.â€ All that hard work. .. If the 2016 transitions are following the example of their predecessors, there is likely already a rough agenda for a potential   Clinton or Trump on November 9.  â€At 3 oâ€™clock on the day after the election, we were scheduled to begin decisions on who the presidentâ€™s White House staff should be, who the national security team should be and who the Cabinet members should be,â€ said Mike Leavitt, the former Utah governor who chaired Mitt Romneyâ€™s transition in 2012.  Trump transition fundraises with email from Christie, But Romney lost, and Leavitt experienced the flip side of transition watching: the heartbreak.  â€I had the benefit of getting up everyday for six or so months believing that Mitt Romney would become president of the United States,â€ Leavitt said. â€By the time we got to election night, not only did we, but other people, believed he would be  . The next morning, it was remarkable disappointment. It was hard every day for weeks not to think, â€™Today is day 17, we would have done X, Y and Z.â€™ We literally had a   schedule based on what needed to be done.â€  Disappointment was also the description from Ryan Cunningham, executive director for John Kerryâ€™s transition in 2004, when Kerry lost to Bush.  â€Itâ€™s extremely disappointing,â€ Cunningham said. â€We had done all of the work, we had our notebooks ready to go, the offices were ready for   Kerry, and we were in Boston on election night. We were in the hotel where   Kerry would have gone to make his acceptance speech and we were literally ready to sit down with him and open the notebook to page one and say, â€™Mr.   letâ€™s begin. â€™â€ Cunningham said all the work was then boxed up and the team would four years later support Obamaâ€™s transition. Leavitt turned his work into a book, â€Romney Readiness Project 2012,â€ which offers a road map for transition planning.  But even though both remember the sadness of election night, neither feels regret for the work they put in along the way.  â€Every four years someone lives the experience I did,â€ Leavitt said. â€Thatâ€™s a difficult part of a democracy, but one that we all ought to be grateful for.â€

title: How Police Found Second Bomb, and a â€˜Total Containment Vesselâ€™ Hauled It Away - The New York Times
content: After the explosion on West 23rd Street on Saturday night, the police did what they typically do when they suspect a bomb has gone off. They spread out and began looking for unexploded bombs  â€”   what those on the New York Police Departmentâ€™s bomb squad call â€œsecondaries. â€ Officers began searching block by block, going as far south as 14th Street and as far north as 34th Street. A few hours into the effort, two state troopers participating in the search found what appeared to be one, on West 27th Street, about four blocks above the explosion. On the sidewalk on the north side of the street, there was a pressure cooker with a cellphone attached to it, law enforcement officials said. A photograph of the device shared on social media shows the cookware, with wires and the cellphone. The authorities confirmed that the photo was authentic. The police have not said whether a tip helped lead the troopers to the device or whether the officers discovered it entirely unaided. â€œThey circled the block and they parked their vehicle and actually walked down the block, and thatâ€™s how they found it,â€ the cityâ€™s new police commissioner, James P. Oâ€™Neill, said at a news conference on Sunday. â€œThey did a great job. â€ The police used a robot to inspect the device and place it in what is called a â€œtotal containment vessel,â€ a spherical chamber hitched to a police truck. The vehicle set off east on West 27th Street around 2:25 a. m. turning north on Avenue of the Americas and then heading toward the Bronx. The total containment vessel is essentially an   diving vessel, Lt. Mark Torre, the commanding officer of the departmentâ€™s bomb squad, said in an interview in July. â€œInstead of keeping the pressure out and keeping you alive in five fathoms of water, it keeps the pressure in,â€ he explained. Should a bomb explode inside, tiny vents allow pressure to escape. â€œIt sounds like a hammer hitting a piece of steel,â€ he said. It was not clear how many such vessels the department has, but it appears to be at least three. In 2014, the department put out an advertisement in search of a company that â€œfeels it can provide services necessary to refurbish three existing total containment vessels,â€ according to contracting records. Such vessels are often capable of containing a blast of 25 pounds of TNT or more, and they are increasingly a common piece of equipment for police agencies across the country. Even the campus force for the University of Georgia has one. Because the purpose of the vessel is to contain the blast, the bomb squad does not typically close streets when it drives through the city with a bomb in the containment vessel. The police brought the device to Rodmanâ€™s Neck, a peninsula in the Bronx where the police have a facility. It is where many suspicious packages and much unexploded ordnance ends up, for the bomb squad to disassemble or blow up in a controlled environment. The police have said little about what the bomb squad has learned about the device found on West 27th Street. It appeared to resemble in some ways the devices used in the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings. The Boston Marathon bombers, the brothers Tamerlan and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, appeared to have gotten their plans for the two   bombs they placed at the finishing line from Inspire, the   magazine published online by Al Qaedaâ€™s branch in Yemen. Each issue includes    instructions on building bombs and mounting attacks. By Sunday afternoon, the bomb squad was struggling to find a way to open the device that minimized the risk of an explosion, a law enforcement official said, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss the continuing investigation. Much about the device remained unknown. But if it was similar to the one that exploded on West 23rd Street, it was powerful. That explosion sent a Dumpster well over 100 feet down the street, the official said. On Sunday, after the police used a small controlled explosion to disable the device, it was being sent to the Federal Bureau of Investigationâ€™s laboratory in Quantico, Va.

title: Lifelong Republican to Speaker Ryan: Obamacare saved my life
content: (CNN) An audience member at CNNâ€™s town hall with House Speaker Paul Ryan said President Barack Obama saved his life through the Affordable Care Act. Jeff Jeans of Sedona, Arizona, told Ryan, who is leading the fight in the House to repeal Obamacare, that he had been a small business owner and â€lifelong Republicanâ€ before being diagnosed with cancer, with just six weeks to live, at age 49.  â€I want to thank President Obama from the bottom of my heart because I would be dead if it werenâ€™t for him,â€ Jeans told Ryan on Thursday night, receiving applause from the audience. He posed a question: â€Why would you repeal the Affordable Care Act Without a replacement?â€ Ryan said Republicans do not plan to repeal the law without better legislation.  â€Oh, we wouldnâ€™t do that,â€ said Ryan. â€We want to replace it with something better.â€ â€I am glad you are standing here,â€ the speaker added.

title: â€™Grave concernsâ€™ over the Trump administrationâ€™s view toward civil rights prompts new investigation
content: â€™  â€™ â€™   An independent, bipartisan federal commission tasked with   advising President Donald Trump and Congress on     issues approved a   investigation that will examine how   the Trump administrationâ€™â€™s â€current budgets and staffing levels   allow civil rights offices to perform,â€  reported   Friday. â€™ â€™   The United States Commission on Civil Rights unanimously approved   an investigation, citing concerns about the impacts that budget   cuts and staffing shortages could have on agencies designed to   uphold   protections â€™ â€™   The investigation was prompted after funding and personnel cuts   were announced, some as high as 23% in departments that oversee     issues. â€™ â€™   â€These proposed cuts would result in a dangerous reduction of   civil rights enforcement across the country, leaving communities   of color, LGBT people, older people, people with disabilities,   and other marginalized groups exposed to greater risk of   discrimination,â€ the statement said. â€™ â€™   â€For 60 years, Congress has charged the Commission to monitor   Federal civil rights enforcement and recommend necessary change,â€   said commission chair Catherine Lhamon. â€We take this charge   seriously, and we look forward to reporting our findings to   Congress, the President, and the American people.â€ â€™ â€™â€™ â€™   The United States Commission on Civil Rights listed seven   entities for their concern, including the Department of   Education, Department of Justice, Department of Housing and Urban   Development, and the Environmental Protection Agency. â€™ â€™   â€Actions by the [Department of Justice] indicate it is minimizing   its civil rights efforts,â€ the statement said. â€For example, a   majority of the Commission criticized DOJâ€™s decision to site   Immigrations and Customs Enforcement officers in courthouses as a   dangerous impediment to access to justice for all Americans.â€ â€™ â€™   Ultimately, the power to enforce any changes made after the   investigation will be in the hands of Congress, according to NBC.   The commission is scheduled to report their findings at the end   of 2019. â€™ â€™An independent, bipartisan federal commission. ..â€™ â€™â€™ â€™â€™ â€™â€™

title: VIDEO: Three Suspected Attackers Beat, Rob Man in Broad Daylight in Philadelphia - Breitbart
content: Three suspected attackers robbed and beat a man in broad daylight on a Philadelphia sidewalk, according to surveillance footage released by the Philadelphia police.[  Police are still searching for the three male suspects, who are shown in the video attacking and robbing the    victim as he left a restaurant where he was looking for a job, the Daily Mail reported. The attack took place around 12:30 p. m. in Philadelphiaâ€™s Kensington neighborhood on the 3500 block of B Street. â€œIt hits really hard when you see something with that level of brutality, and what appears to be that random looking, and again in broad daylight conditions. It does get a little startling,â€ police Captain Sekou Kinebrew told WPVI. The three suspected attackers can be seen peering into storefront windows before the assault, when one of the men wearing a cast on his right arm appears to signal to the other two men as heâ€™s looking into one of the windows. The other two males turn around, as the victim exits the restaurant. The victim told WTXF that he was stopping by the restaurant to pick up a job application. Suddenly, the three attackers knock him to the ground, beating him and stomping on him until he became unconscious. Meanwhile, one of the attackers went through his pocket and stole his money, wallet, and cell phone. Police say they are unsure of whether the victim knew his attackers. The victim was taken to a hospital where he was treated for a broken nose and orbital bone and then released. Police say the suspects include a black or Hispanic male with a scruffy beard and mustache, wearing a black hat, black coat, and black sweatpants a Hispanic male with a light complexion, bushy hair, wearing a red hooded sweatshirt, red pants, and red sneakers and a   Hispanic male with a beard and mustache, a cast on his right arm, tattoos on both arms, wearing a white   black pants, and red sneakers. Detectives are urging anyone with information on the suspects to call them anonymously at   .

title: Mobile Bay boaters missing after storm
content: (CNN) Two bodies have been recovered from Mobile Bay, Alabama, after a severe storm capsized sailboats in a regatta on Saturday, U. S. Coast Guard Capt. Duke Walker said Sunday. Walker said authorities are still looking for five missing people. Maj. Steve Thompson with the Alabama Law Enforcement Agency called the effort â€a recovery operation.â€ Walker said two aircraft and numerous boats searched on Sunday. Searchers have covered more than 2, 500 miles, he said. More than 100 sailboats took part in the Dauphin Island Race on Saturday afternoon and 40 people were rescued from the water, the Coast Guard said. â€Our guys worked hard and long to rescue people,â€ Walker said. â€This is an awful tragedy and our hearts go out to the families.â€  One body was found Saturday night and another Sunday morning, he said. Walker says they believe at least one person was not from the regatta, but was a mariner on the water at the time.  Jeff Carter, deputy director of Mobile County Emergency Management, said besides overturned sailboats, one vessel hit a bridge. Coast Guard Sector Mobile received a report at approximately 4:30 p. m. Saturday that a sailing regatta in Mobile Bay had been struck by severe weather, causing several vessels to capsize and leaving a number of people in the water. The Fairhope Yacht Club sponsors the Dauphin Island Race, according to the club website. The club says this is the 57th year for the event.

title: Donald Trump wins South Carolina primary
content: â€™â€™ â€™Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump just scored his second victory of the election season by winning the South Carolina primary on Saturday.â€™ â€™Trump was declared the winner shortly after South Carolina poll sites closed at 7 p. m. EST.â€™ â€™With 73% of precincts reporting, Trump held a nearly   lead over Sens. Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz.â€™ â€™Trump began his victory speech earlier in the night by thanking his local supporters and South Carolina Lt. Gov. Henry McMaster, who endorsed him. He said heâ€™â€™d take McMaster over South Carolina Gov. Nikki Haley, who endorsed Rubio â€any time. â€â€™ â€™He then turned the stage over to his wife, Melania Trump. â€™ â€™â€Just want to say an amazing place South Carolina,â€ she said. â€Congratulations to my husband, he was working very hard, and he loves you. We love you, and we are going ahead to Nevada and we will see what happens. He will be the best president. â€â€™ â€™Then Trump had his daughter, Ivanka Trump, speak to his supporters. â€™ â€™â€Thank you South Carolina, this is an amazing, amazing night,â€ she said. â€The momentum since the beginning of this campaign has been unbelievable. . .. My father is an incredibly hard worker and he will be working for each and every one of you and together, we will make America great again. â€â€™ â€™Retaking the mic, Trump then took a second to call out political pundits who said that, once other candidates dropped out, Trump would likely be able to be taken out.â€™ â€™â€A number of the pundits said, â€™â€™Well, if a couple of the other candidates drop out, if you add their scores together itâ€™â€™s going to equal Trump,â€™â€™â€ he said. â€Theyâ€™â€™re geniuses. They donâ€™â€™t understand that as people drop out, Iâ€™â€™m going to get a lot of those votes also, so you donâ€™â€™t just add them together. â€â€™ â€™He then congratulated Cruz and Rubio for doing â€quite wellâ€ in the state.â€™ â€™â€™ â€Trumpâ€™s win is  as he just joined a very exclusive group of candidates.â€ â€™Only three Republican candidates prior ro Trump have won both the New Hampshire and South Carolina primaries in contested years. Those three, Ronald Reagan in 1980, George H. W. Bush in 1988 and 1992, and John McCain in 2008, went on to win the nomination. â€™ â€™In addition, just one South Carolina primary winner has not been the Republican nominee  â€”   former House Speaker Newt Gingrich. Gingrich won in 2012, but lost the nomination to former Massachusetts Gov. Mitt Romney.â€™ â€™Most polls had given Trump a big edge heading into the primary. He held a   lead over Rubio and Cruz, per the RealClearPolitics  there.â€™ â€™The South Carolina victory followed an easy win for Trump in New Hampshire and a   showing in Iowa. The Republican caucuses in Nevada will weigh in on the GOP primary on Tuesday.â€™ â€™Trump also tweeted that he would have been happy with a   victory:â€™ â€™â€™ â€™ â€™tâ€™tâ€™tPeople (pundits) gave me no chance in South Carolina. Now it looks like a possible win. I would be happy with a one vote victory! (HOPE)â€™tâ€™tâ€™ â€™â€™ â€™ â€™tâ€™tâ€™tWhat a great night. Thank you South Carolina, a special place with truly amazing people! LOVEâ€™tâ€™tâ€™ â€™Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump. ..â€™

title: Blue State Blues: The Debates Were Shamefully Silent on Benghazi
content: The word â€œBenghaziâ€ was never mentioned in the first presidential debate. It was only mentioned once in the second debate. And it was ignored again in the third debate. (The vice presidential debate ignored it, too. )[That sole mention of Benghazi occurred when Donald Trump brought it up in his own defense, in response to a question about why he had tweeted at three oâ€™clock in the morning. about a dispute with a former Miss Universe.  Yes, the debates were that trivial. Here, for the record, is the only mention of Benghazi: COOPER: Mr. Trump, let me follow up with you. In 2008, you wrote in one of your books that the most important characteristic of a good leader is discipline. You said, if a leader doesnâ€™t have it, quote, â€œhe or she wonâ€™t be one for very long. â€ In the days after the first debate, you sent out a series of tweets from 3 a. m. to 5 a. m. including one that told people to check out a sex tape. Is that the discipline of a good leader? TRUMP: No, there wasnâ€™t check out a sex tape. It was just take a look at the person that she built up to be this wonderful Girl Scout who was no Girl Scout. COOPER: You mentioned sex tape. TRUMP: By the way, just so you understand, when she said 3 oâ€™clock in the morning, take a look at Benghazi. She said who is going to answer the call at 3 oâ€™clock in the morning? Guess what? She didnâ€™t answer it, because when Ambassador Stevens  â€¦     COOPER: The question is, is that the discipline of a good leader? TRUMP:   â€¦     600  â€”   wait a minute, Anderson, 600 times. Well, she said she was awake at 3 oâ€™clock in the morning, and she also sent a tweet out at 3 oâ€™clock in the morning, but I wonâ€™t even mention that. But she said sheâ€™ll be awake. Whoâ€™s going  â€”   the famous thing, weâ€™re going to answer our call at 3 oâ€™clock in the morning. Guess what happened? Ambassador Stevens  â€”   Ambassador Stevens sent 600 requests for help. And the only one she talked to was Sidney Blumenthal, whoâ€™s her friend and not a good guy, by the way. So, you know, she shouldnâ€™t be talking about that. We never had â€œwhat happened at Benghazi?â€  â€”   but we did have â€œdid you tell people to check out a sex tape at 3 a. m.?â€. Trump deserves some criticism for neglecting Benghazi, which he should have brought up in every debate. But the real blame rests with the moderators. Even Fox Newsâ€™ Chris Wallace, who earned praise by conducting the only fair debate of the three, failed to mention Benghazi. Patricia Smith, mother of the late Benghazi hero Sean Smith, told me before the third debate that she hoped to hear about what happened on Sep. 11, 2012  â€”   and told me afterwards how disgusted she was that it was ignored. A simple, straightforward question would have sufficed. â€œSecretary Clinton, the Benghazi terror attack happened while you were Secretary of State. Should the voters consider that a test of your ability to perform as   ?â€ For balance, he could have asked Trump a tough  . â€œMr. Trump, you have criticized Secretary Clinton on Benghazi. But she has been in the Situation Room, and you have no experience in national security. Are you, sir, ready to be   ?â€ But the only time we heard anything about â€œ  â€ was in the first debate, when Clinton invoked the phrase  â€”   to argue that Trump was unfit to serve in that role. No one  â€”   neither the moderators, nor the candidates  â€”   mentioned it again. It might be argued that Benghazi was an issue for 2012, not 2016 that the person in charge that night was Barack Obama, not Hillary Clinton that after years of investigation there was no â€œsmoking gunâ€  â€”   â€œno scandal at all,â€ the Washington Post said. All of that could be true, and the omission of Benghazi would still be a disgrace, not only because so many of the other issues raised were so meaningless, but fundamentally because we still do not know why Americans in danger were left to die alone. What about the future? Will the next president seek the whole truth? What steps will the next president take to ensure that never happens again? How will the men who died  â€”   and saved dozens of others, thanklessly  â€”   be honored for their sacrifice? We have some idea  â€”   from portions of Trumpâ€™s speeches  â€”   but voters deserved to hear answers in the debates. History will not care whether Miss Universe once had sex on television. History will judge our neglect of the dead, and the carelessness with which we treat our future security. Joel B. Pollak is Senior    at Breitbart News. His new book, See No Evil: 19 Hard Truths the Left Canâ€™t Handle, is available from Regnery through Amazon. Follow him on Twitter at @joelpollak.

title: Donald Trumpâ€™s New York Times Interview: Full Transcript - The New York Times
content: Following is a transcript of   Donald J. Trumpâ€™s interview on Tuesday with reporters, editors and opinion columnists from The New York Times. The transcription was prepared by Liam Stack, Jonah Engel Bromwich, Karen Workman and Tim Herrera of The Times. More on the Trump transition here. ARTHUR SULZBERGER Jr. publisher of The New York Times: Thank you very much for joining us. And I want to reaffirm this is on the record. DONALD J. TRUMP,   of the United States: O. K. SULZBERGER: All right, so weâ€™re clear. We had a very nice meeting in the Churchill Room. Youâ€™re a Churchill fan, I hear? TRUMP: I am, I am. SULZBERGER: Thereâ€™s a photo of the great man behind you. TRUMP: There was a big thing about the bust that was removed out of the Oval Office. SULZBERGER: I heard youâ€™re thinking of putting it back. TRUMP: I am, indeed. I am. SULZBERGER: Wonderful. So weâ€™ve got a good collection here from our newsroom and editorial and our columnists. I just want to say we had a good, quiet, but useful and   conversation in there. So I appreciate that very much. TRUMP: I appreciate it, too. SULZBERGER: I thought maybe Iâ€™d start this off by asking if you have anything you would like to start this off with before we move to the easiest questions youâ€™re going to get this administration. [laughter] TRUMP: O. K. Well, I just appreciate the meeting and I have great respect for The New York Times. Tremendous respect. Itâ€™s very special. Always has been very special. I think Iâ€™ve been treated very rough. Itâ€™s well out there that Iâ€™ve been treated extremely unfairly in a sense, in a true sense. I wouldnâ€™t only complain about The Times. I would say The Times was about the roughest of all. You could make the case The Washington Post was bad, but every once in a while Iâ€™d actually get a good article. Not often, Dean, but every once in awhile. Look, I have great respect for The Times, and Iâ€™d like to turn it around. I think it would make the job I am doing much easier. Weâ€™re working very hard. We have great people coming in. I think youâ€™ll be very impressed with the names. Weâ€™ll be announcing some very shortly. Everybody wanted to do this. People are giving up tremendous careers in order to be subject to you folks and subject to a lot of other folks. But theyâ€™re giving up a lot. I mean some are giving up tremendous businesses in order to sit for four or maybe eight or whatever the period of time is. But I think weâ€™re going to see some tremendous talent, tremendous talent coming in. We have many people for every job. I mean no matter what the job is, we have many incredible people. I think, Reince, you can sort of just confirm that. The quality of the people is very good. REINCE PRIEBUS, Mr. Trumpâ€™s choice for chief of staff: [inaudible] TRUMP: Weâ€™re trying very hard to get the best people. Not necessarily people that will be the most politically correct people, because that hasnâ€™t been working. So we have really experts in the field. Some are known and some are not known, but theyâ€™re known within their field as being the best. Thatâ€™s very important to me. You know, Iâ€™ve been given a great honor. Itâ€™s been very tough. Itâ€™s been 18 months of brutality in a true sense, but we won it. We won it pretty big. The final numbers are coming out. Or I guess theyâ€™re coming out. Michiganâ€™s just being confirmed. But the numbers are coming out far beyond what anybodyâ€™s wildest expectation was. I donâ€™t know if it was us, I mean, we were seeing the kind of crowds and kind of, everything, the kind of enthusiasm we were getting from the people. As you probably know, I did many, many speeches that last   period. I was just telling Arthur that I went around and did speeches in the pretty much 11 different places, that were, the massive crowds we were getting. If we had a stadium that held  â€”   and most of you, many of you were there  â€”   that held 20, 000 people, weâ€™d have 15, 000 people outside that couldnâ€™t get in. So we came up with a good system  â€”   we put up the big screens outside with a very good loudspeaker system and very few people left. I would do, during the last month, two or three a day. Thatâ€™s a lot. Because thatâ€™s not easy when you have big crowds. Those speeches, thatâ€™s not an easy way of life, doing three a day. Then I said the last two days, I want to do six and seven. And Iâ€™m not sure anybody has ever done that. But we did six and we did seven and the last one ended at 1 oâ€™clock in the morning in Michigan. And we had 31, 000 people, 17, 000 or 18, 000 inside and the rest outside. This massive place in Grand Rapids, I guess. And it was an incredible thing. And I left saying: â€˜How do we lose Michigan? I donâ€™t think we can lose Michigan.â€™ And the reason I did that, it was set up only a little while before  â€”   because we heard that day that Hillary was hearing that theyâ€™re going to lose Michigan, which hasnâ€™t been lost in 38 years. Or something. But 38 years. And they didnâ€™t want to lose Michigan. So they went out along with President Obama and Michelle, Bill and Hillary, they went to Michigan late that, sort of late afternoon and I said, â€˜Letâ€™s go to Michigan.â€™ It wasnâ€™t on the schedule. So I finished up in New Hampshire and at 10 oâ€™clock I went to Michigan. We got there at 12 oâ€™clock. We started speaking around 12:45, actually, and we had 31, 000 people and I said, really, I mean, there are things happening. But we saw it everywhere. So we felt very good. we had great numbers. And we thought weâ€™re going to win. We thought we were going to win Florida. We thought we were going to win North Carolina. We did easily, pretty easily. We thought strongly we were going to win Pennsylvania. The problem is nobody had won it and it was known, as you know, the great state that always got away. Every Republican thought they were going to win Pennsylvania for 38 years and they just couldnâ€™t win it. And I thought we were going to win it. And we won it, we won it, you know, relatively easily, we won it by a number of points. Florida we won by 180, 000  â€”   was that the number, 180? PRIEBUS: [inaudible] TRUMP: More than 180, 000 voted, and votes are still coming in from the military, which we are getting about 85 percent of. So we won that by a lot of votes and, you know, we had a great victory. We had a great victory. I think it would have been easier because I see every once in awhile somebody says, â€˜Well, the popular vote.â€™ Well, the popular vote would have been a lot easier, but itâ€™s a whole different campaign. I would have been in California, I would have been in Texas, Florida and New York, and we wouldnâ€™t have gone anywhere else. Which is, I mean Iâ€™d rather do the popular vote from the standpoint  â€”   Iâ€™d think weâ€™d do actually as well or better  â€”   itâ€™s a whole different campaign. Itâ€™s like, if youâ€™re a golfer, itâ€™s like match play versus stroke play. Itâ€™s a whole different game. But I think the popular vote would have been easier in a true sense because youâ€™d go to a few places. I think thatâ€™s the genius of the Electoral College. I was never a fan of the Electoral College until now. SULZBERGER: Until now. [laughter] TRUMP: Until now. I guess now I like it for two reasons. What it does do is it gets you out to see states that youâ€™ll never see otherwise. Itâ€™s very interesting. Like Maine. I went to Maine four times. I went to Maine 2 for one, because everybody was saying you can get to 269 but there is no path to 270. We learned that was false because we ended up with what,  . PRIEBUS: Iâ€™ve got to get, weâ€™ve got to get Michigan in. TRUMP: But there is no path to 270, you have to get the one in Maine, so we kept going back to Maine and we did get the one in Maine. We kept going to Maine 2, and we went to a lot of states that you wouldnâ€™t spend a lot of time in and it does get you  â€”   we actually went to about 22 states, whereas if youâ€™re going for popular vote, youâ€™d probably go to four, or three, it could be three. You wouldnâ€™t leave New York. Youâ€™d stay in New York and youâ€™d stay in California. So thereâ€™s a certain genius about it. And I like it either way. But itâ€™s sort of interesting. But we had an amazing period of time. I got to know the country, we have a great country, weâ€™re a great, great people, and the enthusiasm was really incredible. The Los Angeles Times had a poll which was interesting because I was always up in that poll. They had something that is, I guess, a   technique in polling, it was called enthusiasm. They added an enthusiasm factor and my people had great enthusiasm, and Hillaryâ€™s people didnâ€™t have enthusiasm. And in the end she didnâ€™t get the   vote and we ended up close to 15 points, as you know. We started off at one, we ended up with almost 15. And more importantly, a lot of people didnâ€™t show up, because the   community liked me. They liked what I was saying. So they didnâ€™t necessarily vote for me, but they didnâ€™t show up, which was a big problem that she had. I ended up doing very well with women, which was  â€”   which I never understood why I was doing poorly, because weâ€™d go to the rallies and weâ€™d have so many women holding up signs, â€œWomen for Trump. â€ But I kept reading polls saying that Iâ€™m not doing well with women. I think whoever is doing it here would say that we did very well with women, especially certain women. DEAN BAQUET, executive editor of The New York Times: As you describe it, you did do something really remarkable. You energized a lot of people in the country who really wanted change in Washington. But along with that  â€”   and this is going to create a tricky thing for you  â€”   you also energized presumably a smaller number of people who were evidenced at the   convention in Washington this weekend. Who have a very   â€¦     TRUMP: I just saw that today. BAQUET: So, Iâ€™d love to hear you talk about how youâ€™re going to manage that group of people who actually may not be the larger group but who have an expectation for you and are angry about the country and its  â€”   along racial lines. My first question is, do you feel like you said things that energized them in particular, and how are you going to manage that? TRUMP: I donâ€™t think so, Dean. First of all, I donâ€™t want to energize the group. Iâ€™m not looking to energize them. I donâ€™t want to energize the group, and I disavow the group. They, again, I donâ€™t know if itâ€™s reporting or whatever. I donâ€™t know where they were four years ago, and where they were for Romney and McCain and all of the other people that ran, so I just donâ€™t know, I had nothing to compare it to. But itâ€™s not a group I want to energize, and if they are energized I want to look into it and find out why. What we do want to do is we want to bring the country together, because the country is very, very divided, and thatâ€™s one thing I did see, big league. Itâ€™s very, very divided, and Iâ€™m going to work very hard to bring the country together. I mean, Iâ€™m somebody that really has gotten along with people over the years. It was interesting, my wife, I went to a big event about two years ago. Just after I started thinking about politics. And weâ€™re walking in and some people were cheering and some people were booing, and she said, you know, â€˜People have never booed for you.â€™ Iâ€™ve never had a person boo me, and all of a sudden people are booing me. She said, thatâ€™s never happened before. And, itâ€™s politics. You know, all of a sudden they think Iâ€™m going to be running for office, and Iâ€™m a Republican, letâ€™s say. So itâ€™s something that I had never experienced before and I said, â€˜Those people are booing,â€™ and she said, â€˜Yup.â€™ Theyâ€™d never booed before. But now they boo. You know, it was a group and another group was going the opposite. No, I want to bring the country together. Itâ€™s very important to me. Weâ€™re in a very divided country. In many ways divided. BAQUET: So Iâ€™m going to do that thing that executive editors get to do which is to invite reporters to jump in and ask questions. MAGGIE HABERMAN, political reporter: Iâ€™ll start, thank you, Dean. Mr. President, Iâ€™d like to thank you for being here. This morning, Kellyanne Conway talked about not prosecuting Hillary Clinton. We were hoping you could talk about exactly what that means  â€”   does that mean just the emails, or the emails and the foundation, and how you came to that decision. TRUMP: Well, there was a report that somebody said that Iâ€™m not enthused about it. Look, I want to move forward, I donâ€™t want to move back. And I donâ€™t want to hurt the Clintons. I really donâ€™t. She went through a lot. And suffered greatly in many different ways. And I am not looking to hurt them at all. The campaign was vicious. They say it was the most vicious primary and the most vicious campaign. I guess, added together, it was definitely the most vicious probably, I assume you sold a lot of newspapers. [laughter] I would imagine. I would imagine. Iâ€™m just telling you, Maggie, Iâ€™m not looking to hurt them. I think theyâ€™ve been through a lot. Theyâ€™ve gone through a lot. Iâ€™m really looking   â€¦     I think we have to get the focus of the country into looking forward. SULZBERGER: If I could interject, we had a good conversation there, you and I, and it was off the record, but there was nothing secret, just wanted to make sure. The idea of looking forward was one of the themes that you were saying. That we need to now get past the election, right? MATTHEW PURDY, deputy managing editor: So youâ€™re definitively taking that off the table? The investigation? TRUMP: No, but the question was asked. PURDY: About the emails and the foundation? TRUMP: No, no, but itâ€™s just not something that I feel very strongly about. I feel very strongly about health care. I feel very strongly about an immigration bill that I think even the people in this room can be happy. You know, youâ€™ve been talking about immigration bills for 50 years and nothingâ€™s ever happened. I feel very strongly about an immigration bill thatâ€™s fair and just and a lot of other things. There are a lot of things I feel strongly about. Iâ€™m not looking to look back and go through this. This was a very painful period. This was a very painful election with all of the email things and all of the foundation things and all of the everything that they went through and the whole country went through. This was a very painful period of time. I read recently where it was, it was, theyâ€™re saying, they used to say it was Lincoln against whoever and none of us were there to see it. And there arenâ€™t a lot of recordings of that, right? [laughter] But the fact is that there were some pretty vicious elections they say this was, this was the most. They say it was definitely the most vicious primary. And I think itâ€™s very important to look forward. CAROLYN RYAN, senior editor for politics: Do you think it would disappoint your supporters who seemed very animated by the idea of accountability in the Clintons? What would you say to them? TRUMP: I donâ€™t think they will be disappointed. I think I will explain it, that we have to, in many ways save our country. Because our countryâ€™s really in bad, big trouble. We have a lot of trouble. A lot of problems. And one of the big problems, I talk about, divisiveness. I think that a lot of people will appreciate   â€¦     Iâ€™m not doing it for that reason. Iâ€™m doing it because itâ€™s time to go in a different direction. There was a lot of pain, and I think that the people that supported me with such enthusiasm, where they will show up at 1 in the morning to hear a speech. It was actually Election Day, they showed up at, so that was essentially Election Day. Yeah, I think theyâ€™d understand very completely. THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, opinion columnist: Mr.   can I ask a question? One of the issues that you actually were very careful not to speak about during the campaign, and havenâ€™t spoken about yet, is one very near and dear to my heart, the whole issue of climate change, the Paris agreement, how youâ€™ll approach it. You own some of the most beautiful links golf courses in the world   â€¦     [laughter, cross talk] TRUMP: [laughing] I read your article. Some will be even better because actually like Doral is a little bit off   â€¦     so itâ€™ll be perfect. [inaudible] He doesnâ€™t say that. He just says that the ones that are near the water will be gone, but Doral will be in great shape. [laughter] FRIEDMAN: But itâ€™s really important to me, and I think to a lot of our readers, to know where youâ€™re going to go with this. I donâ€™t think anyone objects to, you know, doing all forms of energy. But are you going to take America out of the worldâ€™s lead of confronting climate change? TRUMP: Iâ€™m looking at it very closely, Tom. Iâ€™ll tell you what. I have an open mind to it. Weâ€™re going to look very carefully. Itâ€™s one issue thatâ€™s interesting because there are few things where thereâ€™s more division than climate change. You donâ€™t tend to hear this, but there are people on the other side of that issue who are, think, donâ€™t even   â€¦     SULZBERGER: We do hear it. FRIEDMAN: I was on â€˜Squawk Boxâ€™ with Joe Kernen this morning, so I got an earful of it. [laughter] TRUMP: Joe is one of them. But a lot of smart people disagree with you. I have a very open mind. And Iâ€™m going to study a lot of the things that happened on it and weâ€™re going to look at it very carefully. But I have an open mind. SULZBERGER: Well, since weâ€™re living on an island, sir, I want to thank you for having an open mind. We saw what these storms are now doing, right? Weâ€™ve seen it personally. Straight up. FRIEDMAN: But you have an open mind on this? TRUMP: I do have an open mind. And weâ€™ve had storms always, Arthur. SULZBERGER: Not like this. TRUMP: You know the hottest day ever was in   98. You know, you can make lots of cases for different views. I have a totally open mind. My uncle was for 35 years a professor at M. I. T. He was a great engineer, scientist. He was a great guy. And he was   â€¦     a long time ago, he had feelings  â€”   this was a long time ago  â€”   he had feelings on this subject. Itâ€™s a very complex subject. Iâ€™m not sure anybody is ever going to really know. I know we have, they say they have science on one side but then they also have those horrible emails that were sent between the scientists. Where was that, in Geneva or wherever five years ago? Terrible. Where they got caught, you know, so you see that and you say, whatâ€™s this all about. I absolutely have an open mind. I will tell you this: Clean air is vitally important. Clean water, crystal clean water is vitally important. Safety is vitally important. And you know, you mentioned a lot of the courses. I have some great, great, very successful golf courses. Iâ€™ve received so many environmental awards for the way Iâ€™ve done, you know. Iâ€™ve done a tremendous amount of work where Iâ€™ve received tremendous numbers. Sometimes Iâ€™ll say Iâ€™m actually an environmentalist and people will smile in some cases and other people that know me understand thatâ€™s true. Open mind. JAMES BENNET, editorial page editor: When you say an open mind, you mean youâ€™re just not sure whether human activity causes climate change? Do you think human activity is or isnâ€™t connected? TRUMP: I think right now   â€¦     well, I think there is some connectivity. There is some, something. It depends on how much. It also depends on how much itâ€™s going to cost our companies. You have to understand, our companies are noncompetitive right now. Theyâ€™re really largely noncompetitive. About four weeks ago, I started adding a certain little sentence into a lot of my speeches, that weâ€™ve lost 70, 000 factories since W. Bush. 70, 000. When I first looked at the number, I said: â€˜That must be a typo. It canâ€™t be 70, you canâ€™t have 70, 000, you wouldnâ€™t think you have 70, 000 factories here.â€™ And it wasnâ€™t a typo, itâ€™s right. Weâ€™ve lost 70, 000 factories. Weâ€™re not a competitive nation with other nations anymore. We have to make ourselves competitive. Weâ€™re not competitive for a lot of reasons. Thatâ€™s becoming more and more of the reason. Because a lot of these countries that we do business with, they make deals with our president, or whoever, and then they donâ€™t adhere to the deals, you know that. And itâ€™s much less expensive for their companies to produce products. So Iâ€™m going to be studying that very hard, and I think I have a very big voice in it. And I think my voice is listened to, especially by people that donâ€™t believe in it. And weâ€™ll let you know. FRIEDMAN: Iâ€™d hate to see Royal Aberdeen underwater. TRUMP: The North Sea, that could be, thatâ€™s a good one, right? ELISABETH BUMILLER, Washington bureau chief: I just wanted to follow up on the question you were asked about not pursuing any investigations into Hillary Clinton. Did you mean both the email investigation and the foundation investigation  â€”   you will not pursue either one of those? TRUMP: Yeah, look, you know weâ€™ll have people that do things but my inclination would be, for whatever power I have on the matter, is to say letâ€™s go forward. This has been looked at for so long. Ad nauseam. Letâ€™s go forward. And you know, you could also make the case that some good work was done in the foundation and they could have made mistakes, etc. etc. I think itâ€™s time, I think itâ€™s time for people to say letâ€™s go and solve some of the problems that we have, which are massive problems and, you know, I do think that theyâ€™ve gone through a lot. I think losing is going through a lot. It was a tough, it was a very tough evening for her. I think losing is going through a lot. So, for whatever itâ€™s worth, my, my attitude is strongly we have to go forward, we have so many different problems to solve, I donâ€™t think we have to delve back in the past. I also think that would be a very divisive, well I think it would be very divisive, you know Iâ€™m talking about bringing together, and then they go into all sorts of stuff, I think it would be very, very divisive for the country. SULZBERGER: I agree, I think speaking not as a journalist now, itâ€™s very healthy. There, and then weâ€™re going to go MICHAEL D. SHEAR, White House correspondent: Mr. Trump, Mike Shear. I cover the White House, covering your administration   â€¦     TRUMP: See ya there. [laughter] SHEAR: Just one quick clarification on the climate change, do you intend to, as you said, pull out of the Paris Climate   â€¦     TRUMP: Iâ€™m going to take a look at it. SHEAR [interrupts]: And if the reaction from foreign leaders is to slap tariffs on American goods to offset the carbon that the United States had pledged to reduce, is that O. K. with you? And then the second question is on your sort of mixing of your global business interests and the presidency. Thereâ€™s already, even just in the 10, two weeks youâ€™ve been   instances where youâ€™ve met with your Indian business partners   â€¦     TRUMP: Sure. SHEAR: Youâ€™ve talked about the impact of the wind farms on your golf course. People, experts who are lawyers and ethics experts, say that all of that is totally inappropriate, so I guess the question for you is, what do you see as the appropriate structure for keeping those two things separate, and are there any lines that you think you wonâ€™t want to cross once youâ€™re in the White House? TRUMP: O. K. First of all, on countries. I think that countries will not do that to us. I donâ€™t think if theyâ€™re run by a person that understands leadership and negotiation theyâ€™re in no position to do that to us, no matter what I do. Theyâ€™re in no position to do that to us, and that wonâ€™t happen, but Iâ€™m going to take a look at it. A very serious look. I want to also see how much this is costing, you know, whatâ€™s the cost to it, and Iâ€™ll be talking to you folks in the    future about it, having to do with what just took place. As far as the, you know, potential conflict of interests, though, I mean I know that from the standpoint, the law is totally on my side, meaning, the president canâ€™t have a conflict of interest. Thatâ€™s been reported very widely. Despite that, I donâ€™t want there to be a conflict of interest anyway. And the laws, the president canâ€™t. And I understand why the president canâ€™t have a conflict of interest now because everything a president does in some ways is like a conflict of interest, but I have, Iâ€™ve built a very great company and itâ€™s a big company and itâ€™s all over the world. People are starting to see, when they look at all these different jobs, like in India and other things, number one, a job like that builds great relationships with the people of India, so itâ€™s all good. But I have to say, the partners come in, theyâ€™re very, very successful people. They come in, theyâ€™d say, they said, â€˜Would it be possible to have a picture?â€™ Actually, my children are working on that job. So I can say to them, Arthur, â€˜I donâ€™t want to have a picture,â€™ or, I can take a picture. I mean, I think itâ€™s wonderful to take a picture. Iâ€™m fine with a picture. But if it were up to some people, I would never, ever see my daughter Ivanka again. That would be like you never seeing your son again. That wouldnâ€™t be good. That wouldnâ€™t be good. But Iâ€™d never, ever see my daughter Ivanka. UNKNOWN: That means youâ€™d have to make Ivanka deputy President, you know. TRUMP: I know, I know, yeah. [room laughs] Well, I couldnâ€™t do that either. I canâ€™t, that canâ€™t work. I canâ€™t do anything, I would never see my, I guess the only son Iâ€™d be allowed to see, at least for a little while, would be Barron, because heâ€™s 10. But, but, so there has to be [unintelligible]. Itâ€™s a very interesting case. UNKNOWN: You could sell your company though, right? With all due respect, you could sell your company and then   â€¦     TRUMP: Well   â€¦     UNKNOWN: And then you could see them all the time. TRUMP: Thatâ€™s a very hard thing to do, you know what, because I have real estate. I have real estate all over the world, which now people are understanding. When I filed my forms with the federal election, people said, â€˜Wow thatâ€™s really a big company, thatâ€™s a big company.â€™ It really is big, itâ€™s diverse, itâ€™s all over the world. Itâ€™s a great company with great assets. I think that, you know, selling real estate isnâ€™t like selling stock. Selling real estate is much different, itâ€™s in a much different world. I think getting out of it  â€”   I think we got out of it wrong, then lots of bad things happened, including the formation of ISIS. We could have gotten out of it differently. FRIEDMAN: NATO, Russia? TRUMP: I think going in was a terrible, terrible mistake. Syria, we have to solve that problem because we are going to just keep fighting, fighting forever. I have a different view on Syria than everybody else. Well, not everybody else, but then a lot of people. I had to listen to [Senator] Lindsey Graham, who, give me a break. I had to listen to Lindsey Graham talk about, you know, attacking Syria and attacking, you know, and itâ€™s like youâ€™re now attacking Russia, youâ€™re attacking Iran, youâ€™re attacking. And what are we getting? Weâ€™re getting  â€”   and what are we getting? And I have some very definitive, I have some very strong ideas on Syria. I think whatâ€™s happened is a horrible, horrible thing. To look at the deaths, and Iâ€™m not just talking deaths on our side, which are horrible, but the deaths  â€”   I mean you look at these cities, Arthur, where theyâ€™re totally, theyâ€™re rubble, massive areas, and they say two people were injured. No, thousands of people have died. O. K. And I think itâ€™s a shame. And ideally we can get  â€”   do something with Syria. I spoke to Putin, as you know, he called me, essentially   â€¦     UNKNOWN: How do you see that relationship? TRUMP: Essentially everybody called me, all of the major leaders, and most of them Iâ€™ve spoken to. FRIEDMAN: Will you have a reset with Russia? TRUMP: I wouldnâ€™t use that term after what happened, you know, previously. I think  â€”   I would love to be able to get along with Russia and I think theyâ€™d like to be able to get along with us. Itâ€™s in our mutual interest. And I donâ€™t go in with any preconceived notion, but I will tell you, I would say  â€”   when they used to say, during the campaign, Donald Trump loves Putin, Putin loves Donald Trump, I said, huh, wouldnâ€™t it be nice, Iâ€™d say this in front of thousands of people, wouldnâ€™t it be nice to actually report what they said, wouldnâ€™t it be nice if we actually got along with Russia, wouldnâ€™t it be nice if we went after ISIS together, which is, by the way, aside from being dangerous, itâ€™s very expensive, and ISIS shouldnâ€™t have been even allowed to form, and the people will stand up and give me a massive hand. You know they thought it was bad that I was getting along with Putin or that I believe strongly if we can get along with Russia thatâ€™s a positive thing. It is a great thing that we can get along with not only Russia but that we get along with other countries. JOSEPH KAHN, managing editor: On Syria, would you mind, you said you have a very strong idea about what to do with the Syria conflict, can you describe that for us? TRUMP: I can only say this: We have to end that craziness thatâ€™s going on in Syria. One of the things that was told to me  â€”   can I say this off the record, or is everything on the record? SULZBERGER: No, if you want to   â€¦     TRUMP: I donâ€™t want to violate, I donâ€™t want to violate a   â€¦     SULZBERGER: If you want to go off the record, we have agreed you can go off the record. Ladies and gentlemen, we are off the record for this moment. [Trump speaks off the record.] TRUMP: Now we can go back on. SULZBERGER: Iâ€™m going to play the cop here. Weâ€™ve got only two and a half minutes left, because they have a hard stop at 2. And by the way, I want to thank you again, on behalf of all of us   â€¦     TRUMP: Thank you. SULZBERGER:   â€¦     for this meeting, and really I mean that. We are back on the record. Maggie, you get the last question. TRUMP: Is he a tough boss, folks? Is he tough? HABERMAN: I have two questions, very, very quickly. One is your vice   left open the idea of returning to waterboarding. You talked about that on the campaign trail. Iâ€™m hoping you can talk about how you view torture at this point, and also what are you hoping that Jared Kushner will do in your administration and will you bring him in formally? TRUMP: O. K. O. K. So, I didnâ€™t hear the second question. HABERMAN: Jared Kushner. What will Jared Kushnerâ€™s role be in your administration? TRUMP: Oh. Maybe nothing. Because I donâ€™t want to have people saying â€˜conflict.â€™ Even though the president of the United States  â€”   I hope whoever is writing this story, itâ€™s written fairly  â€”   the president of the United States is allowed to have whatever conflicts he wants  â€”   he or she wants. But I donâ€™t want to go by that. Jaredâ€™s a very smart guy. Heâ€™s a very good guy. The people that know him, heâ€™s a quality person and I think he can be very helpful. I would love to be able to be the one that made peace with Israel and the Palestinians. I would love that, that would be such a great achievement. Because nobodyâ€™s been able to do it. HABERMAN: Do you think he can be part of that? TRUMP: Well, I think heâ€™d be very good at it. I mean he knows it so well. He knows the region, knows the people, knows the players. I would love to be  â€”   and you can put that down in a list of many things that Iâ€™d like to be able to do. Now a lot of people tell me, really great people tell me, that itâ€™s impossible, you canâ€™t do it. Iâ€™ve had a lot of, actually, great Israeli businesspeople tell me, you canâ€™t do that, itâ€™s impossible. I disagree, I think you can make peace. I think people are tired now of being shot, killed. At some point, when do they come? I think we can do that. I have reason to believe I can do that. HABERMAN: And on torture? Where are you  â€”   and waterboarding? TRUMP: So, I met with General Mattis, who is a very respected guy. In fact, I met with a number of other generals, they say heâ€™s the finest there is. He is being seriously, seriously considered for secretary of defense, which is  â€”   I think itâ€™s time maybe, itâ€™s time for a general. Look at whatâ€™s going on. We donâ€™t win, we canâ€™t beat anybody, we donâ€™t win anymore. At anything. We donâ€™t win on the border, we donâ€™t win with trade, we certainly donâ€™t win with the military. General Mattis is a strong, highly dignified man. I met with him at length and I asked him that question. I said, what do you think of waterboarding? He said  â€”   I was surprised  â€”   he said, â€˜Iâ€™ve never found it to be useful.â€™ He said, â€˜Iâ€™ve always found, give me a pack of cigarettes and a couple of beers and I do better with that than I do with torture.â€™ And I was very impressed by that answer. I was surprised, because heâ€™s known as being like the toughest guy. And when he said that, Iâ€™m not saying it changed my mind. [An earlier version made a mistake in transcription. Mr. Trump said â€œchanged my mind,â€ not â€œchanged my man. â€] Look, we have people that are chopping off heads and drowning people in steel cages and weâ€™re not allowed to waterboard. But Iâ€™ll tell you what, I was impressed by that answer. It certainly does not  â€”   itâ€™s not going to make the kind of a difference that maybe a lot of people think. If itâ€™s so important to the American people, I would go for it. I would be guided by that. But General Mattis found it to be very less important, much less important than I thought he would say. I thought he would say  â€”   you know heâ€™s known as Mad Dog Mattis, right? Mad Dog for a reason. I thought heâ€™d say â€˜Itâ€™s phenomenal, donâ€™t lose it.â€™ He actually said, â€˜No, give me some cigarettes and some drinks, and weâ€™ll do better.â€™ SULZBERGER: So, I, with apologies, Iâ€™m going to go to our C. E. O. Mark Thompson, for the last, last question. TRUMP: Very powerful man   â€¦     MARK THOMPSON: Thank you, and itâ€™s a really short one, but after all the talk about libel and libel laws, are you committed to the First Amendment to the Constitution? TRUMP: Oh, I was hoping he wasnâ€™t going to say that. I think youâ€™ll be happy. I think youâ€™ll be happy. Actually, somebody said to me on that, they said, â€˜You know, itâ€™s a great idea, softening up those laws, but you may get sued a lot more.â€™ I said, â€˜You know, youâ€™re right, I never thought about that.â€™ I said, â€˜You know, I have to start thinking about that.â€™ So, I, I think youâ€™ll be O. K. I think youâ€™re going to be fine. SULZBERGER: Well, thank you very much for this. Really appreciate this. TRUMP: Thank you all, very much, itâ€™s a great honor. I will say, The Times is, itâ€™s a great, great American jewel. A world jewel. And I hope we can all get along. Weâ€™re looking for the same thing, and I hope we can all get along well.

title: Trump likely just infuriated China with the USâ€™s first call to Taiwan since 1979
content: â€™  â€™ â€™     Donald Trump spoke with the president of Taiwan   by phone on Friday, in a move likely to infuriate Beijing and   hinder   relations. â€™ â€™   â€  Trump spoke with President Tsai   of   Taiwan, who offered her congratulations,â€ according to a readout   of the call released by Trumpâ€™â€™s transition team. â€™ â€™   â€During the discussion, they noted the close economic, political,   and security tiesâ€ between Taiwan and the United States, the   statement continued. â€  Trump also congratulated   President Tsai on becoming President of Taiwan earlier this   year.â€ â€™ â€™   Trump also  late Friday, saying â€The   President of Taiwan CALLED ME today to wish me congratulations on   winning the Presidency.â€ â€™ â€   The call, first reported by the  is the first time a US president has   directly spoken with Taiwanâ€™s leadership in more than 30 years.   The White House was not made aware of the call until after it   occurred, an administration official told Business Insider. â€ â€™   The US suspended formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan in 1979   after establishing a One China position  â€”   which states that   â€there is but one China and Taiwan is part of Chinaâ€  â€”   in an   effort to establish diplomatic channels with Beijing. â€™ â€   Beijing views Taiwan as a province of China, whereas Taiwan  â€”     which has its own democratically elected government  â€”   has a more   complicated view of the nationsâ€™ relationship. â€ â€™   â€There is no change to our longstanding policy on     issues,â€ said Ned Price, a spokesman for the White Houseâ€™â€™s   National Security Council. â€™ â€™   â€We remain firmly committed to our â€™â€™one Chinaâ€™â€™ policy based on   the three Joint Communiques and the Taiwan Relations Act. Our   fundamental interest is in peaceful and stable     relations,â€ he added. â€™ â€™     who was elected the first female president of Taiwan in   May,  over the summer that she hopes   Chinese President Xi Jinping â€can appreciate that Taiwan is a   democratic society in which the leader has to follow the will of   the people.â€ â€™ â€™   Analysts were quick to point out that the phone call will likely   infuriate Beijing. â€™ â€™   â€Trump has phone call w Taiwan President, 1st by US Pres or     since 1979,â€ geopolitical expert Ian Bremmer,   president of Eurasia Group, tweeted on Friday. â€Beijing will be   absolutely incensed.â€ â€™ â€™   â€Trump almost surely unaware of   sensitivities before   taking Presidentâ€™â€™s call,â€ Bremmer added. â€They donâ€™â€™t yet have   Asia expertise on team.â€ â€™ â€™   Evan Medeiros, former Asia director at the White House national   security council, told the Financial Times that â€the Chinese   leadership will see this as a highly provocative action, of   historic proportions.â€ â€™ â€™   â€œRegardless if it was deliberate or accidental, this phone call   will fundamentally change Chinaâ€™s perceptions of Trumpâ€™s   strategic intentions for the negative,â€ he said. â€With this kind   of move, Trump is setting a foundation of enduring mistrust and   strategic competition for   relations.â€ â€™ â€™  â€™ â€™   Trump has apparently been considering building a luxury hotel   chain    the Shanghaiist reported last month. â€™ â€™   Henry Kissinger  â€”   who, as secretary of state, arranged President   Richard Nixonâ€™â€™s initial trip to Beijing to establish ties in 1972    â€”   is . Kissinger met with Trump at Trump   Tower after the election and told reporters that Trump â€has   absolutely no baggage.â€ â€™ â€™   â€œHe has no obligation to any particular group because he has   become a president on the basis of his own strategy and a program   he put before the American public that his competitors did not   present,â€ Kissinger said. â€So that is a unique situation. â€ â€™ â€™   Still, the Washington Postâ€™â€™s Glenn Kessler said news of the phone   call will likely give Kissinger â€a heart attack.â€ â€™ â€™   â€Years of careful diplomatic winks and nods up in smoke,â€ he   tweeted. â€™ â€™   Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary under George W.   Bush,    on Friday that he â€wasnâ€™â€™t even allowed to referâ€ to the   government â€ofâ€ Taiwan when serving in the Bush administration. â€™ â€™   â€I could say gvt â€™â€™onâ€™â€™ Taiwan,â€ he noted. â€China will go nuts.â€ â€™ â€™   Sen. Chris Murphy, a Democrat from Connecticut,   that while â€itâ€™â€™s Trumpâ€™â€™s right to shift policy, alliances,   strategy . .. what has happened in the last 48 hours is not a   shift. These are major pivots in foreign policy   any plan.   Thatâ€™â€™s how wars start. And if they arenâ€™â€™t pivots  â€”   just radical   temporary deviations  â€”   allies will walk if they have no clue what   we stand for. Just as bad.â€ â€™ â€™   He added: â€Itâ€™â€™s probably time we get a Secretary of State nominee   on board. Preferably w experience. Like, really really soon.â€ â€™ â€™  â€™ â€™   Trump risked damaging the USâ€™â€™ relationship with India earlier   this week after telling Pakistani prime minister Nawaz Sharif in   a phone call that he would â€loveâ€ to visit the country soon. â€™ â€™   â€It sends a powerful message to the people of a country when the   president of the United States goes to visit,â€ White House press   secretary Josh Earnest said when asked about the call with   Sharif. â€Thatâ€™s true whether itâ€™s some of our closest allies, or   thatâ€™s also true if itâ€™s a country like Pakistan, with whom our   relationship is somewhat more complicated.â€ â€™ â€™   Trumpâ€™â€™s communications director, Jason Miller, told reporters   Friday before reports of the phone call between Trump and     emerged that Trump and Vice   Mike Pence   are â€briefed in advanced of their callsâ€ with foreign leaders. He   did not comment on whether the State Department has had any   involvement in briefing Trump and Pence, however. â€™ â€™ Brett LoGiurato contributed reporting. â€™

title: Reports: Mitt Romney to Meet President-Elect Trump - Breitbart
content: Several news outlets are reporting that former Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney will meet with   Donald Trump at Trump Tower this weekend in New York City. [CNN, Fox News, and NBC News are all reporting this development, with NBC speculating that Romney could be angling for a position as Secretary of State.  From Fox News: Donald Trump and Mitt Romney are set to meet this weekend in New York, Fox News has learned. The meeting between the   and the 2012 GOP presidential nominee  â€”   who was one of Trumpâ€™s most outspoken Republican critics during the primary season  â€”   comes amid an intense round of meetings Trump is holding with prominent Republicans. Some are speculated to be under consideration for   Cabinet positions others are thought to be providing guidance. The   meeting could at least be a chance for the two to set aside their differences from the 2016 season and forge political unity. Read the rest of the story here.

title: Debbie Not Welcome in Dallas: Texas AG Sides with City Leaders Against Porn Convention
content: Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton is standing with Dallas business leaders against a pornography convention that is slated to be hosted in the cityâ€™s convention center. Paxton filed a brief today in federal court in support of stopping the   show. [â€œIt is vital that governmental entities have the ability to exclude   businesses from property that they own,â€ General Paxton said. â€œThe City of Dallas, through its   officials, has rightfully decided that its convention center should not be home to an event where obscenity and criminal activity occurs. A federal court should not overturn that decision by elected officials. â€  The amici curiae (friend of the court) brief was filed in the U. S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas. The brief attached below, urges that because the Convention Center is a commercial enterprise that is intended to promote economic development in Dallas, the Convention Center is a nonpublic forum that the City is free to reasonably manage under applicable law. The OAG also urges that it hopes by filing the brief that it will â€œaid the Court in understanding how free speech doctrine accommodates the Cityâ€™s significant interests as proprietor of the Convention Center. â€ â€œIâ€™m proud to be joined by the Dallas Citizens Council on this brief,â€ General Paxton said in a statement obtained by Breitbart Texas. â€œPromoting an environment where economic development can flourish in Texas is an important goal for my administration. It is heartening to see a group of local civic leaders taking a stand and doing their part to ensure that their community remains a place where business can flourish. â€ Lana Shadwick is a writer and legal analyst for Breitbart Texas. She has served as a prosecutor and associate judge. Follow her on Twitter @LanaShadwick2, Attorney General Paxton Brief in Support of City of Dallas Against Pornography Convention,

title: Egyptâ€™s ex-President Mohamed Morsy sentenced to death
content: Cairo (CNN) Former Egyptian President Mohamed Morsy was sentenced Saturday by a Cairo court to death    the latest judicial setback for the ousted leader. He was convicted in a 2011 prison break. Morsyâ€™s name, along with those of more than 100 other defendants, will be passed to the Grand Mufti, the highest legal authority in Egypt, who will have the final say on their sentence. The verdict will be confirmed June 2. This was the harshest sentence that Morsy could have expected to receive in the case.  The leader of the Muslim Brotherhood, Mohamed Badie, and a former parliament speaker, Mohamed Saad   also were referred to the Grand Mufti in the jailbreak case. Cairoâ€™s   government has banned the Muslim Brotherhood, branding it a terrorist group    an allegation it denies.  Morsy and his   were accused of collaborating with the Palestinian Islamist group Hamas and the Lebanese Shiite group Hezbollah to break into several prisons across Egypt in January 2011 and of facilitating the escape of Morsy and 20, 000 others. The jailbreak came amid the chaos of the January 2011 popular uprising that toppled longtime strongman Hosni Mubarak and led to Morsyâ€™s election the following year. Rights group: Trials a â€charadeâ€ Muslim Brotherhood lawyer Abdel Moniem Abdel Maqsoud told CNN that the defense would have to consult with Morsy before deciding whether to lodge an appeal on his behalf. Morsy has said throughout the process â€that he doesnâ€™t recognize these trials,â€ the lawyer said.  Maqsoud characterized Saturdayâ€™s ruling as â€a decision, not a verdict.â€ â€Consequently we will wait until June 2,â€ he said. â€If there is a conviction, we will continue the legal path that we started the past months, which is to point the legal faults of these verdicts.â€ He said he believed the Court of Cassation would overturn all the verdicts handed down. Rights group Amnesty International condemned the trials of Morsy and others as a â€charadeâ€ which demonstrated the â€deplorable stateâ€ of Egyptâ€™s criminal justice system. Condemning Morsy to death â€shows a complete disregard for human rights. His trials were undermined even before he set foot in the courtroom,â€ said Said Boumedouha, deputy director of Amnesty Internationalâ€™s Middle East and North Africa program.  He urged Egypt to ensue the independence and impartiality of the justice system, saying most of those sentenced to death by its courts since July 2013 have been Morsy supporters. â€The death penalty has become the favorite tool for the Egyptian authorities to purge the political opposition,â€ he said. Hamas criticized the death sentences handed down for some of its members in connection with the jailbreak    pointing out that two of the named defendants were already dead. â€Hossam   was martyred in 2008. Martyr leader Raed   was martyred the 2014 war. Today, the Egyptian judiciary sentenced them to death. Fair judiciary indeed,â€ Ismail Haniyyeh, the deputy head of the Hamas politburo, tweeted.  He noted that another Palestinian sentenced to death, Hassan Salama, has been in Israeli prisons since 1996.  Espionage case, In a separate case involving espionage charges, another 16 defendants    but not Morsy    were also sentenced to death. The verdict will be confirmed June 2.  Among those sentenced to death are Mohamed   deputy leader of the Muslim Brotherhood Mohamed   a former Muslim Brotherhood member of parliament Ahmed Abdel Aty, a former presidential aide and Emad Shahin, a political science professor now in the United States. Those defendants present chanted â€Allahu Akbar,â€ meaning â€God is the greatest,â€ as they were sentenced. They remained in the cage where prisoners are held in the courtroom, waving to journalists and lawyers as they chanted. Morsy can expect to learn his verdict in the espionage case on June 2, but it wonâ€™t be the death penalty. Violence against protesters, Morsy, who became Egyptâ€™s first democratically elected President in June 2012, was deposed by a popularly backed military coup in July 2013. He was already sentenced to 20 years in prison in April this year on charges involving violence against protesters outside the presidential palace in December 2012. But he was acquitted of murder in the deaths of protesters. After that verdict, his Freedom and Justice Party, the Muslim Brotherhoodâ€™s political wing, called the trial a â€travesty of justice.â€ The ousted president is still facing an ongoing trial on charges of espionage with Qatar. A fifth trial will start this month on charges of insulting the judiciary.

title: Trump Expands Big Lead In Florida, Up In Ohio - Breitbart
content: Two pollsters looked at two crucial states and delivered only good news for Republican frontrunner Donald Trump. The GOP Establishmentâ€™s stated goal is to stop Trump from winning the number of delegates necessary to outright claim the Republican presidential nomination. The idea is to then go to a brokered convention where Party delegates get to choose whomever they like. In order to do that, Trump must first lose the     of Ohio and Florida. With just six days to go, these polls show Trump  leading in both.    Florida, According to Quinnipiac, despite 10 days of facing down the GOP   Media Death Star, Trump has actually expanded his lead in Florida. Currently, the billionaire businessman leads favorite son Marco Rubio 45% to 22% a full +23 points. Last month, in this same poll, Trump was up by just +16 points over Rubio, 44% to 28%. Only 6% of voters remain undecided. Ted Cruz earns 18% support. John Kasich sits at just 8%. Trump also leads in the demos: Trump leads Rubio 39  â€”   27 percent among women and 50  â€”   17 percent among men.   Tea Party members go 48 percent for Trump, 40 percent for Cruz and 9 percent for Rubio. Trump gets 39 percent of white,   evangelicals, with 30 percent for Cruz and 21 percent for Rubio. In the new CNN poll, Trump is up +16 with 40% to Rubioâ€™s 24%. Cruz sits at 19% Kasich 5%.   Ohio, The race for Ohio is much tighter. According to Quinnipiac, Trump leads current Ohio Governor Kasich by +6 points, 38% to 32%. A month ago, Trump led by +5 points, 31% to 26%. Both men are gaining support. The good news for Trump is that his lead has remained stable. Cruz earns just 16% support. Rubioâ€™s collapse continues with just 9%. Details: Cruz gets 38 percent of Ohio Tea Party members, with 33 percent for Trump and 14 percent for Kasich. Kasich gets 32 percent of white,   evangelicals, with 29 percent for Trump and 24 percent for Cruz. Voters 18 to 44 years old go to Trump over Kasich 41  â€”   24 percent. Trump gets 38 percent of voters 45 to 64 years old to Kasichâ€™s 35 percent. Kasich gets 38 percent of voters over 65 years old to Trumpâ€™s 33 percent. In the new CNN poll, Trump is again up +6 with 41% to Kasichâ€™s 35%. Cruz is in third at 15% and Rubio fourth with just 7%. Kasichâ€™s third place showing in Michigan Tuesday night might deflate some of his Ohio support. He has virtually no chance of winning the nomination. If his comeback was going to begin, it had to begin in Michigan, a state close to and very similar to Ohio. If any, whatever kitchen sinks the Establishment and DC Media have left, they had better be more effective than the last ones.   Follow John Nolte on Twitter @NolteNC

title: MIT Technology Review: Googleâ€™s A.I. â€™Hate Speechâ€™ Detector â€™Erraticâ€™ - Breitbart
content: The MIT Technology Review recently published an article demonstrating that Googleâ€™s new comment detection system, Perspective, seems to have difficulty differentiating offensive words or controversial subjects from actual hate speech. [Breitbart previously reported on the â€œhate speechâ€ detection software, designed to help online publications clear their article comment sections of any offensive content that could potentially be applied to other Internet platforms. The MIT Technology Review decided to test the accuracy of the software, which analyzes comments on a scale of   for â€œtoxicity. â€ Toxic comments are defined by the program as â€œa rude, disrespectful, or unreasonable comment that is likely to make you leave a discussion. â€  â€œTrump sucksâ€ scored a colossal 96 percent, yet   codeword â€œ â€ only scored 5 percent. â€œFew Muslims are a terrorist threatâ€ was 79 percent toxic, while â€œrace war nowâ€ scored 24 percent. â€œHitler was an  â€ scored 70 percent, but â€œHitler was not an  â€ scored only 53% and â€œThe Holocaust never happenedâ€ scored only 21%. And while â€œgas the joosâ€ scored 29 percent, rephrasing it to â€œPlease gas the joos. Thank you. â€ lowered the score to a mere 7 percent. (â€œJews are human,â€ however, scores 72 percent. â€œJews are not humanâ€? 64 percent.) The MIT Technology Review believes the system is designed to detect particular words and phrases in a sentence that may be deemed offensive but does not account for the meaning behind these words. In an example, the word â€œrapeâ€ scored a toxicity rating as high as 77 percent when detected by the program, but a statement such as â€œrape is a horrible crimeâ€ actually rated higher at 81 percent. Curse words receive similar treatment: â€œI fucking love thisâ€ was rated at a 94 percent on the toxicity scale, which is supposed to indicate if a comment is â€œrude, disrespectful, or unreasonable. â€ We may say â€œTrolls are stupidâ€ (toxicity score 96 percent) but the language of toxicity and harassment is often rich in ways that   systems canâ€™t handle. The comment â€œYou should be made into a lamp,â€ an allusion to claims that skin from concentration camp victims was used for lampshades, has been thrown at a number of journalists and other public figures in recent months. It scores just 4 percent on Perspective. But best not reply by saying â€œYou are a Nazi,â€ because thatâ€™s an 87 percent. Read the full article by MIT Technology Review here.
