Lucas Nolan is a reporter for Breitbart News covering issues of free speech and online censorship. Follow him on Twitter @LucasNolan_ or email him at lnolan@breitbart. com

title: Bernie Sandersâ€™s Socialist Allies Helped Shut Down Donald Trumpâ€™s Chicago Event - Breitbart
content: One of the radical groups that helped to shut down Donald Trumpâ€™s Chicago rally has long maintained a close relationship with Sen. Bernie Sanders. [In fact, Sanders raised funds for the group, the Democratic Socialists of America, or DSA, and himself helped to recruit new members to the socialist organization.  Sanders further was a key player in helping to elect   candidates to Congress and was involved in an effort to rebrand and incorporate that   legislative axis within the Congressional Progressive Caucus, or CPC. The DSA in turn was critical in organizing early support for Sandersâ€™ national political career and Sanders has since maintained close working ties to the organization. Sanders was one of six founding members of the CPC. It was also founded in 1991 by Reps. Peter DeFazio,  . Maxine Waters,  . and Ron Dellums,  . The story of Sanders, the CPC and the DSA spotlights the largely forgotten but entirely public role the DSA played in founding the CPC, the largest membership organization within the House Democratic Caucus, currently boasting   members. Besides the DSA, the George     MoveOn. org played a prominent role in organizing the   activism. DSA â€˜Disruptorsâ€™ sent to Trump event, On Sunday, Trump sent out the following Tweet: Bernie Sanders is lying when he says his disruptors arenâ€™t told to go to my events. Be careful Bernie, or my supporters will go to yours!  â€”   Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) March 13, 2016,  Sanders in turn said on Sunday that Trump is â€œlyingâ€ by claiming Sanders campaign sent protesters to the business mogulâ€™s canceled Chicago rally. While Sandersâ€™ campaign may not have been directly involved, the DSA certainly sent its members to the Chicago event. The DSAâ€™s Chicago chapter is the Chicago DSA, which is separately incorporated and is one of the most active branches of the DSA. Anyone paying membership dues to the DSA in the Chicago area is automatically a member of the Chicago DSA local, the website documents. Chicago DSA drove its members to the Trump Protest Rally on March 11 at the University of Illinois at Chicago Pavilion in Chicago, the   arena where Trump had planned his local campaign event.  The event was canceled at the last minute due to safety concerns, with protesters clashing with Trump supporters at the nixed rally. The Chicago DSA website linked to the main Facebook page that provided details for the   rally, which announced it had planned to â€œmake our way to the Pavilion in solidarity. â€ The Facebook page provided a link for activists to sign up to get inside Trumpâ€™s campaign event, purportedly to infiltrate and disrupt the Trump rally. The Chicago DSA is one of over a dozen organizations that drove its members to the Trump event in Chicago.  Other groups, some larger, included Black Lives Matter Chicago, MoveOn. org, La Raza Chicago, International ANSWER Chicago, SEIU Local 73, The Illinois Coalition of Immigrant and Refugee Rights, and more. Chicago DSA is currently actively campaigning for Sanders, participating in numerous events and marches in support of the presidential candidate and drafting petitions to support his bid. The DSAâ€™s own super PAC has been supporting Sanders. The ties between Sanders and the DSA run deep and encompass over two decades of mutual activism. The DSA has worked to utilize the Democratic Party  to push its socialist agenda. â€œStress our Democratic Party strategy and electoral work,â€ instructs an organizing document of the DSA. â€œThe Democratic Party is something the public understands, and association with it takes the edge off. Stressing our Democratic Party work will establish some distance from the radical subculture and help integrate you to the milieu of the young liberals. â€ DSA aided Sanders political rise, This reporter previously first documented the DSAâ€™s role in helping to organize support for Sandersâ€™ national political career: On Oct. 24, 1988, The Nation magazine, identifying Sanders as â€œthe socialist Mayor of Burlington, Vermont,â€ reported he had been endorsed for Congress by both the Democratic Socialists of America and the progressive founders of Ben and Jerryâ€™s Ice Cream. The DSA endorsed Sanders for every one of his subsequent elections and has openly helped to raise funds for him over the years. In 2006, for example, the DSA boasted in its literature about the socialist groupâ€™s â€œinvolvement in Bernie Sandersâ€™ pivotal independent 2006 Senate campaign in Vermont. â€ Indeed, the DSA held â€œElect Sandersâ€ house parties in Atlanta Boston Detroit Portland, Maine Boulder, Colorado Indianapolis Columbus, Ohio Ithaca, New York Springfield, Massachusetts Washington, D. C. and New York City. â€œDSAers wanting to hold Sanders house parties should contact me at fllewellyn@dsausa. org,â€ wrote one senior DSA activist in the socialist groupâ€™s July 2006 newsletter. That same year, Sanders spoke at a Detroit fundraiser for DSAâ€™s Political Action Committee. The fundraiser was connected by telephone link to a simultaneous DSA fundraising event in Atlanta. DSA literature notes that in January 2006, DSA Detroit Chair David Green â€œtook Bernie Sanders to tour Stan Ovshinskyâ€™s United Solar Ovonics plant in Auburn Hills northwest of Detroit. â€ â€œThe plant makes successful,   solar panels and is pioneering the hydrogen fuel cell,â€ added the DSA. Sanders helped recruit new members to the DSA. In one example, he was the featured speaker at numerous DSA â€œhouse partiesâ€ in the fall of 2006 that were aimed not only at garnering support for his senatorial bid but also used by the DSA to recruit new members to its ranks. As this reporter previously documented: One New York City event was held Sept. 19, 2006, at the home of DSA activists Gene and Laurel Eisner on Manhattanâ€™s Upper West Side. â€œThe questions and comments actually had to be cut off to let Bernie get to the plane,â€ reported the DSA. DSA reported the Sanders events helped to recruit new members to the socialist organization. â€œSanders support work provides a natural vehicle in any locality for DSA to reach out to  â€”   and potentially recruit  â€”   unaffiliated socialists and independent radicals. â€ Infiltrating Congress, hosting CPC website, The DSAâ€™s role in openly helping to found the CPC has been documented but largely forgotten. Chicago DSAâ€™s New Ground publication identified the Progressive Caucus in Congress as a group which the DSA â€œhelped to organize. â€ The ties were so close that until November 2002, the CPCâ€™s websute was openly hosted by the DSAâ€™s own website. However, after numerous news media outlets pointed to the connection, the online list of CPC members was relocated to Sandersâ€™ own website before getting its own website. The radicalism of the DSAâ€™s website was openly brandished. In 1998, it featured â€œThe Internationale,â€ the worldwide anthem of communism and socialism, WND. com reported. The website also featured the song titled â€œRed Revolution,â€ which was supposed to be sung to the tune of â€œRed Robin. â€ The lyrics, WND noted, include: â€œWhen the Red Revolution brings its solution along, along, thereâ€™ll be no more lootinâ€™ when we start shootinâ€™ that Wall Street throng.   â€¦    â€ Also: â€œAre you sleeping? Are you sleeping? Bourgeoisie, Bourgeoisie. And when the revolution comes, Weâ€™ll kill you all with knives and guns, Bourgeoisie, Bourgeoisie. â€ The CPC being hosted on the DSAâ€™s website is noted in the Congressional record. This reporter previously documented: The issue of the CPC being hosted on the DSA website rose again in June 2000 in connection with a heated dispute on the House floor among Rep. Randy â€œDukeâ€ Cunningham,  . Rep. Peter DeFazio,  . and David R. Obey,  . over the â€œmerits of the   fighter plane. â€ When Cunningham stood to defend himself, he included in his argument the fact that the relationship between the CPC and DSA was an open secret. The CPC was still hosted by the DSA website in April 2002. On April 23, 2002, Author and political philosopher Balint Vazsonyi noted the connection in the Washington Times when he asked: â€œâ€˜What?â€™ I hear you say. â€˜Socialists in the Congress of the United States? â€™â€ Dozens, dear reader, dozens. And they make no secret of it. Although of late it has been refurbished and the address altered, they have their own Web site. They call themselves members of the Progressive Caucus, until recently an arm of the Democratic Socialists of America, itself an arm of the Socialist International. The Progressive Caucus may be a separate entity now, but the details of its program, as advertised on the website, are indistinguishable from that of the Socialist International. To their credit, they make no secret of it. Only the rest of us prefer not to believe it. In an earlier article in November 2002, Vazsonyi further highlighted the presence of the CPC on the DSA website.  With research by Brenda J. Elliott. Aaron Klein is Breitbartâ€™s Jerusalem bureau chief and senior investigative reporter. He is a New York Times bestselling author and hosts the popular weekend talk radio program, â€œAaron Klein Investigative Radio. â€ Follow him on Twitter @AaronKleinShow. Follow him on Facebook.

title: A scientific tale of two dresses
content: (CNN) Before you strangle your best friend who sees the colors in the   dress differently than you do, please know that thereâ€™s a scientific explanation.  It has to do with the tiny cones in the back of our eyeballs that perceive colors in a slightly different way depending upon our genes. â€Why do some people love cilantro and others say it tastes like soap? Why do some people have perfect pitch and others are tone deaf? Itâ€™s the same with vision  â€”   our sensory apparatus is fine tuned,â€ says Dr. Julia Haller, the    at Wills Eye Hospital in Philadelphia.  The cones in our retinas  â€”   the fine layer of nerve tissue that lines the back of our eyes  â€”   detect the blue, green, and red in an image. The cones and your brain mix those colors to make other colors. â€  percent of the time, weâ€™ll see the same colors,â€ Haller says. â€But the picture of this dress seems to have tints that hit the sweet spot thatâ€™s confusing to a lot of people.â€  The very top section of the dress appears gold to some people, but black to others. This makes sense to Haller.  â€One of the typical color confusions we see is â€ she says. â€So perhaps in this dress, the black has a bit of blue and the gold has a bit of yellow.â€  As retinal specialists met Friday in Scottsdale, Arizona, at the annual meeting of the Macula Society, they swapped theories about why peopleâ€™s cones and brains process the dressâ€™s colors so differently.  One theory has to do with evolutionary biology. Primates, including humans, have developed an excellent sense of color, so weâ€™re able to, for example, distinguish the yellow fruit hanging on the green tree.  To determine the color of that fruit, itâ€™s often necessary to factor out colors in the light around it that might give the fruit a different and misleading tint. There are likely slight variations in how our brains do this automatic filtering.  â€Your brain is constantly estimating the color of the light thatâ€™s falling on the object and factoring that light out,â€ said Wallace Thoreson, a professor of ophthalmology at the University of Nebraska Medical Center. â€Each of us makes slightly different unconscious assumptions.â€  Opinion: Why the dress, llamas and Spock went viral, Haller said the Macula Societyâ€™s meeting was â€totally derailed by the dressâ€ as doctors skipped sessions to stand out in the hallway and compare each otherâ€™s color judgments.  Some of them even think the dress could possibly help advance medical science and hopefully help people with vision problems.  Dr. Emily Chew, an ophthalmologist at the National Institutes of Health, said in more than thirty years of research sheâ€™s never seen an image where people, all with normal vision, have had such dramatically different responses.  â€It would be interesting to use this image to learn more about the pathways of how we understand color,â€ said Chew, the deputy director of the division of epidemiology and clinical applications at the National Eye Institute.  She said it was impressive how â€crowd sourcingâ€ identified the dress.   â€It would be really hard to create this image,â€ she said. â€Itâ€™s serendipitous. Iâ€™ve never seen anything like this. Itâ€™s really unbelievable.â€  CNNâ€™s Nadia Kounang contributed to this report.

title: Limbaugh: Virginia Shooter the Personification of â€™the Lunatic Fringe Base, the Deranged Base of the Democrat Partyâ€™ - Breitbart
content: Wednesday on his nationally syndicated radio show, conservative talker Rush Limbaugh reacted to a shooting at a congressional baseball practice in Alexandria, VA that had resulted in five people hospitalized, including House Majority Whip Rep. Steve Scalise ( ).  Limbaugh argued the shooter, identified as James T. Hodgkinson of Illinois, was influenced by the media and the Democratic Party stoking hatred and resentment. Partial transcript as follows (courtesy of RushLimbaugh. com): The sad and unfortunate fact is that, as evidenced by the sound bite of me yesterday, I have foreseen this coming. You canâ€™t continue to enrage people the way the left, and predominantly the media, has been doing. The Democrat Party and the left for years have been feeding this. And particularly since the election of Trump they have virtually assured their supporters that Trump is guilty, guilty of treason. And every congressional hearing is going to provide the proof. Every one. Sessions yesterday, Comey a couple of times, Sally Yates, you name it. They build up these expectations that Trump is not really the president. He shouldnâ€™t have been. He cheated. He colluded with the Russians. There isnâ€™t any evidence for it, and so every time the left builds up an event where this is going to be established as fact and it blows up in their faces, it creates rising expectations followed immediately by rank disappointment and anger and letdown over the fact that itâ€™s not happening. And I think these people on the left have been driven to this extreme for quite a while. I have been worried about it for I donâ€™t know how long. And Iâ€™ve been telling you so. And we could, if we wanted to, we could scour  â€”   well, we have. I could go back and show you tweets, I could read you tweets. I could read you statements made by elected Democrats and others promoting just this kind of behavior, just this kind of behavior. You can find it. If you look at the TV programs and the media personalities that this guy, Hodgkinson, was devoted to, youâ€™ll find out how radicalized he was by   TV and comedy. Last week Tonight With John Oliver, the Nightly Show on the Comedy Central, Democracy Now, The Ed Show, the Rachel Maddow Show. He apparently loved Rachel Maddow, wanted her to run for president. The Daily Show on Comedy Central, Real Time with Bill Maher. Those are the TV shows that he recommended everybody watch. Clearly, he was radicalized. Now, I also want to say he probably started off this way. I donâ€™t know that this guyâ€™s ever been a rational, invisible functioning member of a community, but at some point he got radicalized, and if you dig deep youâ€™ll find  â€”   weâ€™ve got examples of it to share with you. This guy is the exact personification when I sit here and talk about the lunatic fringe base, the deranged base of the Democrat Party, this is the guy. This is the face. This is the picture. This is what you get when you stoke and fuel hatred, raw hatred and resentment, at some point itâ€™s gonna blow over, because it cannot be contained, this kind of rage and repeated disappointment. You add climate change probably to this guyâ€™s list of grievances, and I think everybody ought to take a step back and realize this guy is not isolated. This guy is probably typical. Not that thereâ€™s going to be rampant shootings, but he just happened to go over the edge and pull the trigger. But he, to me, is exactly what I am unfortunately worried about when I look at the way all of these lies and all these nothingness, nothing burger stories have now been out there for month after month after month. And you add everything else that the Democrat and the liberal media agenda is. Itâ€™s nothing but anger, itâ€™s nothing but rage, itâ€™s nothing but hatred, and it has to have an outlet. And they know it. The fact is, they know it. Follow Jeff Poor on Twitter @jeff_poor

title: Putin warns against â€™intimidatingâ€™ North Korea
content: Beijing  (CNN) Russian President Vladimir Putin has condemned North Koreaâ€™s latest missile launch as â€dangerousâ€ but warned against â€intimidatingâ€ Pyongyang. Speaking in China, Putin called for a peaceful solution to the ongoing tensions on the Korean peninsula, Russiaâ€™s Sputnik news agency reported. â€I would like to confirm that we are categorically against the expansion of the club of nuclear states, including through the Korean Peninsula,â€ Putin told reporters. â€We are against it and consider it counterproductive, damaging, dangerous,â€ he said. But in comments that appeared aimed at the US, he said that â€intimidating (North Korea) is unacceptable.â€ For its part, North Korea said the missile test was in response to the nuclear dangers and threats posed by the US and its followers. â€We will conduct ICBM tests anytime and anywhere in accordance with the decisions made by our central leadership,â€ North Koreaâ€™s ambassador to China Ji Jae Ryong said at an impromptu press conference at the countryâ€™s embassy in Beijing Monday. US territory in reach? North Korea tested a   missile Sunday which reached an altitude of 2, 111. 5 kilometers (1, 312 miles) and flew 787 kilometers (489 miles) according to state news agency KCNA.  Analysts estimated its ranged as 4, 500 kilometers which would put the US territory of Guam within its  reach.  A small island in the Pacific, Guam is home to Andersen Air Force Base, through which the US Air Force rotates heavy bombers including     and  . KCNA said the test showed North Korea â€has all powerful means for retaliatory strikeâ€ should Washington take any military action to stop its nuclear weapons program.  Putin made the comments on the sidelines of the One Belt One Road summit in Beijing, a meeting of 29 heads of state convened by Chinese President Xi Jinping to push his vision for Chinaâ€™s global expansion. The Russian president called on all parties to â€find peaceful solutions.â€ Putinâ€™s partial defense of North Korea came after White House press secretary Sean Spicer suggested that the missile test may provoke a more forceful response from the Kremlin.  In a White House statement released Sunday, Spicer said: â€With the missile impacting so close to Russian soil    in fact, closer to Russia than to Japan    the President cannot imagine that Russia is pleased.â€ The US and Russia also offered differing estimates for where the missile splashed down. The US said it terminated flight just 96 kilometers (60 miles) from the Russian port city of Vladivostock, whereas the Russian Defense Ministry said it landed 500 kilometers (311 miles) from its Pacific coast line.  Russiaâ€™s relations with North Korea  While Russia and North Korea donâ€™t have strong trade ties, they are building on their economic relationship. New ferry services are running between the countries and Russia has given permission for some 50, 000 North Koreans to carry out manual work on projects in Russia. Russia is one of the few countries that has diplomatic relations with North Korea. Kim Jong Unâ€™s father, Kim Jong Il, went to Moscow on a state visit during his rule in 2011, and Putin visited Pyongyang in 2000. â€While Russia is concerned about North Korea and its missiles, it also sees North Korea as an opportunity to gain leverage with the West, the US in particular,â€ said Matthew Chance, CNNâ€™s Moscow correspondent.  â€Russia doesnâ€™t want North Korea to have nuclear weapons, but the response from officials in Moscow has been minimal because they know Russia isnâ€™t one of Pyongyangâ€™s targets,â€ he added. UN Security Council condemns missile launches, The United Nations Security Council (UNSC) on Monday released a statement in which the members â€expressed their utmost concern over the Democratic Peopleâ€™s Republic of Koreaâ€™s highly destabilizing behavior and flagrant and provocative defianceâ€ of the Security Council. â€The members of the Security Council agreed that the Security Council would continue to closely monitor the situation and take further significant measures including sanctions, in line with the Councilâ€™s previously expressed determination,â€ the statement added. Last month, Russia and China backed a United Nations Security Council resolution condemning a previous missile launch, demanding that it â€immediatelyâ€ cease further actions that violate resolutions. Since US President Donald Trump took power in January, rhetoric has ramped up on both sides. Senior US officials made it clear early on that the Obama administrationâ€™s policy of â€strategic patienceâ€ on North Korea had failed. The Trump administration declared early on that the waiting was over, and followed through by deploying a US strike group, led by the aircraft carrier the USS Carl Vinson, to the waters off the Korean Peninsula. North Korea responded with threats and accusations. â€The US has recognized that direct military confrontation didnâ€™t work all that well last time,â€ Carl Baker, Director of Programs at Pacific Forum CSIS in Honolulu, Hawaii, told CNN. â€It didnâ€™t have the effect that they had desired, so they will let (further developments) play out in the UNSC.â€

title: Theresa May Is Poised to Be Britainâ€™s Next Prime Minister - The New York Times
content: LONDON  â€”   Theresa May emerged on Monday as Britainâ€™s next prime minister, becoming the second woman, after Margaret Thatcher, to hold that post. She faces multiple challenges as soon as she takes office, from negotiating the nationâ€™s departure from the European Union to addressing deep social and political divisions to reviving a wounded economy. Her victory came on another day of rapid developments in British politics and set in motion a process that officials said would put her in 10 Downing Street by Wednesday night, succeeding David Cameron. Ms. May, until now Britainâ€™s home secretary, is set to take over at a time of immense upheaval. The nation must not only negotiate its withdrawal from the European Union, a process fraught with economic and political risks, but it must also hold itself together amid a renewed clamor from Scotland for independence. Early signs are that Britainâ€™s economy has already taken a substantial hit from the exit vote, or â€œBrexit. â€ A Conservative like Mrs. Thatcher, who governed from 1979 to 1990, Ms. May, 59, has won a reputation for steeliness in her tenure as home secretary. She has pledged to negotiate a deal to leave the European Union that would reassert Britainâ€™s ability to control immigration, a central issue in the referendum on June 23 on whether to leave the bloc. Yet unlike Mrs. Thatcher, Ms. May is seen as a relative moderate and on Monday she promised to address inequality, give workers greater representation on corporate boards and limit tax cuts. Ms. May said that she was â€œhonored and humbledâ€ to be chosen for the job, promised to get the best deal over Britainâ€™s exit from the European Union, and vowed to create an economy that works not for the â€œprivileged few,â€ but for all. The British referendum on June 23 plunged the European Union into crisis. It left Britain rudderless as the pound sank in value and both the governing and opposition parties engaged in fierce and acrimonious leadership battles. Mr. Cameron, who had supported remaining in the European Union, said after the referendum that he would resign once the governing Conservatives selected a new leader, a process that he had expected to last until September but that was drastically accelerated on Monday. After making a brief statement describing his successor as â€œstrongâ€ and â€œcompetent,â€ Mr. Cameron was caught on a microphone humming as he returned to his office. Mr. Cameronâ€™s statement completed a day of high political drama in which Ms. Mayâ€™s rival for the Conservative Party leadership, Andrea Leadsom, the energy minister, withdrew from the race. Leading party members quickly coalesced around Ms. May, insisting that the contest should not be reopened. A party committee agreed. Ms. Leadsom had already faced accusations  â€”   which she denied  â€”   of embellishing her curriculum vitae, but her campaign ran aground over the weekend after The Times of London published an interview in which she suggested that she was a better candidate because she is a mother, while Ms. May is not. Surrounded by supportive lawmakers, Ms. Leadsom on Monday made no reference to that issue, but said that she was quitting the contest and endorsing Ms. May, and that she hoped to see her installed as prime minister â€œas soon as possible. â€ The turn of events meant that Ms. May would become prime minister without a general election and without completing the campaign she and Ms. Leadsom had been waging for the endorsement of the Conservative Partyâ€™s    members. Last week, the former Conservative cabinet minister Kenneth Clarke described Ms. May as a â€œbloody difficult woman,â€ noting that he had worked for another female politician of similar temperament, namely Mrs. Thatcher. Far from being insulted, Ms. May used the comment to suggest that her negotiating stance with European officials would be as tough as that of Mrs. Thatcher, who went into battle on the Continent, particularly over British financial contributions to the bloc. â€œKen Clarke might have found me to be a â€˜bloody difficult woman.â€™ The next person to find that out will be   Juncker,â€ she told fellow Conservative lawmakers, referring to the president of the European Commission, the blocâ€™s executive, ITV reported. But in a speech on Monday, Ms. May outlined an economic agenda unlike that of Mrs. Thatcher, calling for new mechanisms to curb executive pay and warning big multinational companies that they must pay their share of taxes. Ms. May has also been compared to Angela Merkel, the chancellor of Germany who, like Ms. May, is the daughter of a clergyman and is known for her   methodical and pragmatic approach. The   turmoil in Britain has also gripped the opposition Labour Party, prompting a challenge against its leader, Jeremy Corbyn, who has been accused of not campaigning hard enough against a British withdrawal from Europe. There were growing fears on Monday that the party might split because of the bitter dispute. Nevertheless, opposition politicians called for a general election and questioned Ms. Mayâ€™s democratic mandate, since she will assume the job on the basis of an internal transfer of power within the governing party. So far, Ms. May has rejected the notion of a quick general election. Her top priority will be to frame a negotiating strategy for leaving the union, after the referendum in which she sided with those who wanted to remain. On Monday, Ms. May insisted that â€œBrexit means Brexit,â€ as she sought to reassure   that she was committed to the policy, adding that â€œthere will be no attempt to remain inside the E. U. There will be no attempts to rejoin it by the back door, no second referendum. â€ But, while 52 percent of voters supported Brexit, they did so for differing reasons, including reasserting national sovereignty and opposition to migration from within the bloc, which guarantees the right to live and work within any member nation. Ms. May is expected to take a tough stance on immigration in part because she is politically vulnerable on the issue. As home secretary, she failed to fulfill a Conservative pledge to control the number of people arriving in Britain. The numbers persistently exceeded targets and included arrivals of   which the government had the power to curb. Ms. May has signaled her intention to restrict migration from Europe, even if doing so hurt Britainâ€™s position in negotiating a new trade deal with the bloc. She will also be under pressure from big business to secure the best possible access to Europeâ€™s single market, which normally entails accepting the principle of free movement of workers across national frontiers. One important question for Ms. May is when to invoke Article 50 of the European Unionâ€™s governing treaty, which starts the withdrawal procedure. That effectively sets a   deadline for a deal to be struck. She has suggested that she intends to wait until her government has settled on its negotiating stance before invoking the article despite pressure from Europeâ€™s leaders to act more quickly. On Monday she said more about her wider political agenda in a speech that offered plans to address some of the economic and social inequalities evident in Britain. Those include populist resentments thought to have motivated many   voters in economically depressed areas outside London and in the affluent southeast of England. â€œThere is a growing divide between a more prosperous older generation and a struggling younger generation. And there is a gaping chasm between wealthy London and the rest of the country,â€ she said, positioning herself in a centrist tradition of â€œone nationâ€ Conservatism. Speaking in Birmingham, England, Ms. May also called for efforts to increase productivity, for employees and consumers to gain seats on company boards and for votes on executive pay to become binding rather than advisory. Big multinationals should pay their share of taxes, she said, adding: â€œWhether youâ€™re Amazon, Google or Starbucks, you have a duty to put something back, you have a debt to your fellow citizens, you have a responsibility to pay your taxes. â€

title: A Casualty of â€˜The Birth of a Nationâ€™ Controversy Speaks Out - The New York Times
content: At Fox Searchlightâ€™s holiday party in New York last week, the Bagger bumped into a couple of stars from two of the studioâ€™s splashiest 2016 productions: one of the films soared to great heights, while the other crashed to an unimagined low. The first actor was Natalie Portman, who is raking in rave reviews for her performance in the title role in â€œJackieâ€ and is expecting her second child in a few months. The Bagger asked how she was faring on the awards circuit. â€œWhile pregnant and sober?â€ Ms. Portman dryly replied. The other actor was Colman Domingo, who played Hark in the slave revolt film â€œThe Birth of a Nation,â€ which, for the first half of this year, before controversy engulfed it, was considered one of the brightest prospects for the awards season. He said now that the uproar had subsided, he wanted to share his frustrations and disappointments about how everything played out. â€œYou walk into these rooms, and itâ€™s almost like a bittersweet look people give you in their eyes,â€ Mr. Domingo said. â€œI look at the work of my peers on the film, and I wish it was being celebrated. The cinematography, the music. Aja Naomi Kingâ€™s is one of the best performances of this year. But weâ€™re under the veil of the whole controversy, and people almost donâ€™t want to touch it. â€ It is hard to overstate the ebullience that met â€œThe Birth of a Nationâ€ at its premiere at Sundance in January. â€œBirth,â€ which tells of the slave rebellion led by Nat Turner in 1831, was the passion project of its director, writer and star, Nate Parker, who spent eight years pulling the financing together. The film arrived in Park City, Utah, just as Hollywood was fielding intense scrutiny for its   roster of Oscar acting nominees, and after a bidding war â€œBirthâ€ sold to Fox Searchlight for $17. 5 million, a festival record. There were projections of awards, and while other films featuring black protagonists  â€”   â€œMoonlight,â€ â€œFences,â€ â€œHidden Figuresâ€ and â€œLovingâ€  â€”   have come to dominate Oscar chatter, â€œBirthâ€ was initially at the fore. â€œIt felt like the film had an urgency,â€ Mr. Domingo said. Then, in the summer, after Oprah Winfrey and Spike Lee heartily endorsed the film, news articles emerged detailing harrowing rape accusations made in 1999 against Mr. Parker at Penn State, where he was a student and wrestler, and his roommate at the time, Jean McGianni Celestin (who would go on to share a story credit on the film). Mr. Parker was acquitted, and the case against the roommate, who was initially convicted, was reversed. After news broke that Mr. Parkerâ€™s accuser had killed herself in 2012, the scandal went nuclear. It all came to a head at the Toronto International Film Festival in September, when audiences responded to â€œBirthâ€ with standing ovations. At a jammed news conference attended by every lead in the cast, including Mr. Domingo, Mr. Parker deflected a pointed question (asked by the Bagger). Few would doubt the importance of the film, the Bagger said, but people were having trouble separating the artist from the art. And since the filmâ€™s message was one of moral accountability, people felt Mr. Parker should offer his accuserâ€™s family an apology. Would he now? Mr. Parker demurred, saying he was there to promote the film and celebrate the hundreds of people who made it. At that moment, Mr. Domingo, who had been sitting near Mr. Parker on the panel, said he felt the wind leave his sails. â€œThatâ€™s when I knew that the 45 minutes of the cast speaking in detail about the film would be eviscerated,â€ said Mr. Domingo, who is also a playwright and stars in televisionâ€™s â€œFear the Walking Dead. â€ â€œI was disappointed,â€ he continued. â€œI wouldâ€™ve handled it differently. Could he have handled it better? I donâ€™t know what itâ€™s like to walk in his shoes. I try to deal with things in a different way. I think Iâ€™m always trying to see the otherâ€™s point of view, dealing in a very    way. Itâ€™s    instead of   . But itâ€™s possible he felt embattled by the time he got to Toronto. This was something he created with the spirit of love and community, and suddenly heâ€™s battling other forces of something he dealt with 17 years ago. â€ (Mr. Parkerâ€™s acquittal came in 2001.) Over all, Mr. Domingo believed that Mr. Parker, whom he described as â€œdeeply passionate, generous and kind,â€ had handled the matter â€œthe best way he can. â€ Mr. Domingo also found fault with the Baggerâ€™s question, a criticism others have echoed. â€œLooking back in hindsight, I can see Nateâ€™s point of view. Why apologize when he was vindicated?â€ he asked. â€œBut I believe with the media, you must answer every question in some way. And in very, very, touchy situations, we must answer every question again and again. Even if weâ€™ve said it before, we have to say it again. â€ His   shared his discomfort. Aunjanue Ellis, who played Nat Turnerâ€™s mother, wrote in Ebony that she â€œagonizedâ€ over how Mr. Parker handled the fallout from the accusations and that she grieved for the accuser and her family. Still, she urged people to see the film, as did the groundbreaking director Julie Dash, telling the Bagger, at the Toronto film festival: â€œNo will always mean no. It will always be attached to that film. However, do not miss this experience of seeing that film. â€ But people did miss seeing that film, in droves: according to Box Office Mojo, it has earned just $15. 8 million domestically. Its case was not helped by some middling reviews. But there is no question that the controversy dealt a death blow. (Mr. Parkerâ€™s representatives did not respond to questions for this article.) Looking back, Mr. Domingo said he felt there was â€œa huge takedown by any means necessary,â€ not just toward the film but also toward black resistance in America. After a summer, he said, of â€œdealing with black men on the streets and retaliation and Black Lives Matter, Blue Lives Matter, All Lives Matter, itâ€™s almost as if this film was too powerful,â€ he said. â€œIt was like a big slap on the hand: Never try this again. Who do you think you are? If this were â€˜Madeaâ€™s Halloween,â€™ would they try to take it down? Absolutely not. â€ While opinionators, including Damon Young of the digital magazine Very Smart Brothas, have dismissed the notion of a concerted takedown, itâ€™s hard not to compare Mr. Parkerâ€™s scandal with that of Casey Affleck, the star of the current release â€œManchester by the Sea. â€ Mr. Affleck, who is white, faced sexual harassment complaints from two women  â€”   neither of whom would comment  â€”   and reached a settlement with them in 2010. Different circumstances, to be sure  â€”   â€œBirthâ€ also prominently featured rapes, while â€œManchesterâ€ is about a   family  â€”   but, still, the matter has not seemed to hurt Mr. Affleckâ€™s Oscar chances this season. In the end, Mr. Domingo said, the controversy could be seen as a reflection of how he often sees his position in American culture. â€œI feel in many ways as a black man in this country, you should apologize, or feel gratitude,â€ he said. In recent days, Mr. Domingo said, he has discerned a shift around â€œBirth,â€ with more people being able to see it on its own merit. â€œThis is one of the seminal moments in my career,â€ he said. â€œOne of the moments Iâ€™m so proud of in every way. But you canâ€™t feel proud of your work without the other feelings on top of it. â€

title: NYPD detective apologizes for Uber tirade
content: New York (CNN) A New York Police Department detective apologized Friday for an angry exchange with an Uber driver that was caught on video and landed him on modified assignment.  â€I apologize. I sincerely apologize,â€ Patrick Cherry told WNBCâ€™s Jonathan Dienst. Cherry, an NYPD detective assigned to the FBIâ€™s Joint Terrorism Task Force with   security clearance, faces suspension, reassignment or loss of his clearance after the video of the altercation went viral. â€I was just angry, at that moment, for that exchange.â€ Cherry said. â€If the conversation initially went differently, we probably would have shook hands at the end of that encounter.â€ The altercation began Monday when the Uber driver gestured to a detective in an unmarked car to use his blinker after he was allegedly attempting to park without using it, according to Sanjay Seth, a passenger in the car who uploaded the video to YouTube. The video picks up seconds after the detective began yelling at the driver and mocking his accent, and also shows the unmarked car with lights flashing pulled over behind the Uber car. In the video, the detective tells the driver he has committed â€three traffic and law violationsâ€  and then becomes irate and uses expletives toward the comparably calm driver. A visibly upset Police Commissioner William Bratton on Wednesday said the detective was placed on modified assignment pending an investigation. â€No good cop can watch that without a wince,â€ he told reporters. â€As all good cops know . .. the officer made their jobs a little bit harder. That kind of anger like that is unacceptable in any encounter discourtesy like that and language like that is unacceptable. That officerâ€™s behavior reflected poorly on everyone who wears our uniform.â€ Cherry also apologized to the police commissioner, saying â€heâ€™s doing a lot of good work to strengthen community relations in the city and I set that back. I would work, personally work to fix that.â€ â€You canâ€™t judge three minutes of a tape involving me and me alone as indication that thatâ€™s the kind of practice of the New York City Police Department,â€ he added. Bratton, who said the detective was on duty at the time, issued an apology to the driver and passengers.   Mayor Bill de Blasio told reporters at an unrelated news conference that he had not seen the video. â€Thereâ€™s just no place for any public servant to use discriminatory or negative language,â€ he said. â€Obviously, our police play a particularly sensitive role and need to show respect for all people.â€  In a statement, Michael Palladino, president of the Detectivesâ€™ Endowment Association, called the officer â€a person of good character and an excellent detectiveâ€ who â€should not be judged by one isolated incident.â€ â€I am not trying to minimize the significance of what occurred,â€ Palladino said. â€I am simply pointing out that cops are just like everyone else. They have families, friends and other things going on in their lives, too, that may affect their behavior at times. There is no disputing that we are held to a higher standard, that is why this incident is so newsworthy.â€ In the video, after the detective steps back to his car, the Uber driver, who moved to America less than two years ago, turns to the passenger and thanks him for recording the video. â€Thatâ€™s crazy. Thatâ€™s really inappropriate,â€ the passenger tells the driver. â€Listen, itâ€™s not your fault. He shouldnâ€™t be slamming your car door, throwing things around. He doesnâ€™t have a right to open your door.â€ When the detective comes back, he is irate and doesnâ€™t allow the driver to speak. â€I donâ€™t care what you have to say, people are allowed to park their cars on the side of the street without your interference,â€ the detective tells the driver. â€I donâ€™t know where youâ€™re coming from, where you think itâ€™s appropriate in doing that. Thatâ€™s the way it works.â€ â€Iâ€™ve got news for you,â€ the detective says, â€the only reason youâ€™re not in handcuffs and going to jail and getting summons in the precinct is because I have things to do. Thatâ€™s the only reason thatâ€™s not happening. Because this isnâ€™t important enough for me. Youâ€™re not important enough. Donâ€™t ever do that again.â€ The NYPD said the Internal Affairs Bureau is investigating the incident. â€The behavior in the video is wrong and unacceptable and we appreciate the NYPD investigating the incident. We are in touch with our   who was subjected to this terrible experience and will continue to provide any support he needs,â€ Uber said Tuesday. Seth met Wednesday with an investigator from the Civilian Complaint Review Board, according to board spokeswoman Linda Sachs.  The investigator is attempting to interview the driver as well as the police officer.  The findings will be presented to the board, which will make an official determination on whether misconduct was committed, Sachs said. The board will either refer the decision to the NYPD with a disciplinary recommendation, or decide to bring up the officer on administrative charges, with the decision presented to the police commissioner.

title: Sanders: â€™The Model of Democratic Party Is Failingâ€™ - Breitbart
content: Sunday on CBSâ€™s â€œFace the Nation,â€ Sen Bernie Sanders ( ) declared the model of the Democratic Party was failing and pointed to Republican dominance in not just Congress, but in the states as well.  Sanders said, â€œWell, I think what is clear to anyone who looks at where the Democratic Party today is, that the model of the Democratic Party is failing. We have a Republican president who ran as a candidate as the most unpopular candidate in modern history of this country. Republicans control the House, the Senate,   of governorâ€™s chairs and in the last eight years they have picked up 900 legislative seats. Clearly, the Democratic Party has to change. â€ â€œAnd in my view what it has to become is a grassroots party, a party which makes decisions from the bottom on up, a party which is more dependent on small donations than large donations, a party, john, that speaks to the pain of the working class in this country. The middle class is shrinking. 43 million people living in poverty,â€ he continued. â€œAlmost all new income and wealth is going to the top 1%. People canâ€™t afford to send their kids to college. They canâ€™t afford childcare. They canâ€™t afford health care. The Democratic Party has to take the lead, rallying young people, working people, stand up to the billionaire class, and when we do that, youâ€™re going to see voter turnout swell. Youâ€™re going to see people coming in and running for office. Youâ€™re going to see Democrats regain control of the United States Congress. â€ Follow Pam Key on Twitter @pamkeyNEN

title: Meet the man behind Right Side Broadcasting, the network that live-streams every Donald Trump speech
content: â€™  â€™ â€   Joe Seales was a    dad between jobs. Then he started   watching Donald Trumpâ€™s speeches. â€ â€™   Seales is the CEO of Right Side Broadcasting Network, a website   known best for its YouTube channel, which has hosted feeds   of almost every single Trump rally, town hall, or public   appearance since July 2015. â€™ â€   With broadcasting experience working with   figures   like Glenn Beck, the RSBN CEO and business partner Adam Taxin, a   former reporter, decided they could easily broadcast Trump   events, which were getting    coverage on cable   networks, but were difficult to find online. They flew to Phoenix   on July 11 for Trumpâ€™s rally, turned on the livestream,   and immediately found an audience. â€ â€™   â€We covered that speech and did that live, we got a million views   on that speech within the first few months,â€ Seales told Business   Insider during an interview in September. â€Thatâ€™s when I knew:   â€™â€™Letâ€™s run with this. â€™â€™â€ â€™ â€™   Right Side Broadcasting Network has emerged as a tool for many   Trump fans, journalists, and campaign operatives. â€™ â€™The Trump campaign is blatant about its support   for the network, tweeting out links, while even Clinton campaign   staffers admit privately that they watch the feeds of speeches on   RSBN out of convenience. â€™ â€   The formula for the organizationâ€™s success is simple. The   cable networks often carried Trumpâ€™s speeches, which eschewed   policy detail and rote stump speech regurgitation for      zingers and audience participation. But Seales   recognized that while the networks chopped up the speeches and   posted bits on social media for news   value, â€ â€™  â€™ â€   RSBN has over 186, 000 subscribers on YouTube. MSNBC, by   comparison, has 173, 000 subscribers. RSBNâ€™s most popular   video  â€”   a clip of Secret Service agents surrounding Trump when a   fan tried to charge the stage  â€”   has over 2. 3 million views, while   several videos of entire Trump events have over a million views. â€ â€™   Though Seales said he initially funded the operation out of   pocket, he told Business Insider that RSBN is now completely     with an average of â€roughlyâ€ $  donation.   The RSBN website specifically touts the channelâ€™â€™s status as a     operation. â€™ â€™  â€™ â€™  â€™ â€™  â€™ â€   RSBN doesnâ€™t have the cash to afford a satellite truck, and   instead negotiates with venues and advanced staff in order to get   a hardwire internet connection to broadcast its streams. Its blog   is primarily populated with links to Trump   and   posts directly from   site Breitbart News. â€ â€™  â€™ â€™   Still, Seales has big plans for the operation. â€™ â€™   Over the next several months, RSBN wants to roll out additional   shows on their YouTube channel with the eventual goal of moving   toward a  â€™ â€™   Earlier last summer, Seales signed deals with conservative media   personalities Wayne Dupree and Pastor Mark Burns, who   independently reached out to the RSBN chief about simulcasting   shows on the network. Dupree approached RSBN in June about   starting a show. After several shows, Burns reached out to the   channel interested in launching his own show. â€™ â€™   Burns was a natural fit for the channel. A pastor with a   tiny worship center in South Carolina, Burns gained notoriety for   his televangelism, and was  by former Trump campaign manager Corey Lewandowski   last fall, garnering a spot introducing Trump at his   rallies. His   were so popular that RSBN began   posting clips of just the Burns intros. â€™ â€™  â€™ â€™   But growing from a skeleton crew broadcasting speeches to a   legitimate media organization has also presented obvious   challenges. â€™ â€™   Itâ€™â€™s unclear that the simulcasts with RSBNâ€™â€™s personalities, for   one, are particularly popular outside of a core group of RSBN   viewers. Dupreeâ€™â€™s shows generally garner far less views than   livestreams from rallies or even any of the      reporting that RSBN dubs â€.â€ â€™ â€™   And earlier this month, Burns was forced to apologize for   exaggerating his credentials  revealed that the pastor had lied   about being a part of a fraternity and serving in the US Army   Reserves. â€™ â€   RSBN defended Burns on its website, saying that the   pastorâ€™s fabrications were mistakes like those anyone else would   make. â€ â€™   â€Pastor Burns, we still love you, bro,â€ Seales . â€™ â€   Burns did not respond to Business Insiderâ€™s repeated request for   comment for this article. â€ â€   The   nature of the feed also attracts some of the     magnateâ€™s uglier followers. RSBN streams often fill   up with comments on the sidebar, which often   includes racially, religiously, and sexually charged   language. Seales said he recognizes criticism of   the RSBN comments feed, and told Business Insider he pays   staffers to comb back through comments, and block users posting   offensive material. â€ â€™   With less than two months until the election, Seales is starting   to play for a future he did not envision a year ago. â€™ â€™   â€Our goal is to be relevant after the election when there   are no more Trump speeches,â€ Seales said. â€™ â€™   Still, Seals acknowledged that â€ The network plans to open an office in DC if   Trump is elected, and will attempt to get White House Press Corps   credentials. â€™ â€™   A Clinton win could present more challenges. â€™ â€™    â€I â€™

title: Executive Gun Control: Five Seniors Obama Might Have Disarmed
content: On January 4 â€”  the day before President Obama announced his executive gun control to the nation â€”  the White House released an executive order fact sheet showing that a gun ban for some Social Security beneficiaries was being brought under the auspices of Obamaâ€™s executive action. [This particular gun ban immediately brings to mind the frequency with which grandmas and grandpas use guns to defend themselves and their families and forces the reader to consider what the plight of such seniors might be if Obama took away their guns.  What would have happened to these five seniors if Obama had taken away their guns? 1. On April 21,    Jewell Turner was sitting in her truck in Fort Worth, Texas, when a man walked up and stuck a knife to her throat. She was able to convince him to change his mind by sticking a gun in his face and telling him to â€œback off. â€ 2. On May 15,    Robert Dietz walked outside to check on his surveillance cameras after they had â€œgone dark. â€ According to KHOU. com, Dietz then â€œfound a man rummaging through a storage trailer he keeps parked under his carport. â€ The suspect hit Dietz in the head with a gas can, so Dietz opened fire, shooting the suspect in the stomach. 3. On September 2,    Harvey Lembo grew tired of the frequent robberies of his   apartment and bought a gun for  . The Portland Press Herald reports that Lembo is confined to a wheel chair and felt defenseless in the face of the robberies. Lembo said his place has been robbed â€œfive or six timesâ€ over the past few years, including a robbery in August 2015 in which the robber took his prescription pain pills and money. When a robber entered on the night of September 2, Lembo grabbed his newly purchased gun, wheeled his chair around to face the robber, and held him at gunpoint without incident until the robber tried to escape. Once the attempt at escape was made, Lembo shot the suspect, wounding him. 4. On September 21, an alleged   entered an Indianapolis home and pointed a gun at the head of an elderly woman, only to be shot numerous times by her husband. The suspect had entered the home believing the woman was alone, but the husband was in the back of the house and responded with a gun in his hand when he heard his wife under assault. 5. On September 22, an elderly homeowner in Phoenix, Arizona, had to use a gun for   after a suspect repeatedly tried to enter his home in broad daylight. According to CBS 5, the elderly homeowner was alone when he saw the suspect in his backyard. The homeowner grabbed a gun and met the suspect as he was allegedly attempting to enter through a window.  The homeowner said he warned the suspect that he was armed, but the suspect allegedly continued trying to enter. The homeowner then opened fire, striking him at least once. The police said, â€œThe homeowner reported perceiving a threat and fired at the subject, striking him. â€ Where would these elderly people and their families be right now if Obama had taken away their guns? Follow AWR Hawkins on Twitter: @AWRHawkins. Reach him directly at awrhawkins@breitbart. com.

title: Josh Elliott has reportedly been fired from CBS News after on-air blunder
content: â€™  â€™ â€™   Josh Elliott and CBS News are parting ways. â€™ â€ reports that   Elliott was fired surrounding fallout over his     announcement on Friday that he was leaving his job as the anchor   on CBSâ€™ digital channel, CBSN, for a broader role on CBS News. â€ â€   The columnâ€™s sources say that Elliottâ€™s announcement was   premature and CBS executives didnâ€™t know he was going to quit the   digital job. â€ â€™   â€This is a mess of epic proportions,â€ a network source told Page   Six. â€Nobody at the top at CBS News knew that Josh was going to   do that.â€ â€™ â€™   Elliott reportedly met with CBS News executives on Monday   morning, was fired, and then was escorted out of the building by   security. â€™ â€™â€™ â€™   CBS News released the following statement: â€™ â€™     â€CBS News and Josh Elliott are parting ways. Josh will no     longer be reporting for CBS News. We are grateful for his     contributions over the last year, and we wish him the very best     in his future endeavors.â€   â€™ â€™   Over the past few years, Elliott jumped from ABCâ€™â€™s â€Good Morning   Americaâ€ to NBC News before landing at CBS about a year ago. â€™ â€™Josh Elliott and CBS News are parting ways. The. ..â€™ â€™â€™ â€™â€™ â€™â€™

title: The planet youâ€™ve probably never heard of
content: (CNN) Way out beyond Mars, but before you get to Jupiter, is a planet.  You read that right. Thereâ€™s a planet between Mars and Jupiter.  You may not have heard of it, but it was discovered in 1801    129 years before Pluto. It originally was called a planet, then later an asteroid and now itâ€™s called a dwarf planet. Its name is Ceres (pronounced like series) and youâ€™ll likely be hearing a lot more about it in the coming weeks. Ceres is one of five named dwarf planets recognized by NASA and the International Astronomical Union (IAU). The other four are Eris, Pluto, Makemake and Haumea.  But Ceres is the first of these worlds to get a visitor from Earth: NASAâ€™s Dawn spacecraft is arriving on March 6.  â€Ceres is a â€™planetâ€™ that youâ€™ve probably never heard of,â€ said Robert Mase, Dawn project manager at NASAâ€™s Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, California. Ceres may be considered a dwarf planet, but itâ€™s â€the giant of the main asteroid belt,â€ Dr. Marc Rayman, chief engineer and mission director of the Dawn mission, told CNN. â€It is not only the largest object between Mars and Jupiter, it is the largest object between the sun and Pluto that a spacecraft has not yet visited.â€ â€We are tremendously excited,â€ Rayman said. â€We have guided this robotic probe for well over seven years on an interplanetary journey of more than 3 billion miles. Along the way we sailed past Mars. We spent 14 months orbiting and scrutinizing the giant protoplanet Vesta. . .. Now, finally, we are on the verge of conducting the first exploration ever of the first dwarf planet.â€ Images taken on February 19 when Dawn was about 29, 000 miles (46, 000 kilometers) from Ceres show a bright spot on Ceres and a dimmer companion amid the small worldâ€™s cratered surface. NASA says both spots appear to be in the same basin.  The images are puzzling to scientists and they say theyâ€™ll have to wait until Dawn gets even closer to sort out the cause.  â€We we will have to wait for better resolution before we can make such geologic interpretations,â€ said Chris Russell, principal investigator for the Dawn mission, based at the University of California, Los Angeles.   Rayman said Ceresâ€™ surface is pretty beaten up and that its craters are â€scars from life in the rough and tumble asteroid belt.â€  Why study a   space rock? Rayman said because itâ€™s a survivor    and a mysterious one. Made up of rock and ice, Ceres may even have liquid water deep beneath its surface    â€perhaps as ponds or lakes or even oceans,â€ Rayman said. He said Ceres â€appears to have been in the process of growing to become a   planet when Jupiter terminated its growth nearly 4. 6 billion years ago.â€   So by studying Ceres, scientists learn more about how the rest of the solar system formed. And he said, we should study Ceres because itâ€™s there    and we need to understand the universe we live in. â€We should study it because we hunger for knowledge and understanding. Grand undertakings like this nurture our spirit,â€ Rayman said. Rayman said that if you had learned about the solar system 200 years ago, â€you would have learned that Ceres was a planet, just as people who learned about the solar system in more recent generations learned that Pluto is.â€ Speaking of Pluto, the most famous of the dwarf planets gets its own visitor in July. The New Horizons spacecraft is closing in for a flyby of Pluto and its moons. This talk of planets and dwarf planets is still a little confusing, so hereâ€™s the most recent tally: NASA currently recognizes eight planets: Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune, and the five named dwarf planets we listed earlier.  But a sixth possible dwarf planet already is on NASAâ€™s watch list. Called 2012 VP113, itâ€™s believed to be one of the most distant objects in our solar system. On its Solar System Exploration website, NASA says the object was nicknamed â€Bidenâ€ after Vice President Joseph Biden because of the VP in its initial designation. It will be up to the IAU to decide whether i2012 VP113 is a dwarf planet and whether it gets an official name. But expect the numbers for planets in our solar system to keep changing. Mike Brown, the CalTech astronomy professor who helped discover dwarf planet Eris and who takes responsibility for killing off Pluto as a   planet, has his own tally listing more than 360 possible dwarf planets. And NASA has said there may be many more dwarf planets that we havenâ€™t found yet.  So Ceres, and its cousins, may soon outnumber the traditional planets you learned about in grade school.

title: GOP Rep Franks on Hacks: Russia â€™Did What the Media Should Have Doneâ€™ - Breitbart
content: Rep Franks:â€If Russia succeeded in giving. ..info that was accurate. ..they merely did what the media shouldâ€™ve doneâ€ https:  .  Thursday in an interview with MSNBC, Rep. Trent Franks ( ) said while he supported measures to â€œprotectâ€ American elections, he argued the information that the Russians have been accused of hacking to underm,  â€œThe truth is, and I think that your own station sources would admit that most of what weâ€™re talking about now is based on leaks,â€ Franks said. â€œIâ€™m all for doing whatâ€™s necessary to protect the election here. But thereâ€™s no suggestion that Russia hacked into our voting system or anything like that. They, if anything, whatever they might have done was to try to use information in a way that may have affected something that they believed was in their best interests. â€ â€œBut  if the bottom line is if they succeeded  â€”   if Russia succeeded in giving the American people information that was accurate, then they merely did what the media should have done,â€ he added. (  The Hill) Follow Jeff Poor on Twitter @jeff_poor

title: Michelle Fields: In Her Own Words - Breitbart
content: I never sought to be part of the story. [On Tuesday night, I went to cover Donald Trumpâ€™s press conference at the Trump National Golf Club in Jupiter, Florida. I was looking to cover the event like I have covered many live political events for Breitbart News, including an uneventful Trump press conference in Palm Beach the week before.  Addressing the gathered reporters and the nation at large, Trump was in an especially jovial mood Tuesday night. The networks just declared he had won the Mississippi Republican primary and, during his speech, that he won Michigan Republican primary as well. I wasnâ€™t called upon to ask a question during the televised press conference, but afterwards Trump wandered around, stopping at every reporter to take their questions. When he approached me, I asked him about his view on an aspect of affirmative action.  Trump acknowledged the question, but before he could answer I was jolted backwards. Someone had grabbed me tightly by the arm and yanked me down. I almost fell to the ground, but was able to maintain my balance. Nonetheless, I was shaken.  The Washington Postâ€™s Ben Terris immediately remarked that it was Trumpâ€™s campaign manager, Corey Lewandowski, who aggressively tried to pull me to the ground. I quickly turned around and saw Lewandowski and Trump exiting the building together. No apology. No explanation for why he did this.   Even if Trump was done taking questions, Lewandowski would be out of line. Campaign managers arenâ€™t supposed to try to forcefully throw reporters to the ground, no matter the circumstance. But what made this especially jarring is that there was no hint Trump was done taking questions. No one was pushing him to get away. He seemed to have been happily answering queries from my fellow reporters just a moment before.   Many people have been asking me on Twitter and in emails what exactly happened Tuesday night. I hope this article answers those questions and I can get back to reporting the news, not being a part of it.

title: David Duke running for Senate seat in Louisiana
content: Washington (CNN) Former Ku Klux Klan Grand Wizard David Duke announced his US Senate campaign Friday in Louisiana, promising to defend the rights of European Americans. â€Thousands of special interest groups stand up for   Mexican Americans, Jewish Americans, etc. ,â€ he said in a YouTube video. â€The fact is that European Americans need at least one man in the United States, one man in Congress, who will defend their rights and heritage.â€ Duke, a former Republican state representative and convicted felon, said his emphasis on the rights of European Americans is what distinguishes him. â€I believe in equal rights for all and respect for all Americans. However what makes me different is I also demand respect for the rights and the heritage of European Americans,â€ he said.  Republican Sen. David Vitter announced last year that he would not run for office again when his term was up at the end of this year.  â€We must stop the massive immigration and ethnic cleansing of the people whose forefathers created America,â€ Duke said in the message. The former hate group leader said he popularized the â€America Firstâ€ slogan that Republican nominee Donald Trump has now embraced. â€I was the first major candidate in modern times to promote the term and policy of â€America First.â€ We can not have free trade without fair trade we must protect American jobs and businesses,â€ said Duke, who also said he is â€overjoyedâ€ by Trumpâ€™s campaign. Duke, who previously praised Trumpâ€™s candidacy, said heâ€™s â€overjoyedâ€ by Trumpâ€™s campaign. â€The New York Times admitted that my platform became the GOP mainstream and propelled Republican control of Congress,â€ he said. â€Iâ€™m overjoyed to see Donald Trump and most Americans embrace most of the issues that Iâ€™ve championed for years. My slogan remains â€™America First. â€™â€  Trump disavowed Duke in March after failing to do so when asked about the hate group leaderâ€™s support on CNN. The uproar started when Trump was asked by CNNâ€™s Jake Tapper on â€State of the Unionâ€ if he would disavow Duke and other white supremacist groups supporting his campaign. â€Just so you understand, I donâ€™t know anything about David Duke, OK?â€ Trump responded. The next day, Trump blamed a â€bad earpieceâ€ during an appearance on NBCâ€™s â€Today.â€  On Friday, Trump campaign spokeswoman Hope Hicks said Trump â€has disavowed David Duke and will continue to do so.â€ The National Republican Senatorial Committee leadership said Friday that they will not back Dukeâ€™s run â€under any circumstance.â€ â€Louisiana voters will be able to choose from several Republican Senate candidates who will have a great impact on the Bayou State and the future of our country. David Duke is not one of them,â€ the groupâ€™s executive director Ward Baker said in a statement. â€He will not have the support of the NRSC under any circumstance.â€ And on Saturday, Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus condemned Duke, tweeting, â€David Duke  his hateful bigotry have no place in the Republican Party  the RNC will never support his candidacy under any circumstance.â€ Other Republicans running for the seat include Rep. John Fleming, Rep. Charles Boustany, Jr. Retired Colonel Rob Maness, former Rep. Joseph Cao, State Treasurer John Kennedy and Abhay Patel. The Republican Party of Louisiana said Duke history of â€hateâ€ causes them to oppose his candidacy. â€David Dukeâ€™s history of hate marks a dark stain on Louisianaâ€™s past and has no place in our current conversation,â€ the group said in a statement. â€The Republican Party of Louisiana will play an active role in opposing David Dukeâ€™s candidacy.â€ CORRECTION: An earlier version of this story incorrectly described David Dukeâ€™s political career. He was a state representative.

title: Larry Wilmore: Bill Clintonâ€™s Affair with Monica Lewinsky â€™Was Predatory Behaviorâ€™ - Breitbart
content: Larry Wilmore, host of Comedy Centralâ€™s Nightly Show and keynote speaker at Saturdayâ€™s White House Correspondents Dinner, says Bill Clintonâ€™s amorous pursuit of Monica Lewinsky was â€œpredatory behavior,â€ â€œnot right,â€ and inconsiderate of his own daughter.  [From Politico:  Larry Wilmore really likes Bernie Sanders, is OK with Hillary Clinton and finds Donald Trump â€œinterestingâ€ in the coded language of a   of the liberal persuasion attempting to maintain a veneer of nonpartisan neutrality.  But when it comes to William Jefferson Clinton  â€”   whom he   referred to as a â€œ â€ on the â€œNightly Showâ€ recently  â€”   whoa. â€œAs president of the United States, he decided it was a good thing to fool around with a    staffer [Monica Lewinsky] in the White House,â€ a   Wilmore, the keynote speaker of this weekendâ€™s White House Correspondents Dinner told me during an (otherwise light) interview for POLITICOâ€™s â€œOff Messageâ€ podcast. â€œIt was predatory behavior, you know,â€ added Wilmore, who grew up in a Roman Catholic family outside of Los Angeles. â€œI really supported the Clintons politically, but that really bugged me, that whole Clinton thing.   â€¦     [I]t [still] does, because itâ€™s not  â€”   even though they both said it was consensual, youâ€™re the president of the United States. Thatâ€™s the workplace. You know, thatâ€™s a young girl. Come on, man. Youâ€™ve got a young daughter. Come on, you donâ€™t gotta do that. Thatâ€™s not right. â€ Read the rest of the story here.

title: Duterte Tells Civilians to Take Arms Against Islamic State Affiliate After Soldier Beheading - Breitbart
content: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has ordered an extended military operation against the Islamic State affiliate Abu Sayyaf and assured civilians that any violent action they take to subdue local terrorists will be forgiven in a court of law, following the arrest of a policewoman with ties to the group and the beheading of a soldier. [Abu Sayyaf, which has been active for years in the southern Philippines but more recently pledged allegiance to Islamic State caliph Abu Bakr   has become active in southern Bohol Island, a new territory for them. Duterteâ€™s administration has responded with a reinforced military presence in the region, while Duterte himself has threatened to cannibalize the jihadists.  â€œI can eat you,â€ Duterte said this week. â€œJust give me salt and vinegar. True. Make me mad. Get me a terrorist. Give me salt and vinegar. I will eat his liver. â€ In September, Duterte made a similar promise to â€œeatâ€ Abu Sayyaf terrorists, following a series of attacks on soldiers. Duterte also assured civilians living in affected regions that he would endeavor to protect their right to  . Speaking last week following an attack on soldiers in Bohol, Duterte said, â€œto the police  â€¦     and even civilians interested to fight and kill, the order is dead or alive. â€ â€œI intend to also arm the civilians and I will include the civilians  â€¦     you donâ€™t have to worry,â€ he said. â€œJust go to the police and make a report and state your truth  â€¦     no problem. Iâ€™ll take care of you, Iâ€™ll pardon you, whatever. â€ Duterte has taken a similar stand with drug criminals, assuring civilians of impunity if they kill drug offenders. In addition to the increasingly common clashes between Abu Sayyaf terrorists and police, law enforcement arrested a Philippine policewoman this week for ties to the group. Philippine National Police (PNP) Superintendent Maria Cristina Nobleza is under arrest after police found evidence that she had been engaged in an affair with an Abu Sayyaf bombmaker, potentially handing over sensitive information. The investigation into whether she was a source for the terrorist group is ongoing. Authorities also found the head of Sergeant Anni Siraji, a Philippine soldier abducted on April 20 by the terrorist group. Abu Sayyaf terrorists reportedly beheaded him this weekend after the soldier was assigned to work as an intermediary between the terrorists and police. â€œHe is involved in peace efforts,â€ Brigadier General Cirilito Sobejana told reporters. â€œHe is not actually a combatant. We are using him to engage stakeholders because he is a Tausug [like most Abu Sayyaf],â€ he added, referring to the manâ€™s ethnicity. Dutertespokesman Ernesto Abella called the beheading a â€œbarbaric actâ€ over the weekend and vowed more military action. â€œThe President is firm and decisive in the fight against terrorism,â€ he said. â€œHe has ordered government troops to carry out sustained, focused and intense operations to put an end to lawless and gruesome acts of violence. â€ The Philippine Star quotes another PNP official as stating, â€œ[Our] teams will do nothing except to â€˜eat Abu Sayyaf in breakfast, lunch and dinner. â€™â€ Duterte, who had repeatedly demanded the United States stay out of Philippine matters during the Obama administration, recently changed his disposition, requesting that American soldiers help his country fight the jihadist insurgency in the south. â€œAs we fought together to stay above the enemy then, so we should help each other to address the threats that confront our societies, our region, and our world,â€ Duterte said in April, reaching out to President Donald Trump, according to regional outlet   News.

title: Trump Organization Moves to Avoid Possible Conflicts of Interest - The New York Times
content: In its latest effort to defuse a major public relations problem that might have loomed over Donald J. Trumpâ€™s presidency, the Trump Organization on Wednesday announced union accords at two major hotel holdings. The agreements resolve labor disputes that could have posed a conflict of interest for the   and come on the heels of other similar moves in recent weeks. In November, Mr. Trump paid $25 million to settle a number of lawsuits surrounding fraud allegations at Trump University, his former   education business, and this month the Trump Organization extricated itself from the management of a hotel project in Brazil, where the authorities were investigating allegations of corruption. Taken together, the moves suggest that Mr. Trump is sensitive to at least the perception that his business dealings could cast a shadow over his presidency, even if he has yet to detail how he might seek a more comprehensive solution to potential conflicts, such as outright divestment. â€œOn the one hand, I think itâ€™s important to acknowledge that this is meaningful, it does matter,â€ Danielle Brian, the executive director of the Project on Government Oversight, a nonpartisan ethics watchdog group, said of Wednesdayâ€™s agreements. â€œHowever, this piecemeal approach to dealing with conflicts is not going to deal with the bigger looming problem. â€ The agreements also provide insight into Mr. Trumpâ€™s views on workers and labor unions. In contrast to the deal he helped broker at the Carrier plant in Indiana, which recently agreed to preserve about 850 jobs that it had planned to shift to Mexico, and which Mr. Trump was on hand to announce in person, the announcement of Wednesdayâ€™s deals came by way of a news release featuring statements from the Trump Organization and affiliates of the unions involved. The Trump transition team offered no comment and released no statement. One of the two labor agreements provides a union contract to workers at the Trump International Hotel Las Vegas, whose union the hotel had previously refused to bargain with. The second agreement eases a hurdle to unionization at a recently opened Trump hotel in Washington. The agreements reduce the probability that the National Labor Relations Board, which protects the labor rights of   employees, will be called on to adjudicate disputes between workers and the Trump Organization. That possibility raised the prospect of a conflict of interest if Mr. Trump were to retain a stake in his business. As president, Mr. Trump will eventually nominate all five members of the labor board, as well as its general counsel, who typically has the final say on whether to issue formal complaints against employers. The speed of the negotiations at the hotel in Las Vegas suggested that Mr. Trump was eager to put the issue behind him before his inauguration in January, after the hotel resisted workersâ€™ efforts to unionize there for most of the past year and a half. The hotel hired consultants who spoke with employees at mandatory meetings about the risks of unionizing, according to earlier statements from the union. In charges filed with the labor board, some workers alleged that they had been fired or suspended from their jobs because of their unionization efforts. After the successful union election last December, the hotel appealed within the labor board structure, arguing that workers had been intimidated into voting for the union. When the full board rejected its final appeal last month, the hotel appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Bethany Khan, a union representative, said the new labor agreement had come together over a few days of negotiation last week and been ratified by union members over the weekend. Under the accord, the workers will join locals for culinary workers and bartenders that are affiliated with Unite Here, a prominent national union that represents hotel workers. The two sides agreed to a contract beginning Jan. 1 and running through May 31, 2021, which follows a relatively standard template for hotels in Las Vegas by providing annual wage increases, pension and health benefits, and job protections. Under the second accord, the Trump International Hotel Washington D. C. agreed to remain neutral as workers seek to unionize under a   agreement, enabling workers to simply sign authorization cards indicating that they want to unionize. The hotel will recognize the union if a majority of workers sign cards. The alternative, a   election, typically occurs when the employer opposes the unionization effort, as was the case at the Las Vegas property. In a statement referring to the agreement in Washington, Eric Danziger, the chief executive of Trump Hotels, said, â€œWe share mutual goals with the union, as we both desire to ensure outstanding jobs for the employees, while also enabling the hotel to operate successfully in a competitive environment. â€ Wednesdayâ€™s agreements do not eliminate the potential for conflicts of interest involving Mr. Trump and the labor board. The boardâ€™s general counsel, whose replacement Mr. Trump will probably appoint next year, will be in a position to decide whether to issue complaints about allegations of labor rights violations, but could also leave the decision to career civil servants. Such allegations could include refusing to bargain with the union in the future, or firing or disciplining union stewards for sticking up for fellow members under procedures outlined in the contract. The decision on issuing a complaint is in some sense the critical step of the labor board process. There are typically 20, 000 to 25, 000 charges of unfair labor practices in a given year, of which only a fraction result in a complaint  â€”   about 1, 270 last year  â€”   although some are settled beforehand. Any complaint issued by a regional director or the general counsel could then come before the board, at least some of whose members are likely to have been appointed by Mr. Trump. But if the general counsel declines to issue a complaint, the charge is effectively dead and generally cannot be appealed. â€œItâ€™s the gateway into litigation,â€ said Wilma Liebman, a former labor board chairman. There remains an open charge of unfair labor practices against the Trump Organization, which was filed on behalf of a worker advocacy group in September over the contract that employees of the Trump presidential campaign were required to sign. The group alleged the contractâ€™s noncompete and confidentiality clauses illegally discouraged employees from exercising their labor rights. Mr. Trump and his organization faced a potentially punishing calculus in deciding to bargain with the union in Las Vegas, aside from the issues of conflict of interest. Even if the Trump hotel in Las Vegas had prevailed in its efforts to undo the union election in federal court, which was probably a long shot in itself, the culinary workers would probably have continued their unionization campaign, creating a lingering source of embarrassment for the  . In September, workers at the Boulder Station casino in Las Vegas  â€”   owned by a company controlled by Frank and Lorenzo Fertitta, who until recently operated the Ultimate Fighting Championship, a mixed martial arts promoter  â€”   voted to unionize after a dogged campaign by the union that lasted more than six years. The campaign included the creation of a website highlighting the   tirades of the president of the U. F.
