title: Trump pitched solar panels for his border wall to help cover the costs
content: â€™  â€™ â€™   In a meeting Tuesday with Republican leaders, Trump reportedly   suggested putting solar panels on the proposed   border   wall, and letting the generated electricity from the panels cover   some of the costs. â€™ â€™   Citing three people with direct knowledge of the talks on   Tuesday, Axios  Trump wanted the wall to be 40 to 50 feet tall, and   covered with solar panels. According to the report, Trump called   such a wall, which is intended to prevent people from entering   the US illegally, a â€beautiful structure.â€ â€™ â€™   Trump reportedly told the Republican lawmakers they were free to   talk about the wall as long as they credited him with the solar   panels idea, however it was unclear whether the proposal was   under serious consideration. â€™ â€™   Trumpâ€™â€™s pitch is similar to one the  reported on in April that was submitted to   the government by Gleason Partners of Las Vegas. That company   said solar panels on a border wall could pay for the wall within   20 years through energy sales to the US and Mexico. Electricity   generated from the panels â€would provide for lighting, sensors   and patrol stations along the wall,â€ the Associated Press   reported. â€™ â€™   Here are other   proposals, as reported by the AP: â€™ â€™In a meeting Tuesday with Republican leaders. ..â€™ â€™â€™ â€™â€™ â€™â€™

title: Trump Blasts â€™Democratsâ€™ Fantasy Worldâ€™ at Packed Iowa Rally
content: Republican nominee Donald Trump dismissed the narrative at the Democratic National Convention (DNC) that America is on track, saying Democrats are living in a â€œfantasy world. â€[â€œTheyâ€™re not talking about the real world,â€ Trump stated Wednesday night during his campaign rally in Davenport, Iowa. Trump was referencing President Obamaâ€™s speech referencing the billionaire and said the Democrats arenâ€™t discussing or acknowledging radical Islamic terrorism, open borders, crime, or real wages.  Trump, in Iowa, says Dems are being overly optimistic about the state of USA. â€I watched last night, and it was like all beautiful roses.â€  â€”   Ashley Killough (@KilloughCNN) July 28, 2016,  â€œThey donâ€™t talk about all of the problems we have in our country with education,â€ he added. â€œTheyâ€™re not talking about Obamacare  â€¦    Obamacare is a catastrophe. â€ â€œYouâ€™re going to have increases,â€ Trump warned about the cost of Obamacare. â€œItâ€™s   numbers. â€ â€œWe want to have those numbers revealed prior to the election on November 8,â€ he declared, alleging the Obama administration wants the numbers to come out in December. Trump also jabbed Obama over the debt doubling under his watch, adding thatâ€™s another issue not being discussed at the DNC. â€œWe canâ€™t go for another four years of Obama,â€ Trump stated, meaning Hillary Clinton. Trumpâ€™s campaign additionally released a press release Thursday evening, bashing the Democrats for their â€œfantasy world. â€ The press release read: At Hillary Clintonâ€™s convention this week, Democrats have been speaking about a world that doesnâ€™t exist. A world where America has full employment, where thereâ€™s no such thing as radical Islamic terrorism, where the border is totally secured, and where thousands of innocent Americans have not suffered from rising crime in cities like Baltimore and Chicago. In the Democratsâ€™ fantasy world, there is no problem with Hillary Clinton maintaining an illegal, exposed server full of classified information that could have been hacked by any foreign enemy, and in which Hillary Clinton risked prison time to delete 33, 000 emails that were simply about yoga and wedding planning. In this world, there is no Hillary Clinton disaster in Syria, Libya and Egypt, ISIS doesnâ€™t merit a mention, Iran isnâ€™t on the path to nukes, convention stages donâ€™t need American flags, and our great men and women of law enforcement, our police, do not need to be honored. I propose a different vision for America, one where we can break up Washingtonâ€™s rigged system, and empower all Americans to achieve their dreams. In our vision, we will put America First. If we deliver this change, the future is limitless and we will Make America Great Again for everyone. During his campaign rally in Davenport, Iowa, Trump appealed directly to Hawkeye state voters by promising to keep Iowa the first in the nation caucus state during the primaries, to aide beef sales regarding trade deals, and to help evangelicals by removing the Johnson Amendment, which silences churches on political issues due to tax exempt status. â€Iâ€™m not in love with the caucus system, I have to tell you. No insult,â€ Trump says in Davenport. But promises heâ€™ll keep Iowa 1st in nation,  â€”   Jennifer Jacobs (@JenniferJJacobs) July 28, 2016,  Trump to Iowa: â€If Iâ€™m president theyâ€™re gonna want your beef.â€  â€”   Jim Acosta (@Acosta) July 28, 2016,  Trump appealed to Iowa farmers  â€”   there are  roughly 20, 000 beef farms in the state  â€”   when discussing trade agreements with other countries. According to the Iowa Beef Industry Council, â€œIn 2014, Iowaâ€™s cattle industry contributed in excess of 7. 4 billion dollars in business activity to Iowaâ€™s economy. â€ In addition to the farmers, Trump appealed to evangelicals by promising to remove the Johnson Amendment  â€”   created by Lyndon Johnson  â€”   which prevents churches from speaking out on political issues due to tax exempt status. â€œI figure thatâ€™s one way Iâ€™m getting to heaven,â€ Trump joked. The rally was packed, with no vacant seats inside the Adler Theatre, which holds 2, 400 people.

title: Barbra Streisand Says She Will Move to Australia If Trump Becomes President - Breitbart
content: Add Barbra Streisand to the list of celebrities who will be moving out of the United States if Donald Trump is elected president in November. [The    singer and actress told 60 Minutes correspondent Michael Usher on Sunday that she will leave the country if Donald Trump is elected president.  â€œI worry,â€ Streisand said during the  interview that aired Sunday, according to the Daily Mail. â€œI donâ€™t take anything for granted. I want Hillary Clinton to be President of the United States. But there is still a lot of sexism, and â€˜A woman being president?â€™ you know, and making fun of her, the way [Donald Trump] insults her right and left, and has no facts. â€ â€œI canâ€™t believe it. Iâ€™m either coming to your country if youâ€™ll let me in, or Canada,â€ Streisand added, apparently referring to the possibility that Republican Donald Trump could be elected president. â€œYouâ€™re very, very welcome,â€ the   correspondent told the singer.  Streisand, one of Clintonâ€™s top celebrity backers in the 2016 race for the White House, has been increasingly vocal in her support for the Democratic candidate and increasingly open about her dislike of Republican Donald Trump. The Grammy, Emmy, Oscar and     is set to host an â€œLGBT for Hillaryâ€ dinner fundraiser next month at New York Cityâ€™s Cipriani Wall Street, with tickets ranging from $1, 200 all the way up to $250, 000. In March, Streisand penned an essay in which she blasted the â€œoutright sexismâ€ in the mediaâ€™s coverage of Clinton. â€œWhy is it that today even a woman as impressive as Hillary Clinton is judged not by her merits and extensive resume alone, but held to a pernicious double standard?â€ she wrote in a short essay for the Huffington Post. Last year, Streisand called the prospect of a Trump presidency â€œterrifyingly scary. â€ Streisand is just one of nearly a dozen celebrities who have publicly vowed to move out of the United States in the event that Trump is elected. Other stars who have made the same pledge include Whoopi Goldberg, Miley Cyrus, Samuel L. Jackson, George Lopez,   and Cher. Streisandâ€™s latest album, Encore: Movie Partners Sing Broadway, was released August 26.   Follow Daniel Nussbaum on Twitter: @dznussbaum

title: MILO Named LGBTQ Nationâ€™s 2016 Person Of The Year - Breitbart
content: Breitbart Senior Editor MILO has been named LGBTQ Nationâ€™s 2016 person of the year, an award for the â€œtop newsmakerâ€ in the LGBTQ community. [MILO beat Vice   Mike Pence for the top vote, receiving 70, 000 votes, over 80% of all votes. Pence also received a formidable 23, 000 votes.    LGBTQ Nation say interview with MILO will be released next week. In their announcement of the award, LGBTQ Nation noted some of the allegedly â€œawfulâ€ reasons why MILO made the news in 2016, before acknowledging the Breitbart senior editorâ€™s ability to influence the news cycle.  Yiannopoulos made the news throughout 2016 and always for truly awful reasons. He was a queer cheerleader for Donald Trump, whom he called â€œDaddy. â€ He has harassed and demeaned transgender people repeatedly. Hate him or love him, one thing Yiannopoulos truly excels at is getting attention for himself and his causes. If he decides to highlight an issue, his fans will follow his every word on the subject and more often than not, itâ€™ll get moved to a mainstream audience as the story picks up steam from online chatter. For a gay guy from Britain, he has truly made his mark on conservative American politics and entertainment. Heâ€™s been able to brand himself the ultimate gay provocateur in a year of provocateurs. Yiannopoulos, however, wanted to add to his list of accomplishments in 2016, telling LGBTQ Nation his list included, â€œMy banishment from Twitter, recently announced book deal (  now!)   college tour, my jawline, and a really cute Siberian fox  sable fur I just snapped up. â€ LGBTQ Nationâ€™s editorial staff added a note to the article indicating they removed a reference to MILO as a member of the   movement. Read the full announcement at LGBTQ Nation here. DANGEROUS is available to   now via Amazon, in hardcover and Kindle editions. And yes, MILO is reading the audiobook version himself!

title: French Media Censor Identities Of Terrorists - â€™To Avoid Glorificationâ€™
content: Major French media outlets  â€”   including Le Monde  â€”   have decided to stop publishing photographs and names of terrorists in a move that could become enshrined in French law. [Several major media outlets in France have decided to stop publishing the pictures of Islamic terrorists, some even censoring their names altogether.  The editorial boards of the television news network BFMTV, and newspapers Le Monde and Le Parisien have decided that they will no longer publish the photographs of Islamic terrorists. They all uniformly state that the reason is to â€œavoid glorificationâ€ of the jihadists after their deaths. In an editorial on Wednesday, director of Le Monde, Jerome Fenoglio, announced that the newspaper will not publish pictures of jihadists who have slain French men and women. He stated: â€œFollowing the Nice attack, we will no longer publish the photographs of perpetrators [of terrorism] in order to avoid possible posthumous glorification. â€   also made the move today by not airing photographs of Adel Kermiche, the jihadist who beheaded a priest in Normandy. Another newspaper, Le Croix, has taken it a step further by not only censoring images of terrorists but by identifying them by first name and initial, only. However, broadcaster Europe 1 has come out and said that it would neither reveal the picture nor name of future perpetrators of terror  â€”   redacting entirely jihadistsâ€™ identities. The broadcaster tweeted that it would not â€œmake heroesâ€ of the terrorists. @Europe1 ne citera plus les noms des terroristes Ã  lâ€™antenne pour ne pas en faire des hÃ©ros, dÃ©cision de la direction de la radio.  â€”   SDR_Europe1 (@SDR_Europe1) July 27, 2016,  The   have not stated whether this censorship of details will be rolled out to include all perpetrators of violent crime  â€”   such as serial killers or mass murders  â€”   or whether this practice will be isolated to those acts attributed to Islamic terrorism alone. Rising star of the populist right Marion Le Pen of the Front National reacted angrily to the media outletsâ€™ decision, questioning whether the   of the names and photographs of Islamist terrorists served the purpose to hide terrorismâ€™s link to immigration, a relationship that other European politicians like Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor OrbÃ¡n and Polandâ€™s Interior Minister Mariusz Blaszczak is not afraid to make. Les mÃ©dias annoncent lâ€™  des noms et photos des terroristes islamistes : pour mieux cacher le lien avec lâ€™immigration ?  â€”   Marion Le Pen (@Marion_M_Le_Pen) July 27, 2016,  However, not all major media outlets made pronounced declarations of  . francetÃ©lÃ©visions has decided to continue to identify the terrorists. In a statement by the director, Michel Field asserted: â€œWe have not waited for the recent events to adopt an ethical and responsible course of action in the treatment of terrorist horror. And we do not need statements or postures  â€¦    to do our work. â€ Evoking the â€œperverse effectâ€ of terrorist anonymisation: â€œAnonymous attacks, nameless and faceless perpetrators? Nothing better to provoke conspiracy theories, and promote a social anxiety from a population who already suspect that the media not always tells, or will want to silence, the truth. â€ However, whereas at this point media outlets are voluntarily   controlled media may soon be enshrined into French law. Juliette MÃ©adel, member of the Socialist party and the Secretary of State for victim support, announced that she has launched a working group that will propose the next steps on â€œrethink[ing] the ethics of the mediaâ€ in their coverage of domestic terror attacks committed in the name of Islam. Ms. MÃ©adel in an interview with Metro News said: â€œThe principle of freedom of information is essential. We must be informed of what is happeningâ€ but at the same time believes â€œwe must think of ways to provide information without necessarily delivering all the details of the identity or the biography of the terroristâ€. This is what the Secretary of State terms â€œresponsible journalismâ€. Working with the Secretary of State for digital media, and the Ministry of Culture and Communication, Ms. MÃ©adelâ€™s goal is to make proposals by September of this year, her aim to â€œconvince and ensure that all the media and â€˜Gafaâ€™ [Google, Apple, Facebook, Amazon] agree on ethicsâ€. This is not the first time that a European government official has colluded with media corporations such as Facebook in the policing of information. Breitbart London reported that in May of this year Facebook had signed a European Union pledge to suppress â€˜hate speechâ€™ and promote â€˜counter narrativesâ€™. This came after the German governmentâ€™s demand that social media giants Google, Facebook, and Twitter remove what it called   â€˜hate speechâ€™ from their platforms. However, Cedric Rouquette, the director of studies at the Journalists Training Centre (CFJ) in France, questioned the feasibility of such legislation: â€œEven if there are financial penalties for   with the proposed ban, the media will always prefer to pay and publish what is real information for the purpose of understanding  â€”   and certainly not to glorify. â€ The French media withholding the identities of terrorists from the public is reminiscent of Swedish police sending out a memo to all its officers ordering them not to release descriptions of crime suspects which include race or nationality to avoid accusations of racism.

title: A top medical institution ran a secret study on Theranos â€” hereâ€™s what it found
content: â€™â€™ â€™Medical researchers have finally gone and run the study on   startup  that observers have been waiting for.â€™ â€™A team from the  took a group of volunteers to have their blood tested at Theranos. To evaluate the results, they ran the same tests at Quest and LabCorp, the two companies that have long dominated   testing.â€™ â€™The team behind the study says that they found issues with certain Theranos tests, but that in other cases Theranos test results were roughly equivalent to the results from the other two major labs.â€™ â€Once the subject of adoring media coverage, Elizabeth Holmesâ€™ company has come under fire as serious doubts have surfaced about  along with .â€ â€™Many commenters have asked â€Why not just walk in, get a blood test, and compare the results?â€ But comparing the accuracy of new tests to existing lab services is more complicated than that. You need to run hundreds or thousands of tests before you can really assess how accurate a diagnostic test is.â€™ â€So when this group of medical researchers who specialize in understanding big data wanted to know how good Theranosâ€™ tests were and realized that there was no data, they decided to run a study on Theranos themselves.â€ â€™â€It got odd, to the point that itâ€™â€™s like, â€™â€™Well, thatâ€™â€™s really weird,â€™â€™â€ says Eric Schadt, the founding director of the Icahn Institute at Mount Sinai. So he says that he and coauthor Joel Dudley decided: â€Letâ€™â€™s do the test. â€â€™ â€™They published their results on March 28 .â€™ â€™Schadt says that certain Theranos tests regularly returned results that were far enough off that they could result in unnecessary clinical decisions, affecting patient care and medical research.â€™ â€™But he says that for many of the things they tested, Theranos results were â€much more in line with the others than they are out of line. â€â€™ â€™Even more interestingly, he says that â€there was as much variability between LabCorp and Quest as there was between Theranos and LabCorp or Theranos and Quest. â€â€™ â€™In other words, Theranos has problems, but no blood test is perfect and the labs that people have long used frequently return results with some degree of variation.â€™ â€Theranos disputes the studyâ€™s findings.â€ â€™Daniel Young, a Theranos vice president and lab director of the companyâ€™â€™s Scottsdale facility, tells Tech Insider that itâ€™â€™s still compiling a list of issues that it has with the study. But he says that â€we believe that some basic factors in the way the samples were collected could account for some of the differences that weâ€™â€™re seeing. â€â€™ â€™Schadt, Dudley, a group from Mount Sinai, and one Arizona researcher recruited 60 healthy adult volunteers. They selected 22 common lab tests that they knew Theranos would administer with just a finger prick, in theory taking advantage of the microfluidic technology that first made the company famous for running tests on just a single drop of blood.â€™ â€™â€™ â€They didnâ€™t talk to Theranos about what they planned to do before the study. Schadt says they decided against it at the time because they didnâ€™t want to give the impression that the company was influencing the results.â€ â€™They ran the study between July 27 and July 31 of 2015, when Theranos  for tests other than its one   test for herpes.â€™ â€The team split the 60 volunteers, 33 women and 27 men who ranged in age from 19 to 71, into groups of about five. On testing days, volunteers didnâ€™t eat and avoided exercise, so as not to influence results. Coordinators took them to a   Walgreens with a Theranos testing center inside. They took several samples of each individualâ€™s blood outside and took the individuals inside to get the full suite of 22 tests. Then they went to another Walgreens Theranos location and repeated the process.â€ â€™At one point, Schadt says that their New York team got a call from their Arizona coordinator, saying that a Theranos executive had shown up to ask why they were running so many tests.â€™ â€™But at the time, since they wanted to finish testing before tipping the company off, they said that they were part of a wellness institute that was focused on using testing to better understand health. Schadt says they even checked results that came in after the interruption to see if testing had become more precise in some way, but there were no observable changes.â€™ â€™The team drew enough blood from volunteers to have reference labs Quest and LabCorp run three tests for each individual Theranos test. The study included a total of 2, 640 Theranos results and 7, 920 results each for Quest and LabCorp  â€”   enough, Schadt says, to compare the results to each other.â€™ â€™For most blood tests, results vary day to day, so thereâ€™â€™s a range where results are considered â€normal.â€ The study found that Theranos was 1. 6 times as more likely to find results outside those ranges than either LabCorp or Quest, reporting results either above or below a normal range 12. 2% of the time, compared to 8. 3% of the time for LabCorp and 7. 5% of the time for Quest.â€™ â€™â€™ â€It is worth pointing out that  found that not all drops of blood extracted using just a finger prick are exactly the same. Some give different results for blood tests than others, which could explain some of Theranosâ€™ variation but also raises new questions about how feasible   blood tests are.â€ â€Theranos was more likely to reject blood samples, something that in   circumstances could mean a person has to return to the pharmacy to get tested again. Theranos reported no data for 2. 2% of samples, compared to 0. 2% for LabCorp and 0% for Quest. Technicians  when drawing a drop of blood with a finger prick and there wouldnâ€™t be enough backup material to rerun a test, though we donâ€™t know if that is the responsible factor here.â€ â€™Young says that methodological issues could explain why Theranos found more â€abnormalâ€ results and why they rejected more blood samples. He says that each lab may calculate whatâ€™â€™s normal in their own way, and so  â€”   depending on the test  â€”   a number that looks â€out of rangeâ€ to one lab might be normal to another.â€™ â€™â€Each laboratory essentially establishes or verifies their own reference range,â€ since depending on what specifically is being tested and the way itâ€™â€™s being analyzed, a different result may be expected, according to Young.â€™ â€Strange as that may sound, thatâ€™s not unusual, according to independent experts.â€ â€™â€™ â€™â€That is true for many [tests],â€ says Dr. David Koch, former president and current board member of the American Association for Clinical Chemistry and a professor at Emory University. â€But itâ€™â€™s not necessarily true for the lipid tests that this study points out as one of the main issues for Theranos. â€â€™ â€™The company performed most differently from the other services with   tests that measure cholesterol. In this study, Theranos consistently reported results about 10% lower than the other two reference labs, something the authors say would exceed federal regulatorsâ€™â€™ â€allowable errorâ€ margin. This could mean that someone who should be on medication for high cholesterol could get a result that tells them they are OK, which has clinical implications.â€™ â€Koch says the study does an important thing in pointing out that thereâ€™s a certain amount of variation thatâ€™s to be expected in many tests. But lipid tests, for cholesterol, are some of the few tests that are measured on a standard thatâ€™s generally internationally agreed upon, according to Koch.â€ â€™Young says that the ways the researchers interpreted the results could have made cholesterol results appear more abnormal than they are and that since their test is a unique one, it is going to return slightly different results.â€™ â€The Theranos team also argues that doing   tests after drawing blood from someoneâ€™s arm could have made it more likely that samples would be rejected.â€ â€™â€I donâ€™â€™t buy that,â€ says Koch.â€™ â€™Others agree. â€I canâ€™â€™t see how that would make a difference,â€ says Alan Wu, chief of the clinical chemistry and toxicology laboratories at San Francisco General Hospital. Still, Theranos says its internal data shows lower rejection rates.â€™ â€™A few differences aside,   results between the companies were fairly comparable. For 15 of the 22 tests, there was significant variation in the results between LabCorp, Quest, and Theranos. LabCorp consistently returned lower values for    count, while Theranos consistently reported higher counts of certain white blood cells. For the most part, these variations fit into the normal, allowable range.â€™ â€And as Young points out, this study just compares what Theranos found to what Quest and LabCorp found. We donâ€™t actually know what result was the most accurate.â€ â€™Schadt says that, problems aside, the results show that Theranos is at least â€on the right path,â€ and that perhaps if the company had been more open with its data in the first place it may have been able to fix some of its issues already.â€™ â€™â€™ â€We still donâ€™t have a complete, easy answer to the original question: Do Theranosâ€™ tests work?â€ â€Since the Mount Sinai team didnâ€™t coordinate with Theranos, they didnâ€™t know for sure that all the Theranos tests were actually run on proprietary Theranos technology, which raised some questions about the best way to interpret results.â€ â€™Theranos representatives have confirmed to Tech Insider that these tests were all run on Theranos technology.â€™ â€Schadt says they had reached out to Theranos since the study to confirm details of the study, but says that the company was not responsive. In a letter that Theranos sent to the Journal of Clinical Investigation that Tech Insider has reviewed, Theranos disputes that and says that itâ€™s confirmed that no Theranos executive received an email from Schadt.â€ â€Tech Insider has seen screenshots of LinkedIn messages that Schadt sent to Theranos COO and President Sunny Balwani and to Patrick Oâ€™Neill, chief creative officer of Theranos, though we havenâ€™t been able to confirm whether or not those messages arrived in the email inboxes of those executives.â€ â€™â€™ â€Still, even if these results tell us that some of Theranosâ€™ tests work  â€”   or donâ€™t  â€”   thatâ€™s perhaps even a bigger reason to study the rest of its tests.â€ â€The Mount Sinai team ran 22 different tests, but Theranos offers more than 100. They didnâ€™t run the tests for vitamin D, prostate cancer, and thyroid hormones that were  in The Wall Street Journal report that cited former Theranos employees, and so itâ€™s possible that the company still has problems with those tests  â€”   and potentially with many others. Or they could be within a normal range.â€ â€Outside experts say they think these results donâ€™t look great for Theranos.â€ â€Wu says that itâ€™s perfectly possible that some Theranos tests work much better than others, but if thatâ€™s the case, then a doctor who needs to get a number of tests done wonâ€™t want to send a patient to a Theranos center just for certain tests.â€ â€™ a professor of laboratory medicine and pathobiology at the University of Toronto who  points out that the study is just a snapshot of Theranos performance at one point in time, and that youâ€™â€™d want to see how effective its tests are over months or years if you could. But for now, he says, â€this paper outlines that low volume blood collection via finger prick (Theranos nanotainer) is not as good as standard venipunctureâ€ . .. for now, at least.â€™ â€™â€This article at least is pointing out that there are some systematic biases and this is rather striking,â€ says Koch.â€™ â€™Still, Schadt says that â€at the end of the day, you just want to know: How much confidence can I have in that result?â€ He doesnâ€™â€™t think the results necessarily look bad for Theranos.â€™ â€™Heâ€™â€™s not negative on what Theranos is trying to do and says that allowing people to get more health data and trying new ways of doing things is a good thing. But he wonders why itâ€™â€™s taken so long to figure out whether or not they work: â€The biggest surprise to me is, why did nobody else do this? â€â€™ â€™Asked about their biggest error, Schadt says itâ€™â€™s â€the thought that you donâ€™â€™t have to engage the medical community . .. to help calibrate and validate. â€â€™ â€Elizabeth Holmes has said Theranos considers the US Food and Drug Administration the ultimate arbiter of accuracy, but Schadt says that that isnâ€™t enough.â€ â€™He says:â€™ â€™Medical researchers have finally gone and run. ..â€™

title: Fake News: No, the Pope Hasnâ€™t â€˜Softenedâ€™ Teaching on Abortion
content: Pope Francis has granted all priests of the Catholic Church the faculty of absolving the sin of abortion, which several media outlets immediately misinterpreted as a â€œrelaxingâ€ of the Churchâ€™s stance on abortion. [The Independent, for example, stated that the measure â€œrepresents a significant softening of the churchâ€™s stance on the issue of abortion,â€ while a headline in the Italian daily Il Messaggero trumpeted that the Pope had â€œbroken the tabooâ€ of abortion. For its part, CNN declared that the Pope had said that â€œabortion is forgivable. â€  In another piece, CNN floated the still more ridiculous hypothesis that the Popeâ€™s letter â€œcould be read as the pontiff reflecting on some Catholicsâ€™ decision to vote for Donald Trump. â€ In point of fact, the Pope went out of his way to avoid just this sort of misreading of his intentions. â€œI wish to restate as firmly as I can that abortion is a grave sin, since it puts an end to an innocent life,â€ he wrote in the new letter Misericordia et Misera. â€œIn the same way, however, I can and must state that there is no sin that Godâ€™s mercy cannot reach and wipe away when it finds a repentant heart seeking to be reconciled with the Father. â€ Earlier this week, Francis used particularly blunt language to describe the evil of abortion, calling it both a â€œhorrendous crimeâ€ and a â€œvery grave sin. â€ In his Christmas message two years ago, the Pope compared the slaughter of millions of babies by abortion to the massacre of the innocents at the hand of King Herod, who sought to eliminate the newborn baby Jesus 2, 000 years ago. So, while Pope Francis has reiterated the iniquity of taking the life of an innocent unborn child, he has also wished to make it clear that there is no sin so great that God cannot forgive it. He has also sought to remove obstacles that might prevent people from seeking Godâ€™s mercy when they realize what they have done. Since Catholics consider abortion a particularly grave sin, those who engage in it incur the penalty of automatic excommunication, and so the Church only allowed bishops and designated priests to absolve it. In actual practice, bishops routinely extended this permission to any priest of the diocese who asked for it. A year ago, Pope Francis granted all priests the faculty of absolving the sin of abortion and lifting the excommunication attached to it for the duration of the Jubilee Year of Mercy. Now, he has made that measure permanent. The real news here is interesting enough without twisting it into something else. For some, apparently, the temptation is too strong to resist. Follow Thomas D. Williams on Twitter Follow @tdwilliamsrome.

title: Trump met with Chris Christie at the White House to talk about combatting the USâ€™s drug epidemic
content: â€™  â€™ â€™   President Donald Trump met with Chris Christie, the New Jersey   governor and former Trump campaign surrogate, at the White House   on Tuesday afternoon. â€™ â€   Trump and Christie, who were joined by Christieâ€™s wife, Mary Pat,   discussed how to best combat drug use over the lunch   meeting, reports .  â€ â€   Christie has made New Jerseyâ€™s opioid crisis a top priority for   the remaining months of his term as governor. â€ â€   Christie  that while he supports repealing and   replacing Obamacare, he wants Trump and congressional   Republicans to ensure that those covered by the Medicaid   expansion arenâ€™t hurt.  â€ â€™   â€Iâ€™â€™m really hopeful that weâ€™â€™re going to be able to be a   participant in that conversation,â€ Christie said on CNN,   adding that â€five timesâ€ as many people are now getting   treatment for drug abuse since Obamaâ€™â€™s Medicaid expansion took   effect.  â€™ â€™â€™ â€™   Without the Medicaid expansion, many drug users and addicts would   fall into a â€,â€ or be forced to wait months or even years to get into a     rehabilitation program, reports Business   Insiderâ€™â€™s Harrison Jacobs. â€™ â€™   Christie  â€”   who had the  of any governor in the past twenty   years  â€”   was the head of the Trump transition team before being    the vice   president. â€™ â€   The White House meeting between Christie and Trump stoked   speculation that Christie may be tapped as the new director   of the Office of National Drug Control Policy. Christieâ€™s term as   New Jersey governor ends in January 2018.  â€ â€™President Donald Trump met with Chris Christie. ..â€™ â€™â€™ â€™â€™ â€™â€™

title: Stabbings In Sacramento as Neo-Nazis, â€™Anti-Faâ€™ Clash at Capitol
content: Seven people were sent to the hospital with stab wounds, two with   injuries, on Sunday afternoon as Black Bloc anarchists attacked and fought with white supremacist groups outside the state Capitol in Sacramento. [Several other demonstrators who managed to avoid the hospital suffered bruises after the groups engaged in a chaotic melee.  The Black Bloc activists were part of a militant leftist â€œ â€ group,â€Antifa Sacramento. â€ The   extremists were members of the Traditionalist Worker Party and the Golden State Skinheads, and were holding a permitted rally. The   anarchists, carrying signs reading â€œNazi scum,â€ outnumbered the Traditionalist Workers Party   skinhead group, which was oringally slated to include members of other groups, including â€œBlood  Honor,â€ the National Socialist Movement, and the Ku Klux Klan. The â€œ â€ protestors carried signs reading â€œNazi scum. â€ Shortly before noon, emergency responders were called to the scene as the demonstrations turned violent. Insane video. Crowd sees any signs of â€œNazisâ€ and they runattack. A lot of people   maced. @ABC10 pic. twitter.   â€”   Frances Wang (@ABC10Frances) June 26, 2016, Police,   and traditionalist workers party clashing pic. twitter.   â€”   Ellen Garrison (@EllenGarrison) June 26, 2016, Nice try Naziâ€™ . #Sacramento : @DaveId pic. twitter.   â€”   #FreeJalilMuntaqim (@BlakeDontCrack) June 26, 2016,  Horrifying  â€¦    Blood spatters all over the ground. Police trying to control crowds. @ABC10 pic. twitter.   â€”   Frances Wang (@ABC10Frances) June 26, 2016, The Los Angeles Times also reported: Some protesters came dressed for battle, several seen carrying wooden batons and some wearing plastic shields. â€œThey came ready to fight,â€ said Cooper. One local television crew was accosted by the protesters that showed up to confront the white supremacist group. John Breedlove, a videographer for   said the protester â€œtook his skateboard and just slammed it into the reporterâ€™s gut. â€ Neither journalist was seriously injured. Many media reports are quoting the Southern Poverty Law Center, a   organization, which has provided a description of the Traditionalist Workers Party. For example, Fox News writes: The Southern Poverty Law Center described TWP as a group formed in 2015 as the political wing of the Traditionalist Youth Network, which aims to â€œindoctrinate high school and college students into white nationalism. â€ It is worth noting that the SPLC does not seem to acknowledge the rising danger of the â€œ â€ or â€œ  movement,â€ which makes no distinction between fringe groups like the Traditionalist Workers Party and ordinary people who attend Donald Trump events. As Breitbartâ€™s Adelle Nazarian points out: â€œThe   and Anarchists are one and the same now, and they also have the same colors, i. e. red and black. Under this same   or anarchist umbrella there are also anarchists that claim to not adhere to violence. The Black Bloc are part of this group, but they are actually the violent anarchists. This is a growing movement. â€ Members of â€œ â€ groups like the ones who attacked protestors have also been been responsible for a number of attacks around the country, including attacks on Donald Trump supporters at recent rallies. Some of these attacks follow hyperbolic allegations by some on the left (and even some on the right, such as Glenn Beck) that Donald Trump is â€œHitler. â€   groups were also behind the attack on journalist Lauren Southern from the Canadian news site The Rebel: Although the fringe Traditionalist Workers Party group claims to be against leftism, its political agenda shares many similarities with the far left, including its avowed support for socialism and its hostility to Israel and â€œZionists. â€ In a video broadcast discussing the attack, the TWP also favored the same racial separatist agenda as   groups. As previously reported by Breitbart News, groups like the Freedom Road Socialist Organization believe that Chicano and black people should have their own separate countries. Similarly, commentators on the   extremist Red Ice TV show have suggested that racial groups have their own land area. Similar views are shared by some members of   groups such as Black Lives Matter. title: Guardian: Israeli Self-defense Measures Are â€™Deadly Retaliationsâ€™
content: TEL AVIV  â€”   The Guardian ran a story Thursday in which it called Israeli   against Palestinian terror attacks â€œdeadly retaliations. â€[The article, which focused on Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahuâ€™s call to deport the families of terrorists to Gaza, opened with the following paragraph:  Binyamin Netanyahu has threatened to expel families of Palestinian attackers to Gaza after a   wave of violence against Israeli citizens and targets that has met with deadly retaliation from security forces. Media watchdog HonestReporting. com noted that the story was authored by Guardian â€œstaff and agencies,â€ and no other press agency, including the Associated Press, Reuters, and AFP, used that terminology, leading the watchdog to conclude that it was the Guardianâ€™s decision to refer to â€œdeadly retaliationâ€ by Israeli security forces. HonestReportingâ€™s Simon Plosker includes a dictionary definition of retaliate as â€œdo[ing] something bad to someone who has hurt you or treated you badly: to get revenge against someone. â€ Plosker writes: Israel is not taking revenge against Palestinians, which implies some level of malevolent intent or malice. And Israeli security forces taking actions to defending Israeli citizens or themselves from Palestinian terrorists or rioters is not inherently â€œbad,â€ it is legitimate  . Language is important. While Palestinian actions are described as a â€œwave of violence,â€ Israeli countermeasures are deemed to be â€œdeadly retaliation. â€ It is just this type of language that skews the current Palestinian wave of terror, turning Palestinian assailants into victims and Israelis into perpetrators. The Guardian has been accused of publishing articles that show an   bias. On more than one occasion, the UK newspaper was accused of publishing misleading headlines inverting Palestinian terrorism and its victims. Two weeks ago, Breitbart reported that the Guardianâ€˜s Readers Editor Chris Elliot said the newspaper was issuing new guidelines designed to â€œtell as much of the story as possible, especially where Palestinians are killed when attacking people. â€ More recently, Breitbart reported on a Guardian column claiming that Jewish collective memory was the root cause of Israelâ€™s â€œdeformed society. â€

title: Gun Control Groups Pivot, Look To Bloomberg For White House Win - Breitbart
content: The results of New Hampshire â€”  resounding wins for Bernie Sanders and Donald Trump â€”  have some gun control groups pivoting from away from Hillary Clinton and hoping Michael Bloomberg will step in to win the day for their side. [Gun control groups â€”  Connecticut Against Gun Violence (CAGV) Newtown Action Alliance, and others â€”  want to be sure a candidate who supports gun control wins the White House, and Clintonâ€™s current performance does not inspire their confidence.  According to CT Post, â€œClintonâ€™s stumbleâ€ has the potential of shifting political alliances. CAGV executive director Ron Pinciaro said, â€œOf course, Bloomberg has been very helpful on our issue, and we would see (his possible candidacy) as a good thing. â€ But Senator Richard Blumenthal ( ) â€”  a staunch Clinton supporter â€”  urged the gun control groups not to switch to their loyalties too quick. Blumenthal said: I have deep admiration for Michael Bloombergâ€™s eloquent advocacy on this issue, but I think Hillary Clinton has demonstrated over many years her equal passion and fervor. My hope is that no candidate owns this issue and that they are all on the right side with the same passion and commitment, and that it becomes a defining issue between the Democrat and Republican candidates, not among the candidates on our side. Yet gun control groups are already choosing between candidates on the Democrat side. Newtown Action Alliance chairwoman Po Murray had already made clear that her group believes Hillary will â€œgo    with the NRA,â€ but they donâ€™t trust Sanders to do the same. And Sandersâ€™ 2005 vote for the Protection of Lawful Commerce in Arms Act has cast a shadow over his campaign in the minds of many of gun control groups throughout the primary cycle â€”  even prior to his win in New Hampshire. Now that Sanders has demonstrated a clear ability to defeat Clinton, gun control groups are pivoting to find a way to protect their interests. That pivot puts Bloomberg front and center. AWR Hawkins is the Second Amendment columnist for Breitbart News and political analyst for Armed American Radio. Follow him on Twitter: @AWRHawkins. Reach him directly at awrhawkins@breitbart. com.

title: Itâ€™s Thrilling. Itâ€™s Chilling. Itâ€™s a 30-Minute Commercial. - The New York Times
content: â€œLifelineâ€ is a   thriller directed by an Academy Award winner about a manâ€™s search for his missing girlfriend. In the film, set in Shanghai with a plot driven by corporate malfeasance, punches are thrown, shots are fired and people are killed. At one point, the actress Olivia Munn stands over a dead woman, blood on her hands. But this is no ordinary movie. It is an online advertisement for the mobile technology company Qualcomm and, in particular, its Snapdragon 820 chip set, a smartphone processor. As more people skip or block ads when streaming shows or browsing websites, advertisers are trying to find new ways to deliver their messages. The internet has long been a place where companies have tried to break out of the   and   ad model, but as it has become easier to present   videos online  â€”   and as top directors and actors have shown a willingness to be involved  â€”   these efforts have become more sophisticated. The goal of â€œLifelineâ€ and similar ads is â€œto make something you want to see  â€”   and the holy grail is if people seek you out,â€ said Teddy Lynn, chief creative officer for content and social at Ogilvy  Mather, which produced the film. â€œThis is a piece of entertainment that can compete in a very crowded marketplace. â€ â€œLifelineâ€ was released in May and pushed out on multiple social media channels in the United States and China. â€œInside Lifeline,â€ a      look at the film, is also available on the â€œLifelineâ€ website. It emphasizes the importance of the cellphone to the action in the film and the phoneâ€™s various features the film hopes to highlight, like its long battery life and improved photo capability. In many ways, â€œLifelineâ€ is just an extension of product placement and show sponsorship by advertisers that goes back to the early days of radio and television, said Lou Aversano, chief executive of Ogilvy  Mather NY. â€œI think we continue to push, not just in terms of length, but in terms of the line between entertainment and brand message,â€ he said. Many companies are looking for ways to promote their brand through longer storytelling, such as Johnnie Walker, Nike and Prada. It is an impulse that dates to at least 2001 or 2002, when a series of eight   films for BMW starring Clive Owen appeared online. â€œThat was at the time the internet was still â€ said Steve Golin, founder and chief executive of Anonymous Content, a multimedia development company that produced the BMW ads and â€œLifeline. â€ â€œIt would take all night to download. â€ â€œLifeline,â€ which stars Ms. Munn, Leehom Wang and Joan Chen, is directed by Armando Bo, who won an Oscar for best original screenplay for â€œBirdmanâ€ in 2015. The film has attracted 20 million views. There have been an additional 100 million combined views of the filmâ€™s trailers and the    video, Mr. Lynn said. Eighty percent of the views came from China, which was the primary market. The dialogue is 70 percent in Chinese and 30 percent in English. Mr. Lynn said Qualcomm would not disclose the cost of the ad, but noted that with less money needed to buy time on television, more was available for the production. â€œYou can create content that is compelling and you donâ€™t have to spend money to place it on TV,â€ said Mr. Golin, whose company has been involved with movies like â€œSpotlightâ€ and â€œThe Revenantâ€ and TV shows like â€œMr. Robot. â€ â€œWe think this is the direction advertising is headed. As long as sports exists, we will still do   and   commercials, but with most other entertainment there is a lot of resistance to watching    advertising. â€ Mark Crispin Miller, a professor of media studies at New York University, said the disappearing boundaries between advertising and entertainment could be troubling. Ads, by their nature, often exaggerate â€œthe benefits or virtues of the products and, even more troubling, downplay the dangers or risk of a product,â€ Mr. Miller said. And using big stars â€œmakes the commercial intent even harder to perceive and blurs the true purpose behind the work. â€ Still, more advertisers are eager to experiment. Take â€œThe Ballad of the Dreadnought,â€ a   documentary about the distinctive guitar body originally manufactured by C. F. Martin  Company. It is narrated by Jeff Daniels and includes interviews with musicians like Rosanne Cash, Stephen Stills and Steve Miller. The film appears solely on Martinâ€™s website, but was selected to appear at several film festivals. It has received 40, 000 views since it first streamed on May 5, said Scott Byers, a managing partner at Lehigh Mining  Navigation, the advertising agency that developed the film. The documentary idea developed, Mr. Byers said, when Martin came to his agency wanting to celebrate the dreadnought guitar, which was developed in the early 20th century but never trademarked, enabling many other manufacturers to copy it over the years. â€œThey asked, â€˜What can we do to reclaim ownership of the shape? â€™â€ said Denis Aumiller, also a managing partner at the agency. â€œThe initial thought was that we would produce a short,   product video, or maybe a magazine article. â€ As enticing as it may be to think of every commercial as a potential short film that could play on the festival circuit, creating something that attracts viewers and promotes a product is not easy. Entertainment, after all, is not the ultimate goal. â€œAt some point,â€ Mr. Aversano said, â€œthereâ€™s a responsibility to deliver the message of the brand. Otherwise itâ€™s just empty calories. â€

title: Racing legend Stirling Moss hospitalized
content: (CNN) British motor racing legend Stirling Moss is stable in hospital after being admitted with a serious chest infection late last month, a statement posted on his website Saturday revealed. The    who is widely considered one of the greatest drivers never to win an Formula One title, was taken ill on December 22 in Singapore. â€Because of the severity of the infection it resulted in some complications and his recovery has not been as speedy as was expected or wished,â€ the statement read.  â€However, his condition continues to improve and his doctors now consider him to be stable. â€Stirling is in good spirits and only upset about having missed his Christmas cruise with friends,â€ the statement continued. Moss was an active race driver between 1948 and 1962, competing in numerous classifications and winning 212 of the 529 races he competed in. He was also an F1 driverâ€™s championship runner up on four occasions over the course of his career. READ: Schumacherâ€™s legacy lives on, READ: Rosberg clinches title in tense Abu Dhabi finale, READ: France announces the return of F1, READ: Five memorable F1 moments from 2016, Speaking to CNN in 2012, the daredevil Moss said the reason he got involved in motor racing was â€because it was dangerous.â€ Mossâ€™s wife, Susie Moss, said she was grateful to the medical staff at the Singapore hospital. Visit cnn.  for more news and videos, Once Moss is released he is expected to spend some time recuperating in Singapore.

title: Cheap Gas Prices are Trickle-Down Tax Cut of $1500 - Breitbart
content: Liberals should find a new respect for tax cuts, because cheaper gasoline prices are acting like a $1, 500 â€œ â€ tax cut for every American household, goosing revenue at local restaurants, groceries, charities and retail stories. [The United States has gone through the most epic increase in government spending over the last seven years as the Obama administration conducted an experiment in â€œ â€ economics, in which an increase in consumer demand would be stimulated through government spending, funded by higher taxes on the wealthy.  To pay for his â€œ â€ spending, President Obama and the   Democrat Congress in December 2010 passed Obamacare, the biggest tax increase in U. S. history. According to the Obama Administration â€œstaticâ€ economic models at the time, increases and decreases in federal tax rates would have no impact on economic economy. But that seems clearly wrong, given that the U. S. economy is recovering at the worst rate of growth from a recession in seven decades, and the national debt has almost doubled to $19. 1 trillion. This grim story gets worse when adding to the debt the â€œstatedâ€ underfunding of federal employee and military pensions retiree healthcare the underfunding of Social Security the underfunding of Medicare and the commitments and contingencies guarantees the federal government has made. The net national debt is $65 trillion, according to David Walker, former head of the   Government Accountability Office from 1998 to 2008. Despite average savings per American family of just $9, 149, the average familyâ€™s share of the $65 trillion federal debt is $796, 589, according to the U. S. Debt Clock. To pay off their share of all federal debts as if it were a   mortgage at a 4. 5 percent interest rate, each American family would need to make a $4, 036. 19 payment every month. Liberals have tried wordsmithing away the obvious benefits of President Ronald Reaganâ€™s lower tax rates that stimulate economic activity to generate higher labor demand and wages by calling them â€œ  economics. â€ But as Breitbart News reported, a 2012 study from Christina Romer, the Obama Administrationâ€™s first head of the Council of Economic Advisers, stated: â€œTax increases appear to have a very large, sustained, and highly significant negative impact on output   â€¦     [and] tax cuts have very large and persistent positive output effects. â€ Luckily, the private sector has partly offset Obamas policies. The American energy boom doubled U. S. oil production, cut gasoline prices, and created a quasi   worth about $1, 500 a year for each average American household. That private sector triumph is stimulating the economy by allowing Americans to redirect roughly 80 percent of the gasoline price savings to spending on other household priorities. Breitbart News calculates that for every penny decline in gasoline prices, American consumers are saving about $1 billion in energy costs. With average gasoline prices plunging from about $3. 34 a gallon in 2013 to $1. 77 a gallon on Feb 28, according to AAA, consumers are saving about $157 billion in annual gasoline spending. Adjusting the 1986 Reagan tax cuts of $68. 7 billion for 216 percent inflation equals about $148. 7 billion today, fairly similar to the impact of the current crash in gasoline prices. The JP Morgan Chase Institute estimates that from its huge national customer base of 57 million American credit and debit card holders, consumers will spend about 81 percent of their gasoline expenditures and save about 19 percent. JP Morgan Chase warned that it will take time for households to become confident that savings from lower gasoline prices are here to stay. But the bank suggests the breakdown in   spending from lower gasoline prices will be: 18 percent at restaurants, 23 percent on services, 33 percent on   10 percent on groceries, 6 percent on durable goods, 2 percent charitable donations and 8 percent â€œother. â€

title: Freedom Caucusâ€™ Jordan: Tweets and blame â€™donâ€™t change factsâ€™
content: Washington (CNN) One of President Donald Trumpâ€™s top targets didnâ€™t budge Sunday from his opposition to the failed Republican health care bill in the face of multiple critical tweets from President Donald Trump since the defeat of the proposal, saying the legislation was both bad policy and massively unpopular. â€Tweets and statements and blame donâ€™t change facts,â€ Republican Rep. Jim Jordan, an Ohio member of the conservative House Freedom Caucus, told Jake Tapper on CNNâ€™s â€State of the Union.â€  Citing a recent Quinnipiac University poll, Jordan asked incredulously, â€When have you seen a bill come forward where only 17% of the country supports it?â€ Trump took to Twitter on Thursday to call out Jordan, the former chairman of the conservative House group, as well as its current leader, Mark Meadows of North Carolina and fellow member Raul Labrador of Idaho over their opposition to the   GOP plan to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act, President Barack Obamaâ€™s signature health care program.  On Saturday, the White Houseâ€™s social media director, Dan Scavino, also went after another Freedom Caucus member, Michigan Rep. Justin Amash, saying Trumpâ€™s supporters should drive him out of office in the next primary election. Amash responded shortly afterward by tweeting that Trump had become like the very political establishment that he campaigned against and the caucus has opposed. Jordan defended Amash on Sunday and said he would come to his aid in a primary challenge. â€Justin Amash is a good friend and one of the most principled members of Congress,â€ Jordan said. â€And, frankly, if he is primaried, Iâ€™m going to do everything I can to help him. Richard Painter, a White House ethics lawyer under former President George W. Bush, tweeted that Scavinoâ€™s call to action violated the Hatch Act by using his government position to influence an election, saying the Bush administration would have fired him for such behavior. Scavino responded Sunday afternoon to comments from ethics lawyers, such as Painter, on the issue by tweeting from his personal Twitter account, â€What â€™ethics lawyers?â€™ The ones from the Obama Admin who want to take Trump down, or the Bush Admin who were #NeverTrump? No thanks!â€ He also made a tweak to his Twitter bio, removing the reference to his current White House position and substituting in his role as social media director for Trumpâ€™s campaign. Questioning process, Asked Sunday about the primary threats that those who opposed the GOP health care proposal, including himself, could face, Jordan said, â€If thatâ€™s what happens, thatâ€™s what happens.â€ Republicans needed to get back together on a health care bill that repealed Obamacare, he said, adding that the process needed to be more open next time and include input from interest groups and average citizens. â€Why not actually have doctors come in and testify, maybe hospitals testify, or maybe just some regular American families who this billâ€™s gonna impact,â€ Jordan said. â€Why not have that kind of process take place?â€ On Sunday, just a day after Scavinoâ€™s call to take down Amash, Trump tweeted that those who think the GOP health care proposal is dead donâ€™t know the â€love and strengthâ€ of the Republican Party and said talks to repeal and replace Obamacare will continue. The tweets came as something of a public shift for Trump. After House Speaker Paul Ryan pulled the bill in March amid opposition from conservative and moderate corners of the Republican Party, the Wisconsin Republican said Obamacare would remain the law of the land for the foreseeable future, and Trump said he would move on, likely to tax reform, until Obamacare â€explodes.â€  Trump spent part of his Sunday playing a game of golf and talking health care with Sen. Rand Paul, according to a White House spokeswoman. The Kentucky Republican was among the most vocal opponents of the   health care bill.

title: Propaganda film project backfires on North Korea
content: (CNN) A documentary intended as a portrayal of a happy family in North Korea has instead become a    look at how the countryâ€™s authorities manipulate appearances. The film â€Under the Sun,â€ which airs at a film festival in Washington on Thursday, assembles smuggled outtakes to show the inner workings of how a propaganda film is made in North Korea, a country known for fiercely controlling its image.  With a script agreed upon by North Korean officials and Russian documentary filmmaker Vitaly Mansky, the project began as a portrait of a supposedly ordinary    girl in Pyongyang named Ri Zin Mi, as she prepares to join the upcoming pageantry for the birthday of Kim Jong Il, the late North Korean leader. They also worked out access to the girl, her family, her home, her school, and even the workplaces of her parents. It is unclear whether the film crew and the North Koreans ever had the same vision for how the film should turn out. But soon after filming began, the filmmakers began to chafe at the expectations of the North Korean authorities. â€It was completely fake,â€ said producer Simone Baumann. â€They would come to the scene, and would tell the people what they have to do, where they have to sit, how they have to sit, how they have to smile, they would tell them what they have to say.â€ â€™Say that joyfullyâ€™ In scene after scene, the movie reveals the outtakes of North Korean handlers staging each scene for the cameras, instructing everyone on what to do, feeding them lines, and directing them to show more enthusiasm. In one setup, an official tells factory workers to be more effusive about their work. â€One more time. Why is your applause so weak?â€ he says. At a second factory, the handler feeds the workers lines about productivity and workplace satisfaction. â€Say that joyfully,â€ he adds. Even a highly decorated war veteran is not immune: a minder interrupts him and tells him to finish up his war stories, and segue to his scripted lines. And for a scene where the young Zin Mi is tucked into bed, two handlers are seen arranging the shot, right down to the blankets. As disputes worsened over the direction of the project, North Korean authorities announced they were pulling the plug. But the filmmakers still had the footage, including the outtakes, thanks to a camera that was always rolling, and a recording system that used two memory cards instead of one. Baumann said North Korean censors would review the footage every night and delete clips they did not approve of. But the camera crew, risking unknown consequences if they were caught, kept a duplicate memory card of each shoot.  â€The camerawoman is very brave. She put [the memory card] in her trousers when she went to the toilet,â€ said Baumann. â€They gave one of them to the North Koreans, and the second one they took with them.â€ Using the smuggled footage, the filmmakers decided to continue the project, unauthorized, as a    exposÃ©. â€We decided we had to show that everything is staged,â€ said Baumann. A sardonic explanation is shown onscreen near the beginning of the movie: â€The script of this film was assigned to us by the North Korean side. They also kindly provided us with a    escort service, chose our filming locations, and looked over all the footage we shot, to make sure we did not make any mistakes in showing the life of a perfectly ordinary family in the best country in the world.â€ Parents call director a hypocrite, The movie, with its arresting cinematography and deliberate pacing, includes rarely seen glimpses of daily life in the supposed workersâ€™ paradise: shuffling workers being harangued with loudspeaker slogans colorless streets almost devoid of cars and the dreary sight of piles of flowers carted away from a memorial where children had dutifully placed them. â€This film confirms the reality that everything is â€ said Robert Boynton of New York University, author of a book about North Korea called The   Zone. â€That whatever we see is what they want us to see, that peopleâ€™s lines are fed to them, that everything is choreographed.â€ But the girlâ€™s parents have been quoted denouncing the film, saying it was made under false pretenses and was selectively edited to make an â€  Korean movie.â€ According to a story on the North Korean news site Arirang Meari, they call the director a hypocrite, saying it was the director himself who often insisted on staging their daughterâ€™s scenes. â€Vitaly Mansky directed her, told her, â€™Do this, do that,â€™ â€ her mother is quoted as saying. â€We thought he was making the documentary for the purpose of a friendly cultural exchange,â€ she added. â€We did not know Mansky was such a   person.â€  The government of North Korea intensely protects its image, both at home and abroad. Indeed, shortly before Sony Pictures was to release â€The Interview,â€ a movie depicting the assassination of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, North Korean hackers launched a devastating   on the companyâ€™s infrastructure, according to American officials. The movie has been shown at film festivals, Citing fears of similar retaliatory   one American film festival curator even backed out of showing â€Under the Sun,â€ at the Museum of Modern Art in New York City. The museum has now disavowed that decision, according to museum spokeswoman Margaret Doyle, and the curator is no longer employed there. But in spite of North Korean officials writing to Russian officials demanding the film be blocked, the movie has been shown at film festivals in Russia, South Korea, and elsewhere, including the AFI Docs festival beginning Thursday in Washington. It is also scheduled for a limited run in U. S. theaters, starting July 6 at the Film Forum in New York Cityand July 15 at Laemmle Monica Film Center in Los Angeles. Boynton expects the North Korean family in the movie to suffer no blowback from the way the film turned out. But he added, â€I think the biggest fallout would be probably for, certainly the people who negotiated and allowed Mansky to enter the country, and secondly to the minders who guided his crew. They might be in trouble.â€

title: Baltimore Boy Stops, Prays for Homeless Man - Breitbart
content: A picture of a boy praying over a sleeping homeless man in Baltimore, Maryland, has gone viral on Facebook. [Jonathan A. Stormz said he watched the young boy walk past the homeless man, who was sleeping on the sidewalk. Stormz pulled out his phone as the boy began to approach the destitute stranger.  Stormz said he could not help but snap a photo as he watched the boy place his hand on the manâ€™s body and begin praying over him. â€œThis was an amazing sight! I pray this kid becomes a leader amongst his peers, and continues on this path! !â€ Stormz wrote on his Facebook page. â€œNot all Baltimore youth are lost! !â€ I watched as this young kid was walking pass, stopped and walked over to this sleeping homeless man touched him and  â€¦     Posted by Jonathan A. Stormz on Tuesday, March 1, 2016, Stormz said he had to share the moment with the rest of the world. The iconic picture has been shared more than 32, 000 times on Facebook. Follow Jerome Hudson on Twitter @jeromeehudson.

title: BuzzFeed Still Hounding Christian â€™Fixer Upperâ€™ Hosts
content: BuzzFeed has not let up on Christian TV stars Chip and Joanna Gaines, with reporter Kate Aurthur implicitly warning the hosts of HGTVâ€™s Fixer Upper that they will receive more bad press unless the show features a   couple. [On Thursday, the site posted a statement from HGTV affirming the networkâ€™s policy of LGBT inclusion the network was responding to a Tuesday article from Aurthur implying that the Christian hosts might discriminate against gay couples.  â€œWe donâ€™t discriminate against members of the LGBT community in any of our shows,â€ the network said in a statement. â€œHGTV is proud to have a crystal clear, consistent record of including people from all walks of life in its series. â€ That wasnâ€™t enough for Aurthur, who made a point of noting that Fixer Upper has not yet included a gay couple in each of its first three seasons: â€œWhen pressed about   couples being welcome on Fixer Upper in particular, the representative for HGTV highlighted the phrase â€œin any of our shows. â€ The series, which just launched its fourth season, has yet to do so. â€ Aurthur appears to insinuate that HGTV is   even after acknowledging in her previous article that two other popular programs on the network, Property Brothers and House Hunters, have featured gay couples in the past. The absence of gay couples on Fixer Upper is apparently enough evidence for BuzzFeed to suggest that the show, the couple and the network are all   bigots. Aurthurâ€™s second story on the Gaineses also claims that the first article â€œsparked a firestorm of criticism from Christians who argued that people who oppose   marriage and LGBT rights are persecuted by the media. â€ But most of the criticism of the first article came not just from Christians, but also from BuzzFeedâ€™s own readers and from many of Aurthurâ€™s peers in the media. As one BuzzFeed reader wrote in response to the first article: â€œThis is a tired, forced witch hunt. You are inciting a wave of negative attention on this couple for something that indirectly links to them. Thatâ€™s not journalism, itâ€™s petty bullsh*t. â€ BuzzFeed editor Ben Smithâ€™s weak response to the original article on his Twitter account was similarly challenged by journalists from the Daily Beast and Business Insider. Aurthurâ€™s original story reported that Chip and Joanna Gaines attend a church in their hometown of Waco, Texas whose founder, pastor Jimmy Seibert, believes in traditional marriage. In response to the story, Pastor Seibert told Fox Newsâ€™ Todd Starnes that his Antioch Community Church is â€œabsolutely notâ€  . â€œWe are not only not   but we are   people in their journey to find out who God is and who He has made them to be,â€ he said. â€œFor us  â€”   our heart has always been to love Jesus, preach the word of God and help people in their journey. â€   Follow Daniel Nussbaum on Twitter: @dznussbaum

title: Islamic Kindergarten Used For Orgies, Drugs
content: Sex orgies, drug use and other questionable activities are alleged to have taken place at an Islamic kindergarten in Vienna. [The allegations surround a network of Islamic kindergartens run by a man known only as â€œAbdullah Pâ€ who is currently under investigation on suspected charges of fraud.  One of the kindergartens, which are all subsidised by the Austrian tax payer, is said to have housed sex parties and has also been used as a front for selling and manufacturing drugs, as reported by Austrian paper Kronen Zeitung. The kindergarten, located in the Brigittenau suburb of Vienna, is considered the operational â€œheadquartersâ€ of Abdullah P. Information was handed to the police by witnesses of the sex parties and drug use.   Abdullah, who claims to be a â€œbusinessmanâ€ has been at the centre of controversy before over the   education and integration centres he has ran in the past. Several other Islamic kindergartens he currently runs have also been linked to the teaching of radical Islamist beliefs. The elementary school in Vienna was shut down last year by authorities who said it posed an â€œimminent danger. â€ It is unclear if these are the same schools that employed a Muslim woman who tried to join the Islamic State. The rise in links to radical Islam in Austrian kindergartens had led at least one Austrian academic to say that parallel societies are starting to emerge. The 26   witness who blew the whistle on the sex parties and drugs told prosecutors he learned about them via an online dating site. He said he became friends with one of Abdullahâ€™s colleagues who told him about the wild   parties. The colleague told the witness that he regularly celebrated with Abdullah by having sex parties at the kindergarten on Romano alley, and that they also consumed large quantities of various drugs. The witness also gave names and descriptions of other participants and told how a cleaning lady accidentally discovered â€œwhite powderâ€ in a drawer at the facility where children were daily. The facility may also play a role in the drug scene in the area according to police. Police say that a huge cache of 970 marijuana plants, discovered in a Vienna warehouse in January, may have been grown in an adjacent building to the Romano alley kindergarten. Abdullah took over the building shortly after the last tenant went bankrupt in December 2015. Abdullah had told authorities he acquired the building in order to create an Islamic school. The Muslim network of integration centres and faith schools, which Abdullah is the head of, are funded by Viennese tax payers to the tune of five million euros. The initial case against Abdullah revolves around his application for government money by creating false charities and forging documents in order to secure more cash from the taxpayer. Bogus registrations and false invoices led to him lining his own pockets with money that was meant to train kindergarten teachers and care for children. The total loss to the city is projected to amount to millions of euros. Abdullahâ€™s organization collected at least 1. 8 million euros over two years to May 2015.

title: Dylan, Polite? It Ainâ€™t Him, Babe - The New York Times
content: STOCKHOLM  â€”   â€œIâ€™m Not Thereâ€ was the title of a 2007 movie about the exquisite elusiveness of the singer Bob Dylan. It is also the unofficial theme of the week in Stockholm, where Mr. Dylan, who won the 2016 Nobel Prize in Literature, is not here to accept it. He has not been here for anything else, either. He did not attend the traditional news conference. He did not deliver the traditional lecture. He did not make the traditional visit to a local school, or take part in the traditional fancy dinner with the Swedish Academy, which awards the literature Nobel every year. (All those events were canceled.) And as he said before, he will not be at the ceremony on Saturday, when the literature prize is to be awarded along with the medicine, economics and science prizes, or at the banquet afterward. Though Mr. Dylan has sent a message of thanks to be read aloud, he has not dispatched someone to accept the award on his behalf, as other   have done. â€œFrom a P. R. viewpoint, itâ€™s been a disaster,â€ said Jens Liljestrand, the book editor at the Swedish newspaper Expressen. â€œItâ€™s been a very unfortunate autumn for the Swedish Academy. â€ Mr. Dylanâ€™s absence seems of a piece with his legendarily perverse unpredictability. But it has also saddled the highly secretive academy, which is nearly as inscrutable as Mr. Dylan, with the difficult task of explaining to the world why it does not feel insulted. As the debate rages in Sweden  â€”   is Mr. Dylanâ€™s behavior simple rudeness? a fear of being thrust into the Nobel spotlight? some sort of elaborate piece of performance art?  â€”   the academy has taken the position, at least publicly, that none of it matters. â€œI completely respect his decision, and I assume that he has very good reasons for not coming,â€ Sara Danius, the academyâ€™s permanent secretary, said in an interview. â€œHe may be completely booked, or he may have personal reasons. â€ But in a Nobelcentric place where the literature prize is such big news that people gather around their television sets every October to hear the announcement, Mr. Dylanâ€™s absence has been seen as faintly embarrassing at best. â€œHaving a Nobel Prize without a Nobel Prize winner is not much fun,â€ said the writer and former publisher Per Gedin. Some Swedes have spoken wistfully about what he is missing. â€œItâ€™s a really warm and welcoming program arranged to make the winner happy,â€ said the publisher Dorotea Bromberg, who recalled shepherding J. M. Coetzee, the South African writer, around Stockholm when he won the literature prize in 2003. Initially, Mr. Coetzee was reluctant, she said, but â€œday by day he warmed upâ€ and actually ended up enjoying himself. Mr. Dylan is not the only winner in recent years who has failed to appear. Others include Alice Munro, Doris Lessing, Harold Pinter and Elfriede Jelinek, but their reasons had to do with illness, old age and, in the case of Ms. Jelinek, various prohibitive phobias (crowds, flying). In each case, the winner either delivered a lecture that was filmed and transmitted to Stockholm or had the lecture read aloud. Mr. Dylanâ€™s absence, however, does seem consistent with his general approach. â€œHeâ€™s behaved so strangely for so many years that if he would show up now and be cheerful and pleased, youâ€™d be surprised,â€ said Daniel Sandstrom, the literary director at the publisher Albert Bonniers. Also, he said, Mr. Dylanâ€™s politeness (or not) should have no bearing on whether he deserves to win the prize. â€œIt would be very bad to award it just to nice people,â€ he said. Worse, in the view of some, is that Mr. Dylanâ€™s win may disqualify other Americans, like Don DeLillo and Philip Roth, from winning, at least in the near future. Mr. Dylan is the first American laureate to win since Toni Morrison did so in 1993. â€œItâ€™s very unkind, to put it mildly, to give it to an American but to give it to the wrong American,â€ said Mr. Gedin, who believes the prize should have gone to a more traditional writer. The academy is accustomed to unconventional behavior from Nobel laureates, who do not always exhibit unalloyed joy when they get the notifying telephone call. Some are scared some seem almost irritated some instruct their spouses to say they cannot come to the phone some affect an air of insouciant indifference. With the Belarussian journalist Svetlana Alexievich, who won last year, there was a language issue. â€œI tried French I tried German,â€ Ms. Danius said. â€œShe didnâ€™t understand what I was saying, although she did understand â€˜Nobelâ€™ and â€˜prize. â€™â€ But Mr. Dylanâ€™s behavior has been at the extreme end of the spectrum, starting from a failure, for nearly two weeks, to respond to Ms. Daniusâ€™s phone and email messages. â€œStrange things have happened before, but nothing on this level,â€ said Per Wastberg, the chairman of the Nobel Committee at the academy. Ms. Daniusâ€™s assertion that Mr. Dylanâ€™s behavior is not a concern  â€”   â€œThe important thing is that the Nobel Prize in Literature belongs to Bob Dylan,â€ she said  â€”   is testament to the academyâ€™s view of itself as impervious to outside criticism and pressure. Highly secretive about its inner workings, it exists as something of a paradox: both steeped in the world literary community and strangely apart from and above it. Founded to promote Swedish language and literature by King Gustaf III in 1786, the academy took on the Nobel literature responsibilities in 1901, the first year the prize was awarded (the winner was the French author Sully Prudhomme). Its 18 members, who serve until they die (they can stop attending meetings, but they cannot resign) are an idiosyncratic collection of writers, academics and specialists in  â€”   and advocates for  â€”   particular areas of literature. Each year, the academy invites academic institutions, scholars, literary organizations, former laureates and others to put forth nominees. You are not meant to nominate yourself, though it happens all the time. â€œWe get at least one letter a week from someone who says, â€˜Iâ€™m fantastic  â€”   you should read my book,â€™â€ Ms. Danius said. (These applicants are automatically disqualified.) Winners must have previously made the   shortlist at least once, and it seems that Mr. Dylanâ€™s name had been kicking around for a while. The prize is meant to reward a lifeâ€™s body of work, notwithstanding that even great writers produce material that not everyone loves. â€œDoris Lessing was on the shortlist for quite a while before my time, and then she wrote a series of   novels that sank her in the view of the academy,â€ Mr. Wastberg said. However, her name was resurrected  â€”   in part because of her   autobiography  â€”   and she won the prize in 2007. And what of Mr. Dylanâ€™s Nobel lecture, which under the terms of the prize is required to be given within six months of the ceremony? Rumor has it that heâ€™ll be in Stockholm next spring, â€œthough the details are still unclear,â€ Ms. Danius said, and he has said nothing about giving a speech. â€œIâ€™m not sure a regular concert will do it,â€ she added. â€œBut the Swedish Academy always tries to accommodate the laureateâ€™s wishes, so if thatâ€™s what heâ€™d like to propose, Iâ€™m certain there is a way. â€

title: Roger Stone: Cruz Doesnâ€™t Have â€˜Temperament to Be Presidentâ€™ - Breitbart
content: Veteran political operative Roger Stone questions whether Texas Sen. Ted Cruz has the â€œtemperamentâ€ to be president. On Breitbart News Daily on SiriusXM, Stone cited Cruzâ€™s testy interview with radio host Sean Hannity. [â€œThe pressure really is on Cruz now. Itâ€™s a very, very narrow path going forward,â€ Stone said. â€œI really wonder if Ted Cruz demonstrated he had the temperament to be president last night with Sean Hannity. I donâ€™t want my president blowing up like that. I donâ€™t want the guy with his finger on the button snapping like that. â€  Stone also called GOP frontrunner Donald Trumpâ€™s big win in New York a â€œmassacreâ€ and said Cruz should give up on Northeastern states while building support in California. â€œGiven the fact that Connecticut, the most Republican part of Connecticut, is in the New York media market, and that is also true of the upcoming New Jersey  â€”   the largest part of New Jersey, about 70 percent of New Jersey voters are in the New York media market. This is a win that has an impact on several of the bordering states. So it does magnify the win. This was a massacre,â€ said Stone. â€œTrump spent very little resources,â€ Stone said. â€œThis was once again Donald Trump himself campaigning across the upstate area an in places like Watertown on a very strategically clever operation and targeted congressional districts based on sophisticated polling.
