So we saw a new sophistication in the Trump campaign we havenâ€™t seen previously and I attribute this to a couple things. â€ Stone creditedâ€™s Paul Manafortâ€™s role in the campaign and a â€œ  local operationâ€ for delivering New York to Trump. â€œIt was a big, big win and it puts Ted Cruz at a real disadvantage going forward on this upcoming contests,â€ he said. â€œAnd that in turn can give them a head of steam going into California. â€ He also advised the Cruz campaign to cut its losses in the Northeast and focus on the upcoming California primary. One of the most important factors in the 2016 election, Stone said, was â€œvoters are upset with what they see as a broken system. They equate this with Congress. â€ â€œThis is Trump country,â€ Stone said of Northeastern states. â€œDelaware of course is    but not insignificant in terms of the count. I spoke to someone on Governor Marylandâ€™s staff yesterday. He tells me itâ€™s Trump country as far as they can see. â€ â€œYouâ€™re going to see the same phenomenon in Baltimore of Democrats being unhappy they canâ€™t vote in the Republican primary. Theyâ€™re going to show up in droves, I predict, and be turned away because theyâ€™re not allowed to vote under the state party rules. I think youâ€™re coming into a period here where this is Trumpâ€™s backyard. Heâ€™s expected to do well. Ted Cruz won Oklahoma and thatâ€™s next to Texas. And this in many ways is the same phenomenon,â€ Stone added. Breitbart News Daily airs from 6 am to 9 am EST weekdays on SiriusXM Patriot 125. LISTEN:

title: Source: Huma Abedin Has Not Served Anthony Weiner with Divorce Papers
content: Former Hillary Clinton aide Huma Abedin is not done with disgraced former politician Anthony Weiner yet, sources say. [A source told the New York Post that Abedin has not â€œserved [Weiner] with the divorce papers,â€ and she has invited him back home to their luxury duplex in New York Cityâ€™s Union Square, where she recently renewed the lease.  Abedin filed for divorce from Weiner the same day he pleaded guilty to a charge of sending explicit text messages to a    girl. Abedin and Weiner listed their 1, 500 square foot Union Square duplex for $11, 900 a month but recently pulled the listing. A source from the coupleâ€™s apartment building told the Post that Weiner, who was sleeping on his motherâ€™s couch, was â€œsupposed to moveâ€ Tuesday, â€œbut they just signed for another year. â€ The coupleâ€™s friend said Weiner takes on most of the caretaking duties for their    son. â€œHuma is worried about her son,â€ the friend said. â€œThatâ€™s her priority, and Anthony plays a very strong role in raising him. â€ Even though the couple separated in August 2016, Abedin has reportedly been â€œworking hardâ€ to salvage their relationship amid the sexting scandals. Weiner took a plea deal with the Manhattan U. S. Attorneyâ€™s Office, where he will register as a sex offender and could face 21 to 27 months in prison. He is due back in court for sentencing on September 8.

title: Exclusive â€” Behind Scenes at Presidential Inaugural Committee: Trump Inauguration to Have Less Pomp, Circumstance So He Can Get Right to Work - Breitbart
content: WASHINGTON, D. C.  â€”     Donald J. Trumpâ€™s inauguration will have less official celebration throughout the day and evening so he can focus on getting right to work on behalf of the American people, officials involved in the planning process tell Breitbart News. The inauguration itself will be less focused on the donor class and ritzy Washington insiders as in years past and more focused on the regular working class people across the country for whom Trump has become the champion. [â€œThe inauguration and inaugural is a representation of the   and a representation of the vice â€ Boris Epshteyn, the director of communications for the Presidential Inaugural Committee (PIC) told Breitbart News in an exclusive    tour of the PICâ€™s offices in Washington, D. C. on Thursday.   â€œWhat does that mean? Itâ€™s all about the people,â€ Epshteyn said. â€œItâ€™s not about any one celebrity or any one entertainer or about any of those folks sipping champagne and cocktails somewhere in the Hamptons or in Beverly Hills. Itâ€™s about the American people. Weâ€™re so proud of the amount of support and outreach weâ€™ve received from all over the country. This inaugural will represent the people. Thatâ€™s one, and two itâ€™s about getting to work right away. â€ So, logistically, what does this all mean? Specifically, Epshteyn says, Trump will only have three official inaugural balls as compared with 10 separate balls for Barack Obamaâ€™s 2009 inauguration. â€œThere will three balls instead of 10, as there were in 2009 with President Obama because this president â€”  Donald J. Trump â€”  is all about getting to work and making sure Americans are safe in their homes, safe in their jobs,â€ Epshteyn said. â€œLook at the news that just came out this week: 8, 000 jobs being brought to America between Sprint and OneWeb. â€ Alex Stroman, the deputy director of communications for the PIC, explained that President Trump will also continue the official    Inaugural Ball â€”  a tradition started by George W. Bush and continued by Obama â€”  and expand that. Previously, that ball had just enlisted members of the U. S. military in attendance. Trump is going to expand that ball to include first responders like police, firefighters and EMTs â€”  and will also allow in veterans, military families and wounded warriors. Stroman said: Usually a president will come in and theyâ€™ll have 10 official balls in addition to the unofficial balls that happen. President Obama had 10 in 2009, President Bush in 2001 and 2005 I believe had nine balls each in addition to the unofficial balls that took place. This president is going to attend three balls. We only have three official balls. We have two that are like the official balls, and then we have a third â€”  itâ€™s a tradition President Bush started in 2005 with the    ball, President Obama continued it and President Trump is also continuing it but expanding it. This ball, the general public canâ€™t get a ticket. Historically, itâ€™s only been active duty members of the military â€”  specifically enlisted members. This year, weâ€™ve expanded it to include military families, wounded warriors, veterans, and first responders as well. So youâ€™ll have police, firemen, who will all be there. Itâ€™ll be a thank you for them for their service to our country. Stroman explained that the extra focus is because Trump has an enormous amount of respect for all those who put their lives on the line to protect the country. He went on: I think youâ€™ve seen that [Trumpâ€™s respect for the military, police, veterans and first responders] throughout the  â€™s campaign. Some of my favorite photos are when you see every time he made a stop at his airplane, heâ€™d stop and take photos with the police who were protecting him. This is a president, heâ€™s vowed to be a law and order president. He respects our police, he respects our military, he respects those who put their lives on the line whether itâ€™s firemen or EMTs or police every day. He made that a point throughout his campaign to honor these folks, veterans, military, et cetera, who put their lives on the line for our country. Itâ€™s a way to, in one of his first acts as president, to thank those who do that. Another change from previous inaugurations, Stroman said, is that the parade from the Capitol to the White House on Inauguration Day is expected to be shortened to just an hour or so. That will allow Trump to get right to work at the White House on day one, before he goes to the balls later that night. Stroman told Breitbart: Youâ€™re going to have a parade that is going to be shortened. I think Eisenhowerâ€™s parade was something like six hours long. Youâ€™ve had previous parades that are three or four hours long. This is going to be a shorter parade, an hour to hour and a half or so so he can go to work. Thatâ€™s what the American people elected him to do: To go on with the traditions, heâ€™s going to have a church service, but heâ€™s not going to sit there for hours and then have this parade â€”  and of course for the people who come to Washington to watch the parade, heâ€™s going to have a shortened parade and heâ€™s going to go into the White House and get some work done before he goes to the balls. Again, the thinking, Stroman stressed, is that Trump wants to honor tradition while also wasting no time helping protect Americansâ€™ safety and jobs. He said: The   is about honoring the traditions, and this is a ceremony about the American people more than any one person. Youâ€™ve seen some previous inaugurations are really lavish, you have a lot of long events, a lot of big events. This   is somebody whoâ€™s ready to get to work. So if you look at the Carrier deal, look at Sprint today, look at the Boeing and Lockheed Martin stuff. Heâ€™s already â€”  and this is impressive with our leadership, at least in modern times, in that thereâ€™s a transition and   who is already getting to work before he even takes office. Youâ€™re going to see that reflected in the inauguration itself. Epshteyn added that while Trumpâ€™s inauguration is a â€œcelebration,â€ the focus is going to be on immediately getting to work on behalf of the American people. He said: This is a celebration. It is a celebration of freedom of democracy. There will two inaugural balls and one ball saluting armed services and first responders, which is so important. The first responders are a new addition too. This is the Commander in Chief ball, and weâ€™re honoring first responders because those are the people who are the firefighters and in the ambulances, and the police of course â€”  the police who keep us safe â€”  this is to honor them. These exclusive interviews with Epshteyn and Stroman came as PIC staff, including press secretary Ali Pardo, provided Breitbart News with an exclusive tour of the PIC offices in the General Services Administration (GSA) building near Lâ€™Enfant Plaza in Washington, D. C. The sprawling offices represent the beachhead of Trumpâ€™s looming takeover of the federal government, a culture very different from business as usual in government offices in Washington, D. C.        The halls of the GSA buildingâ€™s PIC corridors are decorated with Trump trophies, including a series of photo spreads of his rallies. A white board in one of the government offices has #MAGA â€”  the Twitter hashtag for the â€œMake America Great Againâ€ campaign slogan â€”  scribbled on it, while the official inaugural seal of the incoming president and vice president is on each of the doors. Make America Great hats line desks inside the communications office, as well.      In addition to the Trump rally photo spreads showing thousands of his supporters, the hallway is adorned with a giant ceramic   elephant â€”  complete with red legs and white stars inside its blue body.    Stroman notes that the building and the space technically are not funded by taxpayers, except for minimal building costs from the GSA. He said: The entire building is two city blocks long on each side. Weâ€™re in a GSA building, a GSA location, and the GSA for the last couple inaugurals by statute have given PIC access to the building for office space to support. They do the same thing for the transition. Itâ€™s a fairly new thing. They come in and they allow us to operate inside the government building, but weâ€™re a 501( c)4 so weâ€™re a not for profit. Itâ€™s not a government entity. Very few taxpayer dollars are expended except for allowing us to be in a building and turning on the lights and giving us temporary office furniture thatâ€™s pretty low key. Since the PIC is a nonprofit charged with putting together Inauguration Day and week, it fundraises â€”  without lobbyists, Stroman says, since the   wants no lobbyists involved â€”  to pay for the events. He went on to explain: We fundraise, weâ€™ve capped donations at a million dollars. No funds from lobbyists, but we do take individual and corporation dollars â€”  but the interesting point about that and the reason why thatâ€™s so important is because the underwriters are the ones who allow the general public to come and attend these and make sure we arenâ€™t using taxpayer dollars for the ceremony. Itâ€™s a group of folks who underwrite the expenses of the inaugural committee and the parade and the stands and the security and the fencing and renting the ballrooms and these people allow it so we can keep prices free or cheap. I wouldnâ€™t say thatâ€™s unique to ours but people kind of think the inauguration itself is kind of exclusive. But the inauguration is for the people and thatâ€™s something this president especially has given the charge to this committee to make sure. The tickets along the parade route, the majority of the parade route is open to the public. Weâ€™ll do a welcome concert on Thursday evening and while there will be ticketed guests the majority of those tickets will be free. And then in addition to the free tickets, you just have to request a ticket, there will be places for the public to watch if theyâ€™re just driving up to Washington. If youâ€™re driving up, people can come to Washington and celebrate this historic inauguration, celebrate this president and do it with minimal cost. Stroman noted that the role of the PIC is to help the transition have a successful Inauguration Day so that President Trumpâ€™s first 100 days can get off the starting block without a hitch â€”  and he can get rolling into setting up the government. The PIC deputy director said: The Presidential Inaugural Committeeâ€™s role is to plan any event outside of the actual swearing in ceremony. Itâ€™s to plan the balls, the parade, any kind of private events, family events, and then also does have a hand in the swearing in ceremony itself. It represents the  â€™s and the vice  â€™s interests in the ceremony itself as well, but also everything surrounding the inauguration. Itâ€™s interesting because our charge from the   is to help set up that kickoff point to that first 100 days. You have the transition that takes place immediately after and through the inauguration itself with the selection of cabinet appointees and kind of setting the initial messaging. Then you have us, whose job is to be that first picture from the second he raises his hand to take the oath of office through the rest of that day and that weekend. So they all kind of three work together. You have the presidential transition, the inaugural committee, and that first 100 days aspect of the administration. I feel itâ€™s our job to tie those three areas together, the transition and the kickoff of the first 100 days which is what the inauguration is. Expectations, he added, are that about a half a million people â€”  maybe more â€”  might make their way to Washington to witness the historic event in person. Stroman went on: We havenâ€™t put out any official numbers on our end here at PIC, but planners outside of PIC are saying probably a half a million or so. But I think the enthusiasm whether itâ€™s folks who make their way to D. C. or folks watching from around the world, I think itâ€™s going to be the biggest event ever. If you look at his rallies where he tens of thousands â€”  hundreds of thousands â€”  of people at rallies all across the country, the amount of interest youâ€™ve seen around the world in the first person to be   and no government service ever elected. So the interest all around the country and around the world is high. Pardo noted, too, that the PICâ€™s media team is working overtime to ensure that the hundreds of millions of Americans who wonâ€™t be able to make it to Washington for the inauguration festivities â€”  and the billions worldwide â€”  can get a front row seat to the action using media tools. â€œWeâ€™re also making sure weâ€™re providing that for people who arenâ€™t here, through technology â€”  weâ€™re being innovating,â€ Pardo said. â€œWeâ€™re trying to make sure everybody across the country has a seat to this historic day. Anyone can access it whether itâ€™s on social media or watching it on the news, but we want to make sure everyone has the ability to watch this historic event across the country and around the world. â€

title: How Yelp Reviews Can Help Improve Patient Care - The New York Times
content: Hospitals and many insurance carriers care about patient satisfaction. It especially matters to hospitals because insurance payments can be influenced by how patients rate the care they receive, as well as by the health of the patient, which hospitals usually report. Many people in the health care profession are put off by this. They argue that patient satisfaction scores arenâ€™t necessarily aligned with outcomes. Moreover, they say that trying to improve satisfaction is a waste of time. Itâ€™s possible, however, that patient satisfaction is being rewarded already, and that the efforts we are making to highlight it arenâ€™t helping as much as we think. Almost every study on patient satisfaction uses the Hospital Consumer Assessment of Healthcare Providers and Systems (H. C. A. H. P. S.) survey. Studies show it is correlated with clinical measures of quality, although some other studies dispute this. Collecting such information is costly, but there may be other sources for quality assessments that donâ€™t require investment from the health care system. In 2012, researchers in the Journal of General Internal Medicine examined online reviews from RateMDs. com and Yelp. They found that a majority of reviews were positive. They noted, however, that patients reported on aspects of care that extended beyond the   encounter. They were concerned about staff, access to the hospital and convenience. They also cared greatly about the bedside manner of the doctors they encountered. Dr. Naomi Bardach, associate professor of pediatrics and health policy at U. C. S. F. Benioff Childrenâ€™s Hospital San Francisco, and her colleagues looked at Yelp to determine how consumer ratings compared with those of the hospital consumer assessment survey. Of the almost 3, 800 hospitals with survey and other data, about 25 percent also had ratings on Yelp. The correlation between Yelp and the survey was quite strong. Moreover, high ratings at Yelp were correlated with lower mortality for myocardial infarctions and pneumonia  â€”   and fewer readmissions for those problems as well as heart failure. A recent study in Health Affairs expanded on this work. Researchers compared the content of Yelp narrative reviews with the factors considered important in the hospital consumer assessment survey. They found that Yelp reviews did cover most things the survey tallied. But they also covered an additional 12 criteria not in the survey. These included the cost of a visit insurance and billing scheduling compassion of staff family member care and the quality of many staff members. All of these things were important to patients, and all might be correlated with outcomes. More important, nine of the 15 most prevalent criteria in reviews were not included in the survey. The use of metrics like the hospital consumer assessment survey assumes that those in the health care system have figured out how best to measure patient satisfaction. They also assume that all the information we need should come from patients or from the medical record. Thatâ€™s not how the real world works. In a more recent study, Dr. Bardach found that the perceptions of other family members matter and can also be powerful because they focus on safety in a way that patients may not be able to do. The same is true of those who help care for patients at home and help make medical decisions for them. Their opinions are ignored by the survey. Those publicly available data may even be more comprehensive than that gathered at the behest of payers. The next question is whether the health care system needs to measure satisfaction  â€”   maybe the publicly available data, like at Yelp, is sufficient. Could those data be used alone to incentivize providers? A couple of weeks ago, my colleague Austin Frakt wrote a column on hospital quality and market share. He argued that people could improve their health by choosing a hospital that has a higher quality rating. He also underscored that patient satisfaction scores are often aligned with quality and with better outcomes. He highlighted a paper published in The American Economic Review that looked at how performance of hospitals was related to market share. Conventional wisdom holds that patients lack information on quality and that they cannot tell, or favor, providers who seem better. But researchers found that hospitals that performed better, on both outcomes and   measures, tended to have greater market share, and experienced greater market growth. Further, they found that as patients shifted to hospitals with higher performance, that change alone drove a significant amount in the improvements seen in overall survival rates for a number of conditions. Overall survival improved, in part, just because patients shifted from hospitals with lower quality to higher quality. If patients had the ability to choose between hospitals, they tended to gravitate to those with higher performance. In other words, this may be an area of health care where the free market is working. When allowed to choose, patients seem able to discern quality  â€”   as they define it  â€”   and gravitate toward it. Itâ€™s not clear that we need to be forcing the issue with measurement and reimbursement. Itâ€™s important to recognize, though, that this was a study of Medicare patients, all of whom arguably have more flexibility in terms of hospitals and doctors than those with private insurance. Those with private insurance often are restricted by â€œnarrow networksâ€ and directed to a few facilities and offices. Americans cry out for more choice in their health care. This sometimes gets translated to mean a choice of insurance companies. But Americans with   Medicare, who have the least choice of insurers, have the most choices when it comes to providers. And they seem to use that freedom to choose providers who perform better. I asked Dr. Bardach about this. â€œItâ€™s still unclear how people are getting the information to choose the hospitals, but the power of stories is likely an important part of why Yelp and other online reviews are compelling,â€ she said. â€œStories add nuance and context to the otherwise somewhat sterile numbers that the H. C. A. H. P. S. produces. â€ Research shows that patients reward quality on their own  â€”   when they can. We might just need to make it easier for more of them to do so.

title: Italy Reacts to Migrant Crisis by Accelerating Asylum, Deportations - Breitbart
content: The Italian parliament has signed into law a series of provisions designed to streamline the processing of asylum requests as well as the deportations of those whose requests are rejected. [As Breitbart News reported Thursday, the number of migrants arriving in Italy in the first quarter of 2017 has exceeded the previous record number by a remarkable 30 percent, and Italyâ€™s infrastructure for dealing with migrants has been stretched to the breaking point.  The     immigration law, named after its sponsors, Interior Minister Marco Minniti and Justice Minister Andrea Orlando, introduces several new features, such as the creation of new centers for repatriation, the elimination of the possibility of a second appeal, and a reduction of the time required for processing an asylum request. The new law allocates 19 million euros to expedite the deportation of asylum applicants who have been turned down. The new holding centers for repatriation with a capacity of 1, 600 persons will be established generally outside urban centers and close to transport infrastructure. The new measures have been praised by leaders of conservative parties such as the Northern League, but they still do not address the fundamental problem of daily arrivals of hundreds of new immigrants by sea. In recent weeks, Italyâ€™s failure to deal with the constant flow of economic migrants leaving from North Africa has drawn considerable criticism, even from groups such as Frontex, the European agency in charge of control of the EUâ€™s borders. In a report released in March, Frontex accused NGOs and other humanitarian organizations of providing a shuttle service for migrants from Africa to Europe, and in this way becoming accomplices of human traffickers by lowering their costs and improving their â€œbusiness model. â€ The presence of rescue vessels ready to transport migrants to Italy has created a significant â€œpull factor,â€ the report stated, significantly increasing the number of migrants who dare to attempt the crossing. â€œMigrants and refugees  â€”   encouraged by the stories of those who had successfully made it in the past  â€”   attempt the dangerous crossing since they are aware of and rely on humanitarian assistance to reach the EU,â€ the report said. Following the release of the report, an Italian public prosecutor pointed out the obvious: that rescue vessels should not be ferrying migrants to Italy in the first place, but to a nearer port, as established by international accords. Carmelo Zuccaro, the chief prosecutor of Catania (Sicily) noted that while it is not a crime to invade the waters of a foreign country to pick migrants up, it is a crime to illegally transport them to Italy. â€œWhat is punishable is bringing them to Italy without respecting the rules of engagement, which establish that vessels should take migrants to the nearest port, which is certainly not Italy,â€ he said. Italy will spend some 3. 9 billion euros ($4. 1 billion) on managing immigration this year alone, almost three times as much as in 2013. Follow Thomas D. Williams on Twitter  Follow @tdwilliamsrome

title: Pence: Hillary Cast â€™Racist Intentionâ€™ on Millions of Americans With Alt-Right Speech - Breitbart
content: Sunday on CNNâ€™s â€œState of the Union,â€ Republican   nominee Gov. Mike Pence ( ) said Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clintonâ€™s speech last week about the   movement cast â€œracist intentionâ€ on millions of Americans.  Pence said, â€œI think Sen. Kaineâ€™s comments, Hillary Clintonâ€™s comments on Thursday night sound desperate to me. I mean, to be honest with you. I donâ€™t talk a lot about the polls, Jake, but I know the polls are all closing up. And the fact that you see Democrats and Hillary Clinton and her running mate rolling out the same old playbook of racial divisiveness, sounds a little bit to me like an act of desperation. I mean, look, the American people are sick and tired of politicians who seek to divide the people of this country, to unite their supporters. â€ He added, â€œHillary Clinton literally condemned not just Donald Trump, by the same terms, but also millions of Americans who long for a better future   â€¦     I think she was calling millions of Americans around this country who believe we can make America great again, who believe that Hillary Clinton and Barack Obamaâ€™s policies have weakened Americaâ€™s place in the world and stifled Americaâ€™s economy, she has put some sort of racist intention those Americans. Thatâ€™s deeply offensive. The American people see through it these days. â€ Follow Pam Key on Twitter @pamkeyNEN

title: Mia Hamm: The most powerful woman in football?
content: (CNN) Sheâ€™s one of the most powerful women in football after cracking one of sportsâ€™ most notorious glass ceilings, but even Mia Hamm is not immune from the demands of domestic drudgery. Follow us on Twitter, @CNNSport, and Like us on Facebook. â€Sorry for all of the noise,â€ she says as the clatter of workmen and screaming kids crackles down the phone line. â€The people who were supposed to be here 30 minutes ago to fix our carpets have just shown up!â€ A proud mother of    twin girls and a baby boy, Hamm was for the best part of two decades Americaâ€™s foremost footballer. Though the World Cup winner and double Olympic gold medalist    described as â€the biggest U. S.  soccer star of all timeâ€    is swift to laugh off such lofty titles. â€Iâ€™m just a former player that every day has to wake up, get her kids to school and figure out what Iâ€™m making them for lunch and dinner,â€ the    Hamm, who played for the U. S. womenâ€™s team on over 200 occasions between 1987 and 2004, told CNN. However, itâ€™s not just the school run and her kidsâ€™ packed lunches that Hamm has on her mind these days. Appointed to the board of directors at major Italian club Roma, she occupies a position within the sport that few other women can match. As well as her role in the â€Eternal City,â€ the Alabama native is a minority owner of the   Los Angeles Football Club (LAFC)    which will join Major League Soccer (MLS) in 2017. â€I never stand up there and say â€™Iâ€™m doing this to get more women in football,â€™â€ says Hamm of her appointment at Roma, which is owned by Italian American investor James Pallotta. â€But I take pride in the fact and I look at it as a great responsibility to make sure I do the best job I can. â€I personally didnâ€™t say yes just to tick a box. I think they will soon learn that I have opinions, I have ideas.â€ Hammâ€™s links to the Italian capital go beyond the boardroom. Her parents lived in the city for over four years when she was younger, with her father    an Air Force pilot    working at the U. S. embassy in Rome. That was when Hamm first became aware of the team affectionately known as the â€Giallorossiâ€ (the  ). â€It was one of the clubs I could follow on the local TV,â€ she explains. â€It was the colors I would see when I would walk around Rome. â€So my holidays, Christmas and a couple of weeks over summer were spent over in Rome. AS Roma was the team I started following then.â€ Pallotta, who took over Roma in 2012, has grand ambitions for the club that include the construction of a new   stadium for the   Italian champions. The Bostonianâ€™s vision appealed to Hamm, who hopes to raise the clubâ€™s international profile    especially in the U. S. She wants to ensure that â€when people are talking about their favorite teams, AS Roma is one of the teams that comes out of their mouthâ€ and hopes the club continues its recent trend of touring the U. S. during the European offseason. â€Iâ€™d love to be a part of that and helping get the fan support,â€ she insists. â€Even though I know thereâ€™s an incredible fan support here for Roma.â€ Hammâ€™s own relationship with the game dates back to her childhood when, perhaps surprisingly, she had a hard time convincing her coach to let her play. That coach also happened to be her dad, and the eager Hamm was barely out of diapers. â€I wasnâ€™t allowed to play organized soccer until I turned five,â€ says Hamm. â€I had an older brother and a sister that were a year apart. They were on the same team and my dad happened to be coaching them.  â€I just remember standing on the sidelines, collecting balls for them when they went wide of the goal, hoping my dad would say, â€™Hey Mia, do you want to jump in?â€™  â€Those are some of the early memories, hanging out with older siblings, getting beat up by them and their friends at practice but loving it.  â€I just wanted to belong to a team.â€ Read: AC Milan unveils grand designs for futuristic stadium, Eventually her father relented and finally let the precocious ball girl enter the fray.  Hamm didnâ€™t look back. Her glittering career saw the prolific goalscorer help grow football in the U. S. firstly as the youngest member of the team which won the inaugural Womenâ€™s World Cup in 1991. Olympic glory followed as Hamm added a gold medal to her resume in front of fervent home support at the 1996 Altanta Games. Three years later    once again on home soil    Hamm scored in a tense penalty shootout as the U. S. narrowly beat China at the Pasadena Rose Bowl to lift the World Cup for a second time. Fast forward to Athens 2004 and she became a double Olympic champion, having added a silver medal to her collection of precious metals at the 2000 Games in Sydney. Hammâ€™s experiences within such successful teams had a profound effect on her as she grew in confidence, learned how to work with others, while also boosting her  . Above all, she learned how to handle failure. â€We have two daughters of our own who are about seven and a half and I just see the excitement,â€ she explains, â€the lessons that they are learning every single time they go out there. â€Itâ€™s no surprise to me. You look across the board, not just with female athletes but with Fortune 500 companies, and women that are in top executive positions all played some kind of sports growing up. They talk about the empowerment they felt. â€Getting kids up and motivated and then all of the wonderful things they experience and learn through sport are so important. Much more than you would ever get sat in front of your TV.â€ As well as her Roma role, Hamm is part of a band of celebrities who have signed up as minority owners of LAFC, a new team hoping to act as rivals to Los Angeles Galaxy, which won its fifth championship in 2014. NBA legend â€Magicâ€ Johnson and Hammâ€™s husband Nomar Garciaparra, a former pro baseball player, are both part of a   ownership team. The continued expansion of MLS    which commissioner Don Garber hopes will swell to 24 teams by 2020    is proof of soccerâ€™s growing popularity in the U. S. with women forming part of the professional ranks. Formed in 2013, the National Womenâ€™s Soccer League (NWSL) allows eight teams to vie for domestic glory, a welcome development following multiple false starts for the female game in America, the most recent setback arriving when Womenâ€™s Professional Soccer ceased operations in 2012. Although the country also boasts the Womenâ€™s Premier Soccer League    which houses both professional and amateur teams    Hamm hopes the NWSL can cement itself on the nationâ€™s sporting landscape. â€The success of the MLS will help the NWSL,â€ insists Hamm. â€The success of the U. S. national teams will help the NWSL. â€There are several teams that are tied to MLS clubs and that could be the potential for the future where weâ€™re able to share facilities, share infrastructure.â€ So when LAFC enters the league, will it also boast a womenâ€™s team? â€Donâ€™t know yet,â€ says a candid Hamm. â€For me, it just makes sense, in one of the largest hotbed of girlsâ€™ club soccer in the country, if not the world. â€Being a part of the ownership group, we have a lot of work ahead of us. The womenâ€™s team isnâ€™t their first priority, but I want it to be in the conversation.  â€Iâ€™m going to make sure itâ€™s something thatâ€™s discussed consistently because itâ€™s the right thing to do and this area will support it. There are so many talented players in this area, up and down the coast.â€ As far as Hamm is concerned, the future of U. S. soccer is bright    regardless of gender. â€Iâ€™m always hopeful, I love the game too much,â€ she says. â€It doesnâ€™t mean Iâ€™m naive, but I want the game to succeed in this country and the womenâ€™s side is a huge part of that.â€

title: Gingrich: Indiana â€™Life or Deathâ€™ For Cruz - Breitbart
content: On the Fox News Channelâ€™s â€œSunday Morning Futures with Maria Bartiromo,â€ former Speaker Newt Gingrich said Republican presidential candidate Sen. Ted Cruz ( ) must win â€œvirtually all the delegatesâ€ in the upcoming Indiana primary to have a chance at securing the GOP nomination.  Gingrich said, â€œIndiana is make or break for Cruz, and itâ€™s a bump in the road for Trump. If Cruz canâ€™t win Indiana, and by win I mean, get virtually all the delegates, do something like close to what he did in Wisconsin, thereâ€™s no possibility that he can stop Trump. Itâ€™ll just be over sometime Wednesday morning. On the other hand, if Trump doesnâ€™t do particularly well in Indiana, he has so much overall momentum, and itâ€™s such a huge lead that he could still win by winning in New Jersey and California on June 7. So, for Trump it is a significant event. For Cruz, itâ€™s life and death. â€ Follow Pam Key On Twitter @pamkeyNEN

title: Kenyan Athletics Manager Recalled after Doping Bribe Report - Breitbart
content: London (AFP)  â€”   The manager of the Kenyan Olympic athletics team has been recalled from the Rio Games after an investigation alleged he demanded money to give warnings about doping tests, a media report said.  The investigation by the Sunday Times newspaper and German television channel ARD into Michael Rotich is a potential new blow to Kenyaâ€™s sporting reputation after doping accusations in recent months. Rotich was filmed by the two media demanding 10, 000 pounds ($800 euros) for agreeing to warn a British coach about imminent doping tests. ARD journalist Hajo Seppelt tweeted an Athletics Kenya statement saying Rotich had been recalled â€œso we can investigate further his role in this. â€ â€œThese are very serious allegations and we cannot have someone of that character managing our team. â€ The statement said the case could be referred to Kenyan police. Rotich introduced reporters purporting to be the coach and an agent of athletes to Paul and Liz Scott, who are official   testers in Kenya.  â€”   Round figure  â€”   The retired school teachers work for a   company which has the IAAF contract for doping tests in Kenya. There was no suggestion of misconduct against them. The company said Rotich was not one of their business contacts. Joseph Mwangi, one of three medical experts arrested after an earlier Sunday   investigation this year, recommended the reporters meet Rotich. â€œHe loves money. So, if you know somebodyâ€™s weakness, it is easier to work with him,â€ Mwangi, who had agreed to procure blood doping EPO for the fictitious British group, was quoted as saying. Rotich reportedly told a Sunday Times reporter he would try to work out the easiest way the purported coachâ€™s athletes could avoid being tested. Asked whether he would warn Mwangi of imminent tests, he answered: â€œYeah I will tell him. Any time, any time. â€ At another meeting the next day, over champagne, the demand for the money was made, the report said. â€œTen (thousand pounds) would be a round figure just for the whole thing,â€ Rotich was quoted as saying. He had been offered three monthly payments of Â£3, 000. For the money, Rotich said he would give Mwangi 12 hours warning of doping tests and suggested how athletes could explain their absence if they felt they had not had enough time to rid their body of blood doping EPO. â€œI mean some of those compassionate ones like you had a sick child and you  â€¦     slept in the hospital or something,â€ said Rotich. He also suggested saying that the sudden illness of a close relative had compelled the athlete to go away. When he left for Rio, Rotich told the media: â€œWe have counselled, taught and even asked them to be cautious about doping. We want to show the world our bid for clean sport. â€ When confronted by The Sunday Times, Rotich claimed he had gone along with the plan as he was investigating Mwangi and the reporter. â€œThere were a lot of white people  â€¦     who were actually moving drugs and doing all those things. So this was an opportunity,â€ he told the reporter. Several Kenyan athletes have failed dope tests in recent months. The government only this week passed   legislation so that the World   Agency could take Kenya off its   list.

title: Twitter Bans Gay Conservative Milo After Anti-Islam Tweets **UPDATE** Twitter Caves - Breitbart
content: **UPDATE** Following tremendous backlash, Milo Yiannopoulosâ€™ Twitter account has been restored. [Original story:  Conservative commentator and Breitbart Tech editor Milo Yiannopoulos has been suspended from Twitter ahead of a planned press conference in Orlando, Florida.  The timing of this suspension cannot be ignored. Yiannopoulos was planning to give a press conference today near the Pulse dance club in Orlando, the target of a deadly Muslim terrorist attack that left over 100 dead or wounded. The event is still scheduled to take place, outside the Christ Church Of Orlando at 2pm EDT. Full details for those wishing to attend can be found at the bottom of this article.  It comes as a number of other figures, great and small, have been censored on social media for being too outspoken about the threat of Islam in the wake of the shootings. Islam critic Pamela Geller was suspended on Facebook. A games developer who called for the surveillance of radical mosques was suspended on Twitter. Masses of users discussing the shooting were censored on Reddit. Jim Hoft, aka â€œThe Gateway Pundit,â€ another gay conservative activists who recently called on LGBT people to acknowledge the homophobia of Islam and â€œcome home to the Republican party,â€ was suspended on YouTube.  And now Milo Yiannopoulos has been censored on Twitter. The pattern is clear.  â€œAmerica has to make a very simple choice here. This is not a question of fine distinctions politicians and our media make between Islam and radical Islamist terrorists, really itâ€™s all the same thing, there is a structural problem with Islam, most of them donâ€™t like gays very much. This isnâ€™t news to anyone except our media. â€ said Milo yesterday on the Todd Shapiro show. Perhaps it is Milos outspoken opinion on this subject that has had him removed from Twitters already restrictive platform.   It is not yet entirely clear why Milo has been suspended but it is unsurprising that this has happened mere days after Milo tweeted his condemnation of Islamic culture and itâ€™s opinions of homosexuals. Yiannopoulos has been highly outspoken in his condemnation of Islam following the Orlando attacks, and recently wrote a viral article slamming the left for â€œchoosing Islam over gays. â€  This is not the first time that Yiannopoulos has been targeted by Twitter staff. Many of our readers will remember the saga that was Milo losing his verification check mark earlier this year. Twitter has a history of punishing those that hold conservative views on its platform, mainly through the process of â€œshadowbanningâ€  â€”   hiding conservative views from users Twitter timelines  â€”   Milo himself has previously reported on. Those wishing to attend Miloâ€™s press conference in Orlando, Florida today gather outside Christ Church of Orlando, at 2200 South Orange Avenue at 2pm EDT. All members of the public and press are welcome to attend, and should contact tim@yiannopoulos. net with further questions. Yiannopoulos will take questions from attending media and listeners, expected to include the New York Times, local television stations, Deutsche Welle, PBS and various student publications. The Breitbart team will be accompanied by private security, for the safety of media and the attending public.

title: The $7 plan bringing solar power to Tanzania
content: (CNN) In   Africa, over 600 million people do not have access to electricity    thatâ€™s 68 percent of the population, according to the International Energy Agency. Thatâ€™s because the power distribution infrastructure    plants and the grid    is severely underdeveloped, requires large investments to improve and ultimately canâ€™t keep up with the growth in demand. One solution to the problem is to go â€off the grid,â€ mimicking the rapid distribution of mobile phones: over 90 percent of Africans have access to cell phone service    more than have access to clean water    but only a fraction of them owns a landline. In the energy sector, the cellphone equivalent is the solar panel, which is easily installed and can provide power to a household or small business. Off Grid Electric, an African startup, is applying this formula to rural areas of Tanzania and Rwanda yielding both commercial success and   results for the recipients. 125, 000 households, The company is backed by Elon Muskâ€™s SolarCity, one of the largest solar energy providers in the US, and Helios, Africaâ€™s largest private equity firm.  In November, at the UNâ€™s climate change conference in Marrakech, it won the 2016 Momentum for Change Award, which focused on projects that are addressing climate change in innovative ways. It already powers 125, 000 households and employs around 1, 000 people    about a third as salesmen who offer the energy packages door to door. â€Most of these families were burning kerosene to make light, with a negative impact on their health and wellbeing,â€ Bill Lenihan, Off Grid Electricâ€™s President, told CNN. Kerosene produces smoke and canâ€™t power anything but a lantern: â€Now they have access to clean energy that can also power radios and TVs.â€ The system includes a solar panel, installed on a roof, and   battery which provides electricity around the clock: â€Kids can study at night, entrepreneurs can increase their income because their phones work all day and farmers can better protect their cattle    itâ€™s like night and day,â€ said Kim Schreiber, the companyâ€™s chief of staff. $7 a month, There are three different sizes of photovoltaic panels, the smallest of which can power four lights and charge one mobile phone. â€We also provide all the energy efficient accessories that go with these, from lights to chargers, to radios and TVs,â€ said Lenihan. Customers pay 10 percent of their package upfront, the rest is financed through monthly installments. The costs are competitive, according to Off Grid Electric: â€Just connecting to the grid can cost $300 to $400, whereas our system is $7 a month and after three years you own it and never have to pay again,â€ said Schreiber. Larger packages cost more: for eight lights, a radio and a   TV, the monthly fee is about $20. In comparison, a monthâ€™s supply of kerosene typically costs $4 to $5. The payments are collected via mobile phone transactions, a popular method in the continent, and a   service plan is included if something breaks. The battery can last seven years, and the panel itself up to 20. In case a customer canâ€™t keep up with the plan, Off Grid Electric says it offers â€room for flexibility,â€ and ultimately the system will be removed after several months of missed installments. But most customers stay on board, according to Lenihan: â€The uptake has been very strong, people continue to pay, and the growth has been really good.â€ A trillion dollar challenge, Providing electricity to people in   Africa is â€a cottage industry and a trillion dollar challenge,â€ said Lenihan. â€We can solve a problem and do it in a way that delivers a return to shareholders, which is the biggest challenge in an industry that, as a whole, has addressed less than 1 percent of this market,â€ he said. For small businesses, the company offers a package called Zola, which contains everything needed to run a business on solar power, including appliances and entertainment systems. Off Grid Electric has recently signed a partnership with EDF, the worldâ€™s largest utility, to expand the program to the Ivory Coast, with a goal of providing clean energy to 2 million people by 2020. See more from Africaâ€™s Energy Surge

title: Salah Abdeslam, Suspect in Paris Attacks, Is Extradited to France - The New York Times
content: PARIS  â€”   Salah Abdeslam, thought to be the only direct participant in Novemberâ€™s Paris attacks to have survived, was handed over to France by Belgium on Wednesday, prosecutors in both countries said. He was later charged in a French court with murder connected to terrorism, participation in a terrorist conspiracy and possession of weapons and explosives, the Paris prosecutorâ€™s office announced. Mr. Abdeslam, who is also believed to be connected to the attacks in Brussels last month, was the subject of a European arrest warrant, which simplified the extradition between the two European Union countries. â€œWithin the framework of the Paris attacks of the 13th of November 2015, Salah Abdeslam has been surrendered to the French authorities this morning,â€ the Belgian federal prosecutorâ€™s office said in a statement. The Paris prosecutorâ€™s office said Mr. Abdeslam arrived in French territory at 9:05 a. m. Frank Berton, Mr. Abdeslamâ€™s French lawyer, said he had been brought to France under heavy escort by a helicopter from the   prison where he was being detained, in Beveren, Belgium. The French justice minister,   Urvoas, said after a cabinet meeting that Mr. Abdeslam would be held in isolation in a prison in the Paris region. Mr. Abdeslam, 26, is believed to have been part of a team of 10 Islamic State operatives who carried out a series of shootings and suicide bombings in Paris, and in the northern suburb of St.  on the evening of Nov. 13, killing 130 people and wounding more than 400. A French citizen of Moroccan ancestry who lived in Belgium, Mr. Abdeslam fled Paris for Brussels in the early hours of Nov. 14. He was the target of a   international manhunt before he was arrested on March 18 in the Molenbeek neighborhood of Brussels, his hometown. Mr. Abdeslam ran a bar there with his brother Ibrahim, who detonated a suicide vest in the Comptoir Voltaire cafe in central Paris on Nov. 13. French and Belgian investigators have found evidence suggesting that Mr. Abdeslam was heavily involved in preparations for the Paris attacks. He rented cars and at least one safe house, bought material used in explosives and drove across Europe to pick up other suspects. But Mr. Abdeslamâ€™s exact role on the night of the attacks is still unclear. Experts have questioned how valuable he will be to investigators in France, though the French authorities and families of the victims have expressed relief that a surviving participant in the attacks will stand trial. He is suspected of driving three suicide bombers to the Stade de France soccer stadium in St.  and investigators are still trying to establish whether he had intended to carry out another attack. Shortly after his arrest, Mr. Abdeslam told investigators that he had â€œbacked outâ€ of carrying out a suicide bombing against the Stade de France. Mr. Berton said Tuesday said that Mr. Abdeslam had to be judged â€œfor what he has done and not for what he represents, because he is the last survivor and some would blame him for deeds and actions that are not his. â€ In an interview with the French newspaper LibÃ©ration, Sven Mary, Mr. Abdeslamâ€™s lawyer in Belgium, was more disparaging, characterizing his client as a â€œlittle jerk from Molenbeekâ€ and as a petty criminal.

title: â€™Cruz is going downâ€™: Donald Trump celebrates new Iowa poll
content: â€™  mogul Donald Trump got some great news on Thursday afternoon in the form of  showing him pulling ahead in Iowa.â€™ â€™That survey showed him leading his top rival, US Sen. Ted Cruz ( ) 37% to 26% among likely Iowa  .â€™ â€™But the CNN poll was apparently too recent for Trump to tout at a Thursday rally in Las Vegas, Nevada. Instead, Trump boasted about  from Emerson College, that found him beating Cruz 33% to 23%.â€™ â€™â€Iâ€™â€™m winning like all of the polls  â€”   and by a lot,â€ Trump declared.â€™ â€™â€Emerson College, very important, great college. Trump 33% Cruz 23%. Nice! Nice! Wow,â€ he added.â€™ â€™After Trump heralded another survey, from North Carolina, the Republican   said Cruz was tanking in the 2016 race.â€™ â€™â€Cruz is going down,â€ Trump exclaimed. â€Heâ€™â€™s going down. No, heâ€™â€™s having a hard time. He looks like a nervous wreck. Heâ€™â€™s going down. He had his moment. He had his moment. He had his moment, and he blew it. â€â€™ â€™Cruz had surged in recent weeks to roughly tie Trump in Iowa, the first state to weigh in on the Republican race. But  showed the February 1 caucus as still neck and neck.â€™ â€™A  found Cruz leading Trump in Iowa 27% to 25% while  found Trump pulling ahead of Cruz by a single point: 26% to 25%.â€™ â€™The CNN Iowa poll also had good news for Sen. Marco Rubio ( ) who ticked up three points since the previous month and placed third at 14%. Retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson, who briefly led in some Iowa polls in October, has dropped from 16% to 6% since the previous month.â€™

title: Online Trail Illuminates Baton Rouge Gunmanâ€™s Path to Violence - The New York Times
content: BATON ROUGE, La.  â€”   He joined the Marines, served in Iraq and earned a Good Conduct Medal. He was an entrepreneur, a   author, a nutrition and fitness counselor, a proponent of the American gospel of  . He considered himself a lifestyle coach, even though he had failed in marriage, neglected to pay his taxes and was, at one point, living on $500 per month. He had also embarked on a spiritual quest to find his roots as a black man, traveling around Africa for two years. But Gavin Longâ€™s life also became a web of paranoid ideas, a professed allegiance to an antigovernment â€œsovereign citizenâ€ group and a belief that bloodshed was a better tool than peaceful protest in the fight against oppression. On Sunday, Mr. Long died in a parking lot just off a commercial street here in a shootout with the police. It was his 29th birthday. He killed three law enforcement officers and wounded three others. On Monday, law enforcement officials said Mr. Long had targeted officers, though his motives otherwise remained murky. Mr. Long had been a resident of Kansas City, Mo. and it is unclear what he was doing in Baton Rouge, though a video that appears to have been posted by him shows him in the Louisiana capital discussing the July 5 fatal police shooting of a fellow   man, Alton B. Sterling, here. Though the police here have released little information about Mr. Long, a deeper portrait is beginning to emerge, based on a large trail left online. Many of these digital bread crumbs  â€”   web posts, YouTube videos and podcasts  â€”   are tied to Mr. Longâ€™s given name, or some version of a new name, Cosmo Ausar Setepenra, which he filed court documents in Missouri to adopt in May 2015. (He never petitioned the court, so the name change was not legally binding, officials said.) Some of these posts and videos included biographical and personal information that aligned with the information released by the authorities. In an interview with a podcast host in March, Mr. Long identified himself as a member of the online community of   targeted individuals, people who believe they are being harassed with   weapons and by armies of stalkers. And in one YouTube video, he discusses the killings of   men at the hands of police officers, including the death of Mr. Sterling, and advocates a bloody response instead of the protests that followed the deaths. â€œOne hundred percent of revolutions, of victims fighting their oppressors,â€ Mr. Long said, â€œhave been successful through fighting back, through bloodshed. Zero have been successful just over simply protesting. â€ â€œYouâ€™ve got to stand on your rights, just like George Washington did, just like the other white rebels they celebrate and salute did,â€ he added. â€œThatâ€™s what Nat Turner did. Thatâ€™s what Malcolm did. â€ In Baton Rouge on Monday, the crime scene along Airline Highway was returning to normal. Bullet holes could be seen in a wall of the Hair Crown Beauty Supply store, where the shooting took place. The city had begun the process of mourning the police officers Mr. Long gunned down  â€”   including Montrell Jackson, 32, an   and   veteran of the Baton Rouge Police Department, who left behind a wife and son. On a podcast posted on iTunes and dated April, the speaker, who gives his name as Cosmo, gives a sketch of his life story. He says he grew up in Kansas City, and was a   student until about middle school, when he became fat and started getting Câ€™s. As a child, he was something of a hustler who made extra money by making loans and charging interest. â€œSay if I loaned out money to my family, even to my mother, I would make her pay me back, with interest,â€ he says. â€œIf I loaned $20, I would make you pay me back $5 on Friday. â€ He says he lost significant weight in high school, bought his first car at age 16 and joined the Marines. Mr. Longâ€™s military records show he served from 2005 to 2010, including a   deployment in Iraq. He was a sergeant and a data network specialist who earned several awards, including one for good conduct. He was also assigned to Okinawa, Japan, and several locations in Southern California. He attended Central Texas College at its Marine Corps Air Station Miramar site in San Diego and via distance education, earning an associate of arts degree. In 2011, court records show, he had an uncontested divorce from a woman named Aireyona Osha Hill. They listed that they had no children or assets and that Mr. Long earned $500 a month. Around this time, Mr. Long befriended a Kansas City schoolteacher who wished to remain anonymous because of the heinous nature of the shootings. The teacher said Mr. Long had taken interest in the Occupy Wall Street movement and   culture, and sympathized with the views of the villain Bane, from the 2012 Batman film â€œThe Dark Knight Risesâ€  â€”   particularly Baneâ€™s vigilantism against corruption. But the man the teacher knew never spoke about violent solutions to the real worldâ€™s problems. â€œIâ€™m surprised he took it as far as he did,â€ the teacher said Monday. â€œIt doesnâ€™t surprise me so much as he had an agenda against the government. Heâ€™d always talk about how the government was corrupt. â€ By 2012, Mr. Long had moved  â€”   briefly, apparently  â€”   to Tuscaloosa, Ala. where he spent one semester at the University of Alabama. He majored in business. He made the deanâ€™s list. The University of Alabama police had no interactions with him during his time there. Mike Mansur, a spokesman for the Jackson County prosecutorâ€™s office, which covers most of Kansas City, said his office also had no record of contact with Mr. Long. He also attended Clark Atlanta University during the   school year, and was in good academic standing, a university spokeswoman said. Although he claimed to be on the deanâ€™s list there, he said he had dropped out, sold his two cars, gave away his possessions and traveled to Africa. Mr. Long appeared to be obsessed with the idea of   for himself and for others, and he embraced more esoteric means of achieving those goals. While traveling to Burkina Faso, Egypt, Ethiopia, Ghana, Kenya, Rwanda, Tanzania and Uganda, he said, he wrote three books, covering topics like â€œholistic detoxification for health,   and successâ€ the â€œancient esoteric secrets of the Pineal Glandâ€ and the â€œ124 Universal Laws and their use in the Laws of the Cosmos. â€ In 2015, Mr. Long filed the petition to change his name. In his statement of intent, he said he was a member of an â€œindigenous societyâ€ called the United Washitaw De Dugdahmoundyah Muâ€™ur nation. It was apparently a reference to the Empire Washitaw De Dugdahmoundyah. On its website, the group says it is â€œa multicultural, highly spiritual nation of aboriginal, indigenous Americans. â€ The group is largely   and subscribes to a â€œsovereign citizenâ€ ideology holding that members are â€œno longer beholden to any form of government,â€ said Ryan Lenz, a senior writer for the Southern Poverty Law Center, which tracks extremist groups. On Monday morning, a man who answered a phone number on the website and said he was a leader of the group, Fredrix Joe Washington, said he had never heard of Mr. Long. â€œWe are about peace  â€”   and especially not about going out and killing some police officers,â€ said Mr. Washington, 71. This year, court records show, a case was filed against Mr. Long for not paying his local earnings tax. Papers in that case were served on his address last month, and his mother accepted them, according to court records. Six days later, the tax case was dismissed. In many of his podcasts, Mr. Long expounds at length on dating and   tips for men, arguing that they must display the characteristics of an â€œalphaâ€ male. But a number of his other online offerings discuss the historical oppression of minorities, and Americaâ€™s current racial problems. In a recent email he sent out to those interested in his ideas, he listed numerous instances of massacres of   people. On July 8, Lance Scurvin, a podcast host in Orlando, Fla. posted a note from Mr. Long on his Facebook page that seemed to suggest that Mr. Long was feeling paranoid about his safety. Mr. Scurvin, who is known for lending a sympathetic ear to   guests, had interviewed Mr. Long in the past. â€œI just want everyone to know that if anything may happen to me or with me, I am NOT affiliated with anybody, any group, nationality, association, religion, corporation, business, etc. â€ the note said. Mr. Long traveled to Dallas after the killing of five police officers at a demonstration there on July 7. Chanattra Long, who is not related to Mr. Long, said he had come into her shop, the His and Hers Barber Shop, two days after that shooting and passed out copies of his book. â€œHe pulled out a wad of money and said: â€˜You think this is something? This is nothing,â€™â€ she recalled. She said he had spoken of being in Africa and of being able to speak five languages. She was startled at his boldness and assertiveness. She had never seen him before and had no idea why he entered her shop that day. â€œI could tell he wasnâ€™t right, his demeanor, his aggressiveness,â€ she said. Still, Mr. Long made no mention of attacking police, she said. One of Mr. Longâ€™s last videos, posted to YouTube but taken down as of Monday, shows him driving around Baton Rouge. He approaches a number of   strangers apparently, and doles out stray nuggets of advice and wisdom, deploying the salty language of the street. He refers to himself as a life coach, a freedom strategist, a real estate entrepreneur, an author, a teacher and a motivational speaker. And he tells them about his book. â€œI want my people to succeed,â€ he says at one point. Later, he refers to â€œArabsâ€ and â€œIndiansâ€ who do not care about people, ostensibly   except when the latter give them their money. At one point he uses the word â€œcracker,â€ apparently in reference to whites. He also makes a passing reference to the shooting of Mr. Sterling. â€œItâ€™s two parts to freedom, bruh,â€ he says. â€œKnowing your rights and standing on your rights. They know we know our rights. â€ But how many black people, he asked, stand on their rights? â€œAnd if you not standing on your rights then you have no rights. â€

title: Putin speaks out on election meddling and more
content: Moscow (CNN) Russian President Vladimir Putin is usually as difficult to read as some of his countryâ€™s most famous literature. Heâ€™s always calm and composed, rarely uttering a superfluous word. This week felt a little different. For several months, the Kremlin has batted down questions on possible Russian collusion with Donald Trumpâ€™s presidential campaign or interference in the 2016 US election, with creative variations on â€No comment.â€ â€Donâ€™t read your morning newspapers,â€ Putin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said in February when reports of multiple contacts between Trump associates and Russia surfaced. â€Itâ€™s a broken record with futuristic songsâ€ was Peskovâ€™s retort in March when asked for a comment on the first congressional hearing on alleged Russian interference. Putin slams US election meddling claims as â€™liesâ€™ The bottom line, analysts and Kremlin watchers said here in Moscow, is that Russia didnâ€™t want to become any more politically toxic for Trump than it already was. â€I think (Putin) didnâ€™t really understand what was going on with Trump,â€ said Dmitry Oreshkin, a Russian political scientist and Kremlin critic. â€So he reduced his rhetorical activity in that direction to avoid, God help him, making any mistakes or pressing any wrong buttons.â€ This week, the policy changed, On Monday, Putin was at Versailles near Paris discussing European Union sanctions on Russia for its annexation of Crimea and military support for separatists in eastern Ukraine. â€You wanted to know how sanctions on Russia could help overcome the crisis in southeastern Ukraine,â€ he challenged a journalist at a joint press conference with French President Emmanuel Macron. â€They cannot,â€ Putin said. He later told French newspaper Le Figaro that those who lost the US election were simply blaming Russia because they couldnâ€™t admit their own failings.  And by Thursday at an international economic forum in his home city of St Petersburg, Putin commented on everything from Trump    whom he called â€sincereâ€ and â€straightforwardâ€    to how Russian hackers might be â€patrioticâ€ without being   to one of his oldest grievances    US missile defense systems around the world.  â€You are all experienced adults,â€ he berated an assembled group of Russian and international news agencies, arguing that American missile defense equipment in both Eastern Europe and Asia disrupt the global military balance. â€You keep silent on this issue. The world remains silent.â€ A conscious decision, The Russians made a conscious decision to speak out, said Fyodor Lukyanov    of Russia in Global Affairs, despite their concerns that anything they say can be used by Trumpâ€™s opponents to discredit him. Lukyanov said he believes itâ€™s a predicament that has made the Kremlin uncomfortable. â€There is a wave, there is a process which Russia actually cannot control and who knows how far it can go?â€ The longtime Kremlin watcher said Putin may be irritated by all the   controversy in Washington, but thereâ€™s also a possibility he feels emboldened by all the attention. â€This campaign in the United States made Putin such a great leader, such a big personality,â€ he said. â€I cannot exclude that heâ€™s pleased by this.â€ And on Friday at a public plenary session at the economic forum in St. Petersburg, Putin once again took full advantage of the spotlight.  He compared accusations of Russian meddling in the US election to   and labeled the reports of Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyakâ€™s meetings with Trump associates as â€hysteria,â€ saying the envoy was simply doing what heâ€™s paid to do.  Putin also accused the West of â€systematic, gross and unceremoniousâ€ interference in Russian internal politics over the years.   Why now? Perhaps Russia smelled an opportunity in the growing sense of US isolation. First, last weekendâ€™s G7 meeting in Sicily highlighted the serious disagreements between the United States and other world powers over issues such as migration and climate change then on Sunday, German Chancellor Angela Merkel delivered a damning assessment that the EU could no longer â€completelyâ€ rely on the United States. And Trump defied allies by announcing Thursday that he was pulling the United States out of the Paris Agreement on climate change.   â€A multipolar world is being established,â€ Putin said Thursday, â€something monopolists donâ€™t like.â€   For Putin, though, it may now be more about having nothing to lose rather than anything to gain, according to Kremlin watchers in Moscow. The relationship with the United States is in free fall    but not because of any new geopolitical disagreements.  And overcoming the old ones may be politically impossible for Trump in this climate. Itâ€™s a â€very stupidâ€ situation for Russia, Lukyanov said.  One thing seems clear from Putinâ€™s rhetorical marathon this week: He really wants to see an end to what he calls â€Russophobiaâ€ as well as allegations of election meddling in the United States. In his final plenary session Friday in St Petersburg, the Russian leader issued a direct appeal: â€Stop it.â€

title: President Trump Blasts European Security: â€™Take a Look at Whatâ€™s Happening in Germany, Take a Look at Whatâ€™s Happening in Franceâ€™
content: Speaking at the Conservative Political Action Conference in Maryland Friday morning President Donald Trump took a swipe at the security situation in Europe, which has seen a number of bloody terror attacks in recent years. [Vowing that he would not allow the same attacks to take place in the United States, and that his administration would â€œkeep radical Islamic terrorists the hell out of our countryâ€ President Trump at first made light of press coverage heâ€™d received over his comments on Sweden earlier in the week.  Referring to the Swedes who spoke out against the widespread perception that the migrant crisis has been well handled by their nation, among them Sweden Democrats leader Jimmie Ã…kesson, President Trump said that his comments were quickly vindicated by civil unrest and criminality in Sweden itself. He said: â€œBy the way, take a look at whatâ€™s happening in Europe. I took a lot of heat on Sweden, and then a day later, I said â€˜has anyone reported whatâ€™s going on? â€™. â€œAnd it turned out that not so many of them did. Take a look  â€¦     I love Sweden, great country, great people. They understand, the people over there understand Iâ€™m rightâ€. Turning to other European nations struggling with the impacts of the migrant crisis and the Islamist terrorists it has enabled to gain access to Europe, President Trump also namechecked Germany and France. Germany saw an unprecedented two years of Islamist terror to the end of December 2016, when a Berlin Christmas market was   by a terrorist driving a stolen truck. 12 were killed. Speaking of Nice, France  â€”   also attacked by an Islamist driving a truck at high speeds to mow down pedestrians  â€”   and of the French capital, the American president relayed an anecdote of a friend who once regularly visited Paris for pleasure. With the deteriorating security situation in the city, President Trump said his friend no longer visited at all. The remarks come just days after the latest Paris tourism figures show visitors fell 1. 5 million in 2016, which cost the French economy some â‚¬1. 3 billion. Looking at these problems in Sweden, Germany, France, and elsewhere, the President promised he wouldnâ€™t allow the same fate to befall the United States. He said: â€œTake a look at what is happening to our world, folks. We have to be smart, we canâ€™t let it happen to us. Let me state this as clearly as I can, we are going to keep radical Islamic terrorists the hell out of our country. â€œWe will not be deterred from this course, and in a matter of days, we will be taking brand new action to protect our people and keep America safe. I will never, ever apologise for protecting the safety and security of the American peopleâ€. Watch: The President Trump CPAC 2017 Speech in Full,

title: Ben Shapiro Tapped to Confront Left on 10+Campuses
content: On Monday, January 10, Young Americaâ€™s Foundation announced that it would be sending Breitbart News senior    Ben Shapiro on a tour of college campuses around America to battle the resurgent campus radical left. [Shapiro famously descended on University of Missouri to combat the student protesters and Black Lives Matter movement after the students achieved the resignation of the president of the university his speech garnered 50, 000 live viewers and over half a million viewers overall. A few weeks later, Shapiro spoke at a   lecture at Otay Ranch High School in California, where a school administrator dismissed the students, claiming that Shapiro â€œcrossed the lineâ€ for speaking about conservatism.  Ron Robinson, president of Young Americaâ€™s Foundation, explained: Ben is the perfect person to provide the education on the importance of free speech and political correctness this countryâ€™s liberal professors have clearly failed to administer. We deeply appreciate the support of Fred R. Allen for making this    kind lecture series possible. He is ensuring that thousands of students will understand and be inspired by freedom. Shapiro told YAF, â€œI look forward to the opportunity given to me by YAF and Fred R. Allen to speak to young people around the country. Itâ€™s time for Americaâ€™s precious snowflakes to learn that facts donâ€™t care about your feelings, and that truth matters far more than the irrational emotional response to it. â€ Breitbart News had the opportunity to speak exclusively with Shapiro on Monday afternoon. BNN: Why are you taking the fight to college campuses? SHAPIRO: The intellectual leadership of the American left is coming from campus. It isnâ€™t particularly intellectual, of course  â€”   itâ€™s mostly about finding new and creative ways of shouting down your political opposition  â€”   but itâ€™s effective nonetheless, and itâ€™s having a massive impact on the country. The â€œmicroaggressionâ€ movement, for example, which seeks to label opposing speech a form of aggression to be stopped, is one of the driving forces behind the young leftâ€™s willingness to curb free speech in favor of political correctness. â€œTrigger warningsâ€ are a way to shut people up, supposedly to protect feelings. Anything considered fringe on the left today will be its mainstream tomorrow. Just take a look at Bernie Sanders. BNN: Whatâ€™s your strategy going to be? SHAPIRO: I want to hit the students between the eyes with values and facts. Conservatives never speak in terms of values to young people, because theyâ€™re afraid theyâ€™ll alienate. But here are some values young people need to know about: you are not a superior human being because you like to steal some peopleâ€™s money using the government gun. You are not a superior human being because you wish to impose your vision of the world on other people with the government gun in the name of tolerance. You are a worse human being for wanting these things. As for facts, as I like to say, facts donâ€™t care about your feelings. To even have a political discussion with the Precious Snowflakes, you first have to remove their unearned sense of moral superiority. Then we can get down to brass tacks. BNN: Do you know how many campuses youâ€™ll be hitting? SHAPIRO: At least ten in the next few months. YAF is setting up locations right now  â€”   if you want your campus to be one of them, contact Patrick Coyle at pcoyle@yaf. org. BNN: Are you concerned about confrontation? SHAPIRO: No. I hope leftists show up so we can talk about why theyâ€™re wrong. As Andrew Breitbart used to say, youâ€™ve got to walk toward the fire.

title: Sperm Banks Accused of Losing Samples and Lying About Donors - The New York Times
content: MONTECITO, Calif.  â€”   Even as she mourned the death of her    husband from a rare genetic disorder, Sarah Robertson was comforted by knowing that six vials of his sperm were safely stored at the Reproductive Fertility Center  â€”   in Tank B, Canister 5, Cane G, Position 6, Color Blue  â€”   waiting until she was ready to have the baby they had both longed for. But 10 years later, when she was ready to use the sperm from her husband, Aaron, she got devastating news. All six vials were missing. â€œIâ€™d been completely focused on having something of Aaronâ€™s live on, and now there was nothing,â€ said Ms. Robertson in an interview at her  â€™ home in Montecito. Now she and her   are suing the Los Angeles clinic, and its owner, Dr. Peyman Saadat, accusing them of negligence, fraud, breach of contract and intentional infliction of emotional distress. The suit, filed in May, also says the clinic misappropriated Mr. Robertsonâ€™s sperm  â€”   which had a 50 percent chance of carrying Marfan syndrome, the disorder that killed him  â€”   and used it to supply other patients who would not know to undergo testing to ensure their babies did not inherit the disorder. The Robertsonsâ€™ case is part of a new wave of lawsuits against sperm banks, highlighting claims of deception and negligence, and adding an array of challenges beyond the longstanding issue of undetected genetic problems. Dr. Saadat declined to be interviewed, but denied the accusations in a statement. Frozen sperm has become a major industry, dominated by a few large sperm banks, but with smaller stocks of sperm maintained at hundreds of   centers nationwide. The Food and Drug Administration requires that donor sperm be tested for infectious diseases. Beyond that, sperm banks are lightly regulated. Several states require health department licensing of the labs, but only New York conducts routine inspections. Some of the new cases accuse sperm banks of careless   or mishandling or misappropriation of sperm banked for a clientâ€™s personal use. Others say the banks use hyped, misleading descriptions to market their donors. Several cases accuse a Georgia facility of marketing sperm as belonging to a neuroscientist with a   I. Q. who turned out to be a schizophrenic felon, and who has fathered at least 36 children. â€œEven in New York, when they inspect, theyâ€™re looking at hygienic conditions not â€ said Arthur Caplan, a bioethics professor at New York University. â€œNobody confirms that you have what you say you have. â€ â€œItâ€™s absurd that we have these materials so valuable that people pay to store them, but we run it like a   grocery,â€ he continued. â€œCryopreservation has historically operated in a casual   environment, where people were just supposed to trust. â€ Sperm banks are not required to verify the information provided by donors, and lawyers familiar with the industry say many do not. They set their own limits on how many children a donor can sire, but unless the mothers voluntarily report the births, they may not know how many   are out there. Some, including the two largest, California Cryobank in Los Angeles and Fairfax Cryobank, headquartered in Virginia, test for many genetic conditions, while others test for very few. So it is    â€”   for people banking their own sperm for personal use after cancer treatment, and for those relying on a sperm bankâ€™s description of an anonymous donor. Sean Tipton, a spokesman for the American Society of Reproductive Medicine, said his group did not see a need for further regulation and believed that the industry was generally reliable. â€œAll indications are that sperm donation has been a terrific way to help people start a family even if, as with anything that involves humans, there are mistakes and some    actors,â€ he said. In the past, few problems with sperm came to light, because most families were unwilling to discuss such an intimate matter in public. But that is changing, with a demographic shift in sperm buyers. Once, sperm banks mostly served heterosexual married couples in which the husband had a fertility problem, but today about   of the buyers are either lesbian couples and single women, who are more open about their childrenâ€™s origins. With genetic testing widely available and relatively cheap, the concept of donor anonymity is increasingly open to question. â€œI can personally attest that there are more cases than you ever hear about, but almost all settle before they get to court,â€ said Andrew Vorzimer, a California fertility lawyer representing the Robertsons.
